b'ABOUT a year ago, I flew to Singapore to join the writer Malcolm Gladwell, the fashion designer Marc Ecko and the graphic designer Stefan Sagmeister in addressing a group of advertising people on \xe2\x80\x9cMarketing to the Child of Tomorrow.\xe2\x80\x9d Soon after I arrived, the chief executive of the agency that had invited us took me aside. What he was most interested in, he began \xe2\x80\x94 I braced myself for mention of some next-generation stealth campaign \xe2\x80\x94 was stillness.'b'A few months later, I read an interview with the perennially cutting-edge designer Philippe Starck. What allowed him to remain so consistently ahead of the curve? \xe2\x80\x9cI never read any magazines or watch TV,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, perhaps a little hyperbolically. \xe2\x80\x9cNor do I go to cocktail parties, dinners or anything like that.\xe2\x80\x9d He lived outside conventional ideas, he implied, because \xe2\x80\x9cI live alone mostly, in the middle of nowhere.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Around the same time, I noticed that those who part with $2,285 a night to stay in a cliff-top room at the Post Ranch Inn in Big Sur pay partly for the privilege of 'b'not'b' having a TV in their rooms; the future of travel, I\xe2\x80\x99m reliably told, lies in \xe2\x80\x9cblack-hole resorts,\xe2\x80\x9d which charge high prices precisely because you can\xe2\x80\x99t get online in their rooms.'b'Has it really come to this?'b'In barely one generation we\xe2\x80\x99ve moved from exulting in the time-saving devices that have so expanded our lives to trying to get away from them \xe2\x80\x94 often in order to make more time. The more ways we have to connect, the more many of us seem desperate to unplug. Like teenagers, we appear to have gone from knowing nothing about the world to knowing too much all but overnight.'b''b'Internet rescue camps'b' in South Korea and China try to save kids addicted to the screen.'b'Writer friends of mine pay good money to get the Freedom software that enables them to disable (for up to eight hours) the very Internet connections that seemed so emancipating not long ago. Even Intel (of all companies) experimented in 2007 with conferring four uninterrupted hours of quiet time every Tuesday morning on 300 engineers and managers. (The average office worker today, researchers have found, enjoys no more than three minutes at a time at his or her desk without interruption.) During this period the workers were not allowed to use the phone or send e-mail, but simply had the chance to clear their heads and to hear themselves think. A majority of Intel\xe2\x80\x99s trial group recommended that the policy be extended to others.'b'THE average American spends at least eight and a half hours a day in front of a screen, Nicholas Carr notes in his eye-opening book \xe2\x80\x9cThe Shallows,\xe2\x80\x9d in part because the number of hours American adults spent online doubled between 2005 and 2009 (and the number of hours spent in front of a TV screen, often simultaneously, is also steadily increasing).'b'The average American teenager sends or receives 75 text messages a day, though one girl in Sacramento managed to handle an average of 10,000 every 24 hours for a month. Since luxury, as any economist will tell you, is a function of scarcity, the children of tomorrow, I heard myself tell the marketers in Singapore, will crave nothing more than freedom, if only for a short while, from all the blinking machines, streaming videos and scrolling headlines that leave them feeling empty and too full all at once.'b'The urgency of slowing down \xe2\x80\x94 to find the time and space to think \xe2\x80\x94 is nothing new, of course, and wiser souls have always reminded us that the more attention we pay to the moment, the less time and energy we have to place it in some larger context. \xe2\x80\x9cDistraction is the only thing that consoles us for our miseries,\xe2\x80\x9d the French philosopher Blaise Pascal wrote in the 17th century, \xe2\x80\x9cand yet it is itself the greatest of our miseries.\xe2\x80\x9d He also famously remarked that all of man\xe2\x80\x99s problems come from his inability to sit quietly in a room alone.'b'When telegraphs and trains brought in the idea that convenience was more important than content \xe2\x80\x94 and speedier means could make up for unimproved ends \xe2\x80\x94 Henry David Thoreau reminded us that \xe2\x80\x9cthe man whose horse trots a mile in a minute does not carry the most important messages.\xe2\x80\x9d Even half a century ago, Marshall McLuhan, who came closer than most to seeing what was coming, warned, \xe2\x80\x9cWhen things come at you very fast, naturally you lose touch with yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d Thomas Merton struck a chord with millions, by not just noting that \xe2\x80\x9cMan was made for the highest activity, which is, in fact, his rest,\xe2\x80\x9d but by also acting on it, and stepping out of the rat race and into a Cistercian cloister.'b'Yet few of those voices can be heard these days, precisely because \xe2\x80\x9cbreaking news\xe2\x80\x9d is coming through (perpetually) on CNN and Debbie is just posting images of her summer vacation and the phone is ringing. We barely have enough time to see how little time we have (most Web pages, researchers find, are visited for 10 seconds or less). And the more that floods in on us (the Kardashians, Obamacare, \xe2\x80\x9cDancing with the Stars\xe2\x80\x9d), the less of ourselves we have to give to every snippet. All we notice is that the distinctions that used to guide and steady us \xe2\x80\x94 between Sunday and Monday, public and private, here and there \xe2\x80\x94 are gone.'b'We have more and more ways to communicate, as Thoreau noted, but less and less to say. Partly because we\xe2\x80\x99re so busy communicating. And \xe2\x80\x94 as he might also have said \xe2\x80\x94 we\xe2\x80\x99re rushing to meet so many deadlines that we hardly register that what we need most are lifelines.'b'So what to do? The central paradox of the machines that have made our lives so much brighter, quicker, longer and healthier is that they cannot teach us how to make the best use of them; the information revolution came without an instruction manual. All the data in the world cannot teach us how to sift through data; images don\xe2\x80\x99t show us how to process images. The only way to do justice to our onscreen lives is by summoning exactly the emotional and moral clarity that can\xe2\x80\x99t be found on any screen.'b'MAYBE that\xe2\x80\x99s why more and more people I know, even if they have no religious commitment, seem to be turning to 'b'yoga'b', or meditation, or tai chi; these aren\xe2\x80\x99t New Age fads so much as ways to connect with what could be called the wisdom of old age. Two journalist friends of mine observe an \xe2\x80\x9cInternet sabbath\xe2\x80\x9d every week, turning off their online connections from Friday night to Monday morning, so as to try to revive those ancient customs known as family meals and conversation. Finding myself at breakfast with a group of lawyers in Oxford four months ago, I noticed that all their talk was of sailing \xe2\x80\x94 or riding or bridge: anything that would allow them to get out of radio contact for a few hours.'b'Other friends try to go on long walks every Sunday, or to \xe2\x80\x9cforget\xe2\x80\x9d their cellphones at home. A series of tests in recent years has shown, Mr. Carr points out, that after spending time in quiet rural settings, subjects \xe2\x80\x9cexhibit greater attentiveness, stronger memory and generally improved cognition. Their brains become both calmer and sharper.\xe2\x80\x9d More than that, empathy, as well as deep thought, depends (as neuroscientists like Antonio Damasio have found) on neural processes that are \xe2\x80\x9cinherently slow.\xe2\x80\x9d The very ones our high-speed lives have little time for.'b'In my own case, I turn to eccentric and often extreme measures to try to keep my sanity and ensure that I have time to do nothing at all (which is the only time when I can see what I should be doing the rest of the time). I\xe2\x80\x99ve yet to use a cellphone and I\xe2\x80\x99ve never Tweeted or entered Facebook. I try not to go online till my day\xe2\x80\x99s writing is finished, and I moved from Manhattan to rural Japan in part so I could more easily survive for long stretches entirely on foot, and every trip to the movies would be an event.'b'None of this is a matter of principle or asceticism; it\xe2\x80\x99s just pure selfishness. Nothing makes me feel better \xe2\x80\x94 calmer, clearer and happier \xe2\x80\x94 than being in one place, absorbed in a book, a conversation, a piece of music. It\xe2\x80\x99s actually something deeper than mere happiness: it\xe2\x80\x99s joy, which the monk David Steindl-Rast describes as \xe2\x80\x9cthat kind of happiness that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t depend on what happens.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s vital, of course, to stay in touch with the world, and to know what\xe2\x80\x99s going on; I took pains this past year to make separate trips to Jerusalem and Hyderabad and Oman and St. Petersburg, to rural Arkansas and Thailand and the stricken nuclear plant in Fukushima and Dubai. But it\xe2\x80\x99s only by having some distance from the world that you can see it whole, and understand what you should be doing with it.'b'For more than 20 years, therefore, I\xe2\x80\x99ve been going several times a year \xe2\x80\x94 often for no longer than three days \xe2\x80\x94 to a Benedictine hermitage, 40 minutes down the road, as it happens, from the Post Ranch Inn. I don\xe2\x80\x99t attend services when I\xe2\x80\x99m there, and I\xe2\x80\x99ve never meditated, there or anywhere; I just take walks and read and lose myself in the stillness, recalling that it\xe2\x80\x99s only by stepping briefly away from my wife and bosses and friends that I\xe2\x80\x99ll have anything useful to bring to them. The last time I was in the hermitage, three months ago, I happened to pass, on the monastery road, a youngish-looking man with a 3-year-old around his shoulders.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99re Pico, aren\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x9d the man said, and introduced himself as Larry; we\xe2\x80\x99d met, I gathered, 19 years before, when he\xe2\x80\x99d been living in the cloister as an assistant to one of the monks.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are you doing now?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI work for MTV. Down in L.A.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'We smiled. No words were necessary.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI try to bring my kids here as often as I can,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, as he looked out at the great blue expanse of the Pacific on one side of us, the high, brown hills of the Central Coast on the other. \xe2\x80\x9cMy oldest son\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 he pointed at a 7-year-old running along the deserted, radiant mountain road in front of his mother \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cthis is his third time.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The child of tomorrow, I realized, may actually be ahead of us, in terms of sensing not what\xe2\x80\x99s new, but what\xe2\x80\x99s essential.'b'IT was Friday before dusk and my husband had corralled our three children \xe2\x80\x94 showered, in good clothes and on notice for good behavior \xe2\x80\x94 to sing Sabbath prayers. If I really cared that much about what time it was (or what year it was), would I still have a VCR?'b'AS parents of a young child, we are in the enviable position of reading a lot of beautifully drawn and smartly written short stories that fall under the moniker\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cchildren\xe2\x80\x99s books.\xe2\x80\x9d And in doing so we have discovered one of the immutable truths of childhood: a book worth reading once is worth reading 17 times in a row.'b'Sometime after the 10th reading of a particular book in a day we find ourselves examining the deeper and unspoken questions brought up by the text: Why is George so curious? According to research on mammalian vision, the brown bear is a dichromat, meaning that it has two types of cells in its eyes to determine color. (Humans have three.) A short-wave cone cell sends violet shades to his brain; a long-wave cone sends something in the yellow or green range. So although the bear would be able to view the colors of some of the later animals in the books, like the white dog and the yellow duck, his perception of a bird\xe2\x80\x99s redness is likely to be very weak. Brightness, more than color, would dominate the experience. What do you see, brown bear?\xc2\xa0'b'A bird-shaped figure with some feathers brightly standing out from a generally drab body.'b''b''b'\xe2\x80\x9cFrog and Toad Are Friends\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'The central theme of Arnold Lobel\xe2\x80\x99s 1970 classic of the anthropomorphic oeuvre is that these tailless amphibians are fast friends. But what about in the real world \xe2\x80\x94 are toads and frogs capable of such friendship?'b'A 2009 paper in the research journal Oecologia examined what happened when cane toads were introduced into the environment of native frogs in Australia. Far from being an ecological disaster, there were some unexpected benefits for the frogs, although it came at a cost that might be better suited to a grisly Greek myth than a children\xe2\x80\x99s book. When frogs consumed toad eggs, which were toxic, both populations suffered; however, the frog tadpoles that survived grew bigger and healthier.'b'In other words, the reason that Lobel did not create a scientifically accurate portrayal of frogs and toads is that the title would have been something on the order of \xe2\x80\x9cFrog Eats Toad\xe2\x80\x99s Poisonous Unborn Children, Gets Sick and Dies (but Frog\xe2\x80\x99s Younger Cousin Thrives!).\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'\xe2\x80\x9cCurious George\xe2\x80\x9d 'b''b'Careful readers of the Curious George canon may have found themselves bedeviled by a wide range of George-related questions: What kind of monkey is he? Who is this fellow in the yellow hat? And why is that monkey so curious, anyway?'b'At least one of these queries may be answered by a paper published in 2010 in the Journal of Comparative Psychology, which examined the curiosity levels of spider monkeys and stumptail macaques. The macaques, which like George are tailless, scored high on a \xe2\x80\x9ccuriosity index\xe2\x80\x9d when faced with oddities like organic paint and mealworms. Males were especially curious, but all macaques were less curious than the spider monkeys. The researchers speculate that this is because spider monkeys live in a society with lax social rules; without a rigid hierarchy and dominant individuals to control others\xe2\x80\x99 activities, animals are presumably more free to investigate, seek novelty and explore.'b'Imagine if George had been a spider monkey! Why?\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t Let the Pigeon Drive the Bus!\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'Throughout Mo Willems\xe2\x80\x99s 2003 book, the reader is sternly instructed not to let one determined pigeon take the wheel of the bus when the driver takes a break. The authors examined captive pigeons\xe2\x80\x99 ability to navigate the traveling-salesman problem, a classic computational puzzle that asks you to devise the shortest round-trip route that stops at each city once.'b'Pigeons were tasked with finding the most efficient route between a handful of feeders holding yummy peas. While the results did not speak to the ability to keep up with a bus timetable, pigeons turn out to be highly skilled in planning efficient travel routes, an ability that is wanting in some human bus drivers.'b'Lest clarity mar the magic of childhood, we will stop there, and be sure not to tell you where the sidewalk ends, where the wild things are and how the Grinch actually stole Christmas.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDO you know how to unclasp this?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the jeweler on West 47th Street in Manhattan, holding a gold bracelet. None of Elizabeth Taylor\xe2\x80\x99s items were \xe2\x80\x9cmelt stuff.\xe2\x80\x9d I watched the auction as even her everyday pieces commanded hundreds of thousands of dollars.'b'My mother\xe2\x80\x99s baubles, which she bought at Fortunoff on Long Island, in the 1970s and \xe2\x80\x9980s, generally cost around $200 then, which was a lot to her. She never had money to burn, but every once in a while she would buy something to make her suburban existence a bit more Elizabeth Taylor-ish. Then she had her bouts with cancer; when chemotherapy swelled her fingers, her rings were banished to a safe deposit box, where they remained for 25 years, along with about a dozen necklaces and bracelets.'b'Last month, with the price of gold at a record high, I decided to find out how much I could get for my mother\xe2\x80\x99s jewelry \xe2\x80\x94 not to fund AIDS research, but for my children\xe2\x80\x99s education, a charity my mother would surely have endorsed.'b'Knowing nothing about selling jewelry, I started with a necklace \xe2\x80\x94 a thick chain with charms hanging from it \xe2\x80\x94 that I didn\xe2\x80\x99t remember from my childhood and therefore didn\xe2\x80\x99t mind giving up. On 47th Street between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, the diamond district, I entered a brightly lighted store, one of many, without even noticing its name. I produced the necklace from the lining of my coat. (A hole in my pocket lining gave me a perfect hiding place.) A young man told me he liked the necklace \xe2\x80\x94 so much that he would give me $1,200 for it. \xe2\x80\x9cBut you\xe2\x80\x99ll have to sell it to me now,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI want to give it to my grandmother for her 80th birthday, and the party is tomorrow night.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'I was in no mood to be hustled. I took the necklace to another store, where I received an offer of $1,250. And then to another, where, when I mentioned the $1,250, I was offered $1,400. (Not one jeweler I talked to believed the grandma-turning-80 story. It was, they said, a fiction to warm my heart \xe2\x80\x94 and cloud my business judgment.) Still, I walked back to the first store I visited, where I invited the young man to match the $1,400 offer. He said he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t afford to spend more than $1,200 for his grandma\xe2\x80\x99s birthday present. I went back to the dealer who offered me $1,400, and took it.'b'Could I have gotten more? Who knows? The price of gold is no secret, nor is the weight of the jewelry (every jeweler I visited had an electronic scale). The purity of the gold in a piece of jewelry is hard to know. But a jeweler looking at an item through a loupe and testing it with acid from an eyedropper can make an educated guess. Still, offers for one piece of jewelry will vary \xe2\x80\x94 sometimes significantly \xe2\x80\x94 from shop to shop, even on one block.'b'And then there\xe2\x80\x99s the X factor \xe2\x80\x94 the cachet that led frenzied bidders to buy Elizabeth Taylor\xe2\x80\x99s jewelry items for hundreds of times their intrinsic value.'b'For my mother\xe2\x80\x99s jewelry, the X factor is 1.'b'My only hope was to play jewelers against one another. A few days after my first outing, the $1,400 safely in the bank, I decided to see what I could get for the bracelet with the tricky clasp. Just two blocks from Christie\xe2\x80\x99s, I tried three stores, where offers ranged from $1,100 to $1,900.'b'I returned to the highest bidder, who walked into a vault and emerged with 19 C-notes. He asked for my driver\xe2\x80\x99s license, and gave it to an assistant to photocopy \xe2\x80\x94 a procedure that reduces the risk that he\xe2\x80\x99s buying stolen property, he said. We chatted for a while, and he told me that the piece weighed about 30 pennyweight (a pennyweight is a 20th of an ounce). If I brought in 200 pennyweight of gold, he said, I could go with him to watch it being melted down.'b'Would I be intrigued or repelled, I wondered, watching my mother\xe2\x80\x99s prized possessions turned into pure lucre?'b'I promised to return with some more pieces; what I didn\xe2\x80\x99t say was that I would take each item to at least three stores before selling. Just like Christie\xe2\x80\x99s, I was running a jewelry auction.'b'COLLECTING the past year\xe2\x80\x99s words is like sifting one\xe2\x80\x99s pockets at the end of a trip. Some things you\xe2\x80\x99ll keep, some you\xe2\x80\x99ll discard \xe2\x80\x94 the dinner receipt for the expense-account meal vs. the one-peso coin. Each is a reminder of what you did, where you went and whom you were with.'b'In 10 years, some of last year\xe2\x80\x99s words will be relics. We\xe2\x80\x99ll think of them the way we now think of the decades-old phrase \xe2\x80\x9cgag me with a spoon.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Others have already proved their staying power. Who could argue that the new sense of \xe2\x80\x9coccupy\xe2\x80\x9d isn\xe2\x80\x99t already a keeper, even starting as it did late in the third quarter of 2011? A movement so well labeled, if not cohesive in thought and action, that its name instantly lent itself to variation and satire.'b'We create all this new language, political and otherwise, for a lot of reasons. We\xe2\x80\x99re school-yard taunters, looking for the joke, the riff or the gag that will stick. We\xe2\x80\x99re novelty-shop fanatics, spending every paycheck in the House of Language on gewgaws and gimcracks and tchotchkes. Below are just a few of the catchwords I\xe2\x80\x99ve snagged during the last 12 months: Some are oldies that have resurfaced and taken on new life.'b''b'53 PERCENTER'b' An American in a household that pays income tax. Coined by conservatives who believe that the economy would improve if those who do not pay income taxes did.'b''b'99 PERCENT, 99 PERCENTERS'b' People claimed by the Occupy movement to be at a financial or political disadvantage when compared with the 1 percenters, those who protesters say have too much money and too much political control.'b''b'9-9-9 PLAN'b' The proposal by Herman Cain, a former Republican presidential candidate, for a 9 percent flat income tax, a 9 percent business flat tax and a 9 percent national sales tax.'b''b'ARAB SPRING'b' Collectively, the popular revolts and protests in Middle Eastern and Arab countries, among them Tunisia, Egypt, Libya, Yemen and Syria. Less frequently called Arab Awakening.'b''b'AUSTERITY MEASURES'b' Reductions or restrictions on government spending, meant to balance budgets, reduce deficits and meet standards set by intergovernmental lenders.'b''b'BASKETBRAWL'b' The fight that broke out between members of the Georgetown Hoyas and the Bayi Rockets during an exhibition basketball game in Beijing.'b''b'BATH SALTS'b' The street name for a group of stimulants made illegal this year.'b''b'BRONY'b' A man who is a fan of the television cartoon \xe2\x80\x9cMy Little Pony: Friendship Is Magic.\xe2\x80\x9d Formed from \xe2\x80\x9cbro,\xe2\x80\x9d brother or male friend, and pony.'b''b'BUFFETT TAX'b' A proposal that people making more than $1 million a year pay a higher rate of income tax than they do now and more than those who make less. Named for the investor Warren Buffett, who advocates the approach. Also called the Buffett rule.'b''b'CLOUD MUSIC'b' Personal digital music collections stored on remote servers so that they may be accessed by all of a person\xe2\x80\x99s digital devices. Both Apple and Google introduced cloud music services this year.'b''b'CRANKSHAFT'b' The code name used for Osama bin Laden by the Navy Seals team that killed him in Pakistan.'b''b'DARK SKY'b' Designates a place free of nighttime light pollution. For example, the island of Sark in the English Channel is a dark-sky island.'b''b'DEATHER'b' Someone who doubts that Osama bin Laden was killed by American troops.'b''b'DEBT CEILING'b' Not a new term, but now familiar to all: the limit to the amount of money the federal government may borrow.'b''b'HUMAN MEGAPHONE'b' A method of amplifying a speaker\xe2\x80\x99s words in which everyone who hears them repeats them in unison. Used in the Occupy protests, though not invented there. Also called the people\xe2\x80\x99s mike. To activate the human megaphone, a speaker will announce a mike check.'b''b'HUMBLEBRAG'b' A complaint, wry remark or self-deprecation that also reveals how famous, rich or important the speaker or writer is. Popularized by the comedian Harris Wittels, a writer for the NBC series "Parks and Recreation.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'KARDASH'b' A unit of time measuring 72 days. Coined by the musician Weird Al Yankovic in response to the 72-day marriage of Kim Kardashian and Kris Humphries.'b''b'LEAP SMEAR'b' Adding a few milliseconds each day to a computer\xe2\x80\x99s time-keeping. Google\xe2\x80\x99s solution for handling leap seconds, which are added to official world time to account for changes in the earth\xe2\x80\x99s rotation.'b''b'LIKEJACKING'b' Tricking users of a social media site, especially Facebook, into posting spammy content in their accounts or on their pages. Usually activated by clicking a \xe2\x80\x9clike,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cfave\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cthumbs up\xe2\x80\x9d button.'b''b'NYM WARS'b' A public debate about the requirement by some Web sites, especially Google+, that users not use pseudonyms. From the suffix -nym, as used in pseudonym, ultimately from the Greek onuma, for name.'b''b'OCCUPY WALL STREET'b' A left-leaning movement protesting wealth inequality and urging more government action against banks and corporations, which are seen by the protesters as being responsible for the current economic downturn. Abbreviated as O.W.S. or just Occupy and extended by replacing \xe2\x80\x9cWall Street\xe2\x80\x9d with any place name, as in Occupy L.A. or Occupy Toronto. Occupy and occupation have been used in the context of political or labor protests since the 1920s.'b''b'PLANKING'b' Posing for a photograph with the body in a stiff prone position, especially in odd situations or places. Similar popular pastimes this year include horsemaning, posing for a two-person picture that makes it look as though a supine headless body is holding a severed head, and Tebowing, kneeling as if praying in the manner of the Denver Broncos quarterback Tim Tebow, with one knee down and one up, and one\xe2\x80\x99s head resting on one\xe2\x80\x99s fist.'b''b'SUPER COMMITTEE'b' A group of 12 lawmakers, 6 Democrats and 6 Republicans, 3 each from the House and the Senate, that tried to make a plan on how to reduce the deficit. Also, the Gang of Six, three Democratic and three Republican senators who worked on reducing the federal government\xe2\x80\x99s debt.'b''b'TOT MOM'b' Casey Anthony, acquitted of charges of killing her 2-year-old daughter. The term was largely popularized by Nancy Grace, host of her own HLN program.'b''b'TWINKLING'b' Silently affirming a speaker by raising one\xe2\x80\x99s hands, palms outward, and wiggling the hands and fingers. Similar to a gesture used in American Sign Language as the equivalent of applause. Brought to wider public attention by the Occupy movement (see human megaphone, above) but predates it by many years.'b''b'WINNING'b' Used repeatedly and not ironically by the actor Charlie Sheen at the time of his tumultuous departure from \xe2\x80\x9cTwo and a Half Men.\xe2\x80\x9d It was quickly taken up as a catchphrase. Related: tiger blood, which Mr. Sheen figuratively used to describe his motivations.'b'DES MOINES'b'IT\xe2\x80\x99S not often that a political wife presents herself as The Decider.'b'There\xe2\x80\x99s too much danger of straying into Lady Macbeth territory, as Nancy Reagan and Hillary Clinton discovered when some sniped that they were wearing the pants.'b'But as Iowa reaches a crescendo, three Republican wives say they\xe2\x80\x99re forcing their humble, self-effacing mates to sacrifice themselves to save the nation.'b'That might be believable, if the mates weren\xe2\x80\x99t Mitt Romney, Newt Gingrich and Donald Trump.'b'Ann Romney told CNN\xe2\x80\x99s Wolf Blitzer that she insisted to her reluctant spouse: \xe2\x80\x9cYou know what, Mitt, you\xe2\x80\x99ve got to do this again.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Mitt resisted, she said, because \xe2\x80\x9che remembered how difficult it is and what the hurdles were going to be.\xe2\x80\x9d Mittens, as her not-so-cuddly mate is called by reporters, knew he was not a natural with voters.'b'According to Mitt, their pillow talk sounded like a political ad. \xe2\x80\x9cShe said, \xe2\x80\x98Look, no one else can beat President Obama. No one else has the background to actually get the economy going, understand the economy in a very fundamental way.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d'b'We\xe2\x80\x99ve seen political wives, like Michelle Obama and Alma Powell, who grimaced at the thought of their husbands running. And ones like Nancy Reagan, who gazed adoringly in public and strategized adeptly in private.'b'But this campaign season, some spouses are not only the power behind the throne, they\xe2\x80\x99re the propulsion out front. Helpful nags have replaced quiet helpmeets.'b'As one top Republican here put it, if Ann can go all out to persuade Mitt to run, even though she has to endure the rigors of campaigning with multiple sclerosis, then voters may begin to believe there\xe2\x80\x99s more to Mittens than a glossy bankroll and glossy hair (especially compared with Newt, who left two wives facing illness.)'b'At Iowa campaign stops, the elegant Ann introduces her husband by describing how steadfast he has been as she fought her disease. In the post-Elizabeth Edwards age, candidates can\xe2\x80\x99t risk looking as if they are placing their ambition ahead of a spouse\xe2\x80\x99s health. So it\xe2\x80\x99s a calculation for Romney\xe2\x80\x99s image that Ann be seen as a driving force rather than a victim.'b'Like another animatronic candidate, Michael Dukakis, Romney uses his wife as a way to convey passion; Mittens also dwells on patriotic songs and poems, and stories about traveling the country with Mom and Dad in a Rambler, to humanize himself and quell some evangelical voters\xe2\x80\x99 fears that Mormonism is an alien cult.'b'Newt Gingrich credits his wife\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cstubbornness\xe2\x80\x9d with keeping him in the race.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere were several critical moments where I said to Newt, \xe2\x80\x98If we can just get to the debates, if we can just get to September,\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d Callista told the Christian Broadcasting Network.'b'Their relationship was born in sin and hypocrisy. Devout Catholic Callista, an aide on the House Agriculture Committee, had a six-year affair with married Newt, including while he was trying to impeach Bill Clinton for lying about an extramarital affair with an intern.'b'But now Newt promotes himself as a man reborn. According to the latest People magazine, Callista has played Henry Higgins to Newt\xe2\x80\x99s Eliza Doolittle, remaking him into a more docile man who plays golf, loves opera, worships at a Catholic church, and, for the first time, shares his calamari.'b'At an event for Iowa mothers at a coffee shop here Friday, Gingrich was asked how he could prove he had really changed.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI would say I am a sadder and slower person than I was 25 years ago,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, noting that back then, \xe2\x80\x9cI thought if you just kept moving fast enough, somehow everything would always work.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Gingrich was emphasizing the influence women have had on him when he broke down as he described his mother\xe2\x80\x99s battles with bipolar disease and depression. His interest in brain science, he said as he wept, is \xe2\x80\x9cnot a theory. It\xe2\x80\x99s, in fact, you know, my mother.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'He said he would consider women \xe2\x80\x94 Sarah Palin and Condoleezza Rice \xe2\x80\x94 for his running mate.'b'You wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t think Donald Trump, who routinely says stuff like \xe2\x80\x9cI mean, part of the beauty of me is I\xe2\x80\x99m very rich,\xe2\x80\x9d would need much connubial coaxing to picture himself in the Trump White House. But a Globe headline this week reads: \xe2\x80\x9cWife Melania Tells The Donald: America Needs You!\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Melania also appears to talk like a political adviser\xe2\x80\x99s fantasy. Donald Trump told the tabloid that his striking Slovenian-born wife recently told him: \xe2\x80\x9cDarling, you know you\xe2\x80\x99d win if you ran, don\xe2\x80\x99t you? You could win and maybe even easily. People really want you. I see it on the streets. People want you and they really need you.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'From Sammy Glick to Al Gore, men on the make who seem too nakedly careerist are off-putting. You don\xe2\x80\x99t become president without clawing your way into the Oval Office, but voters prefer pols like J.F.K., Ronald Reagan and Barack Obama who wear their ambition lightly.'b'The key to ambition is the ability to cloak it. Better yet, attribute it to your wife.'b'IN 1984, after serving three terms in the House of Representatives, Ron Paul was defeated by Phil Gramm in Texas\xe2\x80\x99s Republican Senate primary. Paul left Congress, and a few years later he left the Republican Party entirely to run for president on the Libertarian line. In the 1988 election, after a campaign that Texas Monthly 'b'compared'b' to something \xe2\x80\x9cout of Robert Altman\xe2\x80\x99s movie \xe2\x80\x98Nashville,\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d he took home just 0.47 percent of the popular vote.'b'Thus marginalized by the public, the former congressman proceeded to marginalize himself. Through the various newsletters that bore his name \xe2\x80\x94 most notably the Ron Paul Political Report and the Ron Paul Survival Report \xe2\x80\x94 he spent the early 1990s as a peddler of far-right paranoia. In an exhaustive 2008 'b'piece'b' for Reason magazine, Dave Weigel and Julian Sanchez argued that the most abhorrent language in Paul\xe2\x80\x99s eponymous newsletters \xe2\x80\x94 the claims that the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. \xe2\x80\x9cseduced under-age girls and boys,\xe2\x80\x9d that AIDS sufferers \xe2\x80\x9cenjoy the attention and pity,\xe2\x80\x9d and so on \xe2\x80\x94 weren\xe2\x80\x99t actually written by the man himself. But the fact that they had Paul\xe2\x80\x99s imprimatur suggests that the former congressman had grown comfortable way out on the xenophobic fringe.'b'That fringe is like the Hotel California: When public figures hang out there for a while, they usually find that it\xe2\x80\x99s easier to check out than to leave. Yet in 1997, Paul was back in Congress, representing the same Republican Party that he\xe2\x80\x99d previously abandoned. In 2008, after a decade as a marginal figure on the Hill, his long-shot campaign for the presidency suddenly gained him one of American politics\xe2\x80\x99 most devoted followings. And now this following has grown large enough that a man whose Survival Report once counseled would-be militia members to \xe2\x80\x9cavoid the phone as much as possible\xe2\x80\x9d has a chance to win the Iowa caucuses.'b'There are two commonplace interpretations of Paul\xe2\x80\x99s unusual trajectory. To his many sympathizers \xe2\x80\x94 libertarians, dissident conservatives and some left-wingers as well \xe2\x80\x94 the extremism in his past has nothing to do with the issues that he\xe2\x80\x99s campaigning on today. The case for Paul, as The Atlantic\xe2\x80\x99s Conor Friedersdorf 'b'put it'b', is that \xe2\x80\x9che alone, among viable candidates, favors reforming certain atrocious policies\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 scaling back America\xe2\x80\x99s overseas commitments, ending a failed war on drugs, curbing a runaway public sector and reducing the powers of an imperial presidency. The newsletters may reflect badly on his past, but in the current political landscape he\xe2\x80\x99s a voice of reason rather than of madness.'b'To his many critics, on the other hand, Paul\xe2\x80\x99s present-day positions are connected to his past derangements, because they share the same essentially conspiratorial root. Then as now, Paul blames shadowy elites for the country\xe2\x80\x99s ills; then as now, he flirts with narratives that are straight out of the fever swamp. For all its superficial idealism, the critics insist, his campaign is a conduit through which fundamentally poisonous ideas are entering the mainstream body politic, and thus he needs to be not only defeated but repudiated.'b'But consider a third possibility. There\xe2\x80\x99s often a fine line between a madman and a prophet. Perhaps Paul has emerged as a teller of some important truths precisely because in many ways he\xe2\x80\x99s still as far out there as ever.'b'The United States is living through an era of unprecedented elite failure, in which America\xe2\x80\x99s public institutions are understandably distrusted and our leadership class is justifiably despised. Yet politicians of both parties are required, by the demands of partisanship, to embrace the convenient lie that our problem can be pinned exclusively on the other side\xe2\x80\x99s elites \xe2\x80\x94 as though both liberals and conservatives hadn\xe2\x80\x99t participated in the decisions that dug our current hole.'b'In this climate, it sometimes takes a fearless crank to expose realities that neither Republicans nor Democrats are particularly eager to acknowledge.'b'In both the 2008 and 2012 campaigns, Paul has been the only figure willing to point out the deep continuities in American politics \xe2\x80\x94 the way social spending grows and overseas commitments multiply no matter which party is in power, the revolving doors that connect K Street to Congress and Wall Street to the White House, the long list of dubious policies and programs that both sides tacitly support. In both election cycles, his honest extremism has sometimes cut closer to the heart of our national predicament than the calculating partisanship of his more grounded rivals. He sometimes rants, but he rarely spins \xe2\x80\x94 and he\xe2\x80\x99s one of the few figures on the national stage who says \xe2\x80\x9ca plague on both your houses!\xe2\x80\x9d and actually means it.'b'Obviously it would be better for the country if this message weren\xe2\x80\x99t freighted with Paul\xe2\x80\x99s noxious baggage, and entangled with his many implausible ideas. But would it be better off without his presence entirely? I\xe2\x80\x99m not so sure.'b'Neither prophets nor madmen should be elected to the presidency. But neither can they safely be ignored.'b'Coralville, Iowa'b'AS the hour of actual caucusing drew closer, Ron Paul\xe2\x80\x99s campaign trumpeted his endorsement by a pastor who, as it happens, has 'b'spoken'b' of executing homosexuals. Rick Perry pledged to devote predator drones and thousands of troops to the protection of the Mexican border, making the mission to keep every last illegal immigrant from crossing sound as urgent as rooting out terrorists in Pakistan.'b'And Rick Santorum, bringing his \xe2\x80\x9cFaith, Family and Freedom\xe2\x80\x9d tour to this eastern Iowa town on Thursday, promised never to be cowed by all those craven secularists who believe that a stable, healthy household needn\xe2\x80\x99t be headed by a God-fearing mom and dad.'b'None of these three men is likely to win the Republican nomination. But before they exit stage right \xe2\x80\x94 stage far right, that is \xe2\x80\x94 they and a few of their similarly quixotic, similarly strident competitors will do no small measure of damage to the Republican Party and no great favors to the country as a whole. What happens in Iowa doesn\xe2\x80\x99t stay in Iowa: it befouls Republicans\xe2\x80\x99 image nationally, becomes a millstone around the eventual nominee\xe2\x80\x99s neck and legitimizes debate about some matters that shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be debatable.'b'The run-up to the Iowa caucuses, like the rest of the primary season thus far, has underscored just how much general nuttiness and moral extremism the party has come to accommodate, with Iowa serving as a theater of the conservative absurd. The state\xe2\x80\x99s unrepresentative caucuses \xe2\x80\x94 in which a mere 100,000 or so of the most fervent voters, almost all of them white, are expected to participate \xe2\x80\x94 coax a Bible-thumping, border-militarizing harshness from candidates that\xe2\x80\x99s a tonal turnoff to the swing voters who will probably decide the general election.'b'The more reasoned, practical members of the Republican establishment know this. That\xe2\x80\x99s why many of them are doing all they can to expedite the coronation of Mitt Romney, whose mild manner and time as the governor of a heavily Democratic state give him a centrist aura, or at least the possibility of one. They\xe2\x80\x99d like to get his loopier and more incendiary rivals away from the television cameras, soon.'b'Many Democrats take heart from the spectacle of ultra-conservative pandering in Iowa, correctly surmising that it bolsters their own party\xe2\x80\x99s fortunes and President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s re-election chances. They shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t, not if they care about the country, best served by a vigorous back-and-forth about the proper size and role of government and about budgetary restraint. In its least hypocritical moments, the Republican Party has provided an important counterbalance to a Democratic tropism toward paternalism and bloat. It can\xe2\x80\x99t do that if it marginalizes itself by repelling fiscally conservative but socially moderate voters who have little appetite for the shenanigans in Iowa.'b'Last week, Paul remained at or near the top of polls of the state\xe2\x80\x99s Republicans, despite his refusal to disavow support from white supremacist and anti-Zionist groups and \xe2\x80\x94 on an infinitely lighter note \xe2\x80\x94 a campaign style that just won\xe2\x80\x99t cut it.'b'I caught up with him in Newton, where his staff distributed glossy pamphlets, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Ron Paul Family Cookbook,\xe2\x80\x9d with recipes for \xe2\x80\x9ccherry-pineapple dump cake,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cimpossible pie,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9crazzle bo-dazzle pork tenderloin\xe2\x80\x9d and more. His remarks were less sculptured stump speech than meandering civics seminar, with none of the customary oratorical swells and dips.'b'An advocate of abolishing the Federal Reserve, he got questions unlike those other candidates receive, including one about monetary policy that concluded, \xe2\x80\x9cMy thought is: maybe the silver standard?\xe2\x80\x9d He responded by earnestly weighing silver against gold, the pol as metallurgist.'b'He terrifies more pragmatic conservatives like the commentator Michael Medved, who has called him \xe2\x80\x9cDr. Demento.\xe2\x80\x9d Medved 'b'wrote'b' in The Daily Beast last week that a strong showing by Paul in the caucuses and beyond would be \xe2\x80\x9cdisastrous to Republican prospects,\xe2\x80\x9d validating the impression that \xe2\x80\x9ctoday\xe2\x80\x99s Republicans have become a wild and crazy bunch, harboring oddball, irresponsible notions that place them far outside the American mainstream and make them untrustworthy when it comes to the serious business of governance.\xe2\x80\x9d He added, rightly, that Paul\xe2\x80\x99s associations aren\xe2\x80\x99t helpful to a party whose future may depend on its appeal to Hispanic and black voters.'b'That future was lost on Perry, too. I caught up with him on Wednesday in Pella, where he was introduced by 'b'Joe Arpaio'b', the polarizing Arizona sheriff who once 'b'marched'b' 200 immigrants awaiting deportation through the streets and is widely loathed by Hispanics. Perry spoke of Arpaio\xe2\x80\x99s support as a compliment higher than any imaginable. ORTH'b'\nChapel Hill, N.C., Dec. 29, 2011'b''b''b'The writer is a professor of law at the University of North Carolina.'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'As a psychiatrist and the parent of an adult son with autism, I found \xe2\x80\x9c'b'In Treating Disabled, Potent Drugs and Few Rules'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (front page, Dec. 23) to be unfair and detrimental to the families of the developmentally disabled. Although any medication can be inappropriately administered, the wholesale denigration of psychotropic medication for this population is misplaced.'b'People with autism do indeed have a brain disorder, and so using medications that treat the brain makes perfect sense. They now represent the leading cause of accidental death in the United States, having overtaken motor vehicle accidents for the first time on record.'b'One might expect such news to spur politicians to explore new options for drug abuse treatment, prevention and enforcement. Instead, at precisely the wrong time, extremists on both sides have taken over the conversation. Unless we change the tone of the debate to give drug-policy centrists a voice, America\xe2\x80\x99s drug problem will only get worse.'b'Indeed, moderates have historically been key contributors to both the debate and the practice of effective drug policy. In 1914, Representative Francis B. Harrison, a New York Democrat, worked with Republicans and President Woodrow Wilson to pass the first major piece of federal 'b'anti-drug legislation'b', in response to a surge in heroin and cocaine use.'b'Other moderates, from Theodore Roosevelt to John F. Kennedy, made drug policy an important part of their domestic agendas. President Bill Clinton worked closely with Bob Dole, the Republican Senate majority leader, on sensible measures like drug courts and community policing. And Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is the reason there is a 'b'drug czar'b' in the first place, having pushed the idea for years before President Ronald Reagan approved it.'b'So where are the moderates now? Certainly, the current political climate makes it hard to come together on any question. Republicans are too timid to touch any domestic policy issue, like effective drug prevention and treatment, that might appear to cost taxpayers more money. And too many Democrats have yet to recognize that drugs are an issue that they and their constituents should care deeply about: after all, drug abuse and its consequences affect the most vulnerable in society in especially harmful ways.'b'In their place, a few tough-on-crime conservatives and die-hard libertarians dominate news coverage and make it appear as if legalizing drugs and \xe2\x80\x9cenforcement only\xe2\x80\x9d strategies were the only options, despite the fact that the public supports neither.'b'This stalemate comes just as a new range of cost-effective, evidence-based approaches to prevention, treatment and the criminal justice system are within our reach. We know much more about addiction than we did 20 years ago; with enough support, we could pursue promising medications and behavioral therapies, even a possible vaccine against some drug addictions.'b'Meanwhile, smart, innovative law enforcement strategies that employ carrots and sticks \xe2\x80\x94 treatment and drug testing complete with swift but modest consequences for continued drug use, or incentives for abstinence \xe2\x80\x94 have produced impressive results, through drug courts or closely supervised probation programs.'b'And drug prevention has moved from a didactic classroom exercise to a science of teaching life skills and changing environmental norms based on local data and community capacity. We now know that recovery from addiction is possible, and that policies that give former addicts a second chance are in everyone\xe2\x80\x99s interest.'b'Most recently, R. Gil Kerlikowske, President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s top drug policy adviser, introduced a sensible four-point plan to curb prescription drug abuse: educate prescribers, parents and young people about the dangers of overdose; shut down illegitimate \xe2\x80\x9cclinics\xe2\x80\x9d that freely sell these drugs; establish electronic monitoring at pharmacies; and encourage the proper disposal of unused medications. Yet his plan received little attention from the news media or Capitol Hill.'b'Of course, there is no magic bullet for America\xe2\x80\x99s drug problem. The magnitude and complexity of our drug problem require us to constantly refine and improve our policies through thoughtful analysis, innovation and discussion.'b'Moderates should lead that conversation. To remain silent not only betrays widely shared values of compassion and justice for the most vulnerable. Anybody caught singing his songs without permission, Guthrie once advised, \xe2\x80\x9cwill be mighty good friends of ours.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'He wrote \xe2\x80\x9cThis Land Is Your Land\xe2\x80\x9d to reach beyond the national anthem to the ordinary citizens facing life\xe2\x80\x99s ups and downs with a lyrical edge. \xe2\x80\x9cAs I go walking that freedom highway/ Nobody living can ever make me turn back/ This land was made for you and me.\xe2\x80\x9d Guthrie would probably not have been surprised by Oklahoma\xe2\x80\x99s late embrace. \xe2\x80\x9cLife has got a habit of not standing hitched,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou got to ride it like you find it.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Five years ago, New York State stopped requiring that all applicants for food stamps be electronically fingerprinted. Recently, California and Texas ended their requirement, leaving New York City and Arizona the only jurisdictions to continue the stigmatizing requirement.'b'Especially at a time when so many families are struggling, the Bloomberg administration should drop the requirement that leads too many New Yorkers to forgo help. If it does not, Gov. Andrew Cuomo should issue an executive order ending the city\xe2\x80\x99s exemption.'b'Mayor Michael Bloomberg and his human resources commissioner, Robert Doar, contend that fingerprint matching is essential for detecting and deterring fraud and avoiding costly duplications. But there is no evidence that finger-imaging is either cost-effective or necessary. Collecting fingerprints is useless for uncovering scams like government employees\xe2\x80\x99 making up phony cases or applicants\xe2\x80\x99 lying about their income. Matching applicants\xe2\x80\x99 names with Social Security numbers, as other jurisdictions do, would be cheaper and equally effective.'b'At a recent City Council hearing, Mr. Doar said that fingerprinting allows the city to find about 2,000 duplication errors annually. He could not say how many are due to fraud and how many to innocent administrative errors. Tellingly, he could not cite a single fraud prosecution.'b'Seeking to pressure the Bloomberg administration to end the requirement, Christine Quinn, the City Council speaker, is supporting a bill to require the administration to report annually on the number of cases of food stamp fraud detected, the number referred for prosecution and the cost of the fingerprinting program. Mr. Obama can and should push back hard.'b'This is precisely the moment for him to argue the case for alternative fuel sources and clean energy jobs \xe2\x80\x94 and to lambaste the Republicans for doubling down on conventional fuels while ceding a $5 trillion global clean technology market (and the jobs that go with it) to more aggressive competitors like China and Germany.'b'The payroll tax cut bill, which Mr. Obama signed last month, gave him 60 days to decide on the Keystone XL pipeline. That is not enough time to complete the required environmental review of a project that, in its present design, crosses ecologically sensitive territory and risks polluting an aquifer critical to Midwestern water supplies.'b'The Republicans\xe2\x80\x99 claim that the pipeline will create tens of thousands of new jobs \xe2\x80\x94 20,000 according to House Speaker John Boehner and 100,000 according to Jon Huntsman \xe2\x80\x94 are wildly inflated.
