Ever since blacks first arrived on these shores in chains, they have been perceived as lazy and dependent on whites \xe2\x80\x94 first as slaves, and then as \xe2\x80\x9centitled\xe2\x80\x9d citizens.'b'It is the Shackles-to-Bootstraps Doctrine of Self-Defeat that disavows any and all structural inhibitors to success.'b'The preface of the \xe2\x80\x9cEncyclopedia of Black Folklore and Humor\xe2\x80\x9d tells a story about the first black captives arriving in the New World and one slave \xe2\x80\x9cmuttering angrily to himself.\xe2\x80\x9d The captain of the boat says to him, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s the matter with you? You\xe2\x80\x99ve been in this country for only five minutes and already you\xe2\x80\x99re complaining!\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Folklore or fact, this is the way many have viewed blacks in this country throughout history and even now: with scolding disdain and shocking blindness.'b'In 1935, W.E.B. DuBois\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cBlack Reconstruction in America 1860-1880\xe2\x80\x9d pointed out that one of the major themes that American children were being taught in textbooks about that period was that \xe2\x80\x9call Negroes were lazy, dishonest and extravagant.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The themes are eerily resonant of today\xe2\x80\x99s Republican talking points on welfare.'b'One textbook theme excerpted by DuBois stated that \xe2\x80\x9clegislatures were often at the mercy of Negroes, childishly ignorant, who sold their votes openly, and whose \xe2\x80\x98loyalty\xe2\x80\x99 was gained by allowing them to eat, drink and clothe themselves at the state\xe2\x80\x99s expense.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Another stated that \xe2\x80\x9cassistance led many freed men to believe that they need no longer work.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This tired trope was reprised in 1976. After losing the Iowa caucus to Gerald Ford and heading into the New Hampshire primary, Ronald Reagan glommed onto the idea of the \xe2\x80\x9cwelfare queen.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Reagan explained at nearly every stop that there was a woman in Chicago who \xe2\x80\x9chas 80 names, 30 addresses, 12 Social Security cards and is collecting veteran\xe2\x80\x99s benefits on four nonexisting deceased husbands. And she is collecting Social Security on her cards. She\xe2\x80\x99s got Medicaid, getting food stamps, and she is collecting welfare under each of her names. Her tax-free cash income is over $150,000.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Coincidence? \xe2\x80\x9cUh huh.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Racial politics play well for Republicans. Santorum and Paul finished second and third in Iowa. Time will tell if Gingrich rebounds. Playing to racial anxiety and fear isn\xe2\x80\x99t a fluke; it\xe2\x80\x99s a strategy that energizes the Republican base.'b'Kevin Phillips, who popularized the right\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cSouthern Strategy,\xe2\x80\x9d was quoted in The New York Times Magazine in May 1970 as saying that \xe2\x80\x9cthe more Negroes who register as Democrats in the South, the sooner the Negrophobe whites will quit the Democrats and become Republicans.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cUh huh.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Tokyo'b'DESPITE some small signs of optimism about the United States economy, unemployment is still high, and the country seems stalled.'b'Time and again, Americans are told to look to 'b'Japan'b' as a warning of what the country might become if the right path is not followed, although there is intense disagreement about what that path might be. Here, for instance, is how the CNN analyst 'b'David Gergen'b' has described Japan: \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s now a very demoralized country and it has really been set back.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But that presentation of Japan is a myth. By many measures, the Japanese economy has done very well during the so-called lost decades, which started with a stock market crash in January 1990. By some of the most important measures, it has done a lot better than the United States.'b'Japan has succeeded in delivering an increasingly affluent lifestyle to its people despite the financial crash. In the fullness of time, it is likely that this era will be viewed as an outstanding success story.'b'How can the reality and the image be so different? And can the United States learn from Japan\xe2\x80\x99s experience?'b'It is true that Japanese housing prices have never returned to the ludicrous highs they briefly touched in the wild final stage of the boom. Neither has the Tokyo stock market.'b'But the strength of Japan\xe2\x80\x99s economy and its people is evident in many ways. There are a number of facts and figures that don\xe2\x80\x99t quite square with Japan\xe2\x80\x99s image as the laughingstock of the business pages:'b'\xc2\x95 Japan\xe2\x80\x99s average'b' life expectancy'b' at birth grew by 4.2 years \xe2\x80\x94 to 83 years from 78.8 years \xe2\x80\x94 between 1989 and 2009. This means the Japanese now typically live 4.8 years longer than Americans. The progress, moreover, was achieved in spite of, rather than because of, diet. The Japanese people are eating more Western food than ever. The key driver has been better health care.'b'\xc2\x95 Japan has made remarkable strides in Internet infrastructure. Although as late as the mid-1990s it was ridiculed as lagging, it has now turned the tables. In a recent survey by Akamai Technologies, of the 50 cities in the world with the fastest Internet service, 38 were in Japan, compared to only 3 in the United States.'b'\xc2\x95 Measured from the end of 1989, the yen has risen 87 percent against the U.S. dollar and 94 percent against the British pound. It has even risen against that traditional icon of monetary rectitude, the Swiss franc.'b'\xc2\x95 The 'b'unemployment rate'b' is 4.2 percent, about half of that in the United States.'b'\xc2\x95 According to 'b'skyscraperpage.com'b', a Web site that tracks major buildings around the world, 81 high-rise buildings taller than 500 feet have been constructed in Tokyo since the \xe2\x80\x9clost decades\xe2\x80\x9d began. That compares with 64 in New York, 48 in Chicago, and 7 in Los Angeles.'b'\xc2\x95 Japan\xe2\x80\x99s current account surplus \xe2\x80\x94 the widest measure of its trade \xe2\x80\x94 totaled $196 billion in 2010, up more than threefold since 1989. By comparison, America\xe2\x80\x99s current account deficit ballooned to $471 billion from $99 billion in that time. Although in the 1990s the conventional wisdom was that as a result of China\xe2\x80\x99s rise Japan would be a major loser and the United States a major winner, it has not turned out that way. Japan has increased its exports to China more than 14-fold since 1989 and Chinese-Japanese bilateral trade remains in broad balance.'b'As longtime Japan watchers like Ivan P. Hall and Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr. point out, the fallacy of the \xe2\x80\x9clost decades\xe2\x80\x9d story is apparent to American visitors the moment they set foot in the country. Typically starting their journeys at such potent symbols of American infrastructural decay as Kennedy or Dulles airports, they land at Japanese airports that have been extensively expanded and modernized in recent years.'b''b'William J. Holstein'b', a prominent Japan watcher since the early 1980s, recently visited the country for the first time in some years. \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s a dramatic gap between what one reads in the United States and what one sees on the ground in Japan,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Japanese are dressed better than Americans. They have the latest cars, including Porsches, Audis, Mercedes-Benzes and all the finest models. I have never seen so many spoiled pets. And the physical infrastructure of the country keeps improving and evolving.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Why, then, is Japan seen as a loser? On the official 'b'gross domestic product'b' numbers, the United States has ostensibly outperformed Japan for many years. But even taking America\xe2\x80\x99s official numbers at face value, the difference has been far narrower than people realize. Adjusted to a per-capita basis (which is the proper way to do this) and measured since 1989, America\xe2\x80\x99s G.D.P. grew by an average of just 1.4 percent a year. Japan\xe2\x80\x99s figure meanwhile was even more anemic \xe2\x80\x94 just 1 percent \xe2\x80\x94 implying that it underperformed the United States by 0.4 percent a year.'b'A look at the underlying accounting, however, suggests that, far from underperforming, Japan may have outperformed. For a start, in a little noticed change, United States statisticians in the 1980s embarked on an increasingly aggressive use of the so-called hedonic method of adjusting for inflation, an approach that in the view of many experts artificially boosts a nation\xe2\x80\x99s apparent growth rate.'b'On the calculations of John Williams of 'b'Shadowstats.com'b', a Web site that tracks flaws in United States economic data, America\xe2\x80\x99s growth in recent decades has been overstated by as much as 2 percentage points a year. If he is even close to the truth, this factor alone may put the United States behind Japan in per-capita performance.'b'If the Japanese have really been hurting, the most obvious place this would show would be in slow adoption of expensive new high-tech items. Yet the Japanese are consistently among the world\xe2\x80\x99s earliest adopters. If anything, it is Americans who have been lagging. In cellphones, for instance, Japan leapfrogged the United States in the space of a few years in the late 1990s and it has stayed ahead ever since, with consumers moving exceptionally rapidly to ever more advanced devices.'b'Much of the story is qualitative rather than quantitative. An example is Japan\xe2\x80\x99s eating-out culture. Tokyo, according to the Michelin Guide, boasts 16 of the world\xe2\x80\x99s top-ranked restaurants, versus a mere 10 for the runner-up, Paris. Similarly Japan as a whole beats France in the Michelin ratings. But how do you express this in G.D.P. terms?'b'Similar problems arise in measuring improvements in the Japanese health care system. And how does one accurately convey the vast improvement in the general environment in Japan in the last two decades?'b'Luckily there is a yardstick that finesses many of these problems: electricity output, which is mainly a measure of consumer affluence and industrial activity. In the 1990s, while Japan was being widely portrayed as an outright \xe2\x80\x9cbasket case,\xe2\x80\x9d its rate of increase in per-capita electricity output was twice that of America, and it continued to outperform into the new century.'b'Part of what is going on here is Western psychology. Anyone who has followed the story long-term cannot help but notice that many Westerners actively seek to belittle Japan. Thus every policy success is automatically discounted. It is a mind-set that is much in evidence even among Tokyo-based Western diplomats and scholars.'b'Take, for instance, how Western observers have viewed Japan\xe2\x80\x99s demographics. The population is getting older because of a low birthrate, a characteristic Japan shares with many of the world\xe2\x80\x99s richest nations. Yet this is presented not only as a critical problem but as a policy failure. It never seems to occur to Western commentators that the Japanese both individually and collectively have chosen their demographic fate \xe2\x80\x94 and have good reasons for doing so.'b'The story begins in the terrible winter of 1945-6, when, newly bereft of their empire, the Japanese nearly starved to death. With overseas expansion no longer an option, Japanese leaders determined as a top priority to cut the birthrate. Thereafter a culture of small families set in that has continued to the present day.'b'Japan\xe2\x80\x99s motivation is clear: food security. With only about one-third as much arable land per capita as China, Japan has long been the world\xe2\x80\x99s largest net food importer. While the birth control policy is the primary cause of Japan\xe2\x80\x99s aging demographics, the phenomenon also reflects improved health care and an increase of more than 20 years in life expectancy since 1950.'b'Psychology aside, a major factor in the West\xe2\x80\x99s comprehension problem is that virtually everyone in Tokyo benefits from the doom and gloom story. For foreign sales representatives, for instance, it has been the perfect get-out-of-jail card when they don\xe2\x80\x99t reach their quotas. For Japanese foundations it is the perfect excuse in politely waving away solicitations from American universities and other needy nonprofits. Ditto for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in tempering expectations of foreign aid recipients. Even American investment bankers have reasons to emphasize bad news. Most notably they profit from the so-called yen-carry trade, an arcane but powerful investment strategy in which the well informed benefit from periodic bouts of weakness in the Japanese yen.'b'Economic ideology has also played an unfortunate role. Many economists, particularly right-wing think-tank types, are such staunch advocates of laissez-faire that they reflexively scorn Japan\xe2\x80\x99s very different economic system, with its socialist medicine and ubiquitous government regulation. During the stock market bubble of the late 1980s, this mind-set abated but it came back after the crash.'b'Japanese trade negotiators noticed an almost magical sweetening in the mood in foreign capitals after the stock market crashed in 1990. Although previously there had been much envy of Japan abroad (and serious talk of 'b'protectionist'b' measures), in the new circumstances American and European trade negotiators switched to feeling sorry for the \xe2\x80\x9cfallen giant.\xe2\x80\x9d Nothing if not fast learners, Japanese trade negotiators have been appealing for sympathy ever since.'b'The strategy seems to have been particularly effective in Washington. Believing that you shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t kick a man when he is down, chivalrous American officials have largely given up pressing for the opening of Japan\xe2\x80\x99s markets. Yet the great United States trade complaints of the late 1980s \xe2\x80\x94 concerning rice, financial services, cars and car components \xe2\x80\x94 were never remedied.'b'The \xe2\x80\x9cfallen giant\xe2\x80\x9d story has also even been useful to other East Asian nations, particularly in their trade diplomacy with the United States.'b'A striking instance of how the story has influenced American perceptions appears in \xe2\x80\x9cThe Next 100 Years,\xe2\x80\x9d by the consultant George Friedman. In a chapter headed \xe2\x80\x9cChina 2020: Paper Tiger,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Friedman argues that, just as Japan \xe2\x80\x9cfailed\xe2\x80\x9d in the 1990s, China will soon have its comeuppance. Talk of this sort powerfully fosters complacency and confusion in Washington in the face of a United States-China trade relationship that is already arguably the most destructive in world history and certainly the most unbalanced.'b'Clearly the question of what has really happened to Japan is of first-order geopolitical importance. In a stunning refutation of American conventional wisdom, Japan has not missed a beat in building an ever more sophisticated industrial base. That this is not more obvious is a tribute in part to the fact that Japanese manufacturers have graduated to making so-called producers\xe2\x80\x99 goods. These typically consist of advanced components or materials, or precision production equipment. They may be invisible to the consumer, yet without them the modern world literally would not exist. This sort of manufacturing, which is both highly capital-intensive and highly know-how-intensive, was virtually monopolized by the United States in the 1950s and 1960s and constituted the essence of American economic leadership.'b'Japan\xe2\x80\x99s achievement is all the more impressive for the fact that its major competitors \xe2\x80\x94 Germany, South Korea, Taiwan and, of course, China \xe2\x80\x94 have hardly been standing still. The world has gone through a rapid industrial revolution in the last two decades thanks to the \xe2\x80\x9ctargeting\xe2\x80\x9d of manufacturing by many East Asian nations. Yet Japan\xe2\x80\x99s trade surpluses have risen.'b'Japan should be held up as a model, not an admonition. If a nation can summon the will to pull together, it can turn even the most unpromising circumstances to advantage. Here Japan\xe2\x80\x99s constant upgrading of its infrastructure is surely an inspiration. It is a strategy that often requires cooperation across a wide political front, but such cooperation has not been beyond the American political system in the past. The Hoover Dam, that iconic project of the Depression, required negotiations among seven states but somehow it was built \xe2\x80\x94 and it provided jobs for 16,000 people in the process. Nothing is stopping similar progress now \xe2\x80\x94 nothing, except political bickering.'b'Scientists have long worried that an influenza virus that has ravaged poultry and wild birds in Asia might evolve to pose a threat to humans. Now scientists financed by the National Institutes of Health have shown in a laboratory how that could happen. In the process they created a virus that could kill tens or hundreds of millions of people if it escaped confinement or was stolen by terrorists.'b'We nearly always champion unfettered scientific research and open publication of the results. In this case it looks like the research should never have been undertaken because the potential harm is so catastrophic and the potential benefits from studying the virus so speculative.'b'Unless the scientific community and health officials can provide more persuasive justifications than they have so far, the new virus, which is in the Netherlands, ought to be destroyed. Barring that, it should be put in a few government-controlled laboratories with the highest containment rating, known as biosafety level 4. That is how the United States and Russia contain samples of smallpox, which poses nowhere near the same danger of global devastation.'b'In the future, it is imperative that any such experiments be rigorously analyzed for potential dangers \xe2\x80\x94 preferably through an international review mechanism, but also by governmental funding agencies \xe2\x80\x94 before they are undertaken, not after the fact as is happening in this case.'b'The most frightening research was done by scientists at the Erasmus Medical Center in Rotterdam, who sought to discover how likely it is that the \xe2\x80\x9cbird flu\xe2\x80\x9d virus, designated A(H5N1), might mutate from a form that seldom infects or spreads among humans into a form highly transmissible by coughing or sneezing. Thus far the virus has infected close to 600 humans and killed more than half of them, a fatality rate that far exceeds the 2 percent rate in the 1918 influenza pandemic that killed as many as 100 million people.'b'Working with ferrets, the animal that is most like humans in responding to influenza, the researchers found that a mere five genetic mutations allowed the virus to spread through the air from one ferret to another while maintaining its lethality. A separate study at the University of Wisconsin, about which little is known publicly, produced a virus that is thought to be less virulent.'b'These findings led to an unprecedented request from an American federal advisory board that the researchers and the two scientific journals that plan to publish the studies omit any details that might help terrorists figure out how to unleash a devastating pandemic. That presumably includes details on how the engineered virus was made and details on the precise mutations that allowed it to go airborne.'b'We doubt that anything at all should be published, but it seems clear that something will be.'b'The two journals reviewing the papers seem inclined to follow the advisory board\xe2\x80\x99s recommendations that the research be published in a redacted form, provided there is some way for researchers who need the information to gain access to the full details. The Erasmus team believes that more than 100 laboratories and perhaps 1,000 scientists around the world need to know the precise mutations to look for. That would spread the information far too widely. It should suffice to have a few of the most sophisticated laboratories do the analyses.'b'Defenders of the research in Rotterdam claim it will provide two major benefits for protecting global health. First, they say the findings could prove helpful in monitoring virus samples from infected birds and animals. If genetic analysis found a virus somewhere that was only one or two mutations away from going airborne, public health officials would then know to bear down aggressively in that area to limit human contact with infected poultry and ramp up supplies of vaccines and medicines.'b'But it is highly uncertain, even improbable, that the virus would mutate in nature along the pathways prodded in a laboratory environment, so the benefit of looking for these five mutations seems marginal.'b'A second postulated benefit is that the engineered virus can be used to test whether existing antiviral drugs and vaccines would be effective against it and, if they come up short, design new drugs and vaccines that can neutralize it. But genetic changes that affect transmissibility do not necessarily change the properties that make a virus susceptible to drugs or to the antibodies produced by a vaccine, so that approach may not yield much useful new information.'b'We cannot say there would be no benefits at all from studying the virus. We respect the researchers\xe2\x80\x99 desire to protect public health. But the consequences, should the virus escape, are too devastating to risk.'b'PERHAPS the most widespread peril children face isn\xe2\x80\x99t guns, swimming pools or speeding cars. Rather, scientists are suggesting that it may be \xe2\x80\x9ctoxic stress\xe2\x80\x9d early in life, or even before birth.'b'This month, the American Academy of Pediatrics is issuing a landmark warning that this toxic stress can harm children for life. I\xe2\x80\x99m as skeptical as anyone of headlines from new medical studies (Coffee is good for you! Coffee is bad for you!), but that\xe2\x80\x99s not what this is.'b'Rather, this is a \xe2\x80\x9c'b'policy statement'b'\xe2\x80\x9d from the premier association of pediatricians, based on two decades of scientific research. This has revolutionary implications for medicine and for how we can more effectively chip away at poverty and crime.'b'Toxic stress might arise from parental abuse of alcohol or drugs. It could occur in a home where children are threatened and beaten. It might derive from chronic neglect \xe2\x80\x94 a child cries without being cuddled. Affection seems to defuse toxic stress \xe2\x80\x94 keep those hugs and lullabies coming! \xe2\x80\x94 suggesting that the stress emerges when a child senses persistent threats but no protector.'b'Cues of a hostile or indifferent environment flood an infant, or even a fetus, with stress hormones like cortisol in ways that can disrupt the body\xe2\x80\x99s metabolism or the architecture of the brain.'b'The upshot is that children are sometimes permanently undermined. Even many years later, as adults, they are 'b'more likely to suffer'b' heart disease, obesity, diabetes and other physical ailments. They are also more likely to struggle in school, have short tempers and tangle with the law.'b'The crucial period seems to be from conception through early childhood. After that, the brain is less pliable and has trouble being remolded.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYou can modify behavior later, but you can\xe2\x80\x99t rewire disrupted brain circuits,\xe2\x80\x9d notes Jack P. Shonkoff, a Harvard pediatrician who has been a leader in this field. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re beginning to get a pretty compelling biological model of why kids who have experienced adversity have trouble learning.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This new research addresses an uncomfortable truth: Poverty is difficult to overcome partly because of self-destructive behaviors. Children from poor homes often shine, but others may skip school, abuse narcotics, break the law, and have trouble settling down in a marriage and a job. Then their children may replicate this pattern.'b'Liberals sometimes ignore these self-destructive pathologies. Conservatives sometimes rely on them to blame poverty on the poor.'b'The research suggests that the roots of impairment and underachievement are biologically embedded, but preventable. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is the biology of social class disparities,\xe2\x80\x9d Dr. Shonkoff said. \xe2\x80\x9cEarly experiences are literally built into our bodies.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The implication is that the most cost-effective window to bring about change isn\xe2\x80\x99t high school or even kindergarten \xe2\x80\x94 although much greater efforts are needed in schools as well \xe2\x80\x94 but in the early years of life, or even before birth.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cProtecting young children from adversity is a promising, science-based strategy to address many of the most persistent and costly problems facing contemporary society, including limited educational achievement, diminished economic productivity, criminality, and disparities in health,\xe2\x80\x9d the pediatrics academy said in its policy statement.'b'One successful example of early intervention is home visitation by childcare experts, like those from the 'b'Nurse-Family Partnership'b'. This organization sends nurses to visit poor, vulnerable women who are pregnant for the first time. The nurse warns against smoking and alcohol and drug abuse, and later encourages breast-feeding and good nutrition, while coaxing mothers to cuddle their children and read to them. This program continues until the child is 2.'b'At age 6, studies have found, these children are only one-third as likely to have behavioral or intellectual problems as others who weren\xe2\x80\x99t enrolled. At age 15, the children are less than half as likely to have been arrested.'b'Evidence of the importance of early experiences has been mounting like snowflakes in a blizzard. For example, several studies examined Dutch men and women who had been in utero during a brief famine at the end of World War II. Decades later, those \xe2\x80\x9cfamine babies\xe2\x80\x9d had 'b'more trouble concentrating'b' and more heart disease than those born before or after.'b'Other scholars examined children who had been badly neglected in Romanian orphanages. Those who spent more time in the orphanages 'b'had shorter telomeres'b', a change in chromosomes that\xe2\x80\x99s a marker of accelerated aging. Their brain scans also looked different.'b'The science is still accumulating. But a compelling message from biology is that if we want to chip away at poverty and improve educational and health outcomes, we have to start earlier. For many children, damage has been suffered before the first day of school.'b'As Frederick Douglass noted, \xe2\x80\x9cIt is easier to build strong children than to repair broken men.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'MANCHESTER, N.H.'b'RICK SANTORUM was locking down the youth vote.'b'The man who fondly recalls nuns rapping his knuckles with rulers did some verbal knuckle-rapping of his own on Thursday with students at a forum in Concord hosted by New England College.'b'Not satisfied with mentioning homosexuality in the same breath as bestiality and pedophilia, as he did in 2003, Santorum tried to win over the kids by equating homosexuality with polygamy.'b'Even for Santorum, it was a masterpiece of antediluvian abrasiveness \xe2\x80\x94 slapping gays and Mormons at the same time.'b'When 17-year-old Rhiannon Pyle, visiting with her civics class from Newburyport, Mass., pressed Santorum on how he could believe that all men are created equal and still object to two men in love marrying, he began nonsensically frothing.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSo if everybody has the right to be happy, so if you\xe2\x80\x99re not happy unless you\xe2\x80\x99re married to five other people, is that O.K.?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, adding, \xe2\x80\x9cWell, what about three men?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The grating Santorum was their worst nightmare of a bad teacher. Until then, I am just taking notes.'b'Nice, France'b'ON Wednesday, America\xe2\x80\x99s detention camp at Guant\xc3\xa1namo Bay will have been open for 10 years. For seven of them, I was held there without explanation or charge. During that time my daughters grew up without me. They were toddlers when I was imprisoned, and were never allowed to visit or speak to me by phone. Most of their letters were returned as \xe2\x80\x9cundeliverable,\xe2\x80\x9d and the few that I received were so thoroughly and thoughtlessly censored that their messages of love and support were lost.'b'Some American politicians say that people at Guant\xc3\xa1namo are terrorists, but I have never been a terrorist. Had I been brought before a court when I was seized, my children\xe2\x80\x99s lives would not have been torn apart, and my family would not have been thrown into poverty. It was only after the United States Supreme Court 'b'ordered the government'b' to defend its actions before a federal judge that I was finally able to clear my name and be with them again.'b'I left Algeria in 1990 to work abroad. In 1997 my family and I moved to Bosnia and Herzegovina at the request of my employer, the Red Crescent Society of the United Arab Emirates. I served in the Sarajevo office as director of humanitarian aid for children who had lost relatives to violence during the Balkan conflicts. In 1998, I became a Bosnian citizen. We had a good life, but all of that changed after 9/11.'b'When I arrived at work on the morning of Oct. 19, 2001, an intelligence officer was waiting for me. He asked me to accompany him to answer questions. I did so, voluntarily \xe2\x80\x94 but afterward I was told that I could not go home. The United States had demanded that local authorities arrest me and five other men. News reports at the time said the United States believed that I was plotting to blow up its embassy in Sarajevo. I had never \xe2\x80\x94 for a second \xe2\x80\x94 considered this.'b'The fact that the United States had made a mistake was clear from the beginning. Bosnia\xe2\x80\x99s highest court investigated the American claim, found that there was no evidence against me and ordered my release. But instead, the moment I was released American agents seized me and the five others. We were tied up like animals and flown to Guant\xc3\xa1namo, the American naval base in Cuba. I arrived on Jan. 20, 2002.'b'I still had faith in American justice. I believed my captors would quickly realize their mistake and let me go. But when I would not give the interrogators the answers they wanted \xe2\x80\x94 how could I, when I had done nothing wrong? \xe2\x80\x94 they became more and more brutal. I was kept awake for many days straight. I was forced to remain in painful positions for hours at a time. These are things I do not want to write about; I want only to forget.'b'I went on a hunger strike for two years because no one would tell me why I was being imprisoned. Twice each day my captors would shove a tube up my nose, down my throat and into my stomach so they could pour food into me. It was excruciating, but I was innocent and so I kept up my protest.'b'In 2008, my demand for a fair legal process went all the way to America\xe2\x80\x99s highest court. In a 'b'decision'b' that bears my name, the Supreme Court declared that \xe2\x80\x9cthe laws and Constitution are designed to survive, and remain in force, in extraordinary times.\xe2\x80\x9d It ruled that prisoners like me, no matter how serious the accusations, have a right to a day in court. The Supreme Court recognized a basic truth: the government makes mistakes. And the court said that because \xe2\x80\x9cthe consequence of error may be detention of persons for the duration of hostilities that may last a generation or more, this is a risk too significant to ignore.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Five months later, Judge Richard J. Leon, of the Federal District Court in Washington, reviewed all of the reasons offered to justify my imprisonment, including secret information I never saw or heard. The government abandoned its claim of an embassy bomb plot just before the judge could hear it. After the hearing, he 'b'ordered the government'b' to free me and four other men who had been arrested in Bosnia.'b'I will never forget sitting with the four other men in a squalid room at Guant\xc3\xa1namo, listening over a fuzzy speaker as Judge Leon read his decision in a Washington courtroom. He implored the government not to appeal his ruling, because \xe2\x80\x9cseven years of waiting for our legal system to give them an answer to a question so important is, in my judgment, more than plenty.\xe2\x80\x9d I was freed, at last, on May 15, 2009.'b'Today, I live in Provence with my wife and children. France has given us a home, and a new start. I have experienced the pleasure of reacquainting myself with my daughters and, in August 2010, the joy of welcoming a new son, Yousef. I am learning to drive, attending vocational training and rebuilding my life. I hope to work again serving others, but so far the fact that I spent seven and a half years as a Guant\xc3\xa1namo prisoner has meant that only a few human rights organizations have seriously considered hiring me. I do not like to think of Guant\xc3\xa1namo. The memories are filled with pain. But I share my story because 171 men remain there. Among them is Belkacem Bensayah, who was seized in Bosnia and sent to Guant\xc3\xa1namo with me.'b'About 90 prisoners have been cleared for transfer out of Guant\xc3\xa1namo. And so they sit as captives, with no end in sight \xe2\x80\x94 not because they are dangerous, not because they attacked America, but because the stigma of Guant\xc3\xa1namo means they have no place to go, and America will not give a home to even one of them.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99m told that my Supreme Court case is now read in law schools. Perhaps one day that will give me satisfaction, but so long as Guant\xc3\xa1namo stays open and innocent men remain there, my thoughts will be with those left behind in that place of suffering and injustice.'b'IN the five days since his almost-victory in the Iowa caucuses, Rick Santorum\xe2\x80\x99s critics have tried out an unusual line of attack against the former Pennsylvania senator. This is the second consecutive election cycle in which a Republican politician has endured a bizarre obstetrics-related controversy; last time, we had the various conspiracy theories surrounding Sarah Palin\xe2\x80\x99s pregnancy and her Down syndrome son.'b'In a sense, one could say that these kinds of invasive debates become inevitable once the traditional zone of privacy around public figures collapses. But it would be more accurate to say that the zone of privacy has collapsed precisely because of the deep moral divisions that these kinds of controversies reveal.'b'Privacy is a luxury of moral consensus. Nobody would have thought to politicize the premature birth and death of John F. Kennedy\xe2\x80\x99s son Patrick, because abortion wasn\xe2\x80\x99t a polarizing issue in the America of 1963. But if a white politician in the Jim Crow South had married a black woman, the relationship would inevitably have been seen as a political gesture as well a personal decision.'b'Today, we are less divided over race, but more divided over sex and reproduction. In a country that cannot agree whether fetuses are human beings, even questions like how to mourn and bury a miscarried child are inevitably freighted with ideological significance. Likewise, in a country where the majority of Down syndrome fetuses are aborted, the mere act of carrying a child with a genetic disorder to term \xe2\x80\x94 as both the Palins and the Santorums, whose daughter Bella has Trisomy 18, have done \xe2\x80\x94 feels like a political statement.'b'The same pattern holds with respect to politicians and their marriage vows. In an era that had a clear and stable understanding of marriage, it was easier to treat politicians\xe2\x80\x99 adulteries as a private matter between a husband and a wife. But hypocrisy is the tribute that vice pays to virtue, and a society that can\xe2\x80\x99t agree on the definition of sexual virtue inevitably takes a stronger interest in whether a politician actually lives up to the definition of marriage he defends.'b'When Palin wove special needs children into her 2008 speeches, or when Santorum featured his daughter Bella in a campaign 'b'video'b', they were implicitly acknowledging these personal-is-political realities. So should Washington.'b'Along with their shameful campaign to curb the collective bargaining rights of public sector workers in Wisconsin and Ohio last year, Republicans in statehouses around the country are taking aim at private sector unions.'b'Twenty-two states, mainly in the South and the West, have long had \xe2\x80\x9cright to work\xe2\x80\x9d laws forbidding contracts that require workers to pay union dues. After a decade in which business has ignored the issue, Republicans in 'b'more than 10 states'b' over the last year have begun pushing similar laws. Indiana\xe2\x80\x99s Legislature is expected to approve the antiunion legislation as early as next month.'b'Many Republican leaders are adopting model legislation proposed by the American Legislative Exchange Council, a national corporate-financed conservative organization that is also assisting the Republican push to require voter identification cards to suppress the vote of minorities, young people and other constituencies that tend to favor the Democratic Party.'b'There is little doubt that politics is also behind the Republicans\xe2\x80\x99 push for right-to-work laws: they see an opportunity to further weaken unions, which are far more likely to support Democrats \xe2\x80\x94 as well as health care reform and a higher minimum wage \xe2\x80\x94 by slashing their funding and their donating power.'b'The G.O.P. and its allies, like the Chamber of Commerce and brethren organizations, are trotting out the charge that unions reduce economic growth and jobs.'b'It stands to reason that a union will reduce a company\xe2\x80\x99s profits somewhat, by obtaining a higher share for workers. But over the last three decades, economists have found that unionization has a minimal impact on growth and employment in an entire state or country. In fact, six of the 10 states with the highest unemployment have right-to-work laws. North Carolina, a right-to-work state, has a private sector unionization rate of 1.8 percent, the lowest in the nation. It also has the 'b'sixth highest'b' unemployment rate: 10 percent.'b'Unionized workers earn more and get more generous benefits. In 2010, wages of workers in unionized manufacturing companies in Indiana were 16 percent higher than in nonunion plants. 'b'One study'b' concluded that the decline in unionization since the 1970s is responsible for one-fifth to one-third of the growth in inequality in this country. Voters, unionized or not, should recognize the new \xe2\x80\x9cright to work\xe2\x80\x9d push for what it is: bad economics and cynical politics.'b'Blacksburg, Va.'b'IN the wake of widespread violence during the New York City blackout of 1977, a newspaper columnist quipped that just one flick of a light switch separated civilization from primordial chaos.'b'Leaving the hyperbole aside, artificial illumination has arguably been the greatest symbol of modern progress. By making nighttime infinitely more inviting, street lighting \xe2\x80\x94 gas lamps beginning in the early 1800s followed by electric lights toward the end of the century \xe2\x80\x94 drastically expanded the boundaries of everyday life to include hours once shrouded in darkness. Today, any number of metropolitan areas in the United States and abroad, bathed in the glare of neon and mercury vapor, bill themselves as 24-hour cities, open both for business and pleasure.'b'So it is all the more remarkable that, in what appears to be a spreading trend, dozens of cities and towns across America \xe2\x80\x94 from California and Oregon to Maine \xe2\x80\x94 are contemplating significantly reducing the number of street lamps to lower their hefty electric bills. In some communities, utility companies have already torn posts from the ground. Faced with several million dollars in unpaid bills, Highland Park, Mich., has lost two-thirds of its lamps, whereas officials in Rockford, Ill., have extinguished as many as 2,300, or 16 percent of all the city\xe2\x80\x99s streetlights.'b'Municipal officials, mindful of the winter darkness enveloping residential neighborhoods, have vainly tried to relieve public anxiety. Denials that crime rates will rise are met with skepticism by the public, as are programs to encourage homeowners to install private security lamps or to \xe2\x80\x9cadopt a light\xe2\x80\x9d for a monthly fee. Street lighting is now at risk of being restricted, as it was in earlier ages, to residences and neighborhoods able to afford it.'b'To be sure, night, our oldest terror, no longer poses the perils, both real and imaginary, that it once did. Before the Industrial Revolution, darkness conjured the worst properties in man, nature and the cosmos \xe2\x80\x94 brigands, witches and rapacious beasts were thought to lurk everywhere. \xe2\x80\x9cThe night is no man\xe2\x80\x99s friend,\xe2\x80\x9d warned a French adage.'b'Our ancestors coped by relying upon locks, weapons and prayer. Dogs were also highly prized \xe2\x80\x94 ones, in the words of a 16th-century writer, that were \xe2\x80\x9cbig, hairy, with a big head, big legs, big loins and a lot of courage.\xe2\x80\x9d When treading outdoors, ordinary folk displayed a rough-hewn resourcefulness \xe2\x80\x94 traveling by moonlight in small parties, wearing light-colored clothing and avoiding the dead of night (midnight to 3 a.m.), when demons freely prowled. Beginning at an early age, individuals committed to memory an intimate map of their environs, including every ditch, pond and graveyard (a favorite haunt of ghosts).'b'Darkness, however, was not inevitably a source of foreboding, affording instead unparalleled privacy and personal freedom. Opportunities for behavior forbidden by church and state expanded and intensified. As a consequence, early street lamps provoked sporadic complaints. Emerson observed, \xe2\x80\x9cAs gas-light is found to be the best nocturnal police, so the universe protects itself by pitiless publicity.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But there was never any question that 19th-century communities welcomed lamps, which in conjunction with police forces, posed a powerful deterrent to lawlessness. Another benefit lay in the numerous pedestrians drawn by their inviting glow, whose very presence helped to discourage crime.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAs safe and agreeable to walk out in the evening as by day-light,\xe2\x80\x9d pronounced a New Yorker in 1853.'b'Certainly, public anxiety over the recent removal of lamps should not be minimized. No longer are there witches and wolves to fear, but research strongly suggests, as one might expect, the critical value of street lighting as a hindrance to crime and serious accidents. (One reason for the full-scale removal of the metal posts in Highland Park was a fear that they might be stolen.)'b'Indeed, efforts to eliminate street lighting represent a rare instance in modern history in which a technology of longstanding benefit has been restricted, if not completely discarded.'b'Although some environmentalists with legitimate concerns about light pollution might welcome their removal, a preferable solution, as most recognize, lies in the utilization of lamps whose light, rather than being diffused into the atmosphere, is concentrated downward to the benefit of motorists and pedestrians. Lamps equipped with solar panels or photocell timers offer alternatives that a few communities are exploring to cut costs. After citizens of Concord, Mass., recently rebelled over the threatened loss of more than 500 lamp posts, the town retrofitted 8,200, rendering them more energy efficient and \xe2\x80\x9cdark-sky friendly\xe2\x80\x9d at a projected annual savings of nearly $300,000.'b'Financial costs and public safety, however, are not the only issues. Without the benefit of street lighting, towns and cities, after sunset, will be diminished as communities. Families will be more apt to \xe2\x80\x9ccocoon\xe2\x80\x9d at home, rather than visit friends or attend sporting and cultural events. And, too, our appreciation for night itself will suffer. Evenings can be best enjoyed if they remain inviting and safe, whether for neighborhood gatherings, walking Fido or gazing at the heavens \xe2\x80\x94 all with less chance of losing your wallet or stumbling into a ditch.'b'AS public editor, I begin the New Year with a growing appreciation for the challenge The New York Times faces in maintaining its leadership in American journalism. I want to revisit five issues here, all requiring keen judgment on the part of the paper.'b''b'The presidential campaign:'b' For Times journalists and their peers elsewhere, this quadrennial event is an adrenaline rush that requires sober oversight by senior editors to ensure that balance, fairness and accuracy survive the scramble to compete.'b''b'In a Dec. 4 column,'b' I wrote about journalists\xe2\x80\x99 reflex to impose their own narrative on a race, a dynamic that can eclipse what candidates are actually saying. Nisenholtz; 'b'the $143 million sale of its regional newspaper group'b'; and 'b'a sharp 25 percent increase'b' in the retail price of the Monday-Saturday paper.'b'But what really makes reporting on itself imperative is that The Times so aggressively covers its peers. It is important to hold the line against publishing such anonymous attacks.'b''b'The European debt crisis:'b' Last August, 'b'I said the paper\xe2\x80\x99s hefty investment'b' in the Wall Street-centric DealBook blog would have been better allocated to covering the devastating developments in the euro zone. In some articles, the emphasis is on the huge economic potential; in others, the focus is on the environmental threat posed by the drilling process known as fracking. The coverage seems fragmented and at times contradictory. What\xe2\x80\x99s the big picture?'b''b'Dean Baquet,'b' the managing editor, told me The Times \xe2\x80\x9ccould probably better coordinate on the issue\xe2\x80\x9d in 2012 and should have an editor to \xe2\x80\x9cmake sure everybody knows what everybody else is doing.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'Drone wars and beyond:'b' Kudos to The Times here. 'b'I urged the paper last year'b' to press the Obama administration to reveal the legal rationale for targeted drone attacks, particularly in the case of 'b'Anwar al-Awlaki, an American citizen killed'b' in Yemen.'b''b'On Dec. 20, the newspaper sued to force the Justice Department to disclose its reasoning.'b' This was a worthy step, demonstrating Times leadership and the indispensable role of a free press. And it comes at a time when technology is simultaneously transforming the secret conduct of war, not to mention the landscape where The Times must compete to survive.'b'Bremen, Germany'b'I LEFT 'b'Guant\xc3\xa1namo Bay'b' much as I had arrived almost five years earlier \xe2\x80\x94 shackled hand-to-waist, waist-to-ankles, and ankles to a bolt on the airplane floor. My ears and eyes were goggled, my head hooded, and even though I was the only detainee on the flight this time, I was drugged and guarded by at least 10 soldiers. This time though, my jumpsuit was American denim rather than Guant\xc3\xa1namo orange. I later learned that my C-17 military flight from Guant\xc3\xa1namo to Ramstein Air Base in my home country, Germany, cost more than $1 million.'b'When we landed, the American officers unshackled me before they handed me over to a delegation of German officials. The American officer offered to re-shackle my wrists with a fresh, plastic pair. But the commanding German officer strongly refused: \xe2\x80\x9cHe has committed no crime; here, he is a free man.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'I was not a strong secondary school student in Bremen, but I remember learning that after 'b'World War II'b', the Americans insisted on a trial for war criminals at Nuremberg, and that event helped turn Germany into a democratic country. Strange, I thought, as I stood on the tarmac watching the Germans teach the Americans a basic lesson about the rule of law.'b'How did I arrive at this point? This Wednesday is the 10th anniversary of the opening of the detention camp at the American naval base at Guant\xc3\xa1namo Bay, Cuba. I am not a terrorist. I have never been a member of 'b'Al Qaeda'b' or supported them. I don\xe2\x80\x99t even understand their ideas. I am the son of Turkish immigrants who came to Germany in search of work. My father has worked for years in a Mercedes factory. In 2001, when I was 18, I married a devout Turkish woman and wanted to learn more about Islam and to lead a better life. I did not have much money. Some of the elders in my town suggested I travel to Pakistan to learn to study the Koran with a religious group there.'b'I made my plans just before 9/11. I was 19 then and was na\xc3\xafve and did not think war in Afghanistan would have anything to do with Pakistan or my trip there. So I went ahead with my trip.'b'I was in Pakistan, on a public bus on my way to the airport to return to Germany when the police stopped the bus I was riding in. I was the only non-Pakistani on the bus \xe2\x80\x94 some people joke that my reddish hair makes me look Irish \xe2\x80\x94 so the police asked me to step off to look at my papers and ask some questions. German journalists told me the same thing happened to them. I was not a journalist, but a tourist, I explained. The police detained me but promised they would soon let me go to the airport. After a few days, the Pakistanis turned me over to American officials. At this point, I was relieved to be in American hands; Americans, I thought, would treat me fairly.'b'I later learned the United States paid a $3,000 bounty for me. I didn\xe2\x80\x99t know it at the time, but apparently the United States distributed thousands of fliers all over Afghanistan, promising that people who turned over 'b'Taliban'b' or Qaeda suspects would, in the words of one flier, get \xe2\x80\x9cenough money to take care of your family, your village, your tribe for the rest of your life.\xe2\x80\x9d A great number of men wound up in Guant\xc3\xa1namo as a result.'b'I was taken to Kandahar, in Afghanistan, where American interrogators asked me the same questions for several weeks: Where is Osama bin Laden? Was I with Al Qaeda? No, I told them, I was not with Al Qaeda. No, I had no idea where bin Laden was. I begged the interrogators to please call Germany and find out who I was. During their interrogations, they dunked my head under water and punched me in the stomach; they don\xe2\x80\x99t call this 'b'waterboarding'b' but it amounts to the same thing. I was sure I would drown.'b'At one point, I was chained to the ceiling of a building and hung by my hands for days. A doctor sometimes checked if I was O.K.; then I would be strung up again. The pain was unbearable.'b'After about two months in Kandahar, I was transferred to Guant\xc3\xa1namo. There were more beatings, endless solitary confinement, freezing temperatures and extreme heat, days of forced sleeplessness. The interrogations continued always with the same questions. I told my story over and over \xe2\x80\x94 my name, my family, why I was in Pakistan. Nothing I said satisfied them. I realized my interrogators were not interested in the truth.'b'Despite all this, I looked for ways to feel human. I have always loved animals. I started hiding a piece of bread from my meals and feeding the iguanas that came to the fence. When officials discovered this, I was punished with 30 days in isolation and darkness.'b'I remained confused on basic questions: why was I here? With all its money and intelligence, the United States could not honestly believe I was Al Qaeda, could they?'b'After two and a half years at Guant\xc3\xa1namo, in 2004, I was brought before what officials called a Combatant Status Review Tribunal, at which a military officer said I was an \xe2\x80\x9cenemy combatant\xe2\x80\x9d because a German friend had engaged in a suicide bombing in 2003 \xe2\x80\x94 after I was already at Guant\xc3\xa1namo. I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t believe my friend had done anything so crazy but, if he had, I didn\xe2\x80\x99t know anything about it.'b'A couple of weeks later, I was told I had a visit from a lawyer. They took me to a special cell and in walked an American law professor, 'b'Baher Azmy'b'. I didn\xe2\x80\x99t believe he was a real lawyer at first; interrogators often lied to us and tried to trick us. But Mr. Azmy had a note written in Turkish which he had gotten from my mother, and that made me trust him. (My mother found a lawyer in my hometown in Germany who heard that lawyers at the Center for Constitutional Rights represented Guant\xc3\xa1namo detainees; the center assigned Mr. Azmy my case.) He did not believe the evidence against me and quickly discovered that my \xe2\x80\x9csuicide bomber\xe2\x80\x9d friend was, in fact, alive and well in Germany.'b'Mr. Azmy, my mother and my German lawyer helped pressure the German government to secure my release. Recently, Mr. Azmy made public a number of American and German intelligence documents from 2002 to 2004 that showed both countries suspected I was innocent. One of the documents said American military guards thought I was dangerous because I had prayed during the American national anthem.'b'Now, five years after my release, I am trying to put my terrible memories behind me. I have remarried and have a beautiful baby daughter. Still, it is hard not to think about my time at Guant\xc3\xa1namo and to wonder how it is possible that a democratic government can detain people in intolerable conditions and without a fair trial.'b'A REVOLUTION in cognitive neuroscience is changing the kinds of experiments that scientists conduct, the kinds of questions economists ask and, increasingly, the ways that architects, landscape architects and urban designers shape our built environment.'b'This revolution reveals that thought is less transparent to the thinker than it appears and that the mind is less rational than we believe and more associative than we know. Many of the associations we make emerge from the fact that we live inside bodies, in a concrete world, and we tend to think in metaphors grounded in that embodiment.'b'This metaphorical, embodied quality shapes how we relate to abstract concepts, emotions and human activity. Across cultures, \xe2\x80\x9cimportant\xe2\x80\x9d is big and \xe2\x80\x9cunimportant\xe2\x80\x9d is small, just as your caretakers were once much larger than you. Sometimes your head is \xe2\x80\x9cin the clouds.\xe2\x80\x9d You approach a task \xe2\x80\x9cstep by step.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Some architects are catching on to human cognition\xe2\x80\x99s embodied nature. A few are especially intrigued by metaphors that express bodily experience in the world.'b'Take the visual metaphor of a tree as shelter. Most people live around, use and look at trees. Children climb them. People gather under them. Nearly everyone at some point uses one to escape the sun.'b'Recently, architects have deployed tree metaphors in many different settings. At the 'b'Kanagawa Institute of Technology'b' in Japan, Junya Ishigami created an elegant \xe2\x80\x9cforest\xe2\x80\x9d out of slender, white-enameled metal saplings that congregate in clusters and open into clearings of vocational work spaces. In Seville, Spain, a German architect, J\xc3\xbcrgen Mayer H., gave definition and shade to the city\xe2\x80\x99s Plaza de la Encarnaci\xc3\xb3n with his 'b'Metropol Parasol'b', a lilting, waffled construction of laminated timber.'b'Such projects follow earlier, very different tree-inspired buildings, like Toyo Ito\xe2\x80\x99s well-known 'b'Tod\xe2\x80\x99s'b', a retail store in Tokyo, and the 'b'Mediath\xc3\xa8que media library'b', an exhibition space and cinema in Sendai, Japan, which is so well supported by irregular, hollowed-out, sinuous \xe2\x80\x9ctrunks\xe2\x80\x9d (housing elevators and staircases) that it survived the enormous earthquake last March.'b'Why should tree metaphors appeal to architects? Why should they be useful, even good, for people? In the Seville project, tree imagery helps construct a distinctive public place that offers shelter and areas to congregate. As under spreading trees, the boundaries defining these spaces are permeable; easy to enter and exit, they offer nature\xe2\x80\x99s spatial freedom yet help people to feel more firmly rooted where they are. And tree metaphors, deployed architecturally, simultaneously lament nature\xe2\x80\x99s absence and symbolically insert its presence.'b'Tree metaphors also refer to the experience of living in a body on earth. Trees are static, stable objects. Someone connected to a community is \xe2\x80\x9crooted\xe2\x80\x9d there; a psychologically sturdy friend\xe2\x80\x99s feet are firmly \xe2\x80\x9cplanted\xe2\x80\x9d on the ground. We use trees to describe human bodies and souls: the area from our neck to pelvis is our \xe2\x80\x9ctrunk\xe2\x80\x9d; someone reliable is \xe2\x80\x9csolid as an oak\xe2\x80\x9d; someone exploring a new area of inquiry is \xe2\x80\x9cbranching out.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Buildings aren\xe2\x80\x99t nature, of course. Tree metaphors like the branching-out facade of Mr. Ito\xe2\x80\x99s Tod\xe2\x80\x99s surprise people. But because the surprise comes along with the implied reassurance of structural integrity (they\xe2\x80\x99re trees, after all), it prompts us to focus on the built environment, perhaps to reconsider its role in our everyday lives.'b'Architects may also like tree metaphors because a tree\xe2\x80\x99s overall structure is regular, while its fine-grained composition, its tangles of branches, are irregular, an arrangement conducive to the kind of design experimentation offered by new digital technologies.'b'But the design opportunities that tree metaphors present fail to explain their appearance in such a diverse range of buildings. Trees are familiar. Tree metaphors allow for an architectural inventiveness that stretches people without estranging them.'b'Trees are just one of the growing number of embodied metaphors used in contemporary architecture: Zaha Hadid builds 'b'riverlike spaces'b', while the Japanese firm Sanaa offers up a habitable mountainscape of a 'b'student center'b' at the \xc3\x89cole Polytechnique F\xc3\xa9d\xc3\xa9rale in Lausanne, Switzerland.'b'How many designers are clued in to the ongoing cognitive revolution and its potential for the built environment is unclear. But this collection of architects and projects herald more than just another stylistic or pyrotechnic, technology-driven trend. They point toward how the built environment could \xe2\x80\x94 and should \xe2\x80\x94 be radically reconceptualized around the fundamental workings of the human mind. We need, and are ever more in a position to create, a richer built environment, grounded in the way people actually experience the world around them.'b'Pusan, South Korea'b''b'KIM JONG-UN'b' can count himself lucky that his first birthday in power falls today, on a Sunday, obviating the need for a new national holiday to be created at an awkward time. But the ease with which the new \xe2\x80\x9csupreme leader\xe2\x80\x9d has taken over 'b'North Korea'b' has little to do with luck. For one thing, the propaganda apparatus did its job well. We now know why Kim Jong-un was such a peripheral figure on the evening news until his father\xe2\x80\x99s death: so that North Koreans\xe2\x80\x99 first long look at the pampered young man would be at the rarest of times \xe2\x80\x94 a time when he was suffering more than anyone.'b'More important, though, is the fact that his succession makes perfect sense in North Korea\xe2\x80\x99s ethno-nationalist personality cult. People who value racial purity always consider some bloodlines purer than others, and in \xe2\x80\x9cthe Kim Il-sung race,\xe2\x80\x9d as North Koreans call themselves, no bloodline is purer than the eternal president\xe2\x80\x99s. Kim Jong-un\xe2\x80\x99s increasingly obvious efforts to copy his revered grandfather\xe2\x80\x99s appearance and mannerisms (right down to his'b' signature'b') are naturally meant to show that \xe2\x80\x94 as a Korean saying goes \xe2\x80\x94 blood doesn\xe2\x80\x99t lie.'b'Membership in the great family is also thought to provide greater access to the elders\xe2\x80\x99 wisdom. This makes the time Kim Jong-un spent away in a Swiss school especially problematic, but the propaganda apparatus may be planning to ignore that part of his life altogether. (The latest reports suggest that he is now being credited with having written, at the age of 16, a treatise on his grandfather\xe2\x80\x99s thought, presumably while in Pyongyang, the capital.) In any case, the notion that army generals or any other important faction would object to Kim Jong-un\xe2\x80\x99s takeover was an improbable one to begin with; no North Korean could oppose the hereditary succession without being opposed to the state itself. Such an attitude is unlikely to be held by anyone in the ruling elite.'b'Unfortunately, the West seems determined to continue paying as little attention to North Korean ideology as possible. In the past few weeks the country\xe2\x80\x99s propaganda has been quoted more for comic relief than anything else. (A few over-literal readings of its flowery imagery have made it seem even more bizarre than it is.) Meanwhile the race-thinking pervading the official rhetoric has been ignored, as has the imperial-Japanese provenance of so much of it, like the talk in recent weeks of defending Kim Jong-un with \xe2\x80\x9chuman bombs\xe2\x80\x9d if necessary.'b'Most of the news media around the world continue viewing North Korea as it does not view itself, namely as a Communist state. The result has been a lot of old-school Kremlinological fuss about the power hierarchy. Several reporters have asked for my opinion on whether Kim Jong-un\xe2\x80\x99s main string-puller will be his uncle, Jang Song-taek, or Vice Marshal Ri Yong-ho, though no one has yet been able to explain to me why the question matters. After all, there is no evidence of significant disagreement inside the ruling elite in regard to any issue.'b'By Communist standards, the North Korean masses would have to judge both the government\xe2\x80\x99s economic performance and the succession in the harshest possible terms. It is because they judge them by very different standards that Kim Jong-un was able to take over so effortlessly while promising to budge \xe2\x80\x9cnot an inch\xe2\x80\x9d from his father\xe2\x80\x99s line. We should therefore not make too much of the fraudulence of all that on-screen wailing. Just because North Korean TV never films anything before rehearsing all spontaneity out of it does not mean the average citizen was unmoved. By ultra-nationalist, militarist criteria, which have more to do with North Koreans\xe2\x80\x99 perception of where the country stands in the world than material living conditions, the Dear Leader did a very good job indeed: the Korean Central News Agency may well be correct in saying he made the country virtually impregnable.'b'That very boast, however, makes things harder for 'b'Kim Jong-il'b'\xe2\x80\x99s successor. Though he appears secure inside the elite, the state as a whole must continue showing the masses that it is worthy of its beloved founder. If nuclear armament is to be seen as a closed victorious chapter, the new leader must approach the final tasks in his grandfather\xe2\x80\x99s to-do list, as\xc2\xa0impossible as they may seem from an outsider\xe2\x80\x99s perspective:\xc2\xa0drastic economic growth and national reunification. Perhaps we can discount the rumor \xe2\x80\x94 reported in 2010 \xe2\x80\x94 that internal Workers\xe2\x80\x99 Party memorandums have described unification as a requisite for prosperity, because in the latest official New Year\xe2\x80\x99s editorial, at least, reunification is thought possible in the near future only if the enemy \xe2\x80\x9cdares to infringe upon our dignity and sovereignty.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Even so, there is no reason to assume that the government\xe2\x80\x99s interest in economic matters will reduce tension on the peninsula. Judging from the stale voluntarism espoused in North Korea this month \xe2\x80\x94 the same old calls to emulate this or that heroic factory, to make better use of available resources and so on \xe2\x80\x94 Kim Jong-un will not be advocating any significant reforms. Whether North Korea continues muddling along on Chinese life support, or grows fast enough to start resembling South Korea circa 1980, the military-first government must still justify its separate existence alongside the rival state.'b'How can it do this, except through more displays of military strength and superiority? When the new leadership vaunts its adherence to the old leadership\xe2\x80\x99s policies, it is merely trying to make a virtue out of necessity.'b'Shanghai'b'FROM the outside, China often appears to be a highly centralized monolith. Unlike Europe\xe2\x80\x99s cities, which have been able to preserve a certain identity and cultural distinctiveness despite the homogenizing forces of globalization, most Chinese cities suffer from a drab uniformity.'b'But China is more like Europe than it seems. Indeed, when it comes to economics, China is more a thin political union composed of semiautonomous cities \xe2\x80\x94 some with as many inhabitants as a European country \xe2\x80\x94 than an all-powerful centralized government that uniformly imposes its will on the whole country.'b'And competition among these huge cities is an important reason for China\xe2\x80\x99s economic dynamism. The similar look of China\xe2\x80\x99s megacities masks a rivalry as fierce as that among European countries.'b'China\xe2\x80\x99s urban economic boom began in the late 1970s as an experiment with market reforms in China\xe2\x80\x99s coastal cities. Shenzhen, the first \xe2\x80\x9cspecial economic zone,\xe2\x80\x9d has grown from a small fishing village in 1979 into a booming metropolis of 10 million today. Many other cities, from Guangzhou to Tianjin, soon followed the path of market reforms.'b'Today, cities vie ruthlessly for competitive advantage using tax breaks and other incentives that draw foreign and domestic investors. Smaller cities specialize in particular products, while larger ones flaunt their educational capacity and cultural appeal. It has led to the most rapid urban \xe2\x80\x9ceconomic miracle\xe2\x80\x9d in history.'b'But the \xe2\x80\x9cmiracle\xe2\x80\x9d has had an undesirable side effect: It led to a huge gap between rich and poor, primarily between urban and rural areas. The vast rural population \xe2\x80\x94 54 percent of China\xe2\x80\x99s 1.3 billion people \xe2\x80\x94 is equivalent to the whole population of Europe. And most are stuck in destitute conditions. The main reason is the hukou (household registration) system that limits migration into cities, as well as other policies that have long favored urban over rural development.'b'More competition among cities is essential to eliminate the income gap. Over the past decade the central government has given leeway to different cities to experiment with alternative methods of addressing the urban-rural wealth gap.'b'The most widely discussed experiment is the \xe2\x80\x9cChongqing model,\xe2\x80\x9d headed by Bo Xilai, a party secretary and rising political star. Chongqing, an enormous municipality with a population of 33 million and a land area the size of Austria, is often called China\xe2\x80\x99s biggest city. But in fact 23 million of its inhabitants are registered as farmers. More than 8 million farmers have already migrated to the municipality\xe2\x80\x99s more urban areas to work, with a million per year expected to migrate there over the next decade. Chongqing has responded by embarking on a huge subsidized housing project, designed to eventually house 30 to 40 percent of the city\xe2\x80\x99s population.'b'Chongqing has also improved the lot of farmers by loosening the hukou system. Today, farmers can choose to register as \xe2\x80\x9curban\xe2\x80\x9d and receive equal rights to education, health care and pensions after three years, on the condition that they give up the rural registration and the right to use a small plot of land.'b'While Chongqing\xe2\x80\x99s model is the most influential, there is an alternative. Chengdu, Sichuan\xe2\x80\x99s largest municipality, with a population of 14 million \xe2\x80\x94 half of them rural residents \xe2\x80\x94 is less heavy-handed. It is the only city in China to enjoy high economic growth while also reducing the income gap between urban and rural residents over the past decade.'b'Chengdu has focused on improving the surrounding countryside, rather than encouraging large-scale migration to the city. The government has shifted 30 percent of its resources to its rural areas and encouraged development zones that allow rural residents to earn higher salaries and to reap the educational, cultural and medical benefits of urban life.'b'I recently visited a development zone composed of small firms that export fiery Sichuan chili sauces. Most farmers rented their land and worked in the development zone, but those who wanted to stay on their plots were allowed to. So far, one-third of the area\xe2\x80\x99s farmland has been converted into larger-scale agricultural operations that have increased efficiency.'b'More than 90 percent of the municipality\xe2\x80\x99s rural residents are now covered by a medical plan, and the government has introduced a more comprehensive pension scheme. Rural schools have been upgraded to the point that their facilities now surpass those in some of Chengdu\xe2\x80\x99s urban schools, and teachers from rural areas are sent to the city for training.'b'Empowering rural residents by providing more job opportunities and better welfare raises their purchasing power, helping China boost domestic consumption. And in 2012, Chengdu is likely to become the first big Chinese municipality to wipe out the legal distinction between its urban and rural residents, allowing rural people to move to the city if they choose.'b'Chengdu\xe2\x80\x99s success has been driven by a comprehensive, long-term effort involving consultation and participation from the bottom up, as well as a clear property rights scheme. By contrast, Chongqing has relied on state power and the dislocation of millions to achieve similar results. If Chengdu\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cgentle\xe2\x80\x9d model proves to be more effective at reducing the income gap, it can set a model for the rest of the country, just as Shenzhen set a model for market reforms.'b'There are fundamental differences, of course: Chengdu\xe2\x80\x99s land is more fertile and its weather more temperate, compared to Chongqing\xe2\x80\x99s harsh terrain and sweltering summers. Life is slower in Chengdu; even the chili is milder. What succeeds in one place may fail elsewhere.'b'Ultimately, the central government will decide what works and what doesn\xe2\x80\x99t. And that\xe2\x80\x99s not a bad thing; it encourages local variation and internal competition.'b'European leaders ought to take note. Central authorities should have the power not just to punish \xe2\x80\x9closers\xe2\x80\x9d as Europe has done in the case of Greece, but to reward \xe2\x80\x9cwinners\xe2\x80\x9d that set a good example for the rest of the union.'b'STANFORD, Calif.'b'OVER the last three years, as I delved into the world of American nuclear weapons, I felt increasingly as though I had stepped into a time warp. Despite the nearly total rearrangement of the international security landscape since the demise of the Soviet Union in 1991, the rise of Islamic terrorism and the spread of nuclear materials and technology to volatile nations like Pakistan, North Korea and Iran, the Defense Department remains enthralled by cold war nuclear strategies and practices.'b'Barack Obama took office determined to change that. He has made progress on many fronts. Last week, he outlined a new, no-frills defense strategy, downsizing conventional forces. He now needs to double down on his commitment to refashion nuclear forces. He should trim the American nuclear arsenal by two-thirds to bring it down to a sensible size, order the Pentagon to scale back nuclear war-fighting plans so they are relevant to contemporary threats, remove most American intercontinental, land-based missiles from high alert and drop the quaint notion that a fleet of aging B-52 bombers can effectively deliver nuclear weapons to distant targets.'b'This agenda is not only desirable, it is doable without undercutting American security. It would save tens of billions of dollars a year, a relatively small amount by Pentagon standards, but every billion counts as Leon E. Panetta, the defense secretary, trims his budget. And the steps can safely be taken without requiring reciprocal moves by Russia that must be codified in a treaty.'b'For the last few months, the Obama administration has been conducting a classified review of the doctrines and operations that determine the shape and potential uses of America\xe2\x80\x99s nuclear armaments. If the president pushes back against the defenders of the old order at the Pentagon and other redoubts of the nuclear priesthood, he can preserve American security while making the United States a more credible leader on one of today\xe2\x80\x99s most critical issues \xe2\x80\x94 containing the spread of nuclear weapons. Like a chain smoker asking others to give up cigarettes, the United States, with its bloated arsenal, sounds hypocritical when it puts pressure on other nations to cut weapons and stop producing bomb-grade highly enriched uranium, the key ingredient of a crude nuclear weapon.'b'American actions alone won\xe2\x80\x99t end the proliferation danger, but American leadership is essential to any hope of containing the threat.'b'Sam Nunn, the former chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, and anything but a dove over the years, rightly warns that the spread of weapons and the means to make them may soon reach a combustible stage where New York, Washington, Moscow, Tokyo or London is at risk of a nuclear terrorist attack.'b'Mr. Nunn and other keepers of America\xe2\x80\x99s cold-war armory, George P. Shultz and Henry A. Kissinger, former Republican secretaries of state, and William J. Perry, a former Democratic defense secretary, have banded together in recent years to press, among other things, for cutting nuclear forces, de-alerting missiles and, ultimately, eliminating nuclear arms. Mr. Obama has embraced their aims and welcomed them to the Oval Office. Their high-powered, bipartisan alliance, if adroitly employed by the White House, ought to provide some political cover as Mr. Obama reshapes nuclear policy while running for a second term.'b'There is no national security rationale for maintaining an arsenal of some 5,000 warheads, with nearly 2,000 arms ready to use on short notice and the rest in reserve. We don\xe2\x80\x99t need thousands of warheads, or even hundreds, to counter threats from countries like Iran or North Korea.'b'The only conceivable use of so many weapons would be a full-scale nuclear war with Russia, which has more warheads than the United States. But two decades after the collapse of the Soviet Union, even Vladimir V. Putin, with his authoritarian bent, is not about to put Russia on a collision course with the United States that leads to nuclear war. China, equally unlikely to escalate tensions to the nuclear brink, probably has fewer than 400 warheads and a policy to use them only in self-defense. Pakistan has roughly 100, North Korea fewer than 10 and Iran, so far, zero.'b'The United States could live quite securely with fewer than 1,500 warheads, half in reserve. Defenders of the nuclear faith claim we need 5,000 weapons as a hedge against warheads that may become defective over time. But an elaborate Energy Department program to maintain and refurbish warheads, the 'b'Stockpile Stewardship Program'b', has proved highly effective.'b'Another oft-cited reason for increasing our arsenal is that the Pentagon\xe2\x80\x99s nuclear war-fighting plans still call for striking hundreds of targets in Russia and China, as well as dozens of sites in a number of other publicly unidentified nations \xe2\x80\x94 presumably Iran, North Korea and Syria \xe2\x80\x94 considered potentially hostile to the United States and eager to possess unconventional weapons.'b'Washington\xe2\x80\x99s current nuclear war plans remain far too outsize to deal with any plausible attack on America. Mr. Obama could remove some nations from the hit list, starting with China, and tell his generals to limit the number of targets in the countries that remain.'b'The oversize American nuclear arsenal features an equally outdated reliance on long-distance bombers. The days when lumbering B-52 bombers could play a central role in delivering nuclear weapons \xe2\x80\x94 memorably spoofed in Stanley Kubrick\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cDr. Strangelove\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 ended decades ago. Mr. Obama should ground the bombers and depend on land- and sea-based missiles.'b'The high-alert status of America\xe2\x80\x99s intercontinental ballistic missiles is another anachronism. There are few circumstances that might require the United States to quickly launch nuclear-tipped missiles, and missiles on high alert are an invitation to an accident, or impulsive action. In the first year of his presidency, Mr. Obama outlined an ambitious nuclear weapons agenda. Absent new action, Washington will remain frozen in a costly cold war posture.'b''b'Ladies and gentlemen, during this evening\xe2\x80\x99s performance, flash photography and video recording are strictly prohibited. Now, turn on your cellphones and enjoy the show'b'!'b'In an unsavory confluence of social media and the arts, we now have what are known as the tweet seats \xe2\x80\x94 sections of otherwise dignified theaters where communicating via Twitter during shows is actually encouraged.'b'The Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra has tweet seats from which patrons can carry on what organizers call \xe2\x80\x9cdigital conversations\xe2\x80\x9d during concerts. The answer, in five characters, is \xe2\x80\x9cu bet.\xe2\x80\x9d Here\xe2\x80\x99s a suggestion for the Palm Beach Opera: Since you already have super titles to provide the English translation, why not also display messages from the tweet seats? He\xe2\x80\x99s a blind Italian tenor who is gorgeous \xe2\x80\x94 as good to look at as to listen to.'b''b'READING'b' A book I really enjoyed was recommended to me by the manager of a liquor store in this podunk little town in Kentucky.
