It is fantasy and I\xe2\x80\x99ve never liked fantasy, but this just grabs you.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s a love story which takes place in 19th-century England. A boy and a girl \xe2\x80\x94 the characters all have magical powers \xe2\x80\x94 are pitted against each other and end up falling in love. It\xe2\x80\x99s called \xe2\x80\x9cThe Night Circus\xe2\x80\x9d because the circus appears and disappears overnight and only certain people in certain small villages can see it.'b''b'WATCHING'b' I liked \xe2\x80\x9cThe King\xe2\x80\x99s Speech\xe2\x80\x9d for obvious reasons. Sometimes I\xe2\x80\x99ll be struck by a voice in a crowd, or recently a friend e-mailed me a 'b'YouTube video'b' of a young girl who was like 10 years old, but she sang like a 40-year-old with this deep, resonating voice. 'b''b''b''b'WEARING'b' My granddaughter\xe2\x80\x99s most recent gift to me is, by far, the best thing I\xe2\x80\x99ve had in a long time \xe2\x80\x94 a pair of 'b'red suede UGG moccasins'b'. They are so comfortable, and I\xe2\x80\x99m a person who doesn\xe2\x80\x99t like to wear shoes and goes barefoot a lot.'b''b'STEWING'b' My son-in-law is an Englishman and he makes a mean beef stew. He uses parsnips instead of potatoes and a whole bottle of wine, which is probably why I like it.'b'The Supreme Court has not banned capital punishment, as it should, but it has long held that the death penalty is unconstitutional if randomly imposed on a handful of people. An important new study based on capital cases in Connecticut provides powerful evidence that death sentences are haphazardly meted out, with virtually no connection to the heinousness of the crime.'b'A number of 'b'studies'b' in the last three decades have shown that black defendants are more likely to be sentenced to death if their victim is white rather than black. But defenders of capital punishment often respond to those studies by arguing that the \xe2\x80\x9cworst of the worst\xe2\x80\x9d are sentenced to death because their crimes are the most egregious.'b'The Connecticut 'b'study'b', conducted by John Donohue, a Stanford law professor, completely dispels this erroneous reasoning. It analyzed all murder cases in Connecticut over a 34-year period and found that inmates on death row are indistinguishable from equally violent offenders who escape that penalty. It shows that the process in Connecticut \xe2\x80\x94 similar to those in other death-penalty states \xe2\x80\x94 is utterly arbitrary and discriminatory.'b'From 1973, when Connecticut passed a death penalty law, to 2007, 4,686 murders were committed in the state. Of those, 205 were death-eligible cases (capital murders that include the killing of a police officer, murder for hire, murder-rape and murder committed during a kidnapping) that resulted in some kind of conviction, either through a plea bargain or conviction at trial. The arbitrariness started at the charging level: nearly a third of these death-eligible cases were not charged as capital offenses as they could have been, but as lesser crimes. Sixty-six defendants were convicted of capital murder, 29 went to a hearing for a death sentence, nine death sentences were sustained and one person was executed.'b'Why was this small group of defendants singled out for death? Did their crimes make them more deserving of execution than all the others?'b'To get answers, Professor Donohue designed an \xe2\x80\x9cegregiousness\xe2\x80\x9d ratings system to compare all 205 cases. It considered four factors: victim suffering (like duration of pain); victim characteristics (like age, vulnerability); defendant\xe2\x80\x99s culpability (motive, intoxication or premeditation); and the number of victims. He enlisted students from two law schools to rate each case (based on fact summaries without revealing the case\xe2\x80\x99s outcome or the race of the defendant or victim) on a scale from 1 to 3 (most egregious) for each of the four factors. The raters also gave each case an overall subjective assessment of egregiousness, from 1 (low) to 5 (high), to ensure that more general reactions could be captured.'b'The egregiousness scores for those charged with capital murder and those who were not were virtually identical; the nature of the crime bore almost no relationship to how the case came out. Among the 29 who had a death penalty hearing, there is no clear difference in the level of egregiousness for the 17 who got life without parole and the 12 sentenced to death (three eventually had their sentences vacated for various reasons). Among the 32 most awful cases on the four-factor egregiousness scale, only one resulted in a death sentence.'b'Rather than punish the worst criminals, the Connecticut system, Professor Donohue found, operates with \xe2\x80\x9carbitrariness and discrimination.\xe2\x80\x9d The racial effect is very evident (minority defendants with white victims were far more likely to be sentenced to death than others), as is geographic disparity. In the city of Waterbury, a death-eligible killer was at least seven times as likely to be sentenced to death as in the rest of the state.'b'In 1972, the Supreme Court in 'b'Furman v. Georgia'b' struck down state death-penalty laws that lacked guidelines on how the penalty should be applied. It found that with only 15 percent of death-eligible murder convictions in Georgia leading to a death sentence, imposition of the penalty was \xe2\x80\x9cfreakishly\xe2\x80\x9d rare \xe2\x80\x94 and therefore arbitrary and unconstitutional. The rate in the Donohue study is far more extreme at 4.4 percent.'b'The court also said in Furman that a death-penalty system must have a \xe2\x80\x9cmeaningful basis for distinguishing the few cases in which it is imposed from the many cases in which it is not.\xe2\x80\x9d Clearly, Connecticut\xe2\x80\x99s system fails this requirement. Because it\xe2\x80\x99s a small state, Professor Donohue was able to conduct a comprehensive study of every capital murder case with a conviction. But Connecticut\xe2\x80\x99s lessons also apply to bigger states, like California, Texas and Ohio, where prosecutors even in neighboring counties use drastically different factors to impose the death penalty.'b'In 2011, the number of new death sentences imposed in the United States 'b' fell'b' by 25 percent to 78, the lowest number since capital punishment was reinstated in 1976. This \xe2\x80\x9cfreakishly\xe2\x80\x9d rare application \xe2\x80\x94 among the thousands of murder cases a year \xe2\x80\x94 is strong evidence that every state system is arbitrary and capricious. The death penalty in Connecticut is clearly unconstitutional, barbaric and should be abolished, as it should be everywhere.\xc2\xa0'b''b''b'Robert Jay Lifton, Steven Pinker and readers discuss violence in this and other eras.'b''b'The Letter'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'I have been studying violent events for several decades, so I was deeply interested in Steven Pinker\xe2\x80\x99s new book, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Better Angels of Our Nature,\xe2\x80\x9d which claims that violence has long been declining and that this may be our most peaceful era in our species\xe2\x80\x99 existence. Dr. Pinker argues that, over centuries, human beings have become less prone to kill and engage in torture and other cruel and sadistic behavior.'b'I have not experienced the 20th and 21st centuries that way. My work has taken me to Auschwitz and Hiroshima, and I have come to see these two dreadful events as largely defining our era.'b'Our subsequent development not only in nuclear but also chemical and biological weapons, and our pollution of the planet with our wastes, suggest further directions of mass killing and dying.'b'The deaths over the last two centuries reflect a revolution in the technology of killing. During the 20th century we saw the emergence of extreme forms of numbed technological violence, in which unprecedented, virtually unlimited numbers of people could be killed. Those who did the killing could be completely separated, geographically and psychologically, from their victims.'b'Millions of people were also killed during the 20th century in more old-fashioned, low-tech ways during genocides, induced famines and wars.'b'There is a terrible paradox here. Dr. Pinker and others may be quite right in claiming that for most people alive today, life is less violent than it has been in previous centuries. But never have human beings been in as much danger of destroying ourselves collectively, of endangering the future of our species.'b'We are not helpless about our fate. There could not be a more crucial moment to draw upon our gradual taming of individual violence, along with our growing awareness of the grotesque consequences of numbed technological violence, to achieve lasting forms of what can be called peace.'b'ROBERT JAY LIFTON'b' New York, Jan. 3, 2012'b''b''b'The writer is a psychiatrist and the author of, most recently, \xe2\x80\x9cWitness to an Extreme Century: A Memoir.\xe2\x80\x9d 'b''b''b'Readers React'b''b'Robert Jay Lifton has profoundly illuminated the human dimension of the 20th century\xe2\x80\x99s most destructive events. Yet precisely because he 'b'has'b' singled out the worst events of one century, his observations cannot speak to the prevalence of violence in the world as a whole, or to its trajectory over history. Only quantitative comparisons can do that, and they suggest that Hiroshima and Auschwitz do not, fortunately, define our era.'b'Contrary to decades of predictions that nuclear world war was inevitable, no nuclear weapon has been used since Nagasaki, and today\xe2\x80\x99s threats, as terrifying as they are, cannot compare to the now-defunct prospect of all-out war between the United States and the Soviet Union.'b'Nor did the mid-20th-century genocides become the new normal. While the world has seen some horrific mass killings, the global rate of death from genocide has plummeted over the decades, and may now be at an all-time low.'b'Estimates of the carnage wreaked by the swords, pikes and arrows of earlier centuries (and by the machetes of the past one) show that remote-control technologies are not necessary for high-volume killing.'b'As fellow students of the human mind, Dr. Lifton and I might agree that the causes of violence lie not so much in the machinery of killing as in the psychology of killers: in the balance between tribalism, vengeance, sadism, amoral predation and toxic ideologies on the one hand, and compassion, self-control, fairness and reason on the other.'b'The fact that the balance can change (and, I argue, has changed) over time is perhaps the firmest ground for another shared conviction: that we are not helpless about our fate.'b'STEVEN PINKER'b' Cambridge, Mass., Jan. 4, 2012'b''b''b'The writer is a professor of psychology at Harvard and the author of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Better Angels of Our Nature: Why Violence Has Declined.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b'Steven Pinker and Robert Jay Lifton may be talking at cross-purposes.'b'Dr. Pinker may be correct that the actual number of killings has declined over the centuries, which implies that any given person today stands less of a chance of dying violently than just a few centuries ago. But Dr. Lifton focuses on concentrated instances of mass killing in the 20th century, like Auschwitz and Hiroshima. He rightly implies that humanity\xe2\x80\x99s capacity to kill has increased exponentially with the rise of industrialized technology.'b'But these are two different analyses. Dr. Pinker\xe2\x80\x99s is a statistical description of actual killings. Dr. Lifton\xe2\x80\x99s is an appraisal of humanity\xe2\x80\x99s potential to increase that number almost beyond imagining.'b'Perhaps the moral to be drawn from this comparison is that we can continue the encouraging trends that Dr. Pinker notes only if we\xe2\x80\x99re wise enough to heed Dr. Lifton\xe2\x80\x99s blood-chilling advisory.'b'MARK PACKER'b' Spartanburg, S.C., Jan. 5, 2012'b''b''b'The writer is a professor of interdisciplinary studies at the University of South Carolina, Upstate.'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b'Robert Jay Lifton, picking up on Steven Pinker\xe2\x80\x99s book \xe2\x80\x9cThe Better Angels of Our Nature,\xe2\x80\x9d calls attention to the fact that most of the world\xe2\x80\x99s people today experience less mass killing than in previous eras but endure the modern danger of \xe2\x80\x9cnumbed technological violence.\xe2\x80\x9d Citing the horrific events in Auschwitz and Hiroshima in the 20th century, Dr. Lifton rightly acknowledges yet understates the perilous conditions facing marginalized peoples in our times.'b'Having lived and worked in Africa and Southeast Asia for many years, I have observed structural violence there as a combination of human indignities and entrenched poverty. For the marginalized, systemic violence is a spiral of widespread rape, legalized and other forms of homophobia, chronic hunger and environmental degradation, often worsened by collusion among local elites and external interests in resource grabs.'b'Lasting peace requires measures for controlling technologies of violence, plus achieving human dignity and alleviating poverty.'b'JAMES H. MITTELMAN'b' Bethesda, Md., Jan. 4, 2012'b''b''b'The writer is a professor of international affairs at American University and the author of \xe2\x80\x9cHyperconflict: Globalization and Insecurity.\xe2\x80\x9d 'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b'To judge whether the human species is more or less violent at different times in history, one requires a definition of violence. I have defined violence in my studies as acts and/or socially maintained conditions that inhibit human development by interfering with the fulfillment of universal human needs, including biological/material, social/psychological, productive/creative, security, self-actualization and spiritual needs.'b'Using this concept of violence when examining global realities, one is forced to conclude that large segments of the global population of seven billion are victims of violent acts and conditions. They experience hunger, malnutrition, material and psychological poverty, widespread unemployment, lack of health care, including family planning, lack of meaningful education and adequate social supports, and lack of a sense of security. Moreover, they are subjected to economic and sexual exploitation. Their human development is consequently severely obstructed.'b'These conditions, in addition to constant local and trans-local wars, suggest that the human species may be on a suicidal course rather than a course of declining violence.'b'DAVID G. GIL'b' Lexington, Mass., Jan. 4, 2012'b''b''b'The writer is emeritus professor of social policy at Brandeis University and the author of \xe2\x80\x9cViolence Against Children: 'b''b' Physical Child Abuse in the United States.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b' 'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b'Robert Jay Lifton\xe2\x80\x99s description of nuclear, chemical and biological warfare as well as environmental pollution provides him with ammunition for his argument that the 20th and 21st centuries reflect continuing fratricide.'b'We need more Dr. Liftons. We need curbs and restraints, whether sponsored by the United Nations or promoted by individuals, states or nations. We need a United Nations with sanctions to halt violence. We need to be hailed as the decade that defined peace and made war obsolete.'b'NANCY M. DAVIS'b' Avon, Conn., Jan. 4, 2012'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b'Both Steven Pinker and Robert Jay Lifton left out of their observations what can be referred to a as \xe2\x80\x9cstructural violence,\xe2\x80\x9d a system placing profit over human need resulting in social problems like extreme poverty, lacks of security in old age, access to health care, and socially useful work at reasonable wages.'b'By and large, we have become dulled to such violence, which is something like the \xe2\x80\x9cbanality of evil\xe2\x80\x9d that Hannah Arendt spoke about. These growing economic and social inequalities within and among countries can easily lead to full-scale wars, as former President Jimmy Carter suggested upon accepting the Nobel Peace Prize. Fortunately, movements like Occupy Wall Street may have awakened some of us to such inequities, which are socially violent.'b'JOSEPH WRONKA'b' Springfield, Mass., Jan. 4, 2012'b''b''b'The writer, a professor of social work at Springfield College, is permanent representative to the United Nations in Geneva for the International Association of Schools of Social Work. 'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b'Robert Jay Lifton\xe2\x80\x99s critique of Steven Pinker\xe2\x80\x99s thesis brings to mind the usefulness of the adage that not everything that counts can be counted, and not everything that can be counted counts.'b'Dr. Pinker\xe2\x80\x99s argument depends on statistics, but Dr. Lifton\xe2\x80\x99s rejoinder depends on the historical sense that modernity has been permeated by violence in ever-diversifying forms.'b'We have come to accept a permanent state of war as the \xe2\x80\x9cnew normal.\xe2\x80\x9d Societies throughout the world, including our own, suffer from the structural violence of poverty, inequality, pollution, hunger, racism and so on. And now we read daily reports of soldiers suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder \xe2\x80\x94 invisible violence that is often overlooked by the statistics.'b'MARK HUSSEY'b' Nyack, N.Y., Jan. 4, 2012'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b'I side more with Robert Jay Lifton than with Steven Pinker. My recent book looked at war frequency and fatalities since 1816. Sadly, the number of wars remains about the same.'b'For instance, in the period 1816 to 1825, there were eight wars continuing in the world; in 1996 to 2005, there were twice that \xe2\x80\x94 a rate of 17 a year.'b'In the last five years, there have been eight wars a year, the same number as two centuries ago. Forty-two civil wars started in the 1990s, more than in any previous decade in the last two centuries.'b'Not surprisingly, the number of civil wars has gone down in the first decade of the 21st century. Statistically, something that\xe2\x80\x99s been the worst ever will tend to improve at the next measuring point. This also happens if one compares current death rates to World War II.'b'Meanwhile, as Dr. Lifton indicated, millions can die with the push of a button. We continue to live in an age of great power, great insecurity and, alas, war.'b'FRANK WAYMAN'b' Dearborn, Mich., Jan. 4, 2012'b''b''b'The writer, a professor of political science at the University of Michigan, Dearborn, is co-author of \xe2\x80\x9cResort to War: 1816-2007.\xe2\x80\x9d 'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b'I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t agree more with Robert Jay Lifton. He knows history. He knows humanity. His books about Hiroshima and nuclear war are a testimony to a human being who cares about the survival of the species.'b'His statement that \xe2\x80\x9cwe are not helpless about our fate\xe2\x80\x9d points to a future where \xe2\x80\x9coccupiers of the Progressive mind\xe2\x80\x9d will bring the nation\xe2\x80\x99s power brokers to their knees, and their deadly game of nuclear roulette will become a dim memory for generations to come.'b'DAVID ROTHAUSER'b' Brookline, Mass., Jan. 5, 2012'b''b''b'The Writer Responds'b''b'My concern is with the new dimension of violence at this moment in human history. The lethal technologies of Hiroshima and Auschwitz have vastly improved since the mid-20th century. Nuclear weapons can be made in various sizes, can continue to proliferate to other countries and possibly terrorist groups, and now enable us to do what in the past only God could do: destroy the world.'b'This capacity for killing in numbers nothing short of the infinite cannot be adequately grasped by statistics concerning past war-making and killing.'b'Nor can we simply say, as Dr. Pinker does, that \xe2\x80\x9cthe causes of violence lie not so much in the machinery of killing as in the psychology of killers.\xe2\x80\x9d Rather, I would point to the dynamic of mind and technology, in which the technology creates a psychological attraction to ultimate power and protection from painful feelings associated with more direct forms of killing.'b'People who construct nuclear weapons or plan their possible use do not have to be angry. They need only be socialized to the ideology of nuclear necessity, whether for \xe2\x80\x9cnational security\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cdeterrence\xe2\x80\x9d or other plausible purposes.'b'Of course there has been more to the 20th and 21st centuries than Auschwitz and Hiroshima. But they are nonetheless defining events in that they brutally displayed this new killing potential and created the imagery of extinction that continues to haunt us.'b'I agree with Drs. Mittelman, Gil and Wronka and Mr. Hussey about the more insidious and widespread effects of structural or systemic forms of violence. As for Ms. Davis\xe2\x80\x99s generous sentiment that \xe2\x80\x9cwe need more Dr. Liftons,\xe2\x80\x9d I have to say that there are those who think that one is more than enough.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99m also in full agreement with Dr. Pinker and the other letter writers about our capacity to take constructive steps to diminish the dangers we face. Indeed, much protest over the years has sought to do that, whether as 1960s and 1980s opposition to war and weaponry or today\xe2\x80\x99s Occupy movement. We would do well to channel more of this protest into combating all violence, but especially the numbed technological variety.'b'ROBERT JAY LIFTON'b' New York, Jan. 5, 2012'b''b'HAITI wasn\xe2\x80\x99t always the \xe2\x80\x9cpoorest nation in the Western hemisphere,\xe2\x80\x9d though it\xe2\x80\x99s almost impossible to read about the country today without coming across that phrase. In the two years since the earthquake that devastated it, Haiti has experienced political conflict and its first ever cholera epidemic; hundreds of thousands of the displaced are still living in makeshift tents strewn like dusty flags by the sides of highways. It is easy to forget that, for most of the 19th century, Haiti was a site of agricultural innovation, productivity and economic success.'b'In the wake of the earthquake, many have talked about the need to lay foundations for a better future. To do that, Haiti should look to the past, and the system of small farms and the decentralized economy that once provided Haitians with dignity, autonomy and wealth.'b'The slave revolution that ended with Haiti\xe2\x80\x99s creation in 1804 led to what the sociologist Jean Casimir dubbed a \xe2\x80\x9ccounter-plantation\xe2\x80\x9d system. As slaves, the islanders had harvested and processed sugar cane, but fed themselves by cultivating their own tiny gardens, for which they developed sophisticated techniques of inter-cropping \xe2\x80\x94 a kind of sustainable agriculture that involved planting a variety of crops close together. Once free, Haitians drew on that knowledge to raise livestock and grow fruits, root vegetables and even coffee for export to the global market. In establishing their own small farms, they forestalled any possibility of a return to the large plantations that had defined the days of slavery.'b'This system of agricultural self-reliance provided a better quality of life than that of African descendants anywhere else in the Americas. The country attracted many immigrants, including thousands of African-Americans. And though the United States government didn\xe2\x80\x99t officially recognize Haiti until 1862, American businessmen eagerly traded with the island nation.'b'Haiti\xe2\x80\x99s economy was decentralized, organized around 11 largely autonomous regions, each with its own port. There was plenty of conflict in the country, largely over control of the central government, and heavy taxes on exports, as well as the power of foreign merchants, sapped the profits of farmers. Yet the regional economies thrived, and a decentralized political and military system assured many Haitians a great deal of control over their destiny.'b'In the 20th century, however, this system came under increasing pressure. Outsiders, along with many in the Haitian elite, saw small farms as a barrier to progress. When the United States occupied Haiti, from 1915 to 1934, it worked to centralize the economy in Port-au-Prince. It pushed through a re-writing of the Haitian Constitution to allow foreigners to own land, which the country\xe2\x80\x99s founders had banned for fear of re-enslavement, and worked to replace small farms with large plantations owned by foreign corporations. Many farmers saw their land expropriated.'b'In the teens, when the countryside erupted in a revolt against the occupation and the use of forced labor to build roads, the United States created a newly centralized gendarmerie to suppress the insurrection. Violence and economic decline in the countryside forced many Haitians to flee to the cities or to plantations in neighboring Cuba and the Dominican Republic. In the years since, the countryside has continued to experience environmental and economic degradation as well as exodus, while the big cities, especially Port-au-Prince, have become overcrowded. Today, about half of Haiti\xe2\x80\x99s food is imported.'b'The flow of ideas and money to Haiti that followed the earthquake provides an opportunity to restore the system of small farms that was a pillar of Haitian society after independence. Michel Martelly, Haiti\xe2\x80\x99s new president, has talked of the need to decentralize the economy, and nongovernmental organizations have begun projects to help farmers. But far more can be done.'b'Municipal governments should construct properly equipped marketplaces for the women who sell rural produce. The Haitian state should develop trade policies aimed at protecting the agricultural sector, and take the lead in fixing roads and ports, confronting deforestation and improving systems of water management. Foreign organizations working in the country can help simply by making it a policy to buy food and other goods from local producers.'b'The return on the investment in the rural economy would be self-reliance, the alleviation of dangerous overcrowding in cities and, most important, a path toward ending Haiti\xe2\x80\x99s now chronic problems of malnutrition and food insecurity. As Haitians look to rebuild in 2012, the best blueprints will come from their own proud and vibrant history.'b'Beijing'b'NOT long ago, I was stuck in a dead-end job near Greenwich, Conn. I was in my early 20s, overeducated with a series of non-performing degrees from New York University and Columbia, and frustrated. When I saw the Occupy Wall Street protesters on TV, fed up with the economic status quo in the United States, I saw myself.'b'Or rather, I saw my old self, before I figured a way out.'b'To the occupiers and their sympathizers, I say vote \xe2\x80\x94 not with the ballot, but with your feet. Now that your encampment has disbanded, don\xe2\x80\x99t just leave Zuccotti Park: leave America.'b'For China. At least, that\xe2\x80\x99s what I did. It was the best decision I ever made.'b'In February of last year, I moved to Beijing, having landed a job teaching American culture and English at Tsinghua University. While I was not a global neophyte, I had never set foot in Asia. China had 1.3 billion people, and I didn\xe2\x80\x99t know any of them.'b'But now, after living almost a year here, I feel that China is my second home. My work is fulfilling and my workload is manageable enough to give me time to travel. I have found friends among China\xe2\x80\x99s large expatriate community, my colleagues and, of course, my eager students. The food is outstanding and caters to both the gastronomically meek and the profoundly adventurous.'b'Most of all, my experiences here have been enriched by the Chinese people themselves. Their patience, courtesy and hospitality leave me in no hurry to return home anytime soon.'b'And guess what? I\xe2\x80\x99m not so special.'b'China wants you. Job prospects are abundant. The effects of the Great Recession of 2008 may be felt in the United States for years, but they barely scratched China. Demand for native English speakers is white-hot. 'b'ChinaJob.com'b', 'b'TheBeijnger.com'b' and 'b'Dave\xe2\x80\x99s ESL Cafe'b' are just a few of the places where you can search for work.'b'\xc2\xa0There are problems here, of course. China is a nation that unapologetically rejects Western democracy \xe2\x80\x94 and yet I am surprised to find that Chinese citizens and the news media have as much freedom as they do. Beijing, like much of China, is often enveloped in what local residents euphemistically call \xe2\x80\x9cmist.\xe2\x80\x9d But there are nice days, too, more than you might think.'b'Many critics have rightly pointed out the shocking failures of the Chinese food safety system \xe2\x80\x94 the most famous being the tainted-baby-formula scandal of 2008. But what you may not know is that China meted out swift justice in that case to the perpetrators. That is more than can be said for the handling of many corporations in the United States that have 'b'harmed their consumers'b' and remain unpunished.'b'We live in grim times, but fortune favors the bold. So if you are reading this from some occupied encampment, a soul-crushing cubicle, your parents\xe2\x80\x99 basement or anywhere else in America really, maybe you should consider paying me a visit.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99ll buy you a duck.'b'The Interim Haiti Recovery Commission was one of Haiti\xe2\x80\x99s great hopes after the earthquake, a Haitian-led international partnership that would finally summon the money, will and organizational intelligence to build the country back better than before. But if you visit the commission\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'Web site'b' today, on the eve of the second anniversary of the Jan. 12 disaster, this is what you see:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPlease kindly note that the mandate of the I.H.R.C. expired on October 21, 2011. The coming year should be one in which Haitians begin to take control of their rebuilding, with continued outside help.'b'Chantell and Michael Sackett\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'case'b' against the Environmental Protection Agency before the Supreme Court on Monday might appear to be David versus Goliath. But those supporting the Sacketts with friend-of-the-court briefs are 'b'corporate Goliaths'b' like General Electric and real estate developers eager to weaken the E.P.A.\xe2\x80\x99s ability to protect wetlands and waterways under the federal Clean Water Act.'b'The Sacketts owned a small lot about 500 feet from Idaho\xe2\x80\x99s pristine 'b'Priest Lake'b'. They filled part of it with dirt and rock in preparing to build a house. The E.P.A. determined that the lot is federally protected wetland so the Sacketts needed a permit to do the work, which they did not seek. The agency ordered the couple to remove the fill because pollutants were being discharged.'b'The E.P.A. can issue compliance orders directing violators to get a permit and remedy any damage they caused. But to enforce an order, the agency has to sue in federal court; it does not have power to take action against a violator on its own. The Sacketts in their 'b'brief'b' say they had no reason to believe their lot was covered by the Clean Water Act, though there is 'b'evidence'b' to the contrary. They argue that lack of judicial review of the compliance order violated their due process rights, though they could have challenged the order through the agency\xe2\x80\x99s administrative process \xe2\x80\x94 and could have gotten 'b'a permit'b' after the E.P.A. told them they needed one.'b'Almost every federal court that has considered the issue found that the law does not allow \xe2\x80\x9cjudicial review of compliance orders until the E.P.A. brings an enforcement action,\xe2\x80\x9d as the Ninth Circuit appeals court said in ruling against the Sacketts. The court 'b'explained'b' that this process allows the agency \xe2\x80\x9cto act to address environmental problems quickly and without becoming immediately entangled in litigation.\xe2\x80\x9d Allowing challenges to E.P.A. orders before they are enforced would give landowners the ability to delay in correcting the harm they caused. Compliance orders are useful because they allow the agency to press landowners to negotiate about mitigating harms.'b'This case goes far beyond the Sacketts\xe2\x80\x99 right to fill in their lot without a permit. If the Supreme Court allows them to seek pre-enforcement review, it will be handing a big victory to corporations and developers who want to evade the requirements of the Clean Water Act.'b'In Iowa, the Republican presidential contenders tried to outdo one another in attacking reproductive rights as they sought the support of caucusgoers from the religious right. MEYERS'b'\nWilliamsburg, Va., Dec. 30, 2011'b''b''b'The writer is a professor of English at the College of William and Mary and chairman of the college\xe2\x80\x99s Athletic Policy Advisory Committee.'b''b'THE beginning of a new year is a time for resolutions, and Hillary Clinton\xe2\x80\x99s admirers are already busily, lovingly resolving on her behalf. On one sideline, her friends tell me that after a few years of hyperactive globetrotting what she really needs is to put her feet up and dictate another volume of her memoirs while nagging Chelsea to deliver grandchildren. (\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s tired; she needs some time off,\xe2\x80\x9d her husband 'b'told ABC'b'.) At the other extreme, a couple of Democratic consultants, Patrick Caddell and Douglas Schoen, propose to draft her right now as the 2012 Democratic presidential candidate, whether she likes it or not. (\xe2\x80\x9cNot only is Mrs. Clinton better positioned to win in 2012 than Mr. Obama, but she is better positioned to govern if she does,\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'they wrote 'b'in The Wall Street Journal.) Other helpful devotees have noticed that Brown University is looking for a new president, or have imagined her creating a clone of the Clinton Global Initiative focused on empowering women. Or maybe Ruth Bader Ginsburg will decide to put 'b'her'b' feet up, opening a seat on the Supreme Court.'b'The right choice is none of the above.'b'Hillary Clinton is 64 years old, with a Calvinist work ethic, the stamina of an Olympian, an E.Q. to match her I.Q., and the political instincts of a Clinton. She has an impressive empathic ability \xe2\x80\x94 invaluable in politics or statecraft \xe2\x80\x94 to imagine how the world looks to an ally or adversary. She listens, and she learns from her mistakes. She was a perfectly plausible president four years ago, and that was before she demonstrated her gifts as a diplomatic snake-charmer. (Never mind Pakistan and Libya, I\xe2\x80\x99m talking about the Obama White House.) She is, 'b'says Gallup'b', the most admired woman in America for the 10th year in a row, laps ahead of, in order, Oprah Winfrey, Michelle Obama, Sarah Palin and Condoleezza Rice; her approval rating of 'b'64 percent'b' is the highest of any political figure in the country.'b'So it\xe2\x80\x99s too early to hang up the big ambition. And a lot of us would be deeply disappointed in her if she did. This would be none of our business if she had taken the off-ramp after her time as first lady. (Nobody is thinking very hard about what\xe2\x80\x99s next for Laura Bush.) But she moved on to the Senate, to a near-miss presidential campaign, and to a credible term as secretary of state. She raised our expectations.'b'The proposal to draft her in place of President Obama this year is preposterous. It exaggerates his vulnerability and discounts Hillary\xe2\x80\x99s loyalty. But the idea that she should replace Joe Biden as Obama\xe2\x80\x99s running mate in 2012 is something else. It has been kicking around on the blogs for 'b'more than a year'b' without getting any traction, mainly because it has been authoritatively, emphatically dismissed by 'b'Hillary'b', 'b'Biden'b' and 'b'Team Obama'b'.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s time to take it seriously.'b'I know the arguments against this scenario, and we\xe2\x80\x99ll get to those. But the arguments in favor are as simple as one-two-three. One: it does more to guarantee Obama\xe2\x80\x99s re-election than anything else the Democrats can do. Two: it improves the chances that, come next January, he will not be a lame duck with a gridlocked Congress but a rejuvenated president with a mandate and a Congress that may be a little less forbidding. Three: it makes Hillary the party\xe2\x80\x99s heir apparent in 2016. If she sits out politics for the next four years, other Democrats (yes, Governor Cuomo, we see your hand up) will fill the void.'b'She would bring to this year\xe2\x80\x99s campaign a missing warmth and some of the voltage that has dissipated as Obama moved from campaigning to governing. What excites is not just the prospect of having a woman a heartbeat \xe2\x80\x94 and four years \xe2\x80\x94 away from the presidency, although she certainly embodies the aspirations of many women. It\xe2\x80\x99s the possibility that the first woman at the top would have qualifications so manifest that her first-ness was a secondary consideration.'b'The biggest obstacle to this scenario is, of course, President Obama, reinforced by the people around him. The Obamas have long regarded the Clintons as representing the tawdry side of politics: the deal-cutting, the calculating, the endless schmoozing, the permanent campaign \xe2\x80\x94 in short, the things that this professorial president could have used more of in his first term. The Clintons \xe2\x80\x94 Bill, at least \xe2\x80\x94 have tended to see Obama as politically na\xc3\xafve, steeped in youthful arrogance, a loner, happier to be right than successful. The mistrust may have abated a little, as Hillary has proved herself the most faithful of allies. And Bill has been a pretty disciplined defender of this administration, though his endorsements tend to come with a helping of paternalistic (and public) advice. But the Obamas and Clintons remain a marriage of convenience.'b'The Obama inner circle believes the president doesn\xe2\x80\x99t need Hillary to win a second term. Just now, when the Republican field looks like a bug-spattered windshield and the most likely nominee strikes many in his own party as an empty suit, that confidence is understandable. But Democrats should not get too cocky. Mitt Romney, as I\xe2\x80\x99ve argued before, 'b'has a case'b' to make to voters and the resources to make it. If she can do in 2012 what Obama did in 2008 \xe2\x80\x94 animate that feeling of historic possibility \xe2\x80\x94 the pair can lift some House and Senate candidates along with them. One reason Republicans did so well in the 2010 Congressional elections is that they overcame the gender gap and carried women voters 51 to 49. Those voters will flock back to Hillary, the more so if the Republican ticket is locked into a culture-war agenda. So, by the way, will Hispanic voters, securing such endangered states as Florida, New Mexico, Nevada and Colorado.'b'Vice President Clinton would be a formidable asset in governing as well as campaigning, both as a political calculator and as an emissary to Capitol Hill. She has, to put it mildly, an ability to navigate the world of powerful, problematic men.'b'In the event that Obama has the good sense (or, if the economy fails to perk up, the sense of desperation) to offer her the vice president\xe2\x80\x99s slot, some of her closest friends will implore her to decline. They will tell her that it means tarnishing her reputation by playing the second\xe2\x80\x99s traditional role of campaign attack dog. But that needn\xe2\x80\x99t be the case. But not as sorry as I\xe2\x80\x99ll be if \xe2\x80\x94 as I fear \xe2\x80\x94 it\xe2\x80\x99s just a fantasy.'b''b''b'Navigating the sidewalks of New York City can be as challenging as any rushing sport, like football or rugby. \xc2\xa0But when your opponents are walking while text messaging, their field of view is impaired, and this can render a three-block walk to Starbucks somewhere between infuriating and life-threatening.'b'While there\xe2\x80\x99s little\xc2\xa0current data about the number of people injured while texting, more than 1,000 pedestrians visited emergency rooms in 2008 after they were injured while using a cellphone to talk or text. That had doubled each year\xc2\xa0since 2006, according to a study conducted by\xc2\xa0Ohio State University.'b'I wanted to make a movie about this issue for years, and got started after a discussion with my friend\xc2\xa0'b'Benny Safdie'b'\xc2\xa0on the proper, courteous way to text while walking.\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 By mastering the etiquette of texting, I hope we can gain more control over our increasingly electronic lives.\xc2\xa0 Let\xe2\x80\x99s stop acting like hollowed-out zombies, with BlackBerrys and iPhones replacing eye contact, handshakes and face-to-face conversations.\xc2\xa0 It\xe2\x80\x99s time to live once again in the present and simply be where we are.'b'Last month President Obama gave a speech invoking the spirit of Teddy Roosevelt on behalf of progressive ideals \xe2\x80\x94 and Republicans were not happy. Mitt Romney, in particular, insisted that where Roosevelt believed that \xe2\x80\x9cgovernment should level the playing field to create equal opportunities,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Obama believes that \xe2\x80\x9cgovernment should create equal outcomes,\xe2\x80\x9d that we should have a society where \xe2\x80\x9ceveryone receives the same or similar rewards, regardless of education, effort and willingness to take risk.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'As many people were quick to point out, this portrait of the president as radical redistributionist was pure fiction. What hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been as widely noted, however, is that Mr. Romney\xe2\x80\x99s picture of himself as a believer in a level playing field is just as fictional. Where is the evidence that he or his party cares at all about equality of opportunity?'b'Let\xe2\x80\x99s talk for a minute about the actual state of the playing field.'b'Americans are much more likely than citizens of other nations to believe that they live in a meritocracy. But this self-image is a fantasy: as a 'b'report'b' in The Times last week pointed out, America actually stands out as the advanced country in which it matters most who your parents were, the country in which those born on one of society\xe2\x80\x99s lower rungs have the least chance of climbing to the top or even to the middle.'b'And if you ask why America is more class-bound in practice than the rest of the Western world, a large part of the reason is that our government falls down on the job of creating equal opportunity.'b'The failure starts early: in America, the holes in the social safety net mean that both low-income mothers and their children are all too likely to suffer from poor nutrition and receive inadequate health care. It continues once children reach school age, where they encounter a system in which the affluent send their kids to good, well-financed public schools or, if they choose, to private schools, while less-advantaged children get a far worse education.'b'Once they reach college age, those who come from disadvantaged backgrounds are far less likely to go to college \xe2\x80\x94 and vastly less likely to go to a top-tier school \xe2\x80\x94 than those luckier in their parentage. At the most selective, \xe2\x80\x9cTier 1\xe2\x80\x9d schools, 74 percent of the entering class comes from the quarter of households that have the highest \xe2\x80\x9csocioeconomic status\xe2\x80\x9d; only 3 percent comes from the bottom quarter.'b'And if children from our society\xe2\x80\x99s lower rungs do manage to make it into a good college, the lack of financial support makes them far more likely to drop out than the children of the affluent, even if they have as much or more native ability. One long-term study by the Department of Education found that students with high test scores but low-income parents were less likely to complete college than students with low scores but affluent parents \xe2\x80\x94 loosely speaking, that smart poor kids are less likely than dumb rich kids to get a degree.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s no wonder, then, that Horatio Alger stories, tales of poor kids who make good, are much less common in reality than they are in legend \xe2\x80\x94 and much less common in America than they are in Canada or Europe. Which brings me back to those, like Mr. Romney, who claim to believe in equality of opportunity. Where is the evidence for that claim?'b'Think about it: someone who really wanted equal opportunity would be very concerned about the inequality of our current system. He would support more nutritional aid for low-income mothers-to-be and young children. He would try to improve the quality of public schools. He would support aid to low-income college students. And he would support what every other advanced country has, a universal health care system, so that nobody need worry about untreated illness or crushing medical bills.'b'If Mr. Romney has come out for any of these things, I\xe2\x80\x99ve missed it. And the Congressional wing of his party seems determined to make upward mobility even harder. For example, Republicans have tried to slash funds for the Women, Infants and Children program, which helps provide adequate nutrition to low-income mothers and their children; they have demanded cuts in Pell grants, which are designed to help lower-income students afford college.'b'And they have, of course, pledged to repeal a health reform that, for all its imperfections, would finally give Americans the guaranteed care that everyone else in the advanced world takes for granted.'b'So where is the evidence that Mr. Romney or his party actually believes in equal opportunity? Judging by their actions, they seem to prefer a society in which your station in life is largely determined by that of your parents \xe2\x80\x94 and in which the children of the very rich get to inherit their estates tax-free. Teddy Roosevelt would not have approved.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Stigmatizing Food Stamps'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (editorial, Jan. 2):'b'With an increase of nearly 500,000 people since 2008, the New York City Food Stamp program today provides more than 1.8 million New Yorkers benefits worth more than $3 billion a year. Given the magnitude of the program, it is imperative that we protect its integrity by preventing duplicate benefits.'b'Requiring applicants to be electronically fingerprinted is a simple and effective way to prevent duplication and fraud by ensuring that people cannot be approved for multiple food-stamp benefits, as was too common in the years before welfare reform.'b'Just a quick glance at the facts and you would understand that the purpose is to deter and detect fraud before it happens, which is why it is not surprising that the process does not lead to criminal prosecutions.'b'Referring low-income New Yorkers for prosecution solely because they once tried to get duplicate food-stamp benefits is not our goal, nor is it a good use of taxpayer dollars. Over the past 40 years, liberalism has been astonishingly incapable at expanding its market share.'b'The most important explanation is what you might call the Instrument Problem. They don\xe2\x80\x99t trust the federal government.'b'A few decades ago they did, but now they don\xe2\x80\x99t. It\xe2\x80\x99s not because they dislike individual programs like Medicare. It\xe2\x80\x99s more likely because they think the whole system is rigged. Or to put it in the economists\xe2\x80\x99 language, they believe the government has been captured by rent-seekers.'b'This is the disease that corrodes government at all times and in all places. As George F. Will 'b'wrote in a column'b' in Sunday\xe2\x80\x99s Washington Post, as government grows, interest groups accumulate, seeking to capture its power and money.'b'Some of these rent-seeking groups are corporate types. Will notes that the federal government delivers sugar subsidies that benefit a few rich providers while imposing costs on millions of consumers.'b'Other rent-seeking groups are dispersed across the political spectrum. The tax code has been tweaked 4,428 times in the past 10 years, to the benefit of interests of left, right and center.'b'Others exercise their power transparently and democratically. Yet seniors use their voting power to protect programs that redistribute even more money from the young to the old and affluent.'b'You would think that liberals would have a special incentive to root out rent-seeking. Yet this has not been a major priority. There is no Steve Jobs figure in American liberalism insisting that the designers keep government simple, elegant and user-friendly. Sailors scrub their ships. Farmers clear weeds. Democrats have not spent a lot of time scraping barnacles off the state.'b'Worse, in an attempt to match Republican rhetoric, Democratic politicians are perpetually soiling the name of government for the sake of short-term gain. No one will believe in the instrument they rely on for solutions.'b'Today, I\xe2\x80\x99m going to say some nice things about BP and some not so nice things about the lawyers who are suing BP. Please don\xe2\x80\x99t spill your coffee.'b'As horrific as 'b'the Deepwater Horizon accident'b' was in April 2010 \xe2\x80\x94 killing 11 rig employees, while 'b'pouring millions of gallons of oil'b' into the Gulf of Mexico \xe2\x80\x94 BP has performed quite admirably in its aftermath. It has spared no expense in cleaning up the oil. 'b'It has set aside $1 billion'b' to restore the environment and coastal ecosystem. It underwrote an advertising campaign to lure tourists back to the Gulf Coast. Today, less than two years after the spill, the beaches are sparkling, most fishermen are working and many of the hotels are full.'b'At the urging of President Obama, BP also agreed to 'b'set up a $20 billion fund'b' to compensate anyone who could show that they\xe2\x80\x99d been economically harmed by the accident. Ken Feinberg, the former administrator of the Sept. 11 victim compensation fund, was put in charge of the 'b'Gulf Coast Claims Facility'b', as it was named. Feinberg has since paid out $6.3 billion to nearly 200,000 claimants. 'b'Daniel Becnel'b', a lawyer who has settled thousands of claims, says that his clients often receive more money from Feinberg than they would have if they had gone to court. \xe2\x80\x9cYou couldn\xe2\x80\x99t have done a better job than Feinberg did,\xe2\x80\x9d says Becnel.'b'To put it another way, the Gulf Coast Claims Facility has been a remarkably effective alternative to the cumbersome way damages are usually meted out after a corporate accident: through the tort system. Compare it, for instance, with 'b'the 1989 Exxon Valdez disaster'b' in Alaska, which took nearly two decades of court battles for the plaintiffs to finally get around $1.3 billion.'b'Indeed, the whole point of the Gulf Coast fund is to keep cases out of court; in return for compensation, the claimants have to agree not to sue for further damages. There is much that is right with this approach. Victims don\xe2\x80\x99t have to wait years \xe2\x80\x94 or decades \xe2\x80\x94 to get their money. The uncertainty of litigation is eliminated. The victims get monetary damages, just as they would if they won a court case, but without the expense of a lawsuit. They also pay less in legal fees. And if they don\xe2\x80\x99t like what is being offered, well, they can still sue. It is, as they say, a win-win.'b'Except, it turns out, for a certain group of plaintiffs\xe2\x80\x99 lawyers who, despite the relative ease of using the claims facility, is insisting on pursuing litigation against BP. They say they have more than 100,000 cases, though none are for big money, like the injured workers\xe2\x80\x99 cases; Feinberg has even settled most of those. For months, these lawyers have been preparing for a \xe2\x80\x9c'b'liability trial'b',\xe2\x80\x9d currently set for late February.'b'However that trial turns out, it\xe2\x80\x99s largely pointless: BP has already conceded liability, which it has backed with $20 billion. The lawyers\xe2\x80\x99 motive can\xe2\x80\x99t be to get more money than that; it\xe2\x80\x99s far more than any court would ever award. Punitive damages can\xe2\x80\x99t be the reason either: federal law prevents most of the claimants from getting punitive damages. No, there is only one reason this litigation is taking place. The lawyers want the kind of big fees that only come with big lawsuits. Yet Feinberg\xe2\x80\x99s approach is proving so popular with claimants that many of their cases are evaporating.'b'So here\xe2\x80\x99s what they did. The judge, Carl Barbier \xe2\x80\x94 a former plaintiffs\xe2\x80\x99 lawyer himself \xe2\x80\x94 agreed to do so without even holding a hearing. Eventually, some or all of that reserve would be used to pay the lawyers. That\xe2\x80\x99s right: They are trying to 'b'grab fees from clients'b' they\xe2\x80\x99ve never represented. Amazing. (Judge Barbier 'b'recently backed away a bit'b' from his ruling and is allowing both sides to file briefs that are due on Thursday.)'b'When I asked how they could possibly justify this fee grab, I was told that their lawsuit was the main reason Feinberg was willing to be so generous with BP\xe2\x80\x99s money. But 'b'Tony Buzbee'b', another lawyer who has settled many claims through the fund, blew a gasket when I told him that. \xe2\x80\x9cThey have not done one thing so far that has benefited my clients,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cMy clients have chosen not to be a part of their litigation. Why in the world should they have to pay them?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s a good question. It has proved that it can compensate victims quickly and fairly without the ordeal and cost of litigation. But, for that to happen, it\xe2\x80\x99s not just companies that have to put aside their greed. So do the lawyers.'b'IN 2010, the Chicago Public Schools 'b'declined to hire'b' Darrell Langdon for a job as a boiler-room engineer, because he had been convicted of possessing a half-gram of cocaine in 1985, a felony for which he received probation. It didn\xe2\x80\x99t matter that Mr. Langdon, a single parent of two sons, had been clean since 1988 and hadn\xe2\x80\x99t run into further trouble with the law. In 1967, President Lyndon B. Johnson\xe2\x80\x99s Crime Commission found that about half of American males could expect to be arrested for a nontraffic offense some time in their lives, mostly in their late teens and early 20s. An 'b'article'b' just published in the journal Pediatrics shows how the arrest rate has grown \xe2\x80\x94 by age 23, 'b'30 percent'b' of Americans have been arrested, compared with 22 percent in 1967. The increase reflects in part the considerable growth in arrests for 'b'drug offenses'b' and domestic violence.'b'The impact of these arrests is felt for years. The ubiquity of criminal-background checks and the efficiency of information technology in maintaining those records and making them widely available, have meant that millions of Americans \xe2\x80\x94 even those who served probation or parole but were never incarcerated \xe2\x80\x94 continue to pay a price long after the crime. In November the American Bar Association 'b'released a database'b' identifying more than 38,000 punitive 'b'provisions'b' that apply to people convicted of crimes, pertaining to everything from public housing to welfare assistance to occupational licenses. Yet at the same time, there is a growing public interest in facilitating job opportunities for those who have stayed crime-free for a reasonable period of time. Holder Jr. urged state attorneys general to review laws and policies \xe2\x80\x9cto determine whether those that impose burdens on individuals convicted of crimes without increasing public safety should be eliminated.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'It is well established that the risk of recidivism drops steadily with time, but there is still the question of how long is long enough. By looking at data for more than 88,000 people who had their first arrest in New York State in 1980, and tracking their subsequent criminal histories over the next 25 years, we estimate the \xe2\x80\x9credemption time\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 the time it takes for an individual\xe2\x80\x99s likelihood of being arrested to be close to that of individuals with no criminal records \xe2\x80\x94 to be about 10 to 13 years. Such \xe2\x80\x9cforever rules\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 which fall heavily on minorities, who are particularly likely to be arrested \xe2\x80\x94 are inherently unfair.'b'We propose that the \xe2\x80\x9cforever rules\xe2\x80\x9d be replaced by rules that provide for the expiration of a criminal record. It only makes him look phony.'b'Most troubling was his attack on Jon Huntsman for working in the Obama administration as opposed to agitating for its overthrow. Huntsman signed on at the start, before Obama had shown what kind of leader he would be, and that\xe2\x80\x99s an inherently awful decision only if a president or anyone else from an opposing party is supposed to be denied cooperation automatically and deprived all benefit of the doubt.'b'Besides which, can\xe2\x80\x99t a person exert more influence on the inside than out? It\xe2\x80\x99s just plain hammy.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Harder for Americans to Rise From Economy\xe2\x80\x99s Lower Rungs'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (front page, Jan. 5):'b'America\xe2\x80\x99s stalled mobility is not only disheartening \xe2\x80\x94 it also challenges our sense of national identity and is a threat to economic prosperity.
