Candidates file dollar ranges rather than exact figures to the Federal Election Commission, and only some elect to make their tax returns public.'b'The Republican field is no historic anomaly. Some of our richest presidents were our earliest ones. When The Atlantic two years ago 'b'researched'b' presidents\xe2\x80\x99 wealth and adjusted their estimated net worth to 2010 dollars, it found that eight of the first 10 presidents were worth at least $20 million, and five of those men were worth more than $50 million, at least by the time they left office. George Washington led the pack, with $525 million, much of it courtesy of Martha, a widowed heiress.'b'In the second half of the 19th century, there was a stretch of presidents of humbler means, including Abraham Lincoln. But almost all 20th-century presidents were much richer than the average American.'b'Barack Obama didn\xe2\x80\x99t grow up well-off and remained relatively poor by presidential standards, but he and his wife reported a gross income of nearly $1 million in 2006 and had assets of between $2 million and $7.35 million by the end of 2007, when his presidential bid was under way. By then the Clintons were rich enough that Hillary, challenging Obama for the Democratic nomination, was able to lend her campaign $11 million of her own money.'b'The tens of millions it can take for a credible presidential primary campaign favors candidates with money, if only because they have the ability to abandon salaried jobs and stump. When Mike Huckabee 'b'begged off'b' the 2012 presidential race, a lack of accrued wealth was one reason.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf I run, I walk away from a pretty good income," he said, referring to his daily radio and weekly TV shows.'b'MORE important, candidates of means tend to have access to the sorts of rich people who can pump major money into super PACs. The principal one supporting Romney had already raised $12 million by last July.'b'Even many Congressional campaigns have grown drawn out and exorbitant. Is it any wonder, then, that Congress has become a wealthier club? As Eric Lichtblau 'b'reported'b' in The Times recently, the median net worth of a member of Congress appeared to be $913,000 in 2010 and had grown 15 percent over six years. The median net worth for all Americans was about $100,000 and had declined 8 percent.'b'There\xe2\x80\x99s no simple relationship between privilege and policy. The Roosevelts and Kennedys, both spectacularly rich families, produced leaders known for their populism and protection of the less fortunate. Nancy Pelosi, a staunch defender of government aid, is thought to be worth as much as $196 million. John Boehner? Just $1.8 million, according to figures from 2010.'b'Wealth in politics makes a certain sense. The same drive, vanity, accomplishment and ingenuity that fuel a successful political career often fuel high earnings beforehand. And those earnings in some instances win voters\xe2\x80\x99 confidence.'b'Paul Friedman, 32, an undecided voter who showed up at Romney\xe2\x80\x99s event in Columbia, said, \xe2\x80\x9cIf we\xe2\x80\x99re talking about jobs, and his businesses are successful, then maybe he\xe2\x80\x99d run the country in a way that brings jobs back.\xe2\x80\x9d That\xe2\x80\x99s Romney\xe2\x80\x99s pitch.'b'But he walks a tightrope, wanting to broadcast his success without seeming out of touch. A wealthy candidate\xe2\x80\x99s aides guard against tone-deaf admissions of privilege while opponents itch to pounce, as the first President Bush\xe2\x80\x99s did in 1992, when he seemed unfamiliar with a grocery store\xe2\x80\x99s electronic price scanner.'b'I doubt many politicians at that stage of the game are spending much time in the checkout line or know the price of milk without seeing it on a briefing paper. But the charade persists. The second President Bush learned from his father\xe2\x80\x99s mistakes and seemed to develop an entire folksy persona in response. He spent vacations clearing brush, and though done on a vast Texas ranch purchased with his considerable wealth, it yielded optics preferable to those of John Kerry windsurfing.'b'Romney recalls the Naugahyde chair in an office past and tweets about breakfast at Subway and a flight on Southwest Airlines. The state will have to help the counties develop the very different facilities and expertise for managing violent young offenders.'b'The California juvenile justice system has a long history of abuses. A 2004 court ruling that required the state to improve services and facilities pushed up costs. Beginning in 2007, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger began to downsize the system after the Legislature passed a law barring counties from sending nonviolent youths to state facilities. California did it the right way: providing generous financing to the counties for therapeutically based juvenile offender programs. Spending on the system has dropped by almost half, from nearly $500 million to about $245 million as crime rates dropped over all, and the state has cut its juvenile inmate population from about 10,000 in the mid-1990s to about 1,100 today.'b'Some supporters of the plan worry that certain counties may lack secure facilities to hold juveniles convicted of arson, robbery and other serious crimes and the therapeutic knowhow to succeed with these young people. Central Kitchen'b', the country\xe2\x80\x99s oldest community kitchen providing meals for the poor and homeless, has taken discarded food and marginalized people and found value in both. It\xe2\x80\x99s a nonprofit that gives new meaning to free enterprise.'b'What started with one refrigerator truck has grown into an organization that provides about 5,000 meals a day to homeless shelters, halfway houses and other sites in Washington. Half the staff members are ex-convicts, former addicts or onetime homeless people, who finished the group\xe2\x80\x99s training program and are now prized employees.'b'In 2008, as the economy slid into a downturn, the kitchen employed 60 people and its annual budget was $7.4 million. The kitchen sees itself as helping to carry on Martin Luther King Jr.\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'Poor People\xe2\x80\x99s Campaign'b' for economic justice, empowering the dispossessed and feeding the hungry, caring for the people in line while helping to shorten it. The kitchen provides sustenance, income, dignity and hope.'b'Washington'b'THE debate over how to handle Iran\xe2\x80\x99s nuclear program is notable for its gloom and doom. Many people assume that Israel must choose between letting Iran develop nuclear weapons or attacking before it gets the bomb. But this is a false choice. There is a third option: working toward a nuclear weapons-free zone in the Middle East. And it is more feasible than most assume.'b'Attacking Iran might set its nuclear program back a few years, but it will most likely encourage Iran to aggressively seek \xe2\x80\x94 and probably develop \xe2\x80\x94 nuclear weapons. Slowing Iran down has some value, but the costs are high and the risks even greater. Iran would almost certainly retaliate, leading to all-out war at a time when Israel is still at odds with various Arab countries, and its relations with Turkey are tense.'b'Many hawks who argue for war believe that Iran poses an \xe2\x80\x9cexistential threat\xe2\x80\x9d to Israel. They assume Iran is insensitive to the logic of nuclear deterrence and would be prepared to use nuclear weapons without fear of the consequences (which could include killing millions of Palestinians and the loss of millions of Iranian civilians from an inevitable Israeli retaliation). And even if Israel strikes, Iran is still likely to acquire nuclear weapons eventually and would then be even more inclined to use them.'b'Despite all the talk of an \xe2\x80\x9cexistential threat,\xe2\x80\x9d less than half of Israelis support a strike on Iran. According to our 'b'November poll,'b' carried out in cooperation with the Dahaf Institute in Israel, only 43 percent of Israeli Jews support a military strike on Iran \xe2\x80\x94 even though 90 percent of them think that Iran will eventually acquire nuclear weapons.'b'Most important, when asked whether it would be better for both Israel and Iran to have the bomb, or for neither to have it, 65 percent of Israeli Jews said neither. And a remarkable 64 percent favored the idea of a nuclear-free zone, even when it was explained that this would mean Israel giving up its nuclear weapons.'b'The Israeli public also seems willing to move away from a secretive nuclear policy toward greater openness about Israel\xe2\x80\x99s nuclear facilities. Sixty percent of respondents favored \xe2\x80\x9ca system of full international inspections\xe2\x80\x9d of all nuclear facilities, including Israel\xe2\x80\x99s and Iran\xe2\x80\x99s, as a step toward regional disarmament.'b'If Israel\xe2\x80\x99s nuclear program were to become part of the equation, it would be a game-changer. Iran has until now effectively accused the West of employing a double standard because it does not demand Israeli disarmament, earning it many fans across the Arab world.'b'And a nuclear-free zone may be hard for Iran to refuse. Iranian diplomats have said they would be open to an intrusive role for the United Nations if it accepted Iran\xe2\x80\x99s right to enrich uranium for energy production \xe2\x80\x94 not to the higher levels necessary for weapons. And 'b'a 2007 poll'b' by the Program on International Policy Attitudes found that the Iranian people would favor such a deal.'b'We cannot take what Iranian officials say at face value, but an international push for a nuclear-free Middle East would publicly test them. And most Arab leaders would rather not start down the nuclear path \xe2\x80\x94 a real risk if Iran gets the bomb \xe2\x80\x94 and have therefore welcomed the proposal of a nuclear-free zone.'b'Some Israeli officials may also take the idea seriously. As Avner Cohen\xe2\x80\x99s recent book \xe2\x80\x9cThe Worst-Kept Secret\xe2\x80\x9d shows, Israel\xe2\x80\x99s policy of \xe2\x80\x9copacity\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 not acknowledging having nuclear weapons while letting everyone know it does \xe2\x80\x94 has existed since 1969, but is now becoming outdated. Indeed, no one outside Israel today sees any ambiguity about the fact that Israel possesses a large nuclear arsenal.'b'Although Israeli leaders have in the past expressed openness to the idea of a nuclear-free zone, they have always insisted that there must first be peace between Israel and its neighbors.'b'But the stalemate with Iran could actually delay or prevent peace in the region. As the former Israeli spy chief, Meir Dagan, argued earlier this month, Israel\xe2\x80\x99s current stance might actually accelerate Iran\xe2\x80\x99s quest for nuclear weapons and encourage Arab states to follow suit. Moreover, talk of an \xe2\x80\x9cexistential threat\xe2\x80\x9d projects Israel as weak, hurts its morale, and reduces its foreign policy options. This helps explain why three leading Israeli security experts \xe2\x80\x94 the Mossad chief, Tamir Pardo, a former Mossad chief, Efraim Halevy, and a former military chief of staff, Dan Halutz \xe2\x80\x94 all recently declared that a nuclear Iran would not pose an existential threat to Israel.'b'While full elimination of nuclear weapons is improbable without peace, starting the inevitably long and arduous process of negotiations toward that end is vital.'b'Given that Israelis overwhelmingly believe that Iran is on its way to acquiring nuclear weapons and several security experts have begun to question current policy, there is now an opportunity for a genuine debate on the real choices: relying on cold-war-style \xe2\x80\x9cmutual assured destruction\xe2\x80\x9d once Iran develops nuclear weapons or pursuing a path toward a nuclear-weapons-free Middle East, with a chance that Iran \xe2\x80\x94 and Arabs \xe2\x80\x94 will never develop the bomb at all.'b'There should be no illusions that successfully negotiating a path toward regional nuclear disarmament will be easy. But the mere conversation could transform a debate that at present is stuck between two undesirable options: an Iranian bomb or war.'b'Cambridge, Mass.'b'AMERICA remembers the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. as a national champion of civil rights. But he was an international icon, too \xe2\x80\x94 and like many icons, his legacy was used for a range of purposes that moved far beyond, and even ran counter to, his famous dream.'b'Indeed, it was King\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI have a dream\xe2\x80\x9d'b' speech that sealed his global fame. We\xe2\x80\x99ve all seen photos of the hundreds of thousands marching in 1963 Washington. But thousands also marched that day in London, Tel Aviv and Accra, Ghana.'b'In my home country, Britain, support for the march was overwhelming. Many watched King\xe2\x80\x99s speech live via the newly launched Telstar satellite. In London, demonstrators marched to the American Embassy carrying a banner that read, \xe2\x80\x9cYour fight is our fight.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This was more than just an expression of empathy: that summer, Paul Stephenson, a black community organizer in Bristol, led a boycott of the city\xe2\x80\x99s buses. A charismatic and gifted orator, Mr. Stephenson had been to the Deep South to learn tactics and spoke reverently of King\xe2\x80\x99s Montgomery Bus Boycott.'b'King visited Britain the following year. He accepted invitations abroad, his speechwriter Clarence Jones told me recently, \xe2\x80\x9cto get his message out.\xe2\x80\x9d It seemed to work. King\xe2\x80\x99s sermon at St. Paul\xe2\x80\x99s Cathedral was front-page news in the United States, while his meeting with activists led to the formation of the Campaign Against Racial Discrimination, the pre-eminent anti-discrimination group in Britain, fashioned on King\xe2\x80\x99s nonviolent, pro-integration model.'b'Meanwhile, British liberals looked to the American movement as a template for resolving Britain\xe2\x80\x99s immigrant problems. Politicians seeking to introduce civil rights legislation met with King in Britain and traveled to the United States on fact-finding visits. (King wasn\xe2\x80\x99t alone: in 1967 the archbishop of Canterbury even invited the Temptations, in London on tour, to drop into Lambeth Palace so he could get some advice on race relations.)'b'But even as King sought to get his message out, the watching world repackaged that message for other purposes. Mr. Stephenson\xe2\x80\x99s bus boycott was actually a strike by drivers seeking better working conditions rather than a copy of Montgomery\xe2\x80\x99s passenger boycott, and the timing had more to do with the visit of the touring West Indies cricket team than with King\xe2\x80\x99s efforts in Alabama eight years previously.'b'Meanwhile, Communist governments in Eastern Europe celebrated King as the champion of the \xe2\x80\x9cother America,\xe2\x80\x9d the America that had been subjugated by capitalist tyranny. In Italy, the Catholic left portrayed him as a political activist and ignored the fact that he was also a Protestant preacher.'b'And in white-majority countries with racial minorities, from New Zealand to Western Europe, commentators lauded King\xe2\x80\x99s role in the turmoil \xe2\x80\x9cover there,\xe2\x80\x9d while taking comfort that any problems at home, by comparison, could not be too bad. Conservative politicians in Britain hailed King as a nonviolent role model for immigrants who were threatening to fight for their rights (and much better than another popular black American icon and visitor to Britain, Malcolm X).'b'Today, King\xe2\x80\x99s legacy abroad remains profound, and as contested as ever. In Britain, his statue stands above the west entrance to Westminster Abbey, while the American civil rights movement is among the top five most popular history subjects in high schools.'b'But absent from Westminster is a statue of a black British figure, and black British history remains on the sidelines at schools and universities. Looking to King helps us think about racial justice, but he can be used to forget about it, too.'b'Using and abusing King is perhaps inevitable abroad, where he was so well publicized but little understood. Yet it has echoes here in the United States, where he should be known best. Since moving to America this past summer, I have heard the man who marched for jobs and freedom invoked by all sides of the political spectrum. African-American activists seek to honor his legacy by calling for race-based remedies to combat stubborn racial inequality. Conservatives invoke his color-blind ideology to remove those same race-based remedies.'b'At the 'b'dedication of the King memorial'b' on the National Mall last fall, President Obama even used King\xe2\x80\x99s teachings to challenge the current polarization of politics: \xe2\x80\x9cHe calls on us to stand in the other person\xe2\x80\x99s shoes, to see through their eyes, to understand their pain.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'As King calls on us today, everyone, it seems, can call on him.'b'Is 'b'Section 5 of the Voting Rights Act'b' still necessary? That provision requires nine states and some counties and towns with histories of severe racial discrimination to get approval from the Justice Department or a court before changing their voting procedures. The question hovers over 'b'three consolidated cases'b' the Supreme Court 'b'heard'b' last week on redistricting for legislative and Congressional seats in Texas, a state governed by Section 5.'b'The cases involve two sets of redistricting maps. One was drawn by the Republican-controlled Legislature. It starkly favored Republicans, even though population growth came from new Hispanic residents, who tend to vote Democratic. Hispanic residents sued, and a federal court in San Antonio drew a second set of maps that created new districts where minorities would be the majority.'b'The procedural issue is whether the San Antonio court\xe2\x80\x99s maps should be used for the state\xe2\x80\x99s April primary if the Texas Legislature does not get approval for its maps from a special court in Washington, or whether Texas can use its maps even without that approval.'b'Although Texas has not raised the constitutionality of Section 5, the facts of these cases help explain why the section is crucial and why the justices must rule in a way that preserves its shield against discrimination. Justice Sonia Sotomayor said last week, \xe2\x80\x9cSection 5 says you can\xe2\x80\x99t draw new maps unless they have been precleared.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Without the Section 5 requirement, the Legislature\xe2\x80\x99s maps would have gone into effect immediately. The burden would have been on challengers to prove the maps were unacceptable. When Congress debated reauthorization of the statute in 2006, Republicans contended that Section 5 had served its purpose and that states covered by it should no longer have to prove their good intentions.'b'Democrats prevailed by gathering an enormous amount of 'b'evidence 'b'of continuing discrimination in proposed voting changes, particularly in Alabama, Mississippi, South Carolina and Texas, all states covered by Section 5. Congress reauthorized Section 5 because it saw the risk that many states would try to circumvent the Voting Rights Act. It concluded that discrimination in voter registration and voting and the dilution of minority votes can still be prevented only through the preclearance process and that there would be more discriminatory efforts without the law\xe2\x80\x99s deterrent force.'b'In 15 states, cutbacks in the voting rights of young and poor voters as well as minorities have been turned into law. That doesn\xe2\x80\x99t count contested discriminatory redistricting by Texas and other states. In breaching the right to vote, these efforts violate the fundamental civil right. They underscore a continuing need for Section 5.'b'Queens has been harder hit by foreclosures than any other New York borough, and the Federal Bureau of Investigation believes it has found a culprit. Last July, the F.B.I. accused Edul Ahmad, a local broker, of a $50 million mortgage fraud, saying he lured fellow immigrants into subprime mortgages, inflated the values of their properties and concealed his involvement in deals that were ruinous for scores, if not hundreds, of borrowers. Mr. Ahmad pleaded not guilty, and posted $2.5 million bail. Now, according to court papers, as 'b'reported'b' in The Times, he is plea-bargaining with federal prosecutors.'b'Whatever Mr. Ahmad did or did not do, one thing is sure: he did not act alone. The attention Mr. Ahmad has drawn highlights the relative lack of scrutiny of the big banks and their senior executives. Big banks created demand and provided credit for dubious mortgage loans, which they bundled into securities and sold to investors. If not for reckless lending and heedless securitizing, there would have been no mortgage bubble and no mortgage bust \xe2\x80\x94 and, in all probability, no Edul Ahmad.'b'There have been some prominent civil suits with settlements and fines, including the $550 million deal between Goldman Sachs and the Securities and Exchange Commission over the misleading of investors in a mortgage-backed investment. He should form an interagency task force to investigate and pursue potential civil and criminal wrongdoing by institutions and people whose conduct in the mortgage chain had the greatest economic impact.'b'That would mean focusing on the large banks and their top echelons. The investigators would need to include the departments of Justice and Housing and Urban Development, the S.E.C. and the Internal Revenue Service, as well as bank regulators, with the formal co-operation of the most aggressive state attorneys general. The task force would need a leader with the impulses of a crusading prosecutor.'b'The investigations to date have not had this character. The Goldman Sachs settlement, for instance, was over one security and put the blame on a midlevel banker. When executives have been personally penalized, the fines have been a fraction of the wealth they amassed during the bubble. From 2000 to 2008, Angelo Mozilo, the chief executive of Countrywide, received total compensation estimated at $521.5 million; in 2010, without admitting or denying any wrongdoing, he paid $67.5 million to settle civil fraud charges brought by the S.E.C. The Justice Department, for its part, decided not to pursue a possible criminal case against Mr. Mozilo.'b'Lawsuits by state attorneys general, notably in 'b'Massachusetts'b' and 'b'Nevada'b', may ultimately prove more revealing and helpful to wronged homeowners, because they tend to focus on foreclosure abuses by banks. New York\xe2\x80\x99s attorney general, Eric Schneiderman, is building a comprehensive investigation of the mortgage chain from the origination and securitization of loans to banks\xe2\x80\x99 foreclosure practices. That may lead to more actors in the system being held accountable for creating the mortgage crisis. Mr. Ahmad is accused of swindling na\xc3\xafve borrowers in Queens. There is more to the mortgage mess than that.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI have a dream,\xe2\x80\x9d declared Martin Luther King, in a speech that has lost none of its power to inspire. And some of that dream has come true. When King spoke in the summer of 1963, America was a nation that denied basic rights to millions of its citizens, simply because their skin was the wrong color. Today racism is no longer embedded in law. And while it has by no means been banished from the hearts of men, its grip is far weaker than once it was.'b'To say the obvious: to look at a 'b'photo'b' of President Obama with his cabinet is to see a degree of racial openness \xe2\x80\x94 and openness to women, too \xe2\x80\x94 that would have seemed almost inconceivable in 1963. When we observe Martin Luther King\xe2\x80\x99s Birthday, we have something very real to celebrate: the civil rights movement was one of America\xe2\x80\x99s finest hours, and it made us a nation truer to its own ideals.'b'Yet if King could see America now, I believe that he would be disappointed, and feel that his work was nowhere near done. He dreamed of a nation in which his children \xe2\x80\x9cwill not be judged by the color of their skin but by the content of their character.\xe2\x80\x9d But what we actually became is a nation that judges people not by the color of their skin \xe2\x80\x94 or at least not as much as in the past \xe2\x80\x94 but by the size of their paychecks. And in America, more than in most other wealthy nations, the size of your paycheck is strongly correlated with the size of your father\xe2\x80\x99s paycheck.'b'Goodbye Jim Crow, hello class system.'b'Economic inequality isn\xe2\x80\x99t inherently a racial issue, and rising inequality would be disturbing even if there weren\xe2\x80\x99t a racial dimension. But American society being what it is, there are racial implications to the way our incomes have been pulling apart. And in any case, King \xe2\x80\x94 who was campaigning for higher wages when he was assassinated \xe2\x80\x94 would surely have considered soaring inequality an evil to be opposed.'b'So, about that racial dimension: In the 1960s it was widely assumed that ending overt discrimination would improve the economic as well as legal status of minority groups. And at first this seemed to be happening. Over the course of the 1960s and 1970s substantial numbers of black families moved into the middle class, and even into the upper middle class; the percentage of black households in the top 20 percent of the income distribution nearly doubled.'b'But around 1980 the relative economic position of blacks in America stopped improving. Why? An important part of the answer, surely, is that circa 1980 income disparities in the United States began to widen dramatically, turning us into a society more unequal than at any time since the 1920s.'b'Think of the income distribution as a ladder, with different people on different rungs. Starting around 1980, the rungs began moving ever farther apart, adversely affecting black economic progress in two ways. First, because many blacks were still on the lower rungs, they were left behind as income at the top of the ladder soared while income near the bottom stagnated. Second, as the rungs moved farther apart, the ladder became harder to climb.'b'The Times recently 'b'reported'b' on a well-established finding that still surprises many Americans when they hear about it: although we still see ourselves as the land of opportunity, we actually have less intergenerational economic mobility than other advanced nations. That is, the chances that someone born into a low-income family will end up with high income, or vice versa, are significantly lower here than in Canada or Europe.'b'And there\xe2\x80\x99s every reason to believe that our low economic mobility has a lot to do with our high level of income inequality.'b'Last week Alan Krueger, chairman of the president\xe2\x80\x99s Council of Economic Advisers, gave an important speech about income inequality, presenting a relationship he dubbed the \xe2\x80\x9cGreat Gatsby Curve.\xe2\x80\x9d Highly unequal countries, he showed, have low mobility: the more unequal a society is, the greater the extent to which an individual\xe2\x80\x99s economic status is determined by his or her parents\xe2\x80\x99 status. And as Mr. Krueger pointed out, this relationship suggests that America in the year 2035 will have even less mobility than it has now, that it will be a place in which the economic prospects of children largely reflect the class into which they were born.'b'That is not a development we should meekly accept.'b'Mitt Romney says that we should discuss income inequality, if at all, only in \xe2\x80\x9cquiet rooms.\xe2\x80\x9d There was a time when people said the same thing about racial inequality. Luckily, however, there were people like Martin Luther King who refused to stay quiet. And we should follow their example today. For the fact is that rising inequality threatens to make America a different and worse place \xe2\x80\x94 and we need to reverse that trend to preserve both our values and our dreams.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Big Study Links Good Teachers to Lasting Gain'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (front page, Jan. 6):'b'This'b' study'b' reiterates what others have found before it: teacher effectiveness, which can be partly evaluated using test score data, has the power to affect the futures of innumerable students, for better or worse. Overnight, the government had removed what it called the subsidy on fuel, and almost immediately, transport fares exploded and food prices rose astronomically. It used to cost 4,000 naira \xe2\x80\x94 about $25 \xe2\x80\x94 to fill my petrol tank. Then it cost 10,000 naira. When I stopped to buy okpa, a steam-cooked bean dish, from a street hawker, she said it was no longer 50 naira; it was now 100.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBecause of fuel subsidy.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'A relative who had traveled to her village for the holidays called me to say that she was stranded there, unable to return to her job in Lagos; she could not afford the bus fare, which had doubled in price.'b'Nigeria, one of the world\xe2\x80\x99s biggest exporters of crude oil, does not have adequate refineries and so it imports most of its petrol. The government claims that it pays a subsidy to importers to keep the prices low, and that these companies defraud the government by inflating their costs. Perhaps that is true, but it is a strange reason for raising prices, as though the government is incapable of policing fraud. Politicians have long discussed ending the subsidy, but no one expected it to happen when and how it did. There was something frightening about the abruptness of such a dramatic change, a sense of lurching, a violent uncertainty that captured the general mood in Nigeria.'b'Nigerians, particularly in the heavily Muslim north, live in fear of violence from the 'b'Islamist group Boko Haram'b'. More than a hundred people have been shot to death or killed in bombings in recent weeks. My uncle, who lived most of his adult life in the northern town of Maiduguri, recently moved back east after a Boko Haram bomb exploded mere feet from his bookshop. Now he is struggling to start over, a man past middle age, grasping for hope. I saw him on New Year\xe2\x80\x99s Day. He said he had only barely been able to afford the rent for a new shop in Awka, our state capital, and now he had to deal with the new price of petrol \xe2\x80\x94 he will have to spend much more on transportation and, since there is hardly ever any electricity, on the generator to power his shop. \xe2\x80\x9cHow will I cope?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.'b'Many government officials argued that the price increase would eventually benefit Nigerians, but they were unable to clearly articulate how. They made economic arguments that were abstract at best and nonsensical at worst. Sometimes the arguments conflicted: on one hand, we were told that the government would go bankrupt if it continued to pay the subsidy, and on the other, we were told that the subsidy would still be spent, this time on \xe2\x80\x9cinfrastructure,\xe2\x80\x9d a vague word if ever there was one. Only yesterday, the government announced it would restore some part of the subsidy.'b'Like many Nigerians, I am infuriated \xe2\x80\x94 and puzzled \xe2\x80\x94 by the actions of a government that appears to be indifferent to if not contemptuous of its people. The idea that in a democracy, the government needs to persuade the majority of its citizens, eludes our leaders, perhaps because of the stubborn legacy of military rule, which ended only in 1998. We civilians, in turn, deeply distrust the government, because of our long experience with corrupt leaders. It is obvious that this price increase, the abruptness of it, the murky justifications for it, the government\xe2\x80\x99s inability to properly engage about it, the destructive consequences it will have for millions in a country where there are few government services, will only further calcify the cynicism of a people who are already very cynical. Yet our leaders did it anyway. The message sent to Nigerians is this: You don\xe2\x80\x99t matter. We don\xe2\x80\x99t value you.'b'Economic arguments are useful, but so are human arguments, which seem alarmingly lost on the Nigerian government. Prices have gone up but salaries remain the same. But businesses are not covered, and small companies are especially vulnerable because they move more cash around than individuals and cannot afford high-technology defenses.'b'New malware has been designed to get around the security fixes of recent years. It undercuts the power of the urban districts where the inmates actually live and where they generally return when they are released.'b'There are about 1.5 million people in prison nationally. Prison-based gerrymandering can easily be used to unfairly shift power from one part of a state to another. In Maryland, this gerrymandering distorted the political landscape. In one county commission district, for example, inmates made up 64 percent of the population. In one state legislative district, nearly a fifth of the population were inmates.'b'The state law was explicitly drafted to advance the interests of minority citizens, who are disproportionately represented among inmates and who stand to lose most when political power is shifted away from their home districts. A small group of voters challenged the law, arguing, in essence, that it was illegal for the state to correct for prisoner-related population distortions.'b'The court rightly dismissed this argument, adding that the state was within its rights to adjust census data for redistricting purposes. This sound ruling should encourage more states to join Maryland, New York, Delaware and California in adopting similar anti-gerrymandering laws.'b'What if 'b'Jamie Dimon'b' is right?'b'What if the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase is not just blowing smoke when he complains that the country \xe2\x80\x94 and, indeed, the world \xe2\x80\x94 has imposed so many new rules on the banking industry, some of them overlapping, others seeming to contradict each other, yet others whose sole purpose seems to be to weigh down the industry, that they threaten to do as much harm as good? Last summer, you\xe2\x80\x99ll recall, Dimon confronted Ben Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, at a conference 'b'and asked him'b': \xe2\x80\x9cHas anyone bothered to study the cumulative effect of these things?\xe2\x80\x9d Just last week, during JPMorgan\xe2\x80\x99s earnings call with analysts, Dimon complained that Europe\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cregulatory policy, government policy, central bank policy \xe2\x80\x94 it\xe2\x80\x99s not coordinated. It\xe2\x80\x99s making the situation worse, not better.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Like most nonbankers, I\xe2\x80\x99ve tended to roll my eyes at Dimon\xe2\x80\x99s continuous lamentations. Surely, given all the harm the banks did to the country, regulations aimed at preventing a repeat of the financial crisis struck me as being worth whatever cost they imposed on the industry. And, yes, I admit to a little schadenfreude as well. (To be fair to Dimon, he is not completely opposed to all the new regulations. He just comes across that way when he\xe2\x80\x99s in rant mode.)'b'What has caught me up short recently is the emergence of a new critic of the banking regulations that have been pouring forth from Washington and Europe. Her name is Karen Petrou, and she is the managing partner of 'b'Federal Financial Analytics'b', a consulting firm that, among other things, analyzes bank regulations for clients.'b'Unlike many in the banking industry, Petrou is not ideologically opposed to regulation. For instance, she was a critic of the lack of regulation that allowed so many sleazy subprime mortgage originators to emerge from the precrisis ooze. Yet, now, she\xe2\x80\x99s worried about something different: that the hundreds of new mandates required by the Dodd-Frank law are creating a new kind of risk. She calls it \xe2\x80\x9ccomplexity risk.\xe2\x80\x9d As she put it in a speech she delivered last week in New York: \xe2\x80\x9cIf we don\xe2\x80\x99t understand the cross-cutting effects and inherent contradictions in all of the stringent standards now being written into final form, we risk doing real damage to the sound, stable and \xe2\x80\x94 yes \xe2\x80\x94 profitable financial industry regulators say they support and the economies sorely need.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In 'b'a paper she wrote'b' in November, Petrou laid out a number of examples of new regulatory proposals that were either mind-bogglingly complex or contradictory \xe2\x80\x94 or both. For instance, she told me recently, bank board directors will have 184 more things they will have to acknowledge responsibility for under the latest systemic standards. \xe2\x80\x9cI think boards have to be responsible for what happens at their institutions,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cbut requiring them to be on the front lines of forward-looking cash flow is ridiculous.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'She also points to a contradiction in the way the Too Big to Fail institutions are being dealt with. On the one hand, Dodd-Frank is very clear that if a big bank becomes insolvent, there can be no taxpayer bailout. It must be wound down, just like any other bank. Yet, at the same time, she says, the federal and international regulators are adding a host of special Too Big to Fail capital requirements and rules. \xe2\x80\x9cThey are acting as if these institutions are still too big to fail. The two thrusts are incompatible.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Why does complexity risk matter? One reason is that the more complex the rules are, the greater the likelihood that smart bankers will find ways to game them. Another is that contradictory regulations, however well meaning, simply don\xe2\x80\x99t make the system safer. But the most important reason is that complexity risk is having an effect on business \xe2\x80\x94 and that\xe2\x80\x99s not helping the still-fragile economy.'b'Petrou says that in her own practice she has seen deals fall through \xe2\x80\x94 especially in the mortgage industry \xe2\x80\x94 because nobody can figure out how the new rules will be applied. Given how badly the country needs a revived housing industry, this is nothing short of tragic.'b'In her paper, Petrou offers a series of solutions, revolving around simpler regulations, a reliance on market discipline and transparency. She also calls for the regulators themselves to be held accountable, something that is nowhere to be found in Dodd-Frank, despite their obvious shortcomings in the years leading to the financial crisis.'b'However you feel about banks \xe2\x80\x94 and I know that many people harbor enormous, justifiable anger at what they did \xe2\x80\x94 our economy can\xe2\x80\x99t function without them. And they needed to be regulated. But three years ago, overly complex securities were one of the root causes of the crisis. So why, then, do we have faith that overly complex regulations will prevent the next crisis? Sad but true: they won\xe2\x80\x99t.'b'Sumter, S.C.'b'When I started covering presidential primaries, the best part was getting to know the candidates. We journalists would ride around in vans and buses with them and get an intimate look at what it\xe2\x80\x99s like to endure this soul-destroying process. But the ubiquity of Web cams and tweets has ended that off-the-record culture. As the technology gets more open, the lines of political communications become more closed.'b'Now the best part is meeting the people who come to the rallies. It\xe2\x80\x99s best to get to the events an hour early and treat the waiting crowd like a cocktail party. First, you ask people about the local economy. Then you ask them about their lives (about which they are always interesting). Then you ask them about what they think of the issues and candidates (they generally repeat the banalities they have heard one of us pundits utter on TV the day before).'b'This past weekend in South Carolina I met, among many others, a soldier leaving for Afghanistan who quoted the Book of Revelation from his iPhone, a Vietnam veteran who movingly described the death of his first wife, a textile factory middle manager whose job got sent to El Salvador and a pawnshop manager who supports Ron Paul and said he has clients who buy a new gun every time the government does something they don\xe2\x80\x99t like.'b'I came here wondering how voters would react to the charge that Mitt Romney was a corporate vulture when he ran the private equity firm Bain Capital. I asked dozens of people. They were all familiar with the attacks, thanks to the TV ads. Almost everybody thought the charges were ridiculous, even supporters of Newt Gingrich.'b'A realtor looked at me dismissively: Sometimes deals work, he said, sometimes they don\xe2\x80\x99t. You have to be efficient to survive. That\xe2\x80\x99s the way capitalism works. Romney\xe2\x80\x99s opponents probably would have been smarter to hit him for being a flip-flopper, not a businessman.'b'I was also struck, as in New Hampshire and Iowa, by the mood of this year\xe2\x80\x99s rallies. Republican audiences this year want a restoration. America once had strong values, they believe, but we have gone astray. We\xe2\x80\x99ve got to go back and rediscover what we had. Heads nod enthusiastically every time a candidate touches this theme.'b'I agree with the sentiment, but it makes for an incredibly backward-looking campaign. I sometimes wonder if the Republican Party has become the receding roar of white America as it pines for a way of life that will never return.'b'The other pleasure of covering campaigns is getting to play American Idol judge, evaluating the political performances.'b'Mitt Romney is never going to be confused for Pericles on the stump. Every sigh and utterance is prescripted, so watching his rallies is like watching the 19,000th performance of the road show of \xe2\x80\x9cCats.\xe2\x80\x9d And he has terrible reaction responses. When somebody else is talking and he means to show agreement, he mugs like someone from a bad silent movie. His wife, Ann, is much warmer and more natural on stage.'b'But Romney\xe2\x80\x99s awkwardness seems to endear him to audiences, because he\xe2\x80\x99s trying so hard. He spends an enormous amount of time after the speeches shaking hands, taking pictures and holding babies. Beads of sweat form on his forehead as he throws himself graciously into the crowds. He also has a nice startle response. When something unexpected happens, his face lights up and you get a burst of happy humanity out of him.'b'Newt Gingrich\xe2\x80\x99s presentations are forceful. He has a genius for pithy formulations and a consistent theme: The solutions to everything are obvious if only the idiots would get out of my way.'b'Ron Paul\xe2\x80\x99s supporters are so grateful. The world was once confusing, but then they read \xe2\x80\x9cEnd the Fed\xe2\x80\x9d and the scales fell from their eyes. Paul himself is fascinating because as some smart person observed (I\xe2\x80\x99ve forgotten who), he thinks serially, not causally. The income tax happened 'b'and'b' the Patriot Act happened 'b'and'b' the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben Bernanke, bailed out the banks 'b'and'b' job growth stinks. Paul doesn\xe2\x80\x99t bother with logical links. He just strings events together and assumes causation.'b'I brought my 12-year-old son on this latest trip. My rule is that if a candidate can\xe2\x80\x99t relate well to a 12-year-old, they\xe2\x80\x99ll never win a general election. He approached all the candidates, and they were all wonderful except Gingrich. But that wasn\xe2\x80\x99t Gingrich\xe2\x80\x99s fault. My son, whose heroes include John Boehner and Tupac Shakur, picked an argument about gay marriage. Gingrich engaged, but after 10 seconds signaled security to brush my kid away.'b'Rick Perry ran a poor campaign but seems like the guy you\xe2\x80\x99d most want to have a beer with. He took the time to tell my son how important it is to study hard and prepare for whatever you do.'b'Dad really appreciated that one.'b'At debates his opponents sported ties with colors from the flag: blue or, better yet, blistering Republican red.'b'He wore pink.'b'Onstage and on the stump, they bashed Europe and threatened a trade war with China.'b'He burst spontaneously into Mandarin.'b'For a while Jon Huntsman was the brother from another Republican planet, one where climate change is likely and evolution inarguable. Where it isn\xe2\x80\x99t girlie Limbaugh bait to sit, as he did, for a 'b'Vogue profile'b' illustrated with Annie Leibovitz photographs. Where you don\xe2\x80\x99t have to malign the Democratic president as the devil incarnate \xe2\x80\x94 pitchfork, cloven hooves and all.'b'How alien and refreshing he was.'b'And how depressingly he snapped back into line on Monday, exiting the presidential race by surrendering to the earth\xe2\x80\x99s gravity and reverting to its familiar partisan cant.'b'In his 'b'withdrawal speech'b' in Myrtle Beach, S.C., he declared that the need to get rid of President Obama made this \xe2\x80\x9cthe most important election of our lifetime.\xe2\x80\x9d Not so long ago he worked for and 'b'praised'b' that selfsame president.'b'He said that the remaining candidate \xe2\x80\x9cbest equipped to defeat Barack Obama\xe2\x80\x9d was Mitt Romney \xe2\x80\x94 and endorsed him. Just last week, Romney was so \xe2\x80\x9cdetached from the problems that Americans are facing,\xe2\x80\x9d according to Huntsman, that he was \xe2\x80\x9ccompletely unelectable.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'He remarked on the country\xe2\x80\x99s need for \xe2\x80\x9cbold and principled leadership.\xe2\x80\x9d Note the \xe2\x80\x9cprincipled\xe2\x80\x9d part. And remember, as Huntsman tries to make you forget, that videos on his Web site and his YouTube channel variously labeled Romney a \xe2\x80\x9cpretzel candidate,\xe2\x80\x9d an expert at the \xe2\x80\x9cbackflip\xe2\x80\x9d and, most florid of all, \xe2\x80\x9ca perfectly lubricated weather vane.\xe2\x80\x9d That\xe2\x80\x99s one slippery inconstancy metaphor.'b'On Monday those videos were suddenly 'b'gone'b', as Michael D. Shear noted on The Times\xe2\x80\x99s political blog. And Huntsman\xe2\x80\x99s defeat was complete, not merely because he lost but because conventional politics \xe2\x80\x94 with all its compromises, hypocrisy and obeisance \xe2\x80\x94 won.'b'Of course former rivals morph into allies all the time. John McCain now makes goo-goo eyes at Romney. Hillary Clinton endures permanent jet lag for Obama.'b'But Huntsman\xe2\x80\x99s endorsement of Romney came much more quickly than it had to and in spite of a distaste for each other that\xe2\x80\x99s particularly intense.'b'Although both grew up wildly privileged, Romney sees Huntsman as someone who leaned too hard on his father, never forging his own private-sector success. And Huntsman\xe2\x80\x99s endorsement of McCain over him during the last Republican primary felt like a deliberate slap.'b'Huntsman 'b'by many accounts'b' seethed when Romney snagged, and benefited mightily from, a job that he was passed over for: the stewardship of the 2002 Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City. He squirmed as Romney tacked this way and that in politics. In Huntsman\xe2\x80\x99s eyes he\xe2\x80\x99s a rudderless operator.'b'And in recent weeks Huntsman finally said as much, though he had begun his campaign with a pledge to take the high road and though, on Monday, he implored the remaining Republican candidates to cease \xe2\x80\x9can onslaught of negative and personal attacks not worthy of the American people.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'With Romney, Huntsman had succumbed to the unworthy, getting negative and personal and excising all context in order to slam the front-runner 'b'for saying'b', \xe2\x80\x9cI like being able to fire people.\xe2\x80\x9d The high road dipped into the mud.'b'From the start, he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t find any traction. He arrived late to a patch of moderate turf already cordoned off by another Mormon scion with very good hair, a very blonde wife and a very large brood of absurdly attractive children. To watch footage and see photographs of the Huntsman girls and then the Romney boys was to enter some cyber-political version of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Brady Bunch.\xe2\x80\x9d The two clans together tipped into wholesomeness overload.'b'Huntsman initially ran to Romney\xe2\x80\x99s left, though he possessed the more consistently conservative record. Even when he pivoted and embraced that, he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t summon the gloom and invective that the anyone-but-Mitt crowd craved. He didn\xe2\x80\x99t have the spleen for it.'b'A sort of cool, bland reason oozed from him, and until the last two weeks a certain political expediency seemed beyond him. Then again his personality and past never got worked over by the Romney operation the way, say, Rick Perry\xe2\x80\x99s and Newt Gingrich\xe2\x80\x99s did. He who never surges never need be squashed.'b'Huntsman is unlikely to land on the 2012 ticket. Does he have 2016 in mind?'b'By getting out before a miserable showing in the South Carolina primary and the exodus of an additional candidate or two, he guaranteed himself more news coverage and a greater air of importance than he might have received afterward.'b'And by hopping without pause on the Romney bandwagon, he hastened his journey back from party outlier to dutiful soldier. Reflecting Monday on his campaign experience, he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI have seen the very best of America.\xe2\x80\x9d His voice wasn\xe2\x80\x99t persuasive.'b'His mood matched his tie. Both were blue.'b'Ballston Lake, N.Y.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTHE Adirondacks are preserved forever,\xe2\x80\x9d Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller famously boasted after passage of the Adirondack Park Agency ('b'A.P.A.'b') Land Use law of 1973. The A.P.A. law calls for precious natural resources of the park to be preserved and development of its private lands carefully planned to ensure compatibility with the adjacent, publicly owned Forest Preserve, which our state constitution says must be \xe2\x80\x9cforever wild.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Of course, nothing is preserved forever. Protective laws are not self-executing and require spirited people to apply and renew them. Rockefeller\xe2\x80\x99s agency did stand up for the law in the 1970s when massive second-home subdivisions with names like Horizon and Ton-Da-Lay planned for remote forests were stopped. In the late 1980s, Gov. 'b'Mario M. Cuomo'b'\xe2\x80\x99s A.P.A. prevented Patten Corporation from exploiting this magnificent mountain landscape \xe2\x80\x94 which is larger than the state of Massachusetts and larger than Yellowstone, Yosemite, Grand Canyon, Glacier and Olympic national parks combined \xe2\x80\x94 to make a fast buck.'b'Now comes a serious test for Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo. He, like his predecessors, says the park is a treasure that must be protected. His A.P.A. (the governor names the agency\xe2\x80\x99s chair, and all of its members are either gubernatorial nominations, requiring senate confirmation, or state agency appointments) has been handed the hearing record on the sprawling 'b'Adirondack Club and Resort'b', the largest second-home subdivision application that the A.P.A. has seen in 35 years. During the agency\xe2\x80\x99s January meeting, this Wednesday through Friday in Ray Brook, N.Y., the A.P.A. will decide whether to permit 706 residential units, 332 buildings and 15 miles of new roads, sewer, water and electrical lines spread over 6,235 forested acres with sensitive streams, ponds and wetlands on rugged terrain several miles from 'b'Tupper Lake'b' \xe2\x80\x94 in the very heart of the Adirondack Park.'b'If permitted, the project would stand the 39-year-old A.P.A. law on its head and establish a dangerous precedent for the park\xe2\x80\x99s fragile, remote backcountry. More than three-quarters of the project site lies within 'b'Resource Management'b' \xe2\x80\x94 under the law, the park\xe2\x80\x99s most protected private land zone \xe2\x80\x94 the legislative purpose of which is to \xe2\x80\x9cprotect the delicate physical and biological resources ... and preserve the open spaces that are essential and basic to the unique character of the park.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This project would spread 82 large second homes, including 39 so-called great camps, throughout this zone, with a serious impact on sensitive habitats and wildlife, essentially replacing local hunters and foresters with private driveways and \xe2\x80\x9cNo Trespassing\xe2\x80\x9d signs. A respected conservation biologist, Dr. Michael Klemens, testified at the public hearing last April that \xe2\x80\x9cthe club and resort is classic sprawl on steroids.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIt spreads negative ecological impacts out across the landscape,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is a train wreck resulting from a process that does not allow for understanding natural systems in the first place.\xe2\x80\x9d A smarter alternative, he said, would develop a complete understanding of the project site and only then plan houses in a more compact design that avoids sensitive areas.'b'In exchange for risking such damage to the Adirondacks, some might expect a tremendous economic return. Yet the applicants have no track record developing land or selling lots inside the Adirondack Park. Nor do they have the money to construct the project on their own. The county Industrial Development Agency is being asked for $36 million in private revenue bonds to fund the infrastructure.'b'During the hearing, the applicant\xe2\x80\x99s marketing and fiscal studies were shown to be incomplete, insubstantial and misleading. Evidence suggested that the resort\xe2\x80\x99s inflated sales projections are founded largely upon the speculative dreams of the applicant. One impartial expert in resort development, David Norden, said during the hearing last June that the market for such a remote project \xe2\x80\x9cis very limited ... and as such the project carries a relatively high risk profile.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThis project does not possess the primary characteristics of resorts most likely to succeed as we come out of the recession,\xe2\x80\x9d he added. With sales likely to fall well below projections, tax revenues will also fall well below the mark, Mr. Norden and other experts maintained. Major investments in Big Tupper Ski Area, the most broadly supported aspect of the project, are delayed to its latter phases.'b'Other experts testified that if real estate sales are slow and the project stalls, local residents could be stuck with the operation and maintenance of miles of new roads and sewer lines leading to only a few new homes. Furthermore, the resort\xe2\x80\x99s owners won\xe2\x80\x99t pay taxes directly to the town or school district; they will make payments in lieu of taxes to private bondholders willing to invest in this risky enterprise. The taxing districts will get what\xe2\x80\x99s left over after these payments are made.'b'Since 1892, Adirondack Park has been not only of state and regional importance but also of great national and international significance. The park inspired the national wilderness system and is designated an 'b'International Biosphere Reserve'b'. Standards for building on this scale in the park should be as high as its mountains, and the law says they must be. The Adirondack Club and Resort sets a glaringly low standard, and the A.P.A. should deny it. Only then might we see an alternative that actually makes sense for the park\xe2\x80\x99s environment and marketplace and that concentrates redevelopment where it was intended \xe2\x80\x94 around Big Tupper Ski Area.'b'Will Governor Cuomo, like his father and Nelson Rockefeller, insist that the A.P.A. abide by its law? Or will he risk damaging a park beloved by millions and globally regarded as a model for sustaining people and wild nature?'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'For the first time in more than 60 years, politicians are arguing with great fervor about \xe2\x80\x9cright to work\xe2\x80\x9d laws \xe2\x80\x94 state laws that bar unions and employers from requiring that workers join unions or pay union dues without joining.'b'Currently 22 states have right-to-work laws, and Indiana\xe2\x80\x99s Legislature is now considering passing one, the first in a decade.'b'Beyond the hyperbole of employer and union groups are the two fundamental questions underlying right-to-work laws.'b'Unions ask, \xe2\x80\x9cShould workers who are covered by collective bargaining agreements be permitted to be \xe2\x80\x98free riders\xe2\x80\x99 and receive union protections and benefits without paying for them?\xe2\x80\x9d And employers ask, \xe2\x80\x9cShould workers be compelled to join or pay dues to organizations against their wishes?\xe2\x80\x9d This is nothing less than a clash between the basic free-rider and freedom of association arguments.'b'Right-to-work laws are found in the states with the lowest union membership (such as Texas, Alabama and South Carolina), but it is not clear whether membership is low because there are right-to-work laws and unions are discouraged from organizing, or if there are right-to-work laws because membership is initially low and thus unions lack political clout in these states.'b'Unions argue that right-to-work laws mean less revenues in the form of members\xe2\x80\x99 dues. If it costs them about $1,500 to organize each new member, unions can\xe2\x80\x99t see any return on their organizing investment in right-to-work law states.'b'But employers claim that without right-to-work laws, unions would organize more members, and as wages increase, jobs would be lost.'b'It will not be surprising, as the Republican primaries move to South Carolina and Florida, to hear the candidates energetically promote more right-to-work laws and even a national right-to-work law.'b'GARY CHAISON'b'\nWorcester, Mass., Jan. 17, 2012'b''b''b'The writer is a professor of industrial relations at the Graduate School of Management, Clark University.'b''b''b'\n'b'Editors\xe2\x80\x99 Note: 'b''b''b'We invite readers to respond to this letter for our Sunday Dialogue. ORSI'b' Research Fellow in Law and Religion'b' Ave Maria School of Law'b' Naples, Fla., Jan. 13, 2012'b''b''b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'I disagree with Michael Powell (\xe2\x80\x9c'b'A Developer Between Legal Clouds'b',\xe2\x80\x9d Gotham column, Jan. 10) that two bribery investigations with ties to the developer Bruce Ratner and his company, Forest City Ratner, suggest misdeeds on his part.'b'More important, the professional investigators have not found that the company or its employees behaved in an illegal manner.'b'While I do agree that we have an unprecedented amount of corruption among elected officials, lobbyists and others, you cannot and should not assume that a developer is guilty of the same behavior because, well, he\xe2\x80\x99s a developer.'b'As a former New York City public advocate and during many years in public service, I have had the honor to work with Mr. Ratner. Not long ago, I retold the tale of my single manic episode to her, sharpening memories of that day in all its colors.'b'It was a painful testament to my sister\xe2\x80\x99s skill that scenes that might have been of just passing interest to other viewers pushed me to tears, because in a real way they carried an uncanny emotional resonance.'b'And yet for all that, I feel the show\xe2\x80\x99s creators, writers and producers, and Ms. Danes, have done us all a public service: perhaps, with the show\xe2\x80\x99s glowing reception, Americans can finally talk openly about bipolar disorder.'b'Meredith\xe2\x80\x99s interest in my condition is not, of course, limited to her work as a writer. One of the first things they tell you about the condition is that sleep really is the \xe2\x80\x9cchief nourisher in life\xe2\x80\x99s feast,\xe2\x80\x9d as Macbeth put it. Imposing the death penalty in his case, as in any case, would have been grossly unjust.'b'When February comes, we will receive the gift of an extra day because 2012 is a leap year. But that isn\xe2\x80\x99t all the extra time we get this year. On the night of June 30, 'b'there will be one more second in the day'b' \xe2\x80\x94 a leap second.'b'That may not sound like much, but it is a vital second. While the leap year keeps the calendar in order, the leap second keeps the clock in order by closing the gap between time as measured by atomic clocks, which rely on the oscillation frequency in an isotope of cesium, and time as measured by the daily rotation of the Earth. Without inserting a leap-something at some point, the gap between earth time and official time as calibrated by cesium clocks \xe2\x80\x94 stunningly accurate to one second in 100 million years \xe2\x80\x94 would grow and grow, though very slowly.'b'It is all part of the business of keeping chronological accounts straight, a function performed by 'b'the International Earth Rotation and Reference Systems Service'b' in Paris. The curious part is that it\xe2\x80\x99s easier for our temporally obsessed species to deal with a leap day, which comes every four years, than a leap second, which scientists insert whenever the gap between atomic time and solar time adds up to a second. (The last one was added in 2008; 'b'this one was announced'b' only on Jan. 5.)'b'More and more, the systems we depend on depend themselves on hyperaccurate time signals emitted by official sources like the 'b'National Institute of Standards and Technology'b' in Boulder, Colo. And you can\xe2\x80\x99t just toss an extra second into networks that rely on carefully interrelated time signals, like the Internet or GPS satellites, without causing headaches. There are no Y2K fears here, but the engineers will bound to be watching come June as the leap second passes.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Susan Cain (\xe2\x80\x9c'b'The Rise of the New Groupthink'b',\xe2\x80\x9d Sunday Review, Jan. 15) writes that creative people are more likely to be introverts; that students learn better when alone; and that solitary computer programmers write better code. In each of these cases, research shows just the opposite.'b'Decades of scientific research have revealed that great creativity is almost always based in collaboration, conversation and social networks \xe2\x80\x94 just the opposite of our mythical image of the isolated genius. In the best sense, collaboration is none of the above, and Ms. Cain is wrong to equate it with \xe2\x80\x9cgroupthink.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'As early as the 1970s, Kenneth W. Thomas and Ralph H. Kilmann at the University of Pittsburgh identified collaboration as a problem-solving and conflict-resolution technique in which both parties own the issue and seek to fulfill not only their own needs but also those of the other side. It\xe2\x80\x99s the truest of the win-win models. Authentic collaboration has proved to be a powerful means of achieving more than either party might have accomplished solo.'b'The collaborative process may benefit from the input of individuals who are creative high achievers, but it\xe2\x80\x99s not dependent on them; what\xe2\x80\x99s required are the actual stakeholders whose concerns are threatened by a conflict or a problem. These products are not meant to carry the whole burden of helping smokers quit. Nicotine replacement therapy is intended to jump-start quitting by lessening the physical effects of nicotine withdrawal, and cravings, when they are present. This gives smokers confidence that they can begin living without tobacco.'b'As the study points out, very few smokers use the therapy correctly. Nevertheless, among \xe2\x80\x9cheavy dependent smokers\xe2\x80\x9d in the study, those who got nicotine replacement therapy for more than six weeks plus professional counseling had the lowest long-term relapse rates.'b'By easing the physical effects of quitting, the therapy lets smokers focus on the longer term emotional and behavioral work of adjusting to a smoke-free life. This often involves discarding counterproductive beliefs \xe2\x80\x94 for example, that smokers need to smoke to cope with stress and other life problems. When they can replace these beliefs with healthy approaches to living, they can avoid relapse over the long term.'b'For many smokers, emotional dependence on smoking is a much higher hurdle to overcome than their chemical dependence. In comparison, top rates between 25 percent and 35 percent are applied to the wages and salaries for many working Americans.'b'Worse, an egregious loophole in the law lets private equity partners pay the lower 15 percent rate on much of their income \xe2\x80\x94 known as \xe2\x80\x9ccarried interest\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 even though those earnings are not typically gains from investing their own money, but rather a share of profits from investing someone else\xe2\x80\x99s money.'b'Without seeing Mr. Romney\xe2\x80\x99s tax returns, it is impossible to know how much of his investments \xe2\x80\x94 past and present \xe2\x80\x94 are actually carried interest, though much of his fortune is from his years at the buyout firm Bain Capital, and a significant share of his family\xe2\x80\x99s wealth is still connected to Bain.'b'President Obama has repeatedly, and correctly, called for ending the carried interest loophole. It is morally indefensible because it asserts that the efforts and risks of private equity partners are worthier than those of workers who pay regular tax rates. It also makes no sense. The rationale for keeping the capital gains rate lower than the rate on wages and salaries is to encourage and reward investors for taking risks with their own money. Private equity partners are, by and large, managing other people\xe2\x80\x99s money risk.'b'The controversy over the tax treatment of carried interest is a subset of the larger debate over whether there even should be a preferential rate for capital gains. The answer is no. It is not only excessive, and unjustified, it actually encourages wasteful gamesmanship, by enticing people to engage in tax avoidance schemes to convert ordinary income into capital gains. It also exacerbates inequality and crowds out other ways to foster risk-taking.'b'Mr. Romney has called for keeping the current low rates for capital gains and eliminating capital gains altogether for taxpayers making less than $200,000. That\xe2\x80\x99s an attempt to justify an indefensible tax break for the wealthy by tossing crumbs to others.'b'Mr. Romney does not have to apologize for his wealth. But he cannot keep trying to conceal just how much the tax code has been tilted in his favor.'b''b' 'b''b'SOMETHING historic happened at the 'b'New York Philharmonic'b' on the evening of Jan. 10, about an hour into Mahler\xe2\x80\x99s Ninth Symphony. During the introspective, achingly beautiful fourth movement, an audience member\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'cellphone'b' loudly rang. And rang. And rang again. It was the kind of marimba riff we\xe2\x80\x99ve all heard at some point on the street from a stranger\xe2\x80\x99s phone.'b'From my seat in Row L of the orchestra section, I could see from their body language the horrified discomfort of my fellow audience members. We all wondered whether and how the maestro 'b'Alan Gilbert'b' would react. I noticed that some of the violinists were looking down to the seats in the front rows, trying to find the source of the noise and, by their glares, silence it.'b'I closed my eyes, hoping the sounds of the orchestra would prevail over the obnoxious ringing. Suddenly, in my reverie, there was silence. The orchestra had stopped playing; Mr. Gilbert had halted the performance. He turned from his podium to the offender, who was seated in the front row, and said something to this effect:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAre you going to turn it off? Will you do that?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'There was some \xe2\x80\x9cdiscussion\xe2\x80\x9d between the conductor and the cellphone owner \xe2\x80\x94 was the offender pleading his case? \xe2\x80\x94 but the dialogue went unheard.'b'From the rear orchestra-level and the upper-tier seats of Avery Fisher Hall, shouts of outrage rained down on the hapless cellphone owner like discordant notes. Some people stood and demanded that he leave the hall. The audience was so enraged that I could have pictured them hauling him from his seat on to the stage, tying him to a stake, setting him alight and stoking the fires with the busted-up wood of cellos and violas \xe2\x80\x94 maybe even wheeling in one of the orchestra\xe2\x80\x99s shiny Steinways for added pyrotechnics.'b'When it seemed as if the \xe2\x80\x9cpower off\xe2\x80\x9d button on the phone had finally been located and put to use, Mr. Gilbert turned to the audience. \xe2\x80\x9cUsually, when there\xe2\x80\x99s a disturbance like this, it\xe2\x80\x99s best to ignore it,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cBut this was so egregious that I could not allow it.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'With that, the audience applauded as if Mahler himself, the orchestra\xe2\x80\x99s music director from 1909 to 1911, had suddenly been resurrected onstage. Mr. Gilbert neither smiled nor acknowledged the cheers. Instead he turned to the orchestra, instructing the players to resume, several measures back from the point at which he had stopped the performance. Just before he raised his baton, he turned again to the audience and said, this time with a smile, \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll start again.\xe2\x80\x9d A few seconds later, the percussionist struck his cymbals and the fourth movement resumed.'b'For the fans of the Philharmonic, this episode was, I think, a defining moment in the career of Mr. Gilbert, who was appointed music director in 2007. Like other longtime concertgoers, I\xe2\x80\x99d had some difficulty embracing Mr. Gilbert. I\xe2\x80\x99m old-fashioned. I can\xe2\x80\x99t help thinking a conductor has to be older and Eastern European, and should arthritically mount that podium with a furrowed brow, brooding over every note.'b'Like many New Yorkers, I define eras of my life by the mayor in office \xe2\x80\x94 but also by the Philharmonic conductor in office. I look back on the Zubin Mehta years, when I first arrived in the city after college, as being filled with glamorous, if sometimes over-the-top, showmanship. The Kurt Masur years were stern, even humorless. He once stormed off the stage when someone kept coughing at the start of a dreary Alban Berg piece, returning after several minutes only to lecture the audience on when it was appropriate, and inappropriate, to cough. Lorin Maazel\xe2\x80\x99s term was often described as lackadaisical to the point of indifference. He would sometimes lean against the railing of the podium and wave the baton without looking at the orchestra or score, as if he were counting out the time to intermission.'b'Mr. Gilbert is different. He\xe2\x80\x99s a youngish 44. He appears healthy, plump and cheerful when he comes from the wings. He is generous in pointing to orchestra members to stand and receive recognition for solo moments they\xe2\x80\x99ve played in a piece. Yes, he lacks that gravity of face and body that I associate with a maestro. (The fact that his mother, the violinist Yoko Takebe, often sits two rows away from him doesn\xe2\x80\x99t help.)'b'But in his calm response to the cellphone mishap, Mr. Gilbert hit all the right notes. At the symphony\xe2\x80\x99s conclusion, after the last note had sounded, he kept his hand and baton raised, willing the audience to be silent \xe2\x80\x94 to let the silence continue to sound in the hall. One person, after several seconds, clapped once, but Mr. Gilbert held him, and everyone else, at bay. He was conducting us. That last silent note sounded long and true.'b'Mr. Gilbert\xe2\x80\x99s brave decision that night, to halt a performance and remedy a problem with firmness and dignity, brought new music to the Philharmonic.'b'We chose to focus our cameras on Detroit out of a gut feeling that this city \xe2\x80\x94 often heralded as the birthplace of the middle class \xe2\x80\x94 may well be a harbinger of things to come for the rest of the country. \xc2\xa0'b'Detroit lost 25 percent of its population between 2000 and 2010, and now, broke, finds itself on the verge of a possible state takeover. The past is achingly present in Detroit, and the way its citizens interact with the hulking, physical remnants of yesterday is striking.'b'A few years ago, there was a rash of power outages in Detroit, caused by people illegally cutting down live telephone wires to get to the valuable copper coils inside.
