Detroiters tend to chart with pride the success of Detroiters in the wider world (Eminem or Aretha Franklin, say, or a behind-the-scenes success like Jerry Bruckheimer), and at the reunion it was no different. A friend said, \xe2\x80\x9cPretty much everyone who left looks to be doing better than those who stayed.\xe2\x80\x9d Maybe this was so. After all, almost everyone who left the city did so for a job. But many would like to return.'b'Detroit\xe2\x80\x99s troubles are self-evident. What\xe2\x80\x99s harder to understand is what Detroit looks like to its citizens and the members, like myself, of the Detroit diaspora. For us, the city is not a symbol of despair or decay, but a source, believe it or not, of hope.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99ve lived all over the country, and the idea that Detroit is somehow different, that what has happened there can\xe2\x80\x99t happen anywhere else, seems faulty at best. Drive the bumpy streets of Los Angeles, wait for a subway in New York or pay income tax in Chicago, and you learn that there are budget problems everywhere. The troubles in Detroit seem worse simply because Detroit has fallen so far.'b'Once the center of American industrial might and economic power, Detroit was, from 1920 to 1950, the country\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'fourth most populous city'b'. It called itself, without irony, the Paris of the Midwest. When I was a kid, my dad worked in steel and then as a Ford buyer, a midlevel job that provided a decent living, free medical care and, of course, cars. My stepfather had been temporarily paralyzed in a kamikaze attack at the end of 'b'World War II'b', but he recovered, put on a suit and went into the steel business. \xe2\x80\x9cYou couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help but make money,\xe2\x80\x9d he told me. \xe2\x80\x9cIt must have been like selling drugs today.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The exact causes of Detroit\xe2\x80\x99s decline are still open to debate, but suffice it to say mismanagement within the auto industry, racial strife and bad, often confrontational and sometimes corrupt government played major roles. When General Motors and Chrysler finally succumbed to bankruptcy, it was the result of excessive debt and promises to retirees that could not be met. That may sound like someplace else, but our federal government is running an annual deficit of over a trillion dollars, and will have around $40 trillion in unfunded retiree liabilities. Detroit is not someplace else; it\xe2\x80\x99s America.'b'Are we doomed? Hardly. But to go forward we might do well to look at, well, Detroit. The city simply has no time left to dither or 'b'filibuster'b' or ignore a problem because the solution is unpleasant. If Detroit needs to turn off the lights, they\xe2\x80\x99re going off. If it needs to raze decrepit buildings, it will fire up the bulldozers. This is a city where, once, I met a Ford man who had just turned down a lucrative job with a management consulting company. \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t work for a company that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t make something,\xe2\x80\x9d he explained.'b'Detroit is a city used to the hard work of creation. It reminds us that necessity is the mother not only of invention, but of hope. And hope is necessary for action.'b'And Detroit is moving forward. There\xe2\x80\x99s a long way to go, but the city\xe2\x80\x99s efforts have already brought an influx of young artists and entrepreneurs drawn by cheap rent and programs that provide start-up capital. A lot of brainpower is being deployed to imagine the Detroit of the future. Crime is down overall. Even the auto business is coming back to life, as witnessed by the excitement at this year\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'Detroit auto show'b'.'b'Detroit has been in dire straits before. In 1805, roughly a century before Henry Ford built his first assembly line, a huge fire burned the city to the ground. This gave rise to Detroit\xe2\x80\x99s Latin motto, \xe2\x80\x9cSperamus meliora; resurget cineribus\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cWe hope for better things; it will rise from the ashes.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Berkeley, Calif.'b'WE who love the Internet love the fact that so many people contribute to it. It\xe2\x80\x99s hard to believe that skeptics once worried about whether anyone would have anything worthwhile to say online.'b'There is, however, an outdated brand of digital orthodoxy that ought to be retired. In this worldview, the Internet is a never-ending battle of good guys who love freedom against bad guys like old-fashioned Hollywood media moguls. The bad guys want to strengthen copyright law, and make it impossible to post anonymously copied videos and stories.'b'The proposed Stop Online Piracy Act, or SOPA, which is being considered in the House while the Senate looks at a similar bill, is deemed the worst thing ever. Popular sites like 'b'Wikipedia staged a blackout'b' on Wednesday to protest the bills. 'b'Google'b' put a black banner over its name. Nothing quite like that has ever happened before. This is extraordinary, because it shows that belief in the priority of fighting SOPA is so absolute as to trump the stated nonpartisan missions of these sites.'b'The legislation has indeed included draconian remedies in various drafts, so I join my colleagues in criticizing the bills. But our opposition has become so extreme that we are doing more harm than good to our own cause. Those rare tech companies that have come out in support of SOPA are not merely criticized but barred from industry events and subject to boycotts. We, the keepers of the flame of free speech, are banishing people for their speech. The result is a chilling atmosphere, with people afraid to speak their minds.'b'Our melodrama is driven by a vision of an open Internet that has already been distorted, though not by the old industries that fear piracy.'b'For instance, until a year ago, I enjoyed a certain kind of user-generated content very much: I participated in forums in which musicians talked about musical instruments.'b'For years, I was warned that old-fashioned control freaks like media moguls might separate me from my beloved forums. Perhaps a forum would be shut down because it was hosted on some server with pirated content.'b'While acknowledging that this is a possible scenario, a very different factor \xe2\x80\x94 proprietary social networking \xe2\x80\x94 is ending my freedom to participate in the forums I used to love, at least on terms I accept. Like many other forms of contact, the musical conversations are moving into private sites, particularly 'b'Facebook'b'. To continue to participate, I\xe2\x80\x99d have to accept Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s philosophy, under which it analyzes me, and is searching for new ways to charge third parties for the use of that analysis.'b'At the moment that wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t bother me much, because I know a lot of people at Facebook and I know they are decent. But I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen what happens to companies over time. Who knows who will be using my data in 20 years?'b'You might object that it\xe2\x80\x99s all based on individual choice. That argument ignores the consequences of networks, and the way they function. After a certain point choice is reduced.'b'And it\xe2\x80\x99s not Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s fault! We, the idealists, insisted that information be able to flow freely online, which meant that services relating to information, instead of the information itself, would be the main profit centers. Some businesses do sell content, but that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t address the business side of everyday user-generated content.'b'The adulation of \xe2\x80\x9cfree content\xe2\x80\x9d inevitably meant that \xe2\x80\x9cadvertising\xe2\x80\x9d would become the biggest business in the open part of the information economy. Furthermore, that system isn\xe2\x80\x99t so welcoming to new competitors. Once networks are established, it is hard to reduce their power. Google\xe2\x80\x99s advertisers, for instance, know what will happen if they move away. The next-highest bidder for each position in Google\xe2\x80\x99s auction-based model for selling ads will inherit that position if the top bidder goes elsewhere. So Google\xe2\x80\x99s advertisers tend to stay put because the consequences of leaving are obvious to them, whereas the opportunities they might gain by leaving are not.'b'The obvious strategy in the fight for a piece of the advertising pie is to close off substantial parts of the Internet so Google doesn\xe2\x80\x99t see it all anymore. That\xe2\x80\x99s how Facebook hopes to make money, by sealing off a huge amount of user-generated information into a separate, non-Google world. Networks lock in their users, whether it is Facebook\xe2\x80\x99s members or Google\xe2\x80\x99s advertisers.'b'This belief in \xe2\x80\x9cfree\xe2\x80\x9d information is blocking future potential paths for the Internet. What if ordinary users routinely earned micropayments for their contributions? If all content were valued instead of only mogul content, perhaps an information economy would elevate success for all. But under the current terms of debate that idea can barely be whispered.'b'To my friends in the \xe2\x80\x9copen\xe2\x80\x9d Internet movement, I have to ask: what did you think would happen? We in Silicon Valley undermined copyright to make commerce become more about services instead of content \xe2\x80\x94 more about our code instead of their files. The inevitable endgame was always that we would lose control of our own personal content, our own files. We haven\xe2\x80\x99t just weakened Hollywood and old-fashioned publishers. We\xe2\x80\x99ve weakened ourselves.'b'For months, it seemed as if Congress would pass an online antipiracy bill, even though its main weapons \xe2\x80\x94 cutting off the financing of pirate Web sites and making them harder to find \xe2\x80\x94 risk censoring legitimate speech and undermining the security of the Internet. But the unmovable corporations behind those bills have run into an unstoppable force: an outcry by Internet companies led by Google and Wikipedia that culminated in 'b'an extraordinary online protest on Wednesday'b'.'b'Lawmakers have begun peeling away from the bills, notably Senators Marco Rubio, the Florida Republican who cosponsored the Senate version, and John Cornyn, the powerful Texas conservative. They dropped out after Wikipedia\xe2\x80\x99s English language site went dark and Google put a black bar on its homepage on Wednesday.'b'The 'b'Protect I.P. Act'b' would have easily passed the Senate last summer if not for a hold placed by Senator Ron Wyden, a Democrat of Oregon. The 'b'Stop Online Piracy Act'b', introduced in the House in October, has also lost some of its initial backers. And on Saturday, 'b'the White House released a statement'b' warning that it would \xe2\x80\x9cnot support legislation that reduces freedom of expression, increases cybersecurity risk, or undermines the dynamic, innovative global Internet.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Though we are encouraged by legislators\xe2\x80\x99 newfound caution about the potential consequences of the bills, Congress must keep working on ways to curtail the growing business of foreign rogue Web sites trafficking in counterfeit goods and stolen intellectual property.'b'The Internet industry was pitted against some of the best-honed lobbying groups, including Hollywood and the recording studios, the United States Chamber of Commerce and the A.F.L.-C.I.O. The industry has made a good case that some of the definitions of wrongdoing \xe2\x80\x94 like \xe2\x80\x9cfacilitating\xe2\x80\x9d intellectual property infringement \xe2\x80\x94 were overly broad. They said allowing property rights owners to direct payment companies like Visa and ad networks like Google\xe2\x80\x99s to stop doing business with sites they deemed infringing \xe2\x80\x94 with no penalties if they were proved wrong\xe2\x80\x94 could stymie legitimate online expression.'b'They made the case that the proposal to make infringing Web sites \xe2\x80\x9cdisappear\xe2\x80\x9d from the Internet by forbidding search engines from finding them or redirecting their Web addresses to other Internet domains was easy to get around and could potentially undermine efforts to stop hackers from doing exactly the same thing.'b'The Internet companies now have the responsibility to come up with a workable alternative that gives owners of intellectual property rights better tools to stop piracy by Web sites located in faraway countries. These sites get some 53 billion visits a year, more than Google or Wikipedia. Yet they are outside the grasp of American law.'b'The focus on cutting the financing of online pirates, which features in the House and Senate bills, is the right way to go. Sponsors of both bills have moved to delete, at least temporarily, provisions to make rogue Web sites disappear. The legislation could be further amended to narrow the definition of criminality and clarify that it is only aimed at foreign sites. And it could tighten guarantees of due process. Private parties must first get a court order to block business with a Web site they deem infringing on their copyrights.'b'We are happy that the drive to pass antipiracy legislation has slowed enough that Congress might actually consider all its implications carefully. Lawmakers can now act wisely to create tools that can help combat the scourge of online piracy without excessive collateral damage.'b'CHARLESTON, S.C.'b'This week, Rick Santorum held a town hall meeting on a retired aircraft carrier. It was definitely a more dramatic venue than the last time I saw him, in a nursing home auditorium in New Hampshire.'b'As the candidate made small talk with supporters in the hangar bay of the U.S.S. Yorktown, his staff was frantically trying to fold away some of the empty chairs to make the audience look larger. They shooed the attendees \xe2\x80\x94 who appeared to be mainly a few families with home-schooled children and one woman with a very busy red-white-and-blue hat \xe2\x80\x94 into the middle \xe2\x80\x9cso we can have you guys in the camera shot.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Although the meeting area was cold and smelled vaguely fishy, everyone in the little audience seemed upbeat, even the woman who expressed concern that the federal government was planning to round up local Tea Party members and put them in a FEMA concentration camp \xe2\x80\x9cthat has a razor-wire fence around it.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not familiar with that at all,\xe2\x80\x9d said Santorum, who was looking slightly less chipper than his fans. (The Federal Emergency Management Agency says there is no plan to round up the Tea Party. The agency doesn\xe2\x80\x99t have any concentration camps. Just in case you were worried.)'b'But I digress. The point here is that while South Carolina is a very lively state, this primary has been lacking the kind of anything-can-happen excitement that made Iowa one long frostbitten romp. But things could change! Voting on Saturday! And here\xe2\x80\x99s how everybody is doing:'b''b'MITT ROMNEY'b' The South Carolina primary has been one long obsession with Mitt Romney\xe2\x80\x99s extreme richness. This is partly because Newt Gingrich keeps carping on it. Which, to be honest, we have enjoyed very much. But, mainly, it\xe2\x80\x99s because Mitt is so weird and off-putting on the subject. Like the time he told people he was unemployed. And, this week, when he dismissed the fees he earns as a public speaker, which ran to $374,327 in one recent year, as \xe2\x80\x9cnot very much.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'People, what is it with this guy? Mitt was charging around $42,000 a speech. If you were planning to run for president and didn\xe2\x80\x99t need money, would you deliberately pursue a sideline that would put you in the top 1 percent for about 12 hours\xe2\x80\x99 worth of work? And, while we\xe2\x80\x99re at it, if you were that rich and had a very large family to take to Canada, wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t you hire a plane? What kind of obsession is it that makes a multi-multi-multimillionaire show up for the GoldenTree Asset Management convention for a $68,000 fee? Or drive for 12 hours with the Irish setter strapped to the car roof?'b''b'RON PAUL'b' During the recent South Carolina debate, Paul called for a \xe2\x80\x9cgolden rule in foreign policy,\xe2\x80\x9d in which we would refrain from doing things to other countries we would not like done to us. This triggered cries of outrage from the audience on behalf of the New Exceptionalism, which holds that the United States is the only country with \xe2\x80\x9cdo-to\xe2\x80\x9d rights.'b'But Paul has pretty much written off South Carolina anyway. He\xe2\x80\x99s hoping the race drags on to February and caucus states like Maine and Nevada, where a candidate with a small-but-dedicated following has an advantage. Even if that following appears to be composed largely of slightly abrasive young men with high IQs who smoke and wear hunter caps with ear flaps.'b''b'RICK PERRY'b' You may have heard the rumor that Perry is doing better in his campaign performances lately. Frequently, the words \xe2\x80\x9cdoing better\xe2\x80\x9d are spoken in the same tone used when describing, say, a 97-year-old heart attack victim on a ventilator. Lately, he has been expressing his patriotism by denouncing the Obama administration\xe2\x80\x99s stern treatment of the Marines who urinated on dead Afghans. At a recent speech in South Carolina, he referred to Washington as a \xe2\x80\x9csuburb.\xe2\x80\x9d But, at this point, really, people have stopped keeping track.'b''b'NEWT GINGRICH'b' Once again in South Carolina, Gingrich is proving that he is the top debater in the field. Truly, if the office of president of the United States involved nothing but debating in front of enthusiastic Republican audiences, he would be far and away the best possible choice. If nominated, Newt promises that he will follow Barack Obama around the country challenging him to a series of three-hour-long \xe2\x80\x9cLincoln-Douglas\xe2\x80\x9d debates. He can already imagine it! I bet you can, too.'b''b'RICK SANTORUM'b' Santorum enjoys spending time with his wife and seven kids, doing 50 push-ups every morning, and pressuring for a recount of the Iowa caucus vote. He also likes sweater vests, talking about his coal-miner grandfather and visiting aircraft carriers to drive home his campaign slogan. Which is \xe2\x80\x9cCourage to Fight for America\xe2\x80\x9d not \xe2\x80\x9cAlready in Drydock.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'When I spoke at Swarthmore College recently, I was startled by one question: Is it immoral for students to seek banking jobs?'b'The corollary question, with Mitt Romney\xe2\x80\x99s business career under attack even by staunch Republicans, is this: Is it unethical to make millions in private equity?'b'My answer to both questions: no.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99ve been sympathetic to the Occupy Wall Street movement, but, look, finance is not evil. Banking has contributed immensely to modern civilization. By allocating capital to more efficient uses, banking laid the groundwork for the industrial revolution and the information revolution.'b'Likewise, the attacks on private equity seem over the top. Private equity firms like Bain Capital, where Romney worked, aren\xe2\x80\x99t about destroying companies and picking over the carcasses. Rather, the aim is to acquire poorly managed companies, make them more efficient (sometimes by firing people but often by rejiggering the business model) and then resell them at a profit. That\xe2\x80\x99s the merciless, rugged nature of capitalism.'b'Liberals should also be wary of self-selecting out of certain occupations. After Vietnam and revelations of C.I.A. abuses in the 1970s, many university students avoided the military and the intelligence agencies. So slots were filled disproportionately by ideological conservatives in a way that undermined everyone\xe2\x80\x99s interests. We would have been better off if more Swarthmore idealists had become generals and C.I.A. officers \xe2\x80\x94 and we may be better off if some idealists become bankers as well.'b'Now for my caveats.'b'When young people go into finance, I hope that they\xe2\x80\x99ll show judgment, balance and principles instead of their elders\xe2\x80\x99 penchant for greed and rigging the system. Just as Communists managed to destroy Communism, capitalists are discrediting capitalism.'b''b'A Pew Research Center poll in December'b' found that only 50 percent of Americans reacted positively to the term \xe2\x80\x9ccapitalism,\xe2\x80\x9d while 40 percent reacted negatively. Among Americans ages 18 to 29, more had a negative view of capitalism than a positive view, the survey found. Those young Americans actually viewed socialism more positively than capitalism. In other words, America\xe2\x80\x99s grasping capitalists are turning young Americans into socialists.'b''b'The Financial Times recently published a series'b' about \xe2\x80\x9ccapitalism in crisis.\xe2\x80\x9d It noted that the 'b'Edelman Trust Barometer'b', a survey, found that only 46 percent of Americans had confidence in business to do the right thing (and only 25 percent trusted banks).'b'Public skepticism is warranted, in my view. Corporations have vastly overpaid C.E.O.\xe2\x80\x99s, handsomely rewarding not only success but also failure. Banks that helped cause today\xe2\x80\x99s financial mess lobbied successfully for bailouts for themselves; they privatized profits and socialized losses.'b'Meanwhile, more than four million families have lost their homes to foreclosure, according to Zillow.com, a real estate company. Bankers and shareholders found a safety net, but not working-class families. One reason is that the campaign finance system allows financiers to buy access and special favors. If you\xe2\x80\x99re a tycoon, your best investment often is a lobbying firm in Washington to create a tax loophole for you. The last few years have been a showcase not of capitalism itself, but of crony capitalism.'b''b'Romney\xe2\x80\x99s average tax rate'b', which he says is probably about 15 percent, exemplifies the problem. The Romneys benefit because capital gains tax rates have been slashed to just 15 percent, much lower than rates paid on labor income.'b'Then there\xe2\x80\x99s the most egregious tax loophole of all, for \xe2\x80\x9ccarried interest.\xe2\x80\x9d A triumph of lobbying, it allows private equity and hedge fund managers to pretend that their labor income is a capital gain. So they sometimes pay a tax rate of just 15 percent, compared with up to 35 percent for almost everyone else.'b'Granted, young people haven\xe2\x80\x99t been pouring into finance in recent years out of eagerness to reform this rigged system but to milk it. In 2007, on the eve of the financial crisis, 'b'47 percent of Harvard\xe2\x80\x99s graduating class'b' headed for consulting firms and the financial sector \xe2\x80\x94 a huge misallocation of human capital. However well-meaning these new graduates are initially, they often end up caught up in the scramble at the trough.'b'In the postwar years, labor unions became greedy and rewarded themselves with feather-bedding and rigid work rules \xe2\x80\x94 turning much of the public against them. Likewise, Wall Street feather-bedding is tarnishing the public image of banks and business and undermining confidence in capitalism itself.'b'When financiers rig the system, they should remember the warning of John Maynard Keynes: \xe2\x80\x9cThe businessman is only tolerable so long as his gains can be held to bear some relation to what, roughly and in some sense, his activities have contributed to society.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'So university students would be wrong to mock their classmates who choose Citigroup over CARE. Banking and private equity aren\xe2\x80\x99t evil, and I would never urge college students to stay away. Maybe today\xe2\x80\x99s young socialist sympathizers, along with healthy regulation and a loud public outcry, can help rescue capitalism from the crony capitalists.'b'President Obama 'b'has properly rejected'b', at least for now, the Keystone XL oil pipeline that would run from Canada to the Gulf Coast. He rebuffed the demand of House Republicans that the controversial project be decided in haste under an election-year deadline.'b'The foolish requirement that Mr. Obama issue a decision on the pipeline by Feb. 21 \xe2\x80\x94 cynically inserted into the payroll tax bill passed in December \xe2\x80\x94 could never be met given the need for a thorough environmental study before any judgment is made.'b'The president made the right call in accepting the recommendation of the State Department, which has primary jurisdiction over the proposed 1,700-mile pipeline that would cross through ecologically sensitive areas in the Midwest. Mr. Obama said his judgment was based not on the merits but on a timetable that was \xe2\x80\x9crushed and arbitrary.\xe2\x80\x9d He has maintained that a decision on the current proposal could not be made until some time next year. The pipeline sponsor, TransCanada, could submit a proposal to build along another route, but that, too, would require time for a comprehensive environmental review.'b'Republicans intent on scoring campaign points immediately repeated their fallacious cries that \xe2\x80\x9ctens of thousands of jobs\xe2\x80\x9d would be lost by not instantly approving the project. They made no mention of the risks inherent in the project: harm to the Canadian boreal forests and threats to water supplies in the Midwest. Bipartisan opposition to the pipeline has notably been led by Gov. Dave Heineman of Nebraska, a Republican.'b'The extraction and production of tar sands oil in the fields of northern Alberta would also cause far more greenhouse gas emissions than drilling for conventional crude. Lobbyists and House Republicans have tried to sell the project as a reduction in America\xe2\x80\x99s dependence on Middle Eastern oil. But much of the pipeline oil that would be refined on the Gulf Coast would be destined for foreign export.'b'Far more important to the nation\xe2\x80\x99s energy and environmental future is the development of renewable and alternative energy sources. This is the winning case that Mr. Obama should make to voters in rejecting the Republicans\xe2\x80\x99 craven indulgence of Big Oil.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'\xe2\x80\x9c'b'Preventing a Nuclear Iran, Peacefully'b',\xe2\x80\x9d by Shibley Telhami and Steven Kull (Op-Ed, Jan. 16), is a counterproductive exercise that if taken seriously would increase rather than decrease the chances of military conflict.'b'The two ingredients that are most likely to deter Iran from going nuclear are immediate harsh sanctions aimed at the Iranian central bank and its oil sales, and the real threat of a military attack if Iran persists.'b'Any path that leads Iranian leaders to think they can delay or divert such options will encourage them to move forward with their nuclear program. The notion that discussions of a nuclear-free Mideast, a worthy goal in principle, can be accomplished in a short enough time to change Iran\xe2\x80\x99s course is an illusion.'b'Moreover, there is no evidence that Iran is interested in such an achievement since Iranian leaders seem motivated toward achieving regional dominance through a nuclear capability.'b'The more Iran believes that the world is not truly committed to stopping it from going nuclear, the more likely that it will move forward. And it is that scenario that is most frightening and is the one that will generate the highest likelihood for military confrontation between the West and the Islamic republic.'b'KENNETH JACOBSON'b' Deputy National Director'b' Anti-Defamation League'b' New York, Jan. 17, 2012'b''b''b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'The vision of a Middle East nuclear-weapon-free zone is a good one and should be encouraged. But Shibley Telhami and Steven Kull leave out a critical element: getting from here to there.'b'A nuclear-weapon-free zone will need the imprimatur of the five nuclear powers on the Security Council and a strong anchor of security, both during and after a period of negotiation.'b'The anchor cannot be the sole responsibility of the United States and its putative \xe2\x80\x9cnuclear umbrella.\xe2\x80\x9d A better provider would be NATO, acting under a United Nations mandate. Doing so would be consistent with NATO\xe2\x80\x99s aim of reducing the scope of its conventional military interventions in favor of extending its deterrent to neighboring regions.'b'This would be in the interest of both NATO and its neighbors. And it would help remove discussion of nuclear weapons in the Middle East from the realm of theology to one of utility and real security.'b'KENNETH WEISBRODE'b' Boston, Jan. 16, 2012'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'The prevailing international consensus that Israel can possess a nuclear arsenal, while Iran is not allowed to, is indeed a double standard and an obstacle to Middle East peace efforts. But as the hypocrisy level continues to rise, that forgiveness may become much harder to provide.'b'Washington'b'AT this moment, all over the United States, consumers are buying tickets to games, concerts and other live events under the impression that they have the right to give away, donate or resell the tickets they purchase. They assume that they can do so whenever and with whomever they wish and (as long as they don\xe2\x80\x99t violate the few remaining laws against scalping) at whatever price they choose.'b'But those consumers may be mistaken. In recent years ticket sellers, along with promoters, producers, artists and sports teams, have increasingly taken a new approach to selling tickets. This approach, marketed in the name of innovation, convenience and protecting purchasers, restricts those fundamental freedoms long rightly taken for granted.'b'The practice is so-called paperless ticketing: tickets are purchased by credit card, and to gain entry to an event, the buyer must present the same credit card and a photo ID. You cannot readily give your paperless concert ticket to a friend or sell it to a colleague or buy one for your grandchild to use. In no other format \xe2\x80\x94 traditional paper ticket, printable e-ticket or digital ticket delivered on a smartphone \xe2\x80\x94 are live-event tickets subject to such transfer restraints, and no product other than airline tickets (for which there is a security rationale) involves such restrictions.'b'Ticketmaster, the dominant seller of live-event tickets, and to a lesser extent its much smaller competitor 'b'Veritix'b', both engage in this practice. Ticketmaster says its restrictions on the resale and \xe2\x80\x9cgifting\xe2\x80\x9d of its paperless tickets act as safeguards against various practices: scalping; the bulk purchasing of tickets by automated software bots; and the use of counterfeit, stolen or lost tickets.'b'But in reality, the restrictions represent an effort to control the secondary-ticketing market and stifle competition from independent resellers and resale marketplaces like 'b'StubHub'b', where tickets are often sold for less than face value. ('b'The American Antitrust Institute'b', of which I am president, received a modest contribution, in the form of sponsorship of a conference last year, from an advocacy group financed in part by StubHub.) Paperless tickets bought through Ticketmaster may be resold, for example, only through its own resale 'b'Web site'b', which often prohibits sales below face value, sets maximum sale prices and charges a fee for transfers.'b'The scope of the problem \xe2\x80\x94 how many fans are affected, how much money is involved \xe2\x80\x94 is difficult to quantify. Paperless tickets are estimated to represent only about 1 percent of the well over 100 million live-event tickets sold each year. But in the absence of strong consumer resistance, they are likely to become increasingly common.'b'This week, the American Antitrust Institute is releasing a report on the paperless-ticket market by James D. Hurwitz, an institute fellow and former policy analyst at the Federal Trade Commission. The conclusion: restrictive paperless-ticket practices depart from bedrock market principles by unjustifiably limiting consumer choice and suppressing free competition. They also might violate federal and state antitrust and consumer-protection laws. And they may warrant legislation to protect the market and consumers.'b'As it happens, a number of states are weighing ticket reforms. In 2010, New York became the first state to pass legislation to protect the right of consumers to transfer tickets to others as they see fit. Similar legislation has been introduced in Minnesota, Massachusetts, Connecticut, North Carolina, Florida and New Jersey.'b'We urge reform of these ticketing practices. Specifically, we call on the Federal Trade Commission, along with state attorneys general, consumer-protection agencies and legislators, to investigate the growing threat of restrictive paperless-ticketing practices for live events. Perhaps the threat of an investigation will spur the industry to reform itself.'b'These practices undermine a free, fair, informed and competitive market. Consumers should be enabled to transact with others.'b'Mitt Romney is a rich man, but is Mitt Romney\xe2\x80\x99s character formed by his wealth? Is Romney a spoiled, cosseted character? Has he been corrupted by ease and luxury?'b'The notion is preposterous. All his life, Romney has been a worker and a grinder. He earned two degrees at Harvard simultaneously (in law and business). He built a business. He\xe2\x80\x99s persevered year after year, amid defeat after defeat, to build a political career.'b'Romney\xe2\x80\x99s salient quality is not wealth. It is, for better and worse, his tenacious drive \xe2\x80\x94 the sort of relentlessness that we associate with striving immigrants, not rich scions.'b'Where did this persistence come from? It\xe2\x80\x99s plausible to think that it came from his family history. The philosopher Michael Oakeshott once observed that it takes several generations to make a career. Interests, habits and lore accrue in families and shape those born into them.'b'The Romney family history, which is nicely described in \xe2\x80\x9cThe Real Romney\xe2\x80\x9d by Michael Kranish and Scott Helman, is a story of tenacious work, setbacks and recovery. People who analyze how Mormonism may have shaped Romney generally look to theology. But the Mormon history, the exodus, matters most.'b'Mitt Romney\xe2\x80\x99s great-great-grandfather Miles was a member of the church in Nauvoo, Ill., and spent years building a temple there. Even after Joseph Smith was killed by a mob and most of the Mormons fled, Miles stayed to finish his temple.'b'Then, in 1844, as the great work was being completed, mobs burned it to the ground and forced Miles and his family to head West. Most Mormons made the trek to Salt Lake City, but the Romneys could not afford an ox cart. They were part of a small, malnourished band that took four years of struggle to make it the 1,300 miles west.'b'Mitt\xe2\x80\x99s great-grandfather, also Miles, made the trek starting at age 7. He was married in 1862, but a month after his marriage Brigham Young told him to leave his wife, Hannah, and become a missionary for three years in Britain. Hannah supported herself by taking in other people\xe2\x80\x99s washing.'b'Miles returned in 1867 and bought a two-room house. Young commanded him to take another wife, and Hannah had to prepare the room for the woman who would be her rival. \xe2\x80\x9cI used to walk the floor and shed tears of sorrow,\xe2\x80\x9d she recounted in her own private memoir.'b'Then they were commanded to leave family and friends and build a new settlement in the desert 300 miles south of Salt Lake City. Living at first in primitive huts, they built a community, and Miles prospered. Then came a new command to move 400 miles across the wilderness to settle a desert patch in Arizona.'b'Again the Romneys were thrown back into primeval hardship. Miles, his three wives and their many children lived in a small wooden house and survived on bread, beans and gravy. There, as elsewhere, the locals detested the Mormons for their polygamy, for their religion and for the fact that the Mormons tended to outwork them. The local newspaper said Miles should be hung for polygamy, so two of his wives were sent to hide in cornfields and the mountains of New Mexico.'b'They were compelled to move again. Romney left his family to build a colony in Mexico. It was 1885, and he was living out of a wagon. Hannah led eight children through the Arizona mountains to join him. In Mexico, they lived in a house with a dirt roof, so mud dropped down when it rained. Eventually, all the wives and the 21 children were reunited. Miles and his son Gaskell, Mitt\xe2\x80\x99s grandfather, built a successful community, with brick homes, churches and wealth.'b'George Romney, Mitt\xe2\x80\x99s father, was born in Mexico. But when he was 5, in 1912, Mexican revolutionaries confiscated their property and threw them out. Most of the Romneys fled back to the U.S. Within days, they went from owning a large Mexican ranch to being penniless once again, drifting from California to Idaho to Utah, where again they built a fortune.'b'Mitt Romney can\xe2\x80\x99t talk about his family history on the campaign trail. Mormonism is an uncomfortable subject. But he must have been affected by it.'b'It is a story of relentless effort, of recovery and of being despised (in their eyes) because of their own success. Romney himself experienced none of this hardship, of course, but Jews who didn\xe2\x80\x99t live through the Exodus are still shaped by it.'b'Romney seems to share his family\xe2\x80\x99s remorseless drive to rise \xe2\x80\x94 whether it\xe2\x80\x99s trying to persuade the French to give up wine and join his church, or building a business, or being willing to withstand heaps of abuse in pursuit of the presidency. He may have character flaws, but he does not have the character flaws normally associated with great wealth. His signature is focus and persistence. The wealth issue is a sideshow.'b'Call me peculiar, but I\xe2\x80\x99m actually enjoying the spectacle of Mitt Romney doing the Dance of the Seven Veils \xe2\x80\x94 partly out of voyeurism, of course, but also because it\xe2\x80\x99s about time that we had this discussion.'b'The theme of his dance, for those who haven\xe2\x80\x99t been paying attention, is taxes \xe2\x80\x94 his own taxes. (The elder Romney, by the way, paid 37 percent of his income in taxes).'b'And the public has a right to see the back years: By 2011, with the campaign looming, Mr. Romney may have rearranged his portfolio to minimize awkward issues like his accounts in the Cayman Islands or his use of the justly reviled \xe2\x80\x9ccarried interest\xe2\x80\x9d tax break.'b'But the larger question isn\xe2\x80\x99t what Mitt Romney\xe2\x80\x99s tax returns have to say about Mitt Romney; it\xe2\x80\x99s what they have to say about U.S. tax policy. Is there a good reason why the rich should bear a startlingly light tax burden?'b'For they do. If Mr. Romney is telling the truth about his taxes, he\xe2\x80\x99s actually more or less typical of the very wealthy. Since 1992, the I.R.S. has been releasing income and tax data for the 400 highest-income filers. In 2008, the most recent year available, these filers paid only 18.1 percent of their income in federal income taxes; in 2007, they paid only 16.6 percent. When you bear in mind that the rich pay little either in payroll taxes or in state and local taxes \xe2\x80\x94 major burdens on middle-class families \xe2\x80\x94 this implies that the top 400 filers faced lower taxes than many ordinary workers.'b'The main reason the rich pay so little is that most of their income takes the form of capital gains, which are taxed at a maximum rate of 15 percent, far below the maximum on wages and salaries. So the question is whether capital gains \xe2\x80\x94 three-quarters of which go to the top 1 percent of the income distribution \xe2\x80\x94 warrant such special treatment.'b'Defenders of low taxes on the rich mainly make two arguments: that low taxes on capital gains are a time-honored principle, and that they are needed to promote economic growth and job creation. Both claims are false.'b'When you hear about the low, low taxes of people like Mr. Romney, what you need to know is that it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t always thus \xe2\x80\x94 and the days when the superrich paid much higher taxes weren\xe2\x80\x99t that long ago. Back in 1986, Ronald Reagan \xe2\x80\x94 yes, Ronald Reagan \xe2\x80\x94 signed a tax reform equalizing top rates on earned income and capital gains at 28 percent. The rate rose further, to more than 29 percent, during Bill Clinton\xe2\x80\x99s first term.'b'Low capital gains taxes date only from 1997, when Mr. Clinton struck a deal with Republicans in Congress in which he cut taxes on the rich in return for creation of the Children\xe2\x80\x99s Health Insurance Program. And today\xe2\x80\x99s ultralow rates \xe2\x80\x94 the lowest since the days of Herbert Hoover \xe2\x80\x94 date only from 2003, when former President George W. Bush rammed both a tax cut on capital gains and a tax cut on dividends through Congress, something he achieved by exploiting the illusion of triumph in Iraq.'b'Correspondingly, the low-tax status of the very rich is also a recent development. During Mr. Clinton\xe2\x80\x99s first term, the top 400 taxpayers paid close to 30 percent of their income in federal taxes, and even after his tax deal they paid substantially more than they have since the 2003 cut.'b'So is it essential that the rich receive such a big tax break? There is a theoretical case for according special treatment to capital gains, but there are also theoretical and practical arguments against such special treatment. In particular, the huge gap between taxes on earned income and taxes on unearned income creates a perverse incentive to arrange one\xe2\x80\x99s affairs so as to make income appear in the \xe2\x80\x9cright\xe2\x80\x9d category.'b'And the economic record certainly doesn\xe2\x80\x99t support the notion that superlow taxes on the superrich are the key to prosperity. Yet the government negotiated these deals without consulting those who would bear the greatest burden.'b'In recent months, Sime Darby has begun developing its first 25,000 acres in Grand Cape Mount County in northwestern Liberia. He clearly sees basketball as his means to a better life.'b'But to get to that better life, whether in the N.B.A. or a European league, he needs to be able to play in college, and, so far, the N.C.A.A. has done its best to prevent that from happening. What happened next will be the subject of Tuesday\xe2\x80\x99s column.'b'In a closely watched case about a redistricting battle in Texas, the Supreme Court on Friday issued 'b'a per curiam opinion'b' that added a further twist in a rushed and messy controversy. This may work for him in the primaries, but it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t bode well for his party in November.'b'In the year since President Hosni Mubarak was ousted, Egypt has faced many challenges: the military-led government\xe2\x80\x99s brutality against protesters and pro-democracy groups, its resistance to handing power to civilian leaders and the rise of Islamists in the country\xe2\x80\x99s first free elections. Many are justifiably angry about the military\xe2\x80\x99s autocratic control \xe2\x80\x94 and will be angrier still if economic conditions deteriorate further. Its success, or failure, will have a huge impact on the region and beyond.'b'Egypt\xe2\x80\x99s military rulers are now realizing how big a threat the collapsing economy is \xe2\x80\x94 and they clearly don\xe2\x80\x99t want to be blamed. Such measures can never be sustained without public support.'b'In 'b'a recent interview with Reuters news service'b', the leader of the Muslim Brotherhood\xe2\x80\x99s economic committee, Ashraf Badr el-Din, suggested that the Brotherhood and other main parties are moving toward consensus on managing the economy. If the I.M.F. negotiations over the loan terms succeed, those countries should move quickly on their commitments, including offers to begin free-trade talks with Egypt.'b'Washington and its allies may not have much sway with the military rulers or the newly elected political leaders in the short term, but they have to build long-term relationships with all segments of civil society. Some say Egypt could be one of the world\xe2\x80\x99s top 10 economies in a generation. That\xe2\x80\x99s a goal worth working toward.'b'WITH little fanfare, a dangerous notion has taken hold in progressive policy circles: that the amount of money borrowed by the federal government from Americans to finance its mammoth deficits doesn\xe2\x80\x99t matter.'b'Debt doesn\xe2\x80\x99t matter? Really? That\xe2\x80\x99s the most irresponsible fiscal notion since the tax-cutting mania brought on by the advent of 'b'supply-side economics'b'. And it\xe2\x80\x99s particularly problematic right now, as Congress resumes debating whether to extend the payroll-tax reduction or enact other stimulative measures.'b'Here\xe2\x80\x99s the theory, in its most extreme configuration: To the extent that the government sells its debt to Americans (as opposed to foreigners), those obligations will disappear as aging folks who buy those Treasuries die off.'b'If that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t seem to make much sense, don\xe2\x80\x99t be puzzled \xe2\x80\x94 it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t. Government borrowing is still debt that must eventually be paid off, just as we were taught in introductory economics.'b'Failing to repay the debt would mean not only the ugliness of default but also depriving the next generation of whatever savings their parents parked in government bonds.'b'And remember that just a small fraction of Treasuries are owned by individual Americans. Institutions and many foreign entities own the rest and are not about to give up claims that they are owed.'b'The more realistic alternative of continuing to service that debt offers the unattractive eventual prospect of either higher taxes or sharp cutbacks in government programs, or both.'b'That problem is greatly compounded by the fact that the $10 trillion of debt that is held by investors represents only a fraction of the federal government\xe2\x80\x99s obligations and ignores an additional $46 trillion of commitments to 'b'Social Security'b' and 'b'Medicare'b'.'b'Of course every modern economy both tolerates and benefits from some amount of debt. But the United States has been on a binge, brought on by a toxic mix of spending increases and tax cuts that began with the Reagan tax cuts in the 1980s and were later turbocharged by those of President George W. Bush.'b'The figures are stark. In 1975, government debt per household was roughly equal to half of a typical household\xe2\x80\x99s annual income. Today, it\xe2\x80\x99s 1.7 times. Add entitlements, and the obligations would take a mind-boggling nine years of family income to pay off.'b'Even deficit hawks like me recognize that with the economy still barely above stall speed, now is hardly the moment for the government to slam on the fiscal brakes, debt or no debt.'b'So that means there\xe2\x80\x99s no realistic alternative to more debt. But we can reduce the adverse consequences by how we spend this borrowed money. There are two main forms of stimulus: one kind is channeled through tax cuts and then mostly spent, just like a strapped family that puts its monthly expenses onto a credit card. Alternatively, government can direct its resources toward long-term investments that earn a return; think roads and dams but also medical research and education.'b'At the moment, gridlock grips Washington, and about all that Congress has offered is a two-month cut in the 'b'payroll tax'b', which may help shake the economy out of the doldrums but provides little lasting benefit.'b'We could just as effectively throw borrowed hundred-dollar bills out of airplanes. About the only worse approach would be nothing at all.'b'Government\xe2\x80\x99s focus should shift toward investment. To do so, multiple challenges must be overcome.'b'First, unlike every company in America, the government doesn\xe2\x80\x99t keep its books in a way that highlights these important two categories, investment and consumption. As a result, Congress can\xe2\x80\x99t evaluate the long-term impact of its actions.'b'Second, the dark shadow of the 'b'Tea Party movement'b' has made added spending \xe2\x80\x94 the route for most new government investment \xe2\x80\x94 taboo.'b'While public investment may take longer to unleash its positive forces, the case for it is compelling, in part because rising entitlement expenditures have crowded out government\xe2\x80\x99s investment activities.'b'In the early 1950s, government devoted about 1.2 percent of gross domestic product to infrastructure; by 2010, that amount had fallen to just 0.2 percent. Meanwhile, federal spending on research and development dropped from a high of nearly 2 percent in 1964 to 0.9 percent in 2009.'b'By contrast, Franklin D. Roosevelt\xe2\x80\x99s much-praised Works Progress Administration spent the equivalent of at least $1.5 trillion over eight years on projects that in New York City alone ranged from building La Guardia Airport to reroofing the New York Public Library to creating a lasting body of literary and artistic work.'b'I agree that short-term help for the economy combined with long-term deficit reduction is the right direction for budgetary policy.'b'But we also need to make every dollar of debt matter, and therefore we should be directing our efforts to lifting the economy toward programs that provide long-term benefit, not just a short-term burst of caffeinated energy.'b'Should workers be compelled to join unions or pay dues? Readers debate \xe2\x80\x9cright to work\xe2\x80\x9d laws now being considered.'b''b'The Letter'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'For the first time in more than 60 years, politicians are arguing with great fervor about \xe2\x80\x9cright to work\xe2\x80\x9d laws \xe2\x80\x94 state laws that bar unions and employers from requiring that workers join unions or pay union dues without joining.'b'Currently 22 states have right-to-work laws, and Indiana\xe2\x80\x99s Legislature is now considering passing one, the first in a decade.'b'Beyond the hyperbole of employer and union groups are the two fundamental questions underlying right-to-work laws.'b'Unions ask, \xe2\x80\x9cShould workers who are covered by collective bargaining agreements be permitted to be \xe2\x80\x98free riders\xe2\x80\x99 and receive union protections and benefits without paying for them?\xe2\x80\x9d And employers ask, \xe2\x80\x9cShould workers be compelled to join or pay dues to organizations against their wishes?\xe2\x80\x9d This is nothing less than a clash between the basic free-rider and freedom of association arguments.'b'Right-to-work laws are found in the states with the lowest union membership (such as Texas, Alabama and South Carolina), but it is not clear whether membership is low because there are right-to-work laws and unions are discouraged from organizing, or if there are right-to-work laws because membership is initially low and thus unions lack political clout in these states.'b'Unions argue that right-to-work laws mean less revenues in the form of members\xe2\x80\x99 dues. If it costs them about $1,500 to organize each new member, unions can\xe2\x80\x99t see any return on their organizing investment in right-to-work law states.'b'But employers claim that without right-to-work laws, unions would organize more members, and as wages increase, jobs would be lost.'b'It will not be surprising, as the Republican primaries move to South Carolina and Florida, to hear the candidates energetically promote more right-to-work laws and even a national right-to-work law.'b'GARY CHAISON'b' Worcester, Mass., Jan. 17, 2012'b''b''b'The writer is a professor of industrial relations at the Graduate School of Management, Clark University.'b''b''b'Readers React'b''b'The fundamental question about \xe2\x80\x9cright to work\xe2\x80\x9d laws is whether or not we want to continue the downward plunge in the quality of life for middle-class Americans that has accompanied the de-unionization of the American work force.'b'Take a close look at who has been getting what since about the mid-1950s. That\xe2\x80\x99s roughly when the anti-worker laws adopted in the late 1940s \xe2\x80\x94 and the tightly woven web of arcane anti-labor court and regulatory agency decisions that flow from those laws \xe2\x80\x94 began to bite.'b'In the early 1950s more than a third of American workers in private industry belonged to unions. Today it\xe2\x80\x99s less than 7 percent and dropping. During that same period, real income for American workers adjusted for inflation has been declining, the number of workers without medical insurance and without pensions has been increasing, and the gap in income and wealth between the rich and everyone else in America has been exponentially increasing. In short, the American Dream has been evaporating.'b'Want to see the Dream disappear altogether? Pass more \xe2\x80\x9cright to work\xe2\x80\x9d laws. States with such laws tend to have lower household income, more workers without medical insurance and pensions, higher rates of workplace death and the lowest educational levels.'b'The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. got it exactly right: \xe2\x80\x9cWe must guard against being fooled by false slogans, as \xe2\x80\x98right to work.\xe2\x80\x99 It provides no \xe2\x80\x98rights\xe2\x80\x99 and no \xe2\x80\x98works.\xe2\x80\x99 Its purpose is to destroy labor unions and the freedom of collective bargaining.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'JACK JOYCE'b' Swans Island, Me., Jan. 18, 2012'b''b''b'The writer was president of the International Union of Bricklayers and Allied Craftworkers from 1979 to 1999.'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b'I was a dues-paying member of the Philadelphia Federation of Teachers for 38 years before retiring in 2007. I have seen firsthand how those teachers who chose not to become union members and pay dues benefited from the collective bargaining agreements that our union members had to make numerous sacrifices for, like going out on strike, being jailed and being beaten up on picket lines.'b'In our efforts to improve teachers\xe2\x80\x99 salaries, benefits and working conditions and students\xe2\x80\x99 educational opportunities, we lost months\xe2\x80\x99 worth of pay that would never be recouped, while nonunion members crossed our picket lines, collected their salaries and then enjoyed the fruits of our labor.'b'I believe that every person has the right not to join a labor union, whether in the private or public sector. What they don\xe2\x80\x99t have the right to do is reap the rewards of the gains made by union members through collective bargaining agreements without having had to pay any price of their own.'b'JACK STUTMAN'b' Orlando, Fla., Jan. 19, 2012'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b'Mr. Chaison\xe2\x80\x99s letter represents a fair framing of the key points of the labor freedom (right to work) debate. Here in Michigan we are watching carefully the proceedings in Indiana while executing a broad educational strategy to get Michigan to become the next labor freedom state.'b'Labor freedom means that unions are as free to make their case as workers are to make their choice. This is not anti-union, nor is it intended to be. It is pro-freedom, pro-liberty, pro-civil rights, pro-family, pro-investment, pro-jobs, and, in the end, pro-union. When unions shed their government protections and we unshackle ourselves from what is essentially government-sponsored labor overregulation, they will succeed in re-engineering their business model so that the proof of delivering value will be robust voluntary membership.'b'Both sides of this debate can present data and arguments to support their case. The most compelling argument for labor freedom is the right to choose to belong to a union, or not.'b'Labor freedom states have had the greatest job growth, greatest population growth, greatest rate of increase in disposable income (factoring in localized cost of living) and the greatest increase in union membership! Compulsory union states have experienced the greatest loss of population.'b'It is time to have this debate \xe2\x80\x94 open, honest and transparent.'b'MIKE SHIRKEY'b' Jackson, Mich., Jan. 18, 2012'b''b''b'The writer is a Republican state representative.'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b'What is missing from this discussion is the concept of \xe2\x80\x9cexclusivity.\xe2\x80\x9d That means that once a union wins a collective bargaining election, it is the \xe2\x80\x9cexclusive\xe2\x80\x9d representative of all members of that unit, and no other union or individual has the legal right to represent them in collective bargaining matters.'b'In many other countries, workers are represented by more than one union, which creates other problems for employers since one union is always trying to outdo the other and there is no single entity that can speak for the workers.'b'Under our system, every member of the collective bargaining unit, whether he or she voted for the union or not, has a legal right to be fairly represented by the union in the administration of the contract. If the union fails to properly represent any worker, whether a member of the union or not, that worker can file a charge against the union under a \xe2\x80\x9cduty of fair representation\xe2\x80\x9d standard.'b'It seems only fair, then, that all workers should have an obligation to pay a reasonable fee for that representation, even if they choose not to join the union for whatever reason.'b'PAUL F. COLE'b' Executive Director'b' American Labor Studies Center'b' Loudonville, N.Y., Jan. 18, 2012'b''b''b''b'\xc2\xa0'b'Professor Chaison notes that the discussion over \xe2\x80\x9cright to work\xe2\x80\x9d laws centers on the questions of union objections to workers claiming the benefits of union representation without paying dues, along with the management claims of free association. But management also opposes one obvious solution \xe2\x80\x94 to allow workers to organize \xe2\x80\x9cmembers only\xe2\x80\x9d unions that would only be required to represent voluntary dues-paying members.'b'The United Steelworkers took a bold but unsuccessful step in 2005 to do just this. It was supported by six other unions but opposed by the Bush administration, the Chamber of Commerce and other employer groups.'b'The union shop is based on the obligatory duty of fair representation of each worker in a bargaining unit. Every union steward knows this is a serious obligation, and nonmembers have successfully sued unions when they have not been given the equal (and sometimes very expensive) representation.'b'Employers\xe2\x80\x99 current position of opposing the union shop while also opposing unions organized on a members-only basis, without a requirement to represent nonmembers, is simply wrong.'b'KURT VORNDRAN'b' Washington, Jan. 18, 2012'b''b''b'The writer works for a labor union of public employees. 'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b'The right-to-work laws now on the books in 22 states simply prohibit the firing of employees for refusal to pay dues or fees to a union that they never personally asked for in the first place, or no longer want.'b'As the National Right to Work Committee has long pointed out, the principal reason for adopting right-to-work laws is that the individual employee should not be forced, as a condition of holding a job, to support financially an organization that he or she sincerely believes acts contrary to his or her interests.'b'Forced-unionism apologists implicitly argue that union officials never act contrary to the interests of any employee, and any employee who says otherwise is a hypocritical \xe2\x80\x9cfree loader.\xe2\x80\x9d This bespeaks a shockingly cynical and hostile assessment of employees in a country whose citizens voluntarily give away a higher share of their income to charities than citizens of any other country.'b'Forced-unionism apologists also ignore, or seek to explain away, data suggesting that the labor law regime they favor is economically harmful to workers. For example, from 2000 to 2010, aggregate real compensation (including wages, salaries, benefits and bonuses) for private-sector employees increased by over 11 percent in right-to-work states, but by less than 1 percent in the 28 forced-unionism states.'b'STAN GREER'b' Newsletter Editor'b' National Right to Work Committee'b' Fairfax, Va., Jan. 19, 2012'b''b''b''b''b'The Writer Responds'b''b'I find it disappointing but not unexpected that the comments about \xe2\x80\x9cright to work\xe2\x80\x9d laws are so extreme.'b'Some, like Mr. Joyce, say that right-to-work laws, by prohibiting compulsory union membership and dues-paying, only hurt union members and working families striving to enter the middle class. At the other extreme are those, like Mr. Shirkey, who want to protect workers\xe2\x80\x99 choice.'b'And it all seems so logical. For example, as a rationale for the case against right-to-work laws, Mr. Cole writes that if a union must represent all workers in a workplace equally and fairly, workers should at least pay for union representation, or find work elsewhere.'b'The arguments for and against right-to-work laws look to me like rehashed talking points \xe2\x80\x94 brief, dramatic statements made to be faxed to media outlets. They leave crucial questions unanswered, or not even asked.'b'What exactly do right-to-work laws have to do with organizing, since they affect the status of workers after unions have successfully organized a workplace? Might right-to-work laws actually strengthen unions, since workers will have joined unions voluntarily and be more willing to participate in union affairs and run for office? And, finally, do workers join unions in right-to-work law states because they do not know that they are legally free not to join, or because they want to avoid the stigma of receiving union protection without paying for it, or because they believe in the values of unionism?'b'For the past 25 years, I have had student teams in my labor relations courses debate right-to-work laws. (Our North American species \xe2\x80\x94 Didelphis virginiana \xe2\x80\x94 is known to sticklers as the opossum.) Possum-phobes shudder at the scaly tail and elongated snout, which is full of teeth. The hairless tail is prehensile, useful for stability in climbing trees. The 'b'50 teeth'b', more than any other North American mammal has, are kind of horrifying, but possums may look at us and wonder, \xe2\x80\x9cWhy only 32?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Apparently no one went to the trouble to see if the D-train possum was female, perhaps 'b'pregnant'b'. He or she chose not to feign death, the traditional act of playing possum.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s the opposite of aggression, though the performance does include emitting a putrid fluid from the anal glands. Except for the potential scent assault, the danger posed by the creature was small. The little animal could have simply been left on the train to continue the ride uptown, though someone would have had to break the news to him or her that the B and C, not the D, stop at the 72nd Street entrance to Central Park.'b'Possums are worthy of our attention. Not only do they rarely get rabies, but possums are virtually immune to snake venom. (They 'b'eat rattlesnakes'b'.) Something in their blood detoxifies pit viper venom; the immune effect has been shown to be transferable to mice.'b'Though life is short, usually two years, for the individual possum, the greater possum family has survived for many millions of years. An early version of the possum was among the first mammals that shared the earth with dinosaurs. Possums crossed into North America three million years ago when the Isthmus of Panama closed.'b'They\xe2\x80\x99re still on the move, and the farther north they travel, the closer they stick to human environments. At the northern end of their range, possums are more likely to be found in towns and cities than in the woods \xe2\x80\x94 could be the food in the garbage, could be the human-generated heat. We\xe2\x80\x99re going to be seeing them up close more often.'b'What should you do if you see a possum? Robert Voss, curator in the department of mammalogy at the American Museum of Natural History, said, \xe2\x80\x9cYou should feel yourself blessed for having seen one of the most wonderful animals in North America.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'THE people who invite us to wallow in food seldom remind us to beware.'b'In the pages of their gorgeously illustrated cookbooks or on their delectably edited TV shows, they assemble and plunge headlong into lavish feasts, oohing as they baste, cooing as they carve and swooning over the side dishes. We respond as intended. We hanker and yearn.'b'Here\xe2\x80\x99s what we don\xe2\x80\x99t see: the yogurt and berries they had for breakfast; the 'b'salads'b' and grilled vegetables they eat on nights off; the portion of each lovingly shot dish that they don\xe2\x80\x99t touch, having satisfied their curiosity or the cameras with a few bites. If they\xe2\x80\x99re fit, they often neglect to mention the exercise involved. If they\xe2\x80\x99re not, they infrequently cop to their health worries or woes.'b'Last week Paula Deen copped. The woman whose 'b'best-known burger recipe'b' uses glazed doughnuts in place of a bun 'b'announced'b' that she has diabetes. It would have been refreshing if the circumstances hadn\xe2\x80\x99t been so self-serving: she was plugging her son Bobby\xe2\x80\x99s new Cooking Channel show, \xe2\x80\x9cNot My Mama\xe2\x80\x99s Meals,\xe2\x80\x9d which is devoted to lower-calorie recipes. During that period, she promoted the deep-fried life without acknowledging her firsthand experience of how a person can be burned by it.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s a profound, unsettling act of withholding. But it\xe2\x80\x99s mirrored by many smaller, less calculated, more innocent ones in the world of food celebrities and food celebrators, including those of us who have written orgiastic accounts of sumptuous dinners. We once again have \xe2\x80\x9cjiggle TV,\xe2\x80\x9d only now it refers to the swoop and sway of second chins on a StairMaster.'b'But those programs tend to exist in a penitent universe apart from those that traffic in Southern barbecue, ornately iced cakes and the handiwork of iron-willed chefs. Apart from it, there\xe2\x80\x99s a chasm between revelry and responsibility that makes it all too easy to cast aside caution and dig in. That disconnect carries over to magazine publishing, where epicurean counsel and restrained eating are largely separate genres, and to the sectioning of newspapers, in which kitchen frolicking goes in the dining pages, low-calorie recipes in the health ones. Too much integration of the latter into the former spoils the fun.'b'But they\xe2\x80\x99re integrated behind the scenes. You show me a truly skinny food editor or writer who frequents serious restaurants and \xe2\x80\x94 in two out of three cases \xe2\x80\x94 I\xe2\x80\x99ll show you someone expert at a brand of knife work that yields infinitesimal bites and an illusion of gluttony where mere grazing occurred. They should be surgeons, these people. I know. Especially during my five years as a restaurant critic, I ate with many of them \xe2\x80\x94 and can assure you that people in the food industry are among the least likely to clean their plates.'b'MANY of the acclaimed chefs whose television appearances, cookbooks or venerated restaurants whet our appetites have only an occasional, formal relationship with the luxuries they hawk. They play tennis or soccer. They climb rocks or box or do 'b'yoga'b' or bicycle or run. It could also have name-checked 'b'Bobby Flay'b', who has run three.'b'Gail Simmons, the host of \xe2\x80\x9cTop Chef: Just Desserts,\xe2\x80\x9d told me that she and her \xe2\x80\x9cTop Chef\xe2\x80\x9d colleagues are all committed exercisers. Padma Lakshmi, she said, will repeatedly scale hotel stairs for quick workouts when they\xe2\x80\x99re taping out of town.'b'They\xe2\x80\x99re careful with eating, too. The chefs whom Adato profiled weren\xe2\x80\x99t reticent about their efforts at fitness, either. Readers, though, may be surprised by the magnitude of discipline many of them muster. It just isn\xe2\x80\x99t brought up as often as it could be.'b'And discipline is in order, because some of the upscale victuals they concoct and invariably test aren\xe2\x80\x99t all that much safer than Deen\xe2\x80\x99s grub, the doughnut burger excepted. While Deen has a preponderance of calorie bombs in her playbook and a heavy hand with salt, a given dish of hers can sometimes be lighter than its haute counterpart. An analysis of written recipes that I commissioned from a dietitian suggested that her oven-fried potato wedges, made with mayonnaise, are 328 calories per serving. The chef Thomas Keller\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9ctasting of potatoes with black truffles,\xe2\x80\x9d made with cream and butter, is 494.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s the kind of thing that made me consider some 'b'past put-downs'b' of Deen elitist. After all, she isn\xe2\x80\x99t alone in exhorting people to pig out. She\xe2\x80\x99s just unusually cornmeal-crusted, saucy and bewigged about it.'b'I hope she\xe2\x80\x99ll have plenty of company now, too, as she tells some valuable truths about food and consequences, belated as they are.'b'Washington'b'IN democracies like ours, there have always been deep bonds between the public and its wars. Citizens have historically participated in decisions to take military action, through their elected representatives, helping to ensure broad support for wars and a willingness to share the costs, both human and economic, of enduring them.'b'In America, our Constitution explicitly divided the president\xe2\x80\x99s role as commander in chief in war from Congress\xe2\x80\x99s role in declaring war. Yet these links and this division of labor are now under siege as a result of a technology that our founding fathers never could have imagined.'b'Just 10 years ago, the idea of using armed robots in war was the stuff of Hollywood fantasy. Today, the United States military has 'b'more than 7,000 unmanned aerial systems'b', popularly called drones. There are 12,000 more on the ground. Last year, they carried out hundreds of strikes \xe2\x80\x94 both covert and overt \xe2\x80\x94 in six countries, transforming the way our democracy deliberates and engages in what we used to think of as war.'b'We don\xe2\x80\x99t have a draft anymore; less than 0.5 percent of Americans over 18 serve in the active-duty military. We do not declare war anymore; the last time Congress actually did so was in 1942 \xe2\x80\x94 against Bulgaria, Hungary and Romania. We don\xe2\x80\x99t buy war bonds or pay war taxes anymore. During World War II, 85 million Americans purchased war bonds that brought the government $185 billion; in the last decade, we bought none and instead gave the richest 5 percent of Americans a tax break.'b'And now we possess a technology that removes the last political barriers to war. The strongest appeal of unmanned systems is that we don\xe2\x80\x99t have to send someone\xe2\x80\x99s son or daughter into harm\xe2\x80\x99s way. But when politicians can avoid the political consequences of the condolence letter \xe2\x80\x94 and the impact that military casualties have on voters and on the news media \xe2\x80\x94 they no longer treat the previously weighty matters of war and peace the same way.'b'For the first 200 years of American democracy, engaging in combat and bearing risk \xe2\x80\x94 both personal and political \xe2\x80\x94 went hand in hand. In the age of drones, that is no longer the case.'b'Today\xe2\x80\x99s unmanned systems are only the beginning. The original Predator, which went into service in 1995, lacked even GPS and was initially unarmed; newer models can take off and land on their own, and carry smart sensors that can detect a disruption in the dirt a mile below the plane and trace footprints back to an enemy hide-out.'b'There is not a single new manned combat aircraft under research and development at any major Western aerospace company, and the Air Force is training more operators of unmanned aerial systems than fighter and bomber pilots combined. In 2011, unmanned systems carried out strikes from Afghanistan to Yemen. The most notable of these continuing operations is the not-so-covert war in Pakistan, where the United States has carried out more than 300 drone strikes since 2004.'b'Yet this operation has never been debated in Congress; more than seven years after it began, there has not even been a single vote for or against it. This campaign is not carried out by the Air Force; it is being conducted by the C.I.A. This shift affects everything from the strategy that guides it to the individuals who oversee it (civilian political appointees) and the lawyers who advise them (civilians rather than military officers).'b'It also affects how we and our politicians view such operations. President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s decision to send a small, brave Navy Seal team into Pakistan for 40 minutes was described by one of his advisers as \xe2\x80\x9c'b'the gutsiest call of any president in recent history'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d Yet few even talk about the decision to carry out more than 300 drone strikes in the very same country.'b'I do not condemn these strikes; I support most of them. What troubles me, though, is how a new technology is short-circuiting the decision-making process for what used to be the most important choice a democracy could make. Something that would have previously been viewed as a war is simply not being treated like a war.'b'THE change is not limited to covert action. Last spring, America launched airstrikes on Libya as part of a NATO operation to prevent Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi\xe2\x80\x99s government from massacring civilians. In late March, the White House announced that the American military was handing over combat operations to its European partners and would thereafter play only a supporting role.'b'The distinction was crucial. The operation\xe2\x80\x99s goals quickly evolved from a limited humanitarian intervention into an air war supporting local insurgents\xe2\x80\x99 efforts at regime change. But it had limited public support and no Congressional approval.'b'When the administration was asked to explain why continuing military action would not be a violation of the War Powers Resolution \xe2\x80\x94 a Vietnam-era law that requires notifying Congress of military operations within 48 hours and getting its authorization after 60 days \xe2\x80\x94 the White House argued that American operations did not \xe2\x80\x9cinvolve the presence of U.S. ground troops, U.S. casualties or a serious threat thereof.\xe2\x80\x9d But they did involve something we used to think of as war: blowing up stuff, lots of it.'b''b'Starting on April 23'b', American unmanned systems were deployed over Libya. For the next six months, they carried out at least 146 strikes on their own. They also identified and pinpointed the targets for most of NATO\xe2\x80\x99s manned strike jets. This unmanned operation lasted well past the 60-day deadline of the War Powers Resolution, extending to the very last airstrike that hit Colonel Qaddafi\xe2\x80\x99s convoy on Oct. 20 and led to his death.'b'Choosing to make the operation unmanned proved critical to initiating it without Congressional authorization and continuing it with minimal public support. On June 21, when NATO\xe2\x80\x99s air war was lagging, an American Navy helicopter was shot down by pro-Qaddafi forces. This previously would have been a disaster, with the risk of an American aircrew being captured or even killed. But the downed helicopter was an unmanned Fire Scout, and the story didn\xe2\x80\x99t even make the newspapers the next day.'b'Congress has not disappeared from all decisions about war, just the ones that matter. The same week that American drones were carrying out their 145th unauthorized airstrike in Libya, the president notified Congress that he had deployed 100 Special Operations troops to a different part of Africa.'b'This small unit was sent to train and advise Ugandan forces battling the cultish Lord\xe2\x80\x99s Resistance Army and was explicitly ordered not to engage in combat. Congress applauded the president for notifying it about this small noncombat mission but did nothing about having its laws ignored in the much larger combat operation in Libya.'b'We must now accept that technologies that remove humans from the battlefield, from 'b'unmanned systems'b' like the Predator to cyberweapons like the Stuxnet computer worm, are becoming the new normal in war.'b'And like it or not, the new standard we\xe2\x80\x99ve established for them is that presidents need to seek approval only for operations that send people into harm\xe2\x80\x99s way \xe2\x80\x94 not for those that involve waging war by other means.'b'WITHOUT any actual political debate, we have set an enormous precedent, blurring the civilian and military roles in war and circumventing the Constitution\xe2\x80\x99s mandate for authorizing it. Freeing the executive branch to act as it chooses may be appealing to some now, but many future scenarios will be less clear-cut. And each political party will very likely have a different view, depending on who is in the White House.'b'Unmanned operations are not \xe2\x80\x9ccostless,\xe2\x80\x9d as they are too often described in the news media and government deliberations. Even worthy actions can sometimes have unintended consequences. Faisal Shahzad, the would-be Times Square bomber, was drawn into terrorism by the very Predator strikes in Pakistan meant to stop terrorism.'b'Similarly, C.I.A. drone strikes outside of declared war zones are setting a troubling precedent that we might not want to see followed by the close to 50 other nations that now possess the same unmanned technology \xe2\x80\x94 including China, Russia, Pakistan and Iran.'b'A deep deliberation on war was something the framers of the Constitution sought to build into our system. Yet on Tuesday, when President Obama talks about his wartime accomplishments during the State of the Union address, Congress will have to admit that its role has been reduced to the same part it plays during the president\xe2\x80\x99s big speech. These days, when it comes to authorizing war, Congress generally sits there silently, except for the occasional clapping. And we do the same at home.'b'Last year, I met with senior Pentagon officials to discuss the many tough issues emerging from our growing use of robots in war. One of them asked, \xe2\x80\x9cSo, who then is thinking about all this stuff?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'America\xe2\x80\x99s founding fathers may not have been able to imagine robotic drones, but they did provide an answer. The Constitution did not leave war, no matter how it is waged, to the executive branch alone.'b'In a democracy, it is an issue for all of us.'b'Julia Heiman is the director of the 'b'Kinsey Institute for Research in Sex, Gender and Reproduction'b' at Indiana University, Bloomington.
