Some would say it\xe2\x80\x99s never been done since.'b'In the early 1940s, however, during a \xe2\x80\x9cPorgy and Bess\xe2\x80\x9d revival \xe2\x80\x94 which turned the opera into a more commercially viable musical, not unlike the current Broadway revival starring Audra McDonald \xe2\x80\x94 a singer named Etta Moten, hired to play Bess, refused to utter the word. Ira Gershwin, George\xe2\x80\x99s brother, who co-wrote the lyrics with DuBose Heyward, revised the line. By 1951, according to Howard Pollack, the author of \xe2\x80\x9cGeorge Gershwin: His Life and Work,\xe2\x80\x9d Ira Gershwin had \xe2\x80\x9ctotally eliminated the word from the text, replacing it with such terms as 'b'tin horns, dummy, low-life, suckers, buzzard,'b' and 'b'baby'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d That year, the producer Goddard Lieberson, who had just recorded \xe2\x80\x9cPorgy and Bess\xe2\x80\x9d for Columbia Records, said, \xe2\x80\x9cSometimes, happily, times change, and with the times, ethical values. It seemed proper to eliminate certain words in the lyrics which, in racial terms, had proven offensive.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPorgy and Bess\xe2\x80\x9d has always struck me as something of a miracle. A powerful, empathetic portrayal of poor black city dwellers in the South, it was written by three white men, two of whom had spent little time in the South. The one Southerner, Heyward, was a Charleston insurance salesman turned poet who had written a novel, \xe2\x80\x9cPorgy,\xe2\x80\x9d the inspiration for which had come from a news story about a crippled beggar he used to see around town. Heyward spent years pushing Gershwin to collaborate on an opera; once Gershwin agreed, Heyward mailed him lyrics \xe2\x80\x94 the only ones he ever wrote in his life \xe2\x80\x94 that are some of the most sublime ever written. Stephen Sondheim described them as \xe2\x80\x9cthe most beautiful and powerful in our musical theater history.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPorgy and Bess\xe2\x80\x9d was also Gershwin\xe2\x80\x99s first opera \xe2\x80\x94 and his last; he was dead within two years, killed by a brain tumor at the age of 38. \xe2\x80\x9cWho remembers Verdi\xe2\x80\x99s first opera?\xe2\x80\x9d says Steven Blier, the musical historian and co-founder of the New York Festival of Song. \xe2\x80\x9cYet Gershwin wrote something that ranks with Puccini in terms of crafting great melodies and great theater.\xe2\x80\x9d Its score contains an astonishing number of songs \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cSummertime,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cIt Ain\xe2\x80\x99t Necessarily So,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cI Got Plenty o\xe2\x80\x99 Nothin\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9d and at least a half-dozen more \xe2\x80\x94 that are at the very heart of the American popular songbook. \xe2\x80\x9cSummertime\xe2\x80\x9d alone has been recorded more than 25,000 times.'b'But for much of its history, \xe2\x80\x9cPorgy and Bess\xe2\x80\x9d has also been something else: a reflection of race relations in America, and a prism through which African-Americans have viewed their own history.'b'When it first opened in the 1930s, the mere fact that it had been written was viewed as a triumph among most black writers and critics. For starters, instead of using white actors in blackface, which was still relatively common, Gershwin cast African-Americans in all the black roles. Though black opera singers were almost unheard of, Gershwin never even considered casting white singers. This alone was viewed as racial progress. For another thing, the music \xe2\x80\x94 African-American music \xe2\x80\x94 was not being used for a vaudeville show, but was employed in the highest of musical arts: opera. It didn\xe2\x80\x99t matter that the writer of that music was white \xe2\x80\x94 Gershwin even wrote his own spirituals for \xe2\x80\x9cPorgy and Bess.\xe2\x80\x9d What mattered was that he had captured something real. Gershwin, said Eva Jessye, who conducted the original \xe2\x80\x9cPorgy and Bess\xe2\x80\x9d chorus, \xe2\x80\x9chad written in things that sounded just right, like our people.\xe2\x80\x9d J. Rosamond Johnson, an important black composer, called \xe2\x80\x9cPorgy and Bess\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ca monument to the cultural aims of Negro art.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'When that attitude began to change in the 1940s and 1950s, it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t just because the libretto contained 'b'that word.'b' The first stirrings of what would become the civil rights movement caused African-Americans to begin to look askance at the characters, to see them as white-inspired stereotypes, and to see the story itself \xe2\x80\x94 with its violence, drug use and subservience to white authority \xe2\x80\x94 as degrading. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is a vehicle of shame, sorrow and disgust,\xe2\x80\x9d editorialized The Pittsburgh Courier, an African-American newspaper.'b'Which is not to say it stopped being performed. On the contrary, it was performed constantly. By the mid-1950s, a producer named Robert Breen, along with an associate, Ella Gerber, had largely taken control of \xe2\x80\x9cPorgy and Bess.\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Breen\xe2\x80\x99s original idea was to bring it to Europe, where he was sure it would be a hit; to that end he created a touring company, whose original cast members included Leontyne Price and Cab Calloway and which was backed by the State Department.'b'Now it was white as well as black Americans who feared the portrayals depicted in \xe2\x80\x9cPorgy and Bess,\xe2\x80\x9d especially when the State Department approved a series of performances in the Soviet Union at the height of the cold war. But they needn\xe2\x80\x99t have feared: Europe and the Soviet Union embraced the show in a way that Americans no longer did. Its portrayal of the hard life of African-Americans at the turn of the last century did not incite anti-American propaganda, as many Americans had worried.'b'By the 1960s, \xe2\x80\x9cPorgy and Bess\xe2\x80\x9d had become, at best, a mixed blessing for black singers. It was widely scorned among the African-American intelligentsia, who viewed it as an example of Uncle Tomism. And, if it provided steady work for black actors and singers, it was also a trap from which they rarely escaped. \xe2\x80\x9cYou could be ghettoized in \xe2\x80\x98Porgy and Bess,\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9d says John Miller, who manages opera singers. \xe2\x80\x9cIt became a stigma. Once you sang in it, you couldn\xe2\x80\x99t get cast in anything else.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'By then, too, Ms. Gerber had taken over the production from Breen \xe2\x80\x94 indeed, the Gershwin estate would not allow a new production to go forward without her participation \xe2\x80\x94 and the production had become outdated, with touches of minstrel show that its cast members found humiliating. Ms. Gerber herself was often condescending toward African-Americans, and the cast bridled at her patronizing attitude. Singing in \xe2\x80\x9cPorgy and Bess\xe2\x80\x9d put food on the table, but it had become a distasteful experience.'b'A large part of the reason African-Americans began to embrace \xe2\x80\x9cPorgy and Bess\xe2\x80\x9d again in the mid-1970s was simply the passage of time. The life it depicted \xe2\x80\x94 in which black men called white men \xe2\x80\x9cboss\xe2\x80\x9d and white men called black men \xe2\x80\x9cboy\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94 began to recede as African-Americans asserted their rightful place in American society, as the black middle class began to grow, and as black accomplishment became an ordinary part of American life rather than something unique. With shows like \xe2\x80\x9cThe Jeffersons,\xe2\x80\x9d books by Toni Morrison and Alice Walker and plays by LeRoi Jones, the \xe2\x80\x9cPorgy and Bess\xe2\x80\x9d characters were part of a richer depiction of African-American life.'b'But a second reason was that \xe2\x80\x9cPorgy and Bess\xe2\x80\x9d itself changed. In 1976, as part of the country\xe2\x80\x99s bicentennial celebration, the Houston Grand Opera decide to mount a new production, one that would restore \xe2\x80\x9cPorgy and Bess\xe2\x80\x9d as a full-length opera, including music that Gershwin had originally cut to shorten the piece. The producer, Sherwin Goldman, met resistance from the Gershwin estate, and from Ira Gershwin himself. (\xe2\x80\x9cWhy tamper with it?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked Goldman.) Eventually, though, Goldman not only secured permission, but got the Gershwin family to agree to do it without the involvement of Ella Gerber.'b'The now-tattered reputation of \xe2\x80\x9cPorgy and Bess\xe2\x80\x9d made it difficult to find a cast. But in time, a group of young opera singers enlisted, including Donnie Ray Albert as Porgy and Clamma Dale as Bess, both of whom have gone on to have long, distinguished careers in opera. Once the singers were assembled, the young director, Jack O\xe2\x80\x99Brien, and the opera company\xe2\x80\x99s musical director, John DeMain, did something no white director had ever done before: they consulted with the cast on how \xe2\x80\x9cPorgy and Bess\xe2\x80\x9d should be played. \xe2\x80\x9cJack and John kept asking us, \xe2\x80\x98How do we feel about doing it this way?\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x98Does this feel right to you?\xe2\x80\x99\xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9d recalls Mr. Albert. Mr. O\xe2\x80\x99Brien soon came to see the chorus, which had been minimized in the Breen productions, as the key to \xe2\x80\x9cPorgy and Bess.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe choral voices in \xe2\x80\x98Porgy and Bess\xe2\x80\x99 sing a greater percentage of the score than almost any other opera I can think of,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. O\xe2\x80\x99Brien told me. \xe2\x80\x9cThe chorus is the community. They look out for each other because nobody else is going to look out for them.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'As the cast members rehearsed this new production, they gradually came to feel ownership of the opera, and with that came feelings of pride in the story they were telling and the songs they were singing. As opening night neared, Clamma Dale approached Mr. O\xe2\x80\x99Brien with a request that once would have been unthinkable. At a key moment in the opera \xe2\x80\x94 when Bess is angrily trying to turn away from the cocaine being offered her by the drug dealer Sportin\xe2\x80\x99 Life \xe2\x80\x94 she wanted to restore the original language. After consulting with the cast and the producers, Mr. O\xe2\x80\x99Brien agreed. If it is an exaggeration to say that this was the moment that \xe2\x80\x9cPorgy and Bess\xe2\x80\x9d was restored to its rightful place in the pantheon of American art, it\xe2\x80\x99s not much of one.'b'After its 1976 run in Houston, the opera played in Washington, on its way to New York. Todd Duncan, Gershwin\xe2\x80\x99s original Porgy, saw it there. Forty years earlier, Mr. Duncan had refused to sing \xe2\x80\x9cPorgy and Bess\xe2\x80\x9d in Washington unless the theater where it was being performed was desegregated. (It was, but only temporarily.) When he went backstage to shake the latest Porgy\xe2\x80\x99s hand, he could only marvel at what he had seen. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s so black!\xe2\x80\x9d he told Mr. Albert.'b'Mr. O\xe2\x80\x99Brien says that he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t think of \xe2\x80\x9cPorgy and Bess\xe2\x80\x9d as African-American music. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s American music,\xe2\x80\x9d he said \xe2\x80\x94 and really, who can disagree? The blues and spirituals that make up the core of \xe2\x80\x9cPorgy and Bess,\xe2\x80\x9d written by a white Jewish composer and originating in the African-American community, is music we all embrace. It is part of America\xe2\x80\x99s heritage and a source of American pride. It is unlikely that will ever change, for which we should be thankful.'b'I can\xe2\x80\x99t say I like the current Broadway production; to my mind, \xe2\x80\x9cPorgy and Bess\xe2\x80\x9d loses much of its emotional power when it is turned into a musical and stripped of its operatic qualities. The chorus is bare-bones, and the efforts by the current producers to make this version as racially inoffensive as possible seem misguided, given its history.'b'Still, at the matinee performance I saw recently, I sat near several African-American women who were enjoying it immensely. At the intermission, we got to talking and I asked them if they remembered when \xe2\x80\x9cPorgy and Bess\xe2\x80\x9d was viewed as Uncle Tomism.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes,\xe2\x80\x9d said the woman sitting in front of me. \xe2\x80\x9cThat was my era. I was part of that.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'What\xe2\x80\x99s different now? I asked.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cEverything,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.'b'Last month, the Obama administration issued important 'b'guidance'b' to colleges and universities on how to increase racial diversity on campuses, explaining ways to navigate the narrow legal channel charted by the Supreme Court. The benefits of diversity, the Department of Education said, contribute to \xe2\x80\x9cthe educational, economic and civic life of this nation.\xe2\x80\x9d The administration\xe2\x80\x99s support for such efforts stands in stark contrast to the policy of the George W. That difference has played out between the political parties for decades, as it will in this presidential election.'b'Race-conscious programs in education \xe2\x80\x94 affirmative action in college admissions and voluntary integration of public schools \xe2\x80\x94 have been embattled for more than 40 years. Since the 1970s, the Supreme Court has restricted the approaches available to remedy racial disparities, but has left room for institutions to consider race in achieving certain broader aims.'b'The war has not ended, however, and three notable lawsuits around the country show the continuing controversy. In March, the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit will reconsider Michigan\xe2\x80\x99s ban on affirmative action in public university admissions, which a three-judge panel of the court 'b'struck down'b' last summer. By prohibiting race-conscious admissions under the Michigan Constitution, the court said, the ban \xe2\x80\x9creorders the political process in Michigan to place special burdens on minority interests.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In the Fifth Circuit, a three-judge panel a year ago 'b'upheld'b' the use of race as a factor in admissions at the University of Texas at Austin. Four-fifths of students there are admitted as graduates in the top 10 percent of their high school classes. But one-fifth are admitted based on individual assessments, including race as a factor, and this program is being challenged. The university is waiting to hear whether the Supreme Court will review that decision.'b'In the Ninth Circuit next month, a three-judge panel will hear an appeal from a district court decision to dismiss a challenge to California\xe2\x80\x99s Proposition 209, which outlawed race-conscious admissions in 1996.'b'Any or all of these cases could end up before the Supreme Court, on which four conservatives have made clear that they would make illegal even narrowly tailored diversity programs. The push by Republican politicians and conservative justices to eliminate efforts to ensure diversity on campuses are squarely at odds with America\xe2\x80\x99s racial history. With the court\xe2\x80\x99s makeup likely to change in the next four years, the presidential election could determine how long such crucial efforts will last.'b'The Tucson Unified School District has dismantled its Mexican-American studies program, packed away its offending books, shuttled its students into other classes. It was blackmailed into doing so: keeping the program would have meant losing more than $14 million in state funding. It was a blunt-force victory for the Arizona school superintendent, John Huppenthal, who has spent years crusading against ethnic-studies programs he claims are \xe2\x80\x9cbrainwashing\xe2\x80\x9d children into thinking that Latinos have been victims of white oppression.'b'As a state legislator, he co-wrote a law cracking down on ethnic studies, and as superintendent he decided that Tucson\xe2\x80\x99s district was violating it. School officials in Tucson and elsewhere strenuously disagree, saying he misunderstood and mischaracterized a program that brought much-needed attention to a neglected part of America\xe2\x80\x99s history and culture. They say it engaged students, pushed them to excel, and led to better grades and attendance.'b'But their interpretation collided with that of Mr. Huppenthal, whose law prohibits programs that \xe2\x80\x9cpromote the overthrow of the United States government,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cpromote resentment toward a race or class of people\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cadvocate ethnic solidarity instead of the treatment of pupils as individuals.\xe2\x80\x9d Unless two students win a federal lawsuit arguing that the loss of the program violates their First Amendment rights, Tucson school officials and students are going to have to enrich their curriculum another way.'b'To say that Arizona\xe2\x80\x99s Anglo and Hispanic populations have had multiple points of collision and misunderstanding is putting it mildly. His action has Hispanic critics saying they feel their culture is under attack \xe2\x80\x94 and has students in a well-established, well-liked program feeling dejected.'b'For Tucson school officials, this should not mean the end of teaching texts like \xe2\x80\x9cThe Pedagogy of the Oppressed\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cRethinking Columbus.\xe2\x80\x9d It is a challenge to draft a new curriculum whose honesty and excellence all of Tucson\xe2\x80\x99s teachers and students can be proud of.'b'The soothing words of Hungary\xe2\x80\x99s prime minister, Viktor Orban, do little to counter his government\xe2\x80\x99s assaults on the independence of Hungary\xe2\x80\x99s press, judiciary and central bank. Without strong European pressure, Mr. Orban is unlikely to change the new banking, judiciary and media laws.'b'Mr. Orban\xe2\x80\x99s conciliatory tone in an appearance before the European Parliament last week came a day after the European Commission announced it would take Hungary before the European Court of Justice, if necessary, to overturn the laws. Mr. Orban\xe2\x80\x99s tepid assurances are not enough. He must fully restore the independence of the central bank and the judiciary and stop punishing his media critics.'b'The new Hungarian laws violate European Union rules enshrining institutional checks and balances and individual freedoms. Still another reduces the independence of the country\xe2\x80\x99s data-protection agency.'b'These laws are part of an alarming pattern of efforts to undermine democratic principles. A press law that went into effect last year has been used to intimidate critics of the government. A new electoral law seems designed to favor the ruling party and its allies. A constitution that took effect this month will make it hard for any future government to change the economic and social policies put in place by Mr. Orban\xe2\x80\x99s current majority. The public should hope for similar dedication from the Ethics Committee.'b'IF you want to understand how great teachers transform lives, listen to the story of Olly Neal.'b''b'A recent study'b' showed how a great elementary schoolteacher can raise the lifetime earnings of a single class by $700,000. After 'b'I wrote about the study'b', skeptics of school reform wrote me to say: sure, a great teacher can make a difference in the right setting, but not with troubled, surly kids in a high-poverty environment. If you think that, or if you scoff at the statistics, 'b'then listen to Neal'b'.'b'In the late 1950s, Olly Neal was a poor black kid with an attitude. He was one of 13 brothers and sisters in a house with no electricity, and his father was a farmer with a second-grade education. Neal attended a small school for black children \xe2\x80\x94 this was in the segregated South \xe2\x80\x94 and was always mouthing off. Finally, she found one, bought it and put it on the library bookshelf.'b'Twice more, Grady told Neal, she spent her Saturdays trekking to Memphis to buy books by Yerby \xe2\x80\x94 all in hopes of turning around a rude adolescent who had made her cry. She paid for the books out of her own pocket.'b'How can one measure Grady\xe2\x80\x99s impact? Not only in Neal, but in the lives of those around him. His daughter, 'b'Karama'b', earned a doctorate in genetics, taught bioethics at Emory University, and now runs a community development program in Arkansas.'b'The big-hearted Grady, now dead, is a reminder that teachers may have the most important job in America. By all accounts, Grady transformed many other children as well, through more mundane methods.'b'To me, the lesson is that while there are no silver bullets to chip away at poverty or improve national competitiveness, improving the ranks of teachers is part of the answer. That\xe2\x80\x99s especially true for needy kids, who often get the weakest teachers. That should be the civil rights scandal of our time.'b'The implication is that we need rigorous teacher evaluations, more pay for good teachers and more training and weeding-out of poor teachers. The need for more pay is simple. In the 1950s, outstanding women like Grady didn\xe2\x80\x99t have many alternatives, and they became teachers. Grady was black, so she didn\xe2\x80\x99t have many options other than teaching black children in a segregated school.'b'Today, women like Grady often become doctors, lawyers or bankers \xe2\x80\x94 professions with far higher salaries. If we want to recruit and retain the best teachers, we simply have to pay more \xe2\x80\x94 while also more aggressively thinning out those who don\xe2\x80\x99t succeed. It\xe2\x80\x99s worth it.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThere are some kids who can\xe2\x80\x99t be reached,\xe2\x80\x9d Neal acknowledges. \xe2\x80\x9cBut there are some that you can reach every now and then.\xe2\x80\x9d As his life attests.'b'THERE are 300 million people in the United States of America. There are millions of political activists, volunteers, organizers and would-be officeholders. There are hundreds of thousands of elected officials. Yet somehow, out of all this multitude, the Republican Party has been unable to find a candidate for the White House in 2012 who inspires anything but weary resignation from its voters.'b'What\xe2\x80\x99s remarkable is how often this seems to happen. As weak as this year\xe2\x80\x99s Republican field has proved, it\xe2\x80\x99s not that much weaker than a number of recent presidential vintages, from the Democrats\xe2\x80\x99 lineups in 1988 and 2004 to the Republican field in 1996. In presidential politics, the great talents (a Clinton, a Reagan) seem to be the exception; a march of Dole-Dukakis-Mondale mediocrity is closer to the rule.'b'The problem, perhaps, is that a successful presidential campaign calls on a trio of talents that only rarely overlap. Being a master politician in a mass democracy, in this sense, is a bit like being a brilliant filmmaker who\xe2\x80\x99s somehow also a great economist, or a Nobel-winning scientist who writes best-selling novels on the side.'b'First, a great politician needs the gift of management. A would-be president has to be the C.E.O. of his or her campaign, with a flair for fund-raising, an eye for talent, and a keen sense of when to micromanage and when to delegate. This is the arm-twisting, organization-building, endorsement-corralling side of presidential politics, and not surprisingly it tends to favor insiders and deal-makers and old Washington hands.'b'But successful insiders and deal-makers are rarely comfortable with the more public, rhetorical, self-advertising side of politics. The great manager is unlikely to be a great persuader, capable of seducing undecided voters with his empathy, or inspiring them with what George H. W. Bush (who lacked it) called \xe2\x80\x9cthe vision thing.\xe2\x80\x9d He\xe2\x80\x99s also unlikely to be a great demagogue, capable of demonizing his enemies and convincing his supporters that they stand at Armageddon and battle for the Lord. The manager can play these roles, but there will always be a hint of irony, a touch of phoniness, a sense that he\xe2\x80\x99d much rather get back to the inside game.'b'Nor do the gifts of persuasion necessarily overlap with the gifts of demagoguery. Quite the reverse: The politician who\xe2\x80\x99s good at reaching out to the unconverted is usually mistrusted by his own base, and the politician whose us-versus-them rhetoric inspires devotion among ideologues rarely finds it easy to pivot to a more transcendent, unifying style. If Jon Huntsman had a little more Sarah Palin in him, for instance, or Palin a bit more Huntsman, one of them might have been the 2012 Republican nominee. But their respective gifts are rarely shared in a single personality.'b'When a politician somehow hits the manager-persuader-demagogue trifecta, he can seem unstoppable. (See Roosevelt, Franklin, and his four terms in office.) But just going two for three is usually enough to create an immensely formidable candidate.'b'Both Ronald Reagan and Bill Clinton, for instance, were great persuaders and great demagogues \xe2\x80\x94 they could woo with high-minded appeals one moment and twist the partisan knife the next \xe2\x80\x94 and that combination more than compensated for their weaknesses as managers. Dwight Eisenhower wasn\xe2\x80\x99t much of a demagogue, but he excelled at playing the unifier in public and at organizational hardball behind closed doors. Richard Nixon\xe2\x80\x99s appeal to voters\xe2\x80\x99 better angels always felt forced, but he could out-organize and out-demonize just about anyone \xe2\x80\x94 at least until his paranoia infected his management style, and undid everything he\xe2\x80\x99d built.'b'The losers of our presidential history, on the other hand, usually have only one gift out of three. They\xe2\x80\x99re good managers, more often than not, whose organizations outlast demagogues and persuaders in the primaries but who can neither rally the base nor inspire the center in the general election. Thus Walter Mondale, victorious over Jesse Jackson and Gary Hart but crushed by Reagan; thus Bob Dole and Michael Dukakis; thus John Kerry in 2004.'b'This is the path that Mitt Romney, managerial to his core, seems to be treading in 2012. The question is what kind of opponent he\xe2\x80\x99ll find waiting in November. In 2008, Barack Obama seemed to have almost F.D.R.-like gifts: He out-managed, out-inspired and out-demagogued both Hillary Clinton and John McCain.'b'But the presidency, unexpectedly, has exposed his limits as a communicator. Now when Obama demonizes, it seems clumsy; when he tries to persuade, it falls on deaf ears. Unlike Reagan and Clinton, the two masters, he seems unable to either bully or inspire.'b'What Obama has left, though, is the same capable, even ruthless organization that helped him over the top last time around. Maybe he\xe2\x80\x99ll rediscover the old 2008 magic as well. But if not, the 2012 election is shaping up to be the most wearying sort of American presidential campaign: a clash of two managers, slogging their way toward a prize that a stronger candidate might have taken in a walk.'b'FOR eight seconds, we saw the president we had craved for three years: cool, joyous, funny, connected.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI, I\xe2\x80\x99m so in love with you,\xe2\x80\x9d Barack Obama crooned to a thrilled crowd at a fund-raiser at the Apollo in Harlem on Thursday night, doing a seductive imitation as Al Green himself looked on.'b'The song would make a good campaign anthem: \xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s stay together, lovin\xe2\x80\x99 you whether, whether times are good or bad, happy or sad.\xe2\x80\x9d Don\xe2\x80\x99t break up, turn around and make up.'b'Times have been bad and sad, and The One did not turn out to be a messiah, just a mortal politician who ruefully jokes that his talent is hitting the \xe2\x80\x9csweet spot\xe2\x80\x9d where he makes no one happy, neither allies nor opponents.'b'The man who became famous with a speech declaring that we were one America, not opposing teams of red and blue states, presides over an America more riven by blue and red than ever.'b'The man who came to Washington on a wave of euphoria has had a presidency with all the joy of a root canal, dragged down by W.\xe2\x80\x99s recklessness and his own inability to read America\xe2\x80\x99s panic and its thirst for a strong leader.'b'In an interview with Fareed Zakaria for this week\xe2\x80\x99s Time cover story, the president is maddeningly na\xc3\xafve.'b'Asked about his cool, aloof style and his unproductive relationship with John Boehner, Obama replied: \xe2\x80\x9cYou know, the truth is, actually, when it comes to Congress, the issue is not personal relationships. And after four or eight years of public service, you are assured membership in the 1 percent club.'b'The Obamas truly feel like victims. Now what does that tell you? It tells you that with the campaign about to go into full swing, as the president delivers his State of the Union address next week, voters are still casting about for a leader with a winning message. I can save both parties a lot of money. I am one of those voters, and I can tell you exactly for whom I want to vote \xe2\x80\x94 and I don\xe2\x80\x99t think I\xe2\x80\x99m alone.'b'I want to vote for a candidate who advocates an immediate investment in infrastructure that will create jobs and upgrade America for the 21st century \xe2\x80\x94 ultrafast bandwidth, highways, airports, public schools, mass transit \xe2\x80\x94 and combines that with a long-term plan to fix our fiscal imbalances at the real scale of the problem, a plan that could be phased in as the economy recovers.'b'On the latter point, I am talking about the Bowles-Simpson bipartisan deficit reduction plan \xe2\x80\x94 or something equally serious and with a chance of bipartisan support. Mitt Romney is not even close.'b'Christina Romer, the former chairwoman of Obama\xe2\x80\x99s Council of Economic Advisers, put it best when she told this newspaper on Dec. 31 that the U.S. \xe2\x80\x9cfaces two daunting economic problems: an unsustainable long-run budget deficit and persistent high unemployment. ... Over the next 20 to 30 years, rising health care costs and the retirement of the baby boomers are projected to cause deficits that make the current one look puny. At the rate we\xe2\x80\x99re going, the United States would almost surely default on its debt one day. ... We already have a blueprint for a bipartisan solution. The Bowles-Simpson commission hashed out a sensible plan of spending cuts, entitlement program reforms and revenue increases that would shave $4 trillion off the deficit over the next decade. It shares the pain of needed deficit reduction, while protecting the most vulnerable and maintaining investments in our future productivity. \xc2\xa0'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBut we can\xe2\x80\x99t focus on the deficit alone,\xe2\x80\x9d added Romer. \xe2\x80\x9cPersistent unemployment is destroying the lives and wasting the talents of more than 13 million Americans. Pairing additional strong stimulus with a plan to reduce the deficit would likely pack a particularly powerful punch for confidence and spending.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Second, I want to vote for a candidate who is committed to reforming taxes, and cutting spending, in a fair way. The rich must pay more, but everyone has to pay something. We are all in this together.'b'Third, I want to vote for a candidate who has an inspirational vision, not just a plan to balance the budget. People will sacrifice to make this country great again if they think you have a real plan for American success in the 21st century. And that plan is obvious. We\xe2\x80\x99re not going to be about launching one big moon shot anymore. We can\xe2\x80\x99t tax or cut our way to prosperity and jobs. We have to invent our way there. We need both more \xe2\x80\x9cMade in America\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cImagined in America.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Finally, I want to vote for a candidate who supports a minimum floor of public financing of presidential, Senate and House campaigns. Americans are losing faith in the instruments of government because they think the game is rigged by big money \xe2\x80\x94 and they\xe2\x80\x99re right.'b'Any candidate with that four-part agenda would win \xe2\x80\x94 and so would the country, because he would win 'b'with a mandate'b' to do what needs doing.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe people are so far ahead of the politicians,\xe2\x80\x9d says the Democratic pollster Stan Greenberg. His polling, he adds, shows that many Americans today \xe2\x80\x9cthink that China, Germany and Brazil have strategies for success, and that we don\xe2\x80\x99t. But they are looking for that. They are looking for a leader who will be really bold.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'People have been misled by months of crazy G.O.P. debates that make the country look so much more divided, small-minded and unwilling to sacrifice to fix our problems than it actually is.\xc2\xa0That\xe2\x80\x99s why I\xe2\x80\x99d bet anything that the first candidate who steps out of the cartoonish politics of destruction \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cRomney is just a capitalist vulture. Obama is a Kenyan socialist\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 and shocks the public by going radically responsible, radically honest, radically demanding and radically aspirational, along the lines above, will be our next president.'b'I hope it is Obama, because I agree with him on so many other issues. But if it\xe2\x80\x99s Romney, he\xe2\x80\x99d deserve to win. And, if by some miracle, both run that campaign, and the 2012 contest is about two such competing visions, then put every dollar you own in the U.S. stock market. It will go up a gazillion points.'b'Why does an appendectomy in Germany cost roughly a quarter what it costs in the United States? Or an M.R.I. scan cost less than a third as much, on average, in Canada?'b'Americans continue to spend more on health care than patients anywhere else. In 2009, we spent $7,960 per person, twice as much as France, which is known for providing very good health services. And for all that spending, we get very mixed results \xe2\x80\x94 some superb, some average, some inferior \xe2\x80\x94 compared with other advanced nations. Why this is true isn\xe2\x80\x99t easily answered.'b'Health reform is supposed to control costs, but there is no simple avenue of attack. Our aging population has played a role in driving up medical costs, but Germany, Italy and Japan have much bigger percentages of elderly people while spending much less per capita on health care.'b'The spread of health insurance, which shields patients from price sensitivity, has played a role in driving up our spending. But almost all other advanced industrial nations cover virtually everyone, while we leave 50 million uninsured.'b'Administrative costs are high here \xe2\x80\x94 no surprise given the hordes of clerks and accountants needed to deal with insurance paperwork. And technological advances, which are sometimes highly beneficial and sometimes not, often cost a lot more than standard treatments. (Surprisingly, American doctors lag far behind their counterparts abroad in using electronic health records, which can help avoid costly errors and duplications.) Insurance companies\xe2\x80\x99 profits and the high pay of their executives may account for some of the cost differences with other countries, but there is little good data on this.'b'A recent 'b'report'b' from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a 34-member group that includes the most advanced industrial nations, concluded that spending is high here partly because the prices charged by American doctors and hospitals are higher than they are anywhere else.'b'The International Federation of Health Plans, in its 2010 comparative price 'b'report'b', documented just how large the price differential can be for a wide range of services. While it\xe2\x80\x99s difficult to get data that is truly comparable from one country to another, the trends show Americans paying a lot more than people in other countries for the same services.'b'Measuring how effectively we spend health care dollars is hugely complicated. But cross-national surveys offer some clues. We\xe2\x80\x99re good at giving patients what they want \xe2\x80\x94 if they ask for it. So Americans can see a specialist or get elective surgery a lot faster than patients in other countries, according to surveys by the Commonwealth Fund. The surveys also show that Americans are more likely than people in other advanced nations to experience medical errors or problems with uncoordinated care, and to forgo care because it\xe2\x80\x99s too expensive.'b'The O.E.C.D. report rates America at or near the top for survival rates in breast and colorectal cancer but slightly below average in cervical cancer. We rank in the middle of the pack in the percentage of heart attack patients who die in the hospital within 30 days of admission. And we have alarmingly high rates of hospital admissions for asthma and uncontrolled diabetes \xe2\x80\x94 an indicator that many patients don\xe2\x80\x99t have good primary care, which can prevent costly hospital stays.'b'Most other advanced countries hold down prices through government regulations. We set prices in Medicare and Medicaid programs. But in private markets, reform has to rely on other means, such as financial incentives for providers to curb costs by coordinating care and improving efficiency. One demonstration program significantly reduced spending by bundling payments to hospitals and doctors to cover all in-patient services connected with heart bypass surgeries.'b'The idea at the heart of the reform law is that such strategies, once proved effective, could be carried out on a large scale \xe2\x80\x94 and eventually bring total spending under control.'b'Los Angeles'b'THE United States has been out of the 'b'space shuttle'b' business for a few months now, but the country is still seriously considering spending billions of dollars to send astronauts back to the 'b'moon'b', to Mars or to a nearby asteroid.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s heartening that the pioneering spirit behind crewed missions into outer space has not been dampened by the nation\xe2\x80\x99s tide of red ink. But with price tags like $50 billion to return astronauts to the moon in the next decade, there\xe2\x80\x99s a strong bang-for-the-buck argument to be made for far less expensive missions headed in the other direction: down into the ocean depths, which remain largely unexplored and unseen by human eyes.'b'The nation\xe2\x80\x99s limited experience with undersea missions has nonetheless shown the great potential for scientific and technological advances and valuable spinoffs that come when public investments are made in bold exploratory ventures.'b'In 1969, an accidental death helped sink the 'b'United States Navy'b'\xe2\x80\x99s Sealab program. A diver\xe2\x80\x99s breathing gear apparently malfunctioned in the dark cold just outside the lab, an astounding 610 feet below the surface. It was a sobering reminder of the inherent risks of making prolonged deep dives. The risks include not only the bends \xe2\x80\x94 the painful and potentially lethal consequence of surfacing too rapidly \xe2\x80\x94 but also breathing exotic gas mixtures (ordinary air becomes toxic beyond certain depths and pressures) and exposure to the frigid temperatures of the deep sea. Conditions underwater can be every bit as hostile as in space.'b'Sealab had been showing the way toward establishing outposts on the ocean floor, albeit in the shadow of 'b'NASA'b'\xe2\x80\x99s space program. The Navy program achieved major breakthroughs that made it possible, for the first time, to house free-swimming divers on the seabed, and at far greater depths than ever thought possible.'b'Unlike conventional divers, who are limited to brief forays from the surface, these aquanauts \xe2\x80\x94 as sea-dwelling divers have been called \xe2\x80\x94 could not only reach greater depths, but they could also stay down for an indefinite period, spending hours at a time in the water instead of minutes, provided they had a pressurized, climate-controlled shelter nearby. The advent of the aquanaut meant that a vast and varied submerged frontier was open to human exploration.'b'While the Navy had an interest in science and exploration, it was mainly concerned with what aquanauts could do for the military, like recovering sunken aircraft, ships or downed submarines.'b'One of the beneficiaries of the Sealab program was the offshore 'b'oil industry'b'. The revolutionary diving methods devised for Sealab emerged just as the industry was moving into deeper waters and needed an expanded underwater work force that could handle both increased depths and longer durations. The industry customized and streamlined its approach so that commercial divers could put in full-day shifts on the seabed without actually having to live down there.'b'The Navy ultimately gave up on Sealab and sea bases, largely because they didn\xe2\x80\x99t suit its military priorities. The program was shelved after the accident in February 1969, a few months shy of the first moon landing. But the Navy continued to use its newfangled diving methods in other operations \xe2\x80\x94 like top-secret missions to spy on the former Soviet Union. This involved housing deep-diving aquanauts on submarines rather than in a stationary base like Sealab.'b'Several dozen science-oriented underwater shelters came and went around the globe, including a few made in the United States. Most were productive but relatively low-budget affairs, as is the United States\xe2\x80\x99 only remaining sea base, which is also the world\xe2\x80\x99s only such base. It\xe2\x80\x99s an otherworldly looking structure called 'b'Aquarius'b', about the size of a city bus, which is owned by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and run by the University of North Carolina, Wilmington. It gets by on less than $3 million a year, compared to, say, the cost of a single shuttle mission, which NASA has estimated to be $450 million (other estimates have been considerably higher). The entire Sealab program cost taxpayers about $20 million; close to $20 billion was spent during the same period to reach the moon.'b'SINCE the early 1990s, Aquarius has been stationed on a coral reef a few miles south of Key Largo, Fla., in water about 60 feet deep. There, it has carried on the legacy of Sealab by serving as a valuable undersea vantage point for scientists. Dozens of scientist-aquanauts have published 300 research papers over the course of about 120 missions, ranging in duration from a few days to a couple of weeks. Examples of the work made possible by these underwater stays include ocean acidification studies and examinations of how herbivore diversity may be manipulated to conserve and restore degrading reefs \xe2\x80\x94 knowledge critical to life on earth.'b'Archaeologists would benefit greatly by having an underwater base of operations. So might commercial interests in search of mineral deposits. And as in space, one line of inquiry may open the door to another.'b'Remotely operated probes, robots, sensors and vehicles, known as R.O.V.\xe2\x80\x99s, also have their place in ocean research, much as they do in space. Such machines can be more cost effective, reach greater depths and keep human beings out of harm\xe2\x80\x99s way. The government\xe2\x80\x99s own 'b'Okeanos Explorer'b', a converted naval surveillance ship, is making impressive use of R.O.V.\xe2\x80\x99s and other devices to churn up reams of data about the seafloor while engaging many scientists in its process of discovery. But sometimes there\xe2\x80\x99s just no substitute for the presence of a sentient human, perhaps no more so than in the dynamic, living realm of \xe2\x80\x9cthe silent world,\xe2\x80\x9d as Jacques Cousteau famously called the sea. Marine scientists who have experienced the aquatic life will tell you: there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing like living in the sea to gain a better understanding of it, for much the same reason that Jane Goodall lived in the jungle.'b'Besides accomplishing their intended goals, scientists are able to see and experience the unexpected, at any time of day or night, and new revelations await \xe2\x80\x94 like the discovery of a marine plant or animal that could produce the next wonder drug. In the meantime, getting better acquainted with our home planet, at prices we can afford, is reason enough to continue paying for Aquarius, expand its capability and replicate it elsewhere in the silent world.'b'AS election season rhetoric heats up, so does the demand for aggressive examination of candidates\xe2\x80\x99 claims.'b'This is not new. The \xe2\x80\x9cfact-checking\xe2\x80\x9d movement, shorthand for news organizations\xe2\x80\x99 rebuttal of factual claims, has been building for years. Now, though, as Republicans grapple in earnest with nominee selection and 'b'President Obama rolls out his first campaign ads'b', the fact-check war is entering a new phase.'b'At The New York Times, coverage of campaign debates typically includes a main article and a sidebar labeled 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFact Check\xe2\x80\x9d'b' in which candidates\xe2\x80\x99 claims are vetted. Last week, to Mitt Romney\xe2\x80\x99s claim that the president does not have a jobs plan, 'b'The Times countered: \xe2\x80\x9cThis is incorrect.\xe2\x80\x9d'b' To Ron Paul\xe2\x80\x99s statement about troop deployment costs, 'b'The Times hedged: \xe2\x80\x9cnot as black and white as Mr. Paul made it sound.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'The Times\xe2\x80\x99s fact-check function is low-key compared with some others. The work is done by regular staff members who have other duties. The \xe2\x80\x9cFact Check\xe2\x80\x9d feature does not have its own branded spot on 'b'NYTimes.com'b'. Beyond \xe2\x80\x9cFact Check,\xe2\x80\x9d the paper reviews political advertising and undertakes deeper investigations of candidates\xe2\x80\x99 claims as part of its broader campaign coverage.'b''b'PolitiFact,'b' in contrast, is a dedicated unit of fact-checkers employed by 'b'The Tampa Bay Times.'b' In operation since 2007, PolitiFact explores claims and publishes results alongside its trademarked \xe2\x80\x9cTruth-O-Meter,\xe2\x80\x9d a graphic that rates claims from true to false to 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPants on Fire,\xe2\x80\x9d'b' in the case of a real whopper.'b'The Washington Post has 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe Fact Checker,\xe2\x80\x9d'b' also with a dedicated staff and rating mechanism, in this case a scheme involving 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPinocchios\xe2\x80\x9d:'b' one Pinocchio for \xe2\x80\x9cselective telling of the truth\xe2\x80\x9d up to four Pinocchios for raving prevarications, with the occasional Geppetto checkmark when someone has actually told the truth (it happens).'b'Journalists have always seen it as a duty to check claims, but the form has evolved. The current movement has its roots in the late 1980s, a response to aggressive advertising like the Willie Horton ads aimed at Michael Dukakis, the Democratic nominee in 1988, according to 'b'Bill Adair,'b' editor of PolitiFact.'b'He traces the most recent approach, involving dedicated fact-checking units, to 2003, when 'b'FactCheck.org'b' was created by the 'b'Annenberg Public Policy Center at the University of Pennsylvania.'b''b'The progression, he and others say, stems from a dynamic that is changing the news business. When there were fewer media outlets, Mr. Adair said, journalists acted as gatekeepers to filter some false claims.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf the media heard a cockamamie story, it wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t pass it along without evidence,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cNow those stories can get passed along in so many ways \xe2\x80\x94 whether it is cable, talk radio, chain e-mails. There are a million different sources. There is no filter. It is important now that we fact-check because people are getting their information from so many sources and they wonder whether it is true.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Newspaper journalism\xe2\x80\x99s traditional way of dealing with spurious claims, meanwhile, isn\xe2\x80\x99t satisfying readers. Often derided as the \xe2\x80\x9che said, she said\xe2\x80\x9d approach, this method entails finding and quoting someone to counter a claim, thereby offering a form of balance but no resolution. This sufficed in the past, for many at least, but now many readers are asking for more aggressive rebuttals.'b'I heard this loud and clear last week 'b'when I asked readers on my blog'b' whether they wanted more fact-checking in straight news articles and they said, resoundingly, yes.'b''b'James Fallows,'b' author of \xe2\x80\x9cBreaking the News\xe2\x80\x9d and a national correspondent for 'b'The Atlantic,'b' told me it is incumbent on reporters to correct falsehood, not just balance it. \xe2\x80\x9cIf the reporter doesn\xe2\x80\x99t do that, he or she implicitly becomes part of a disinformation system that treats all statements as equally plausible claims and gives the reader no help in sorting them out.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The case for day-to-day fact-checking is compelling, but I would raise serious cautions.'b'First, are you rebutting a fact that is quantifiable and knowable, or are you rebutting an opinion? Political rhetoric is replete with buzzwords and labels, many of them stretched to reflect the speaker\xe2\x80\x99s opinion. A lot of this isn\xe2\x80\x99t worth rebutting.'b'Can you fact-check without displaying bias? Some argue that fact-checking operations fail this test. Writing in 'b'The Weekly Standard,'b' Mark Hemingway 'b'cited a University of Minnesota study'b' that found PolitiFact had assigned \xe2\x80\x9csubstantially harsher grades\xe2\x80\x9d to Republicans than Democrats between January 2010 and January 2011.'b'Fact-checking organizations, he told me, \xe2\x80\x9care doing opinion journalism, but they are doing it under the guise of pseudo-scientific objectivity.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'(Mr. Adair responded: \xe2\x80\x9cWe don\xe2\x80\x99t keep score by party because we want our selection to be based on what\xe2\x80\x99s timely and relevant to our readers \xe2\x80\x94 not on false balance that tries to make sure each side gets an equal number of Pants on Fire ratings.\xe2\x80\x9d)'b'Another caution: Don\xe2\x80\x99t you risk making errors when you fact-check on short deadlines? 'b'Rem Rieder,'b' editor and senior vice president of 'b'American Journalism Review,'b' told me: \xe2\x80\x9cYou can\xe2\x80\x99t do it all the time right out of the box. If you are in Iowa covering a speech and you are filing for the Web in 10 minutes, you are not going to have the time or the resources a serious charge will require.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Mr. Rieder, though, believes The Times should come back as quickly as possible to rebut false claims that were in a news article, and make sure that rebuttals stay in coverage going forward.'b'I join others who worry that The Times needs to be very careful with this. 'b'Jill Abramson,'b' the executive editor, said that if fact-checking were made a \xe2\x80\x9creflexive element of too many news stories, our readers would find The Times was being tendentious.\xe2\x80\x9d Readers, she added, could come to see The Times \xe2\x80\x9cas a combatant, not as an arbiter of what the facts were.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Ubiquitous argument in straight news articles is not the way to go. Checking facts in politics \xe2\x80\x94 and in other subjects \xe2\x80\x94 takes time, resources and great care. Editors and reporters need to identify priorities and exercise judgment: they cannot do everything.'b'For these reasons, I think The Times should broaden the \xe2\x80\x9cFact Check\xe2\x80\x9d sidebars to include issues that arise outside of the debate forum. Regular installments of fact-checking journalism, identified as such, would strengthen the paper\xe2\x80\x99s approach. Links from fact-check items back to the original articles online would help readers connect the dots.'b'I favor rebutting assertions in some routine news articles. But The Times needs to be disciplined about it. The paper\xe2\x80\x99s straight news function remains its most valuable asset, which would be undermined if argument replaced fact-gathering.'b'IN France I live near a little village called Sadillac. It\xe2\x80\x99s no more than a cluster of houses, an old chateau, a church and a graveyard surrounded by a few farms and vineyards. The village probably hasn\xe2\x80\x99t changed much since the French Revolution; its population hovers around 100. By the graveyard is a simple obelisk with the names of the 30 or so young men from Sadillac who died in the First World War, 1914-18. It\xe2\x80\x99s almost impossible to imagine the effect on this tiny community of these fatalities over four years. Every year on Nov. 11 at 11 a.m. \xe2\x80\x94 the hour and the day of the 1918 armistice \xe2\x80\x94 villagers gather to participate in a short memorial service around the obelisk.'b'In 2014 it will be a hundred years since the First World War began, and yet its presence in novels, films and television has never been greater \xe2\x80\x94 in \xe2\x80\x9cDownton Abbey,\xe2\x80\x9d on television, in Steven Spielberg\xe2\x80\x99s movie \xe2\x80\x9cWar Horse,\xe2\x80\x9d in a mini-series of Sebastian Faulks\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Birdsong'b'\xe2\x80\x9d and, coming soon, in Tom Stoppard\xe2\x80\x99s adaptation of Ford Madox Ford\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Parade\xe2\x80\x99s End'b'.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The last old soldier or sailor has died and almost all of the witnesses have gone, but the war exerts a tenacious hold on the imagination.'b'For us British, the memories, images and stories of 1914-18 seem to have a persistence and a power that eclipse those of the Second World War. I\xe2\x80\x99m symptomatic of this urge to revisit the conflict: my new novel will be my third with the First World War at its center. When I wrote and directed a movie, \xe2\x80\x9c'b'The Trench'b',\xe2\x80\x9d about a group of young soldiers in 1916 waiting for the Battle of the Somme to begin, I was obsessed with getting every detail right: every cap-badge worn and cigarette smoked, every meal eaten. It was as if I wanted the absolute verisimilitude to provide an authentic, vicarious experience so the viewer would be in a position to say, \xe2\x80\x9cSo this is what it was like, this is what they went through, how they lived \xe2\x80\x94 and died.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'I think this is the key behind the enduring obsession with that war. To our modern sensibilities it defies credulity that for more than four years European armies faced one another in a 500-mile line of trenches, stretching from the Belgian coast to the border of Switzerland. The war was also fought in other arenas \xe2\x80\x94 in Galicia, Italy, the Bosporus, Mesopotamia, East and West Africa, in naval battles on many oceans \xe2\x80\x94 but it is the Western Front and trench warfare that define the war in memory. It was a deadly war of attrition in which millions of soldiers on both sides slogged through the mud of no man\xe2\x80\x99s land to meet their deaths in withering blasts of machine-gun fire and artillery. And at the end of four years and with about nine million troops dead, the two opposing forces were essentially where they were when they started.'b'IN France and Germany, the traumas of the Second World War have to a degree erased memories of the First. But in Britain, where almost a million servicemen died, it\xe2\x80\x99s still images of the trenches of the Western Front that are shown and that resonate on Remembrance Day. One of the reasons for this is, paradoxically, the resonance of the poetry. The poets of the First World War \xe2\x80\x94 Wilfred Owen, Siegfried Sassoon, Edmund Blunden, Isaac Rosenberg \xe2\x80\x94 are taught in almost all British schools. I can remember Wilfred Owen\xe2\x80\x99s terrifying poem \xe2\x80\x9cDulce et Decorum Est,\xe2\x80\x9d about a mustard-gas attack, being read aloud to us in the classroom when I was 10 or 11. One boy actually ran outside, he was so overcome and upset. The war poems shaped your earliest perceptions of the First World War and were swiftly buttressed by the familiar images of the trenches and the histories of the futile, costly battles.'b'Intensifying the powerful art was the visual documentation, because it was the first war to be extensively filmed.'b'And finally, there were family stories. One hundred years is not so very long ago. My great-uncle Alexander Boyd was wounded and decorated at the Battle of the Somme. His brother, my grandfather William Boyd, was wounded a year later at Passchendaele, as the Third Battle of Ypres was known. Family legend and anecdote fueled my interest in the war.'b'But there is another deeper, perhaps more profound reason the war continues to preoccupy us. It was a conflict between 19th-century armies equipped with 20th-century weapons \xe2\x80\x94 hence the unprecedented carnage. To put it in an American context: imagine an officer in the United States Army \xe2\x80\x94 in his 50s, say \xe2\x80\x94 on the Argonne front in 1918. As a young soldier he could conceivably have fought, 30 years earlier, in the last of the wars against the Plains Indians in the late 1880s. Yet now he stands surveying a different world. The tactics were 19th century \xe2\x80\x94 advance on the enemy. But the enemy had weapons of mass destruction \xe2\x80\x94 the battlefield was dominated by tanks, machine guns, howitzers, aircraft and poisonous gas. Some 117,000 American servicemen died in the 'b'19 months of United States participation'b' in World War I \xe2\x80\x94 more than twice as many as in Vietnam, nearly 20 times as many as in Iraq and Afghanistan.'b'No society today would accept such a horrendous casualty count. At the beginning of the Battle of the Somme, on July 1, 1916, the British Army suffered 60,000 dead and wounded \xe2\x80\x94 in one day. It was arguably the worst butcher\xe2\x80\x99s bill in military history, of army versus army. There is a very real sense in which the modern world \xe2\x80\x94 our world \xe2\x80\x94 was born between 1914 and 1918. Something changed in human sensibility. Soldiers wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be willing to engage in such slaughter. Toward the end of the First World War, even, tolerance for past norms had begun to end. In 1917, much of the French Army mutinied and refused to attack. They would defend but not attack. The days of cannon fodder were over forever as a result of that war, which is a further reason artists try to re-imagine it constantly.'b'To quote another poem, Philip Larkin\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9c'b'MCMXIV'b'\xe2\x80\x9d: \xe2\x80\x9cNever such innocence again.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'After the First World War, nothing in the world would ever be the same.'b'CAN you trademark the color red?'b'This week a federal appellate court will hear arguments in a 'b'case'b' involving this very question. The issue arises in connection with shoes, specifically, the vivid red soles beneath Christian Louboutin shoes. The high-end designer says four separate styles of Yves Saint Laurent shoes infringe its trademarked sole. All four shoes are red all over \xe2\x80\x94 including the soles.'b'Last summer a 'b'federal court'b' denied Louboutin\xe2\x80\x99s request that YSL be stopped from selling its red shoes pending resolution of Louboutin\xe2\x80\x99s effort to enforce its federally registered Red Sole Mark. (In its opinion, the court said Louboutin\xe2\x80\x99s trademark infringement claim was unlikely to succeed.) Now, the shoedown escalates to the appeals court.'b'The quirky lawsuit dramatizes the law\xe2\x80\x99s ambivalence toward fashion. The law does not protect fashion design, but it does recognize the rights inherent in branding. Louboutin\xe2\x80\x99s claim spotlights the pressure on fashion designers to frame their aesthetic choices as brand identifiers, and the legal contortions that result.'b'Those familiar with high-end fashion associate the red underside of a woman\xe2\x80\x99s shoe with the Louboutin brand. And for good reason: Louboutin has invested plenty in that red sole and successfully linked the sole\xe2\x80\x99s shade with the shoemaker. Since a main purpose of trademark law is to protect one\xe2\x80\x99s investment in reputation, Louboutin\xe2\x80\x99s sole-saving efforts are understandable.'b'But red; it\xe2\x80\x99s a color. An interlocking LV on a Louis Vuitton handbag or a Nike swoosh on a sneaker is one thing, some say. But monopolizing a color ... just doesn\xe2\x80\x99t seem right.'b'As it turns out, however, the Supreme Court has previously held that a color alone could be a trademark, in a case about a solid green-gold color on pads used in dry cleaning press machines, because the color served to identify the maker of the product \xe2\x80\x94 and had no other function. Thus an important caveat is that if the color is a useful feature in a product \xe2\x80\x94 green for farm equipment or yellow for banana-flavored gum \xe2\x80\x94 it can\xe2\x80\x99t be a trademark, even if it is source-identifying, because excluding competitors from a useful feature would be anti-competitive. Applying this logic, the judge in the Louboutin case suggested that particularly in fashion, a single color could not be a trademark. The judge reasoned that in fashion, color is always \xe2\x80\x9cfunctional\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 meaning that color is a useful aesthetic feature to which all designers should have access.'b'The red elephant in the room is that though it is the artistic and creative core of the fashion industry, design is not protected qua design, but only as a symbol of who created it. Fashion designers find no comfort in the federal copyright statute, which protects authors and creators, but does not extend to \xe2\x80\x9cuseful articles,\xe2\x80\x9d including apparel and shoes.'b'A pending Congressional bill may offer some copyright protection for fashion design, but until then, fashion, unlike other visual media such as film and painting, remains a realm in which copying is perfectly legal \xe2\x80\x94 unless a design is deemed a trademark, that is. The Burberry plaid design, for example, is legally protected because it identifies Burberry, while the design of a dress the plaid may adorn is not, no matter how artful or original. Hence the pressure to frame design features \xe2\x80\x94 like an eye-catching color or a pleasing plaid \xe2\x80\x94 as trademarks.'b'That brings us to the fashion Catch-22 that the red sole throws into relief: Trademark law does not protect design features that are \xe2\x80\x9cfunctional,\xe2\x80\x9d the meaning of which, it turns out, encompasses even aesthetic appeal. But in copyright law it is precisely the utilitarian and non-aesthetic aspect of apparel and shoes that leaves fashion design unprotected from copying. Fashion design is caught between opposing demands and exclusions, and snubbed from both ends.'b'It is unlikely a court will allow Louboutin to monopolize \xe2\x80\x9cred,\xe2\x80\x9d even if all that is claimed is placement on the sole. A trademark claim on the precise \xe2\x80\x9cChinese Red\xe2\x80\x9d that Louboutin uses on its soles might be more palatable, but the company seemingly wants to trademark \xe2\x80\x9cred\xe2\x80\x9d rather than a particular shade of this color. (YSL\xe2\x80\x99s shoes are not the same shade of red as Louboutin\xe2\x80\x99s.) Still, YSL\xe2\x80\x99s red soles are part of a red-all-over shoe design; arguably Louboutin\xe2\x80\x99s soles are recognizable precisely because of the contrast between shoe and sole color.'b'It is time for Congress to address directly the fusion of practicality and beauty that makes fashion such a compelling medium of expression and a profitable creative industry, one that merits its own limited industry-specific protections. Otherwise, colorful as they are, lawsuits like the red sole case are likely to compound the uncertainty that results from the absence of statutory delineation of fashion design protection \xe2\x80\x94 and invite more lawsuits.'b'A SOCIAL revolution began in 'b'Saudi Arabia'b' this month, and it has little if anything to do with the Arab Spring. Women are going to work in lingerie shops.'b'The Ministry of Labor is enforcing a royal decree issued last summer ordering that sales personnel in shops selling garments and other goods, like cosmetics, that are only for women must be female. More than 'b'28,000 women applied'b' for the jobs, the ministry said. Anywhere else in the world, it would not be news that sales assistants in shops selling panties and bras were female. In Saudi Arabia, where women have always been excluded from the public work force, it is a critical breakthrough. This is not just about intimate garments; this is a milestone on the arduous path to employment equality for women in a country where they are systematically excluded from retail activity.'b'Saudi Arabia\xe2\x80\x99s economic planners recognize that if women are going to be educated at public expense, as they now are in increasing numbers, they will expect to work and the country will need their economic output. Society has increasingly accepted the idea that women will work outside the home. They have long been employed in medicine and education. Retail commerce, however, has generally remained closed because such work usually requires interaction with men, which is prohibited. The lingerie shops are breaking that taboo.'b'One of the oddest sights in Saudi Arabia is that of fully veiled women, hidden from others by their enveloping garments, going into the Saudi equivalent of Victoria\xe2\x80\x99s Secret stores in the many upscale malls and being greeted and assisted exclusively by male sales clerks, most of whom are from South Asia. This absurd situation so embarrassed many women that they waited until they were out of the country to buy their underwear and nightgowns.'b'The campaign to change the rules began several years ago, and was led by 'b'Reem Asaad'b', a fashion-conscious financial adviser who speaks flawless English and is comfortable with the Western media. It appeared to have 'b'succeeded in 2006'b' when the government ordered that the sales jobs be transferred to women. But social conservatives and the religious establishment objected, arguing that Islam prohibited women from working outside the home and that putting women in retail shops would expose them to the view of any passing stranger. If the sales clerks were female, the shop windows would have to be covered, the opponents said.'b'Shop owners objected, too, saying that no women were trained to do such work. In addition, the 2006 decree failed to address the transportation problem: if women were going to work in those shops, they would need a man to drive them because they are prohibited from driving. Saudi cities have virtually no public transportation. So the decree was never enforced. Ms. Asaad then used Facebook to organize a boycott of the shops, and arranged for some women to be trained in retail work.'b'This time, King Abdullah has put his personal authority behind the new decree. Under the new rules, the country\xe2\x80\x99s thousands of lingerie and cosmetics shops have until June to replace their male employees with women. The feared religious police, who are really the behavior police, have been ordered to cooperate.'b'King Abdullah generally supported an expansion of opportunities for women, but steps in this direction can\xe2\x80\x99t be traced to any burst of enlightenment within the royal family. While women are still constrained by law, religion and custom, more and more are likely to enter the work force. They will be better educated than their predecessors, will marry later and will have fewer children. The range of jobs and professions open to them will expand. Steve Wynn wants to build a \xe2\x80\x9clow rise\xe2\x80\x9d casino in Foxborough, Mass., near a shopping center and the New England Patriots\xe2\x80\x99 football stadium. The Sands opened a casino in Pennsylvania in 2009 on the site of a Bethlehem Steel plant.'b'Florida, Illinois, Kentucky and Maine are among the states considering similar moves to raise revenue. It is all part of a broader gambling expansion that includes efforts to legalize Internet gambling at the federal level and in several states. New Jersey wants to legalize sports betting.'b'Thirty years ago, Las Vegas and Atlantic City were the only legal casino destinations in the country. But over the last few decades there has been a steady increase in lottery offerings, riverboat casinos and gambling on Indian reservations. Today, 41 states have some form of casino gambling, and all but 7 have a lottery.'b'Governor Cuomo is correct that New York \xe2\x80\x94 which has a state lottery, casinos on Indian reservations and video lottery terminals at the Aqueduct Racetrack \xe2\x80\x94 is already in the gambling business. Many New Yorkers also travel to Atlantic City, Pennsylvania and Connecticut to gamble. But making gambling even more convenient to residents is not the answer to the state\xe2\x80\x99s budget or unemployment woes. Lawmakers are sworn to protect residents, not make it easier for them to lose money.'b'The economist Paul A. Samuelson described gambling as the \xe2\x80\x9csterile transfer of money or goods between individuals, creating no new money or goods.\xe2\x80\x9d Warren E. Buffett called gambling a \xe2\x80\x9ctax on ignorance.\xe2\x80\x9d Governor Cuomo\xe2\x80\x99s father, Mario, himself a former governor, understood the negative impact. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is a respectable body of economic thought that holds that casino gambling is actually economically regressive to a state and a community,\xe2\x80\x9d he wrote in a 1994 book, \xe2\x80\x9cThe New York Idea.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Indeed, studies show that where casinos are established there is often an increase in crime, bankruptcy, divorce and suicide. A 'b' study last year by the University of Maryland, Baltimore County'b' found that one in every 30 state residents had a gambling problem. Those most at risk for developing gambling addictions are single men between the ages of 18 and 29, either African-American or Latino, with less education and income than the overall population.'b'For New Yorkers, opening casinos closer to home would create new gamblers and prompt many residents to gamble more often, especially low rollers who are more likely to get hooked on slot machines. That has been the case in Pennsylvania, which legalized slots in 2004.'b'At the Parx Casino in Bensalem, Pa., many gamblers come in an average of three to four times a week \xe2\x80\x94 or roughly 150 to 200 times a year, David Jonas, the former president and the chief operating officer of the casino, 'b'said at a gambling conference in 2010'b'.'b'Over all, the number of calls to Pennsylvania\xe2\x80\x99s problem gambling help line jumped by 26 percent in the first quarter of last year, according to the Pennsylvania Council on Compulsive Gambling.'b'New York can expect the same payoff from its bad bet.'b'BOTANISTS long thought the tallest trees on Madagascar all belonged to only three species of the genus Canarium, but two scientists have now determined that there are actually 35 species of the genus there, of which 29 are new to science.'b'To make this startling discovery, Douglas Daly of the New York Botanical Garden and his Malagasy colleague Jeannie Raharimampionona hiked through rainforests for months in 2006 and then toiled in scientific collections to sort out all of the species. Only then did they start the laborious process of formally describing each of the new species in Latin for publication in scientific papers, a requirement for making a new species public.'b'Considering all the work involved, perhaps it\xe2\x80\x99s no wonder that, despite centuries of research and exploration to create a complete inventory of the world\xe2\x80\x99s plant life, there may be as many as 100,000 plant species that are not yet known to science, waiting to be cataloged \xe2\x80\x94 if we can find and describe them in time.'b'The requirement to use Latin \xe2\x80\x94 which has been in place, officially, since 1908, and in practice since the 18th century \xe2\x80\x94 doesn\xe2\x80\x99t make this process any faster. At a time when deforestation, the spread of invasive species and climate change are putting as many as one-third of all plant species at risk of extinction in the next 50 years, we don\xe2\x80\x99t have time for traditions like these. That\xe2\x80\x99s why, as of Jan. 1, the International Code of Botanical Nomenclature no longer compels botanists to provide a 'b'Latin description'b' of a new species. Perhaps even more significant, the code now recognizes publication in online academic journals as equally valid as print publication. Both changes will help to speed up the race to catalog the world\xe2\x80\x99s plant life.'b'No longer will botanists have to write sentences like: \xe2\x80\x9cArbor usque ad 6 m alta. Folia decidua; lamina oblanceolata vel elliptica-oblongata, 2-7 cm longa,\xe2\x80\x9d as I did in 2009, describing a new species from Mexico. Instead, I could simply write that Bourreria motaguensis was a six-meter-tall tree with deciduous leaves that were 2 to 7 centimeters long.'b'Simplifying the process for describing and publishing new species will undoubtedly help, but cataloging all our planet\xe2\x80\x99s plant life will require much more than that. Plants are a vital source of materials and medicine; they are the basis of the food chain; they produce the oxygen we breathe. If a species becomes extinct before it is found \xe2\x80\x94 a phenomenon known as \xe2\x80\x9canonymous extinction\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 there is no way to explore its potential. We must prevent that from happening.'b'That will take concerted efforts to conduct research expeditions to the parts of the tropics that still remain unexplored, to generate financial support for the scientists needed to do the work and to train a new generation of botanists. They will have enough to do without having to memorize Latin declensions.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Fees to Doctors by Drug Makers to Be Disclosed'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (front page, Jan. 17):'b'The proposed requirement to disclose fees paid by drug and device manufacturers to doctors is on target and long overdue.
