Kroenig, an academic who spent a year as a fellow at the Obama administration\xe2\x80\x99s Defense Department, apparently aspires to the Strangelovian superhawk role occupied in previous decades by the likes of John Bolton and Richard Perle. His former colleagues at Defense were pretty 'b'appalled'b' by his article, which combines the alarmist worst case of the Iranian nuclear threat with the rosiest best case of America\xe2\x80\x99s ability to make things better. (Does this remind you of another pre-emptive war in a country beginning with I?)'b'This scenario represents one pole in a debate that is the most abused foreign policy issue in this presidential campaign year. The opposite pole, also awful to contemplate, is the prospect of living with a nuclear Iran. In that case, the fear of most American experts is not that Iran would decide to incinerate Israel. (Mahmoud Ahmadinejad does a good impression of an evil madman, but Iran is not suicidal.) The more realistic dangers, plenty scary, are that a conventional conflict in that conflict-prone neighborhood would spiral into Armageddon, or that Iran would extend its protective nuclear umbrella over menacing proxies like Hezbollah, or that Arab neighbors would feel obliged to join the nuclear arms race.'b'For now, American policy lives between these poles of attack and acquiescence, in the realm of uncertain calculation and imperfect options. If you want to measure your next president against a hellish dilemma, here\xe2\x80\x99s your chance.'b'In the Republican field we have one candidate ('b'Rick Santorum'b') who is about as close as you can get to the bomb-sooner-rather-than-later extreme, another ('b'Ron Paul'b') who is at the let-Iran-be-Iran extreme, and Mitt Romney and Newt Gingrich are 'b'in between'b'. Of particular interest is Romney, who has performed the same rhetorical trick with Iran that he did with health care. That is, he 'b'condemns'b' Obama for doing pretty much what Romney would do.'b'Although much about Iran\xe2\x80\x99s theocracy is murky, a few assumptions are widely accepted by specialists in and out of government.'b'First, for all its denials, the Iranian regime is determined to acquire nuclear weapons, or at least the capacity to make them quickly in the event of an outside threat. Having a nuclear option is seen as a matter of Persian pride and national survival in the face of enemies (namely us) who the Iranians believe are bent on toppling the Islamic state. The nuclear program is popular in Iran, even with many of the opposition figures admired in the West. The actual state of the program is not entirely clear, but the best open-source estimates are that if Ayatollah Ali Khamenei ordered full-speed-ahead \xe2\x80\x94 which there is no sign he has done \xe2\x80\x94 they could have an actual weapon in a year or so.'b'American policy has been consistent through the Bush and Obama administrations: (1) a declaration that a nuclear Iran is \xe2\x80\x9cunacceptable\xe2\x80\x9d; (2) a combination of sticks (sanctions) and carrots (supplies of nuclear fuel suitable for domestic industrial needs in exchange for forgoing weapons); (3) unfettered international inspections; (4) a refusal to take military options off the table; (5) a concerted effort to restrain Israel from attacking Iran unilaterally \xe2\x80\x94 beyond the Israelis\xe2\x80\x99 presumed campaign to slow Iran\xe2\x80\x99s progress by sabotage and assassination; and (6) a wish that Iran\xe2\x80\x99s hard-liners could be replaced by a more benign regime, tempered by a realization that there is very little we can do to make that happen. This is also the gist of Romney\xe2\x80\x99s Iran playbook, for all his bluster about Obama the appeaser.'b'In practice, Obama\xe2\x80\x99s policy promises to be tougher than Bush\xe2\x80\x99s. Because Obama started out with an offer of direct talks \xe2\x80\x94 which the Iranians foolishly spurned \xe2\x80\x94 world opinion has shifted in our direction. We may now have sufficient global support to enact the one measure that would be genuinely crippling \xe2\x80\x94 a 'b'boycott of Iranian oil'b'. The administration and the Europeans, with help from Saudi Arabia, are working hard to persuade such major Iranian oil customers as Japan and South Korea to switch suppliers. The Iranians take this threat to their economic livelihood seriously enough that people who follow the subject no longer minimize the chance of a naval confrontation in the Strait of Hormuz. It\xe2\x80\x99s not impossible that we will get war with Iran even without bombing its nuclear facilities.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s not the only problem with the current \xe2\x80\x94 let\xe2\x80\x99s call it the Obamney \xe2\x80\x94 approach to Iran.'b'The point of tough sanctions, of course, is to force Iranians to the bargaining table, where we can do a deal that removes the specter of a nuclear-armed Iran. (You can find 'b'some thoughts'b' on what such a deal might entail on my blog.) But the mistrust is so deep, and the election-year pressure to act with manly resolve is so intense, that it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to imagine the administration would feel free to accept an overture from Tehran. Anything short of a humiliating, unilateral Iranian climb-down would be portrayed by the armchair warriors as an Obama surrender. Likewise, if Israel does decide to strike out on its own, Bibi Netanyahu knows that candidate Obama will feel immense pressure to go along.'b'That short-term paradox comes wrapped up in a long-term paradox: an attack on Iran is almost certain to unify the Iranian people around the mullahs and provoke the supreme leader to redouble Iran\xe2\x80\x99s nuclear pursuits, only deeper underground this time, and without international inspectors around. Over at the Pentagon, you sometimes hear it put this way: Bombing Iran is the best way to guarantee exactly what we are trying to prevent.'b'How goes the state of the union? Well, the state of the economy remains terrible. Three years after President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s inauguration and two and a half years since the official end of the recession, unemployment remains painfully high.'b'But there are reasons to think that we\xe2\x80\x99re finally on the (slow) road to better times. And we wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be on that road if Mr. Obama had given in to Republican demands that he slash spending, or the Federal Reserve had given in to Republican demands that it tighten money.'b'Why am I letting a bit of optimism break through the clouds? Recent economic data have been a bit better, but we\xe2\x80\x99ve already had several false dawns on that front. More important, there\xe2\x80\x99s evidence that the two great problems at the root of our slump \xe2\x80\x94 the housing bust and excessive private debt \xe2\x80\x94 are finally easing.'b'On housing: as everyone now knows (but oh, the abuse heaped on anyone pointing it out while it was happening!), we had a monstrous housing bubble between 2000 and 2006. Home prices soared, and there was clearly a lot of overbuilding. When the bubble burst, construction \xe2\x80\x94 which had been the economy\xe2\x80\x99s main driver during the alleged \xe2\x80\x9cBush boom\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 plunged.'b'But the bubble began deflating almost six years ago; house prices are back to 2003 levels. And after a protracted slump in housing starts, America now looks seriously underprovided with houses, at least by historical standards.'b'So why aren\xe2\x80\x99t people going out and buying? Because the depressed state of the economy leaves many people who would normally be buying homes either unable to afford them or too worried about job prospects to take the risk.'b'But the economy is depressed, in large part, because of the housing bust, which immediately suggests the possibility of a virtuous circle: an improving economy leads to a surge in home purchases, which leads to more construction, which strengthens the economy further, and so on. And if you squint hard at recent data, it looks as if something like that may be starting: home sales are up, unemployment claims are down, and builders\xe2\x80\x99 confidence is rising.'b'Furthermore, the chances for a virtuous circle have been rising, because we\xe2\x80\x99ve made significant progress on the debt front.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s not what you hear in public debate, of course, where all the focus is on rising government debt. But anyone who has looked seriously at how we got into this slump knows that private debt, especially household debt, was the real culprit: it was the explosion of household debt during the Bush years that set the stage for the crisis. And the good news is that this private debt has declined in dollar terms, and declined substantially as a percentage of G.D.P., since the end of 2008.'b'There are, of course, still big risks \xe2\x80\x94 above all, the risk that trouble in Europe could derail our own incipient recovery. And thereby hangs a tale \xe2\x80\x94 a tale told by a recent report from the McKinsey Global Institute.'b'The 'b'report'b' tracks progress on \xe2\x80\x9cdeleveraging,\xe2\x80\x9d the process of bringing down excessive debt levels. It documents substantial progress in the United States, which it contrasts with failure to make progress in Europe. And while the report doesn\xe2\x80\x99t say this explicitly, it\xe2\x80\x99s pretty clear why Europe is doing worse than we are: it\xe2\x80\x99s because European policy makers have been afraid of the wrong things.'b'In particular, the European Central Bank has been worrying about inflation \xe2\x80\x94 even raising interest rates during 2011, only to reverse course later in the year \xe2\x80\x94 rather than worrying about how to sustain economic recovery. And fiscal austerity, which is supposed to limit the increase in government debt, has depressed the economy, making it impossible to achieve urgently needed reductions in private debt. The end result is that for all their moralizing about the evils of borrowing, the Europeans aren\xe2\x80\x99t making any progress against excessive debt \xe2\x80\x94 whereas we are.'b'Back to the U.S. situation: my guarded optimism should not be taken as a statement that all is well. We have already suffered enormous, unnecessary damage because of an inadequate response to the slump. We have failed to provide significant mortgage relief, which could have moved us much more quickly to lower debt. And even if my hoped-for virtuous circle is getting under way, it will be years before we get to anything resembling full employment.'b'But things could have been worse; they would have been worse if we had followed the policies demanded by Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s opponents. For as I said at the beginning, Republicans have been demanding that the Fed stop trying to bring down interest rates and that federal spending be slashed immediately \xe2\x80\x94 which amounts to demanding that we emulate Europe\xe2\x80\x99s failure.'b'And if this year\xe2\x80\x99s election brings the wrong ideology to power, America\xe2\x80\x99s nascent recovery might well be snuffed out.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Upset by Gingrich Shifts G.O.P. But the article doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mention the long-term solution to keeping heating costs down. While it is far too soon to start a victory lap, signs of progress abound.'b'JOE COURTNEY'b'\nWashington, Jan. 12, 2012'b''b''b'The writer, a Democrat, represents Connecticut\xe2\x80\x99s Second District in the House. 'b''b'WE have a tool that can prevent hundreds of murders, rapes and robberies each year at minimal cost to taxpayers. But we\xe2\x80\x99re not using it in a majority of cases because a state law restricts its use.'b'DNA evidence solves crimes. Since 1996, when New York State\xe2\x80\x99s DNA'b' databank'b' opened with strong support from my predecessor, Robert M. Morgenthau, the bank\xe2\x80\x99s DNA samples have been linked to more than 3,500 sexual assaults, 860 murders, 1,100 robberies and 3,400 burglaries. Thousands of criminal convictions have resulted. Today, however, we are hamstrung by a law that does not authorize the collection of DNA following convictions of certain misdemeanors. This has meant that we can\xe2\x80\x99t use DNA technology in more than half of our cases. By expanding the collection of DNA to include those convicted of all crimes in New York State\xe2\x80\x99s penal law, as Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has called for, we will be better able to identify the guilty, exonerate the innocent, bring justice to crime victims and prevent additional crimes from occurring.'b'In 2006, lawmakers decided to include some but not all misdemeanors in the DNA databank. Opponents questioned why someone convicted of a low-level misdemeanor \xe2\x80\x94 petty larceny, for example \xe2\x80\x94 should be required to provide a DNA sample. The answer can be found in the results of that decision: samples collected from people convicted of petty larceny have been linked to roughly 48 murders and 220 sexual assaults. Clearly, the 2006 expansion of the DNA program \xe2\x80\x94 which passed with only six dissenting votes in the State Assembly \xe2\x80\x94 confirmed that collecting samples from offenders convicted of minor crimes helps solve and prevent more serious crimes.'b'Whom does DNA bring to justice, and how does it prevent future crimes? The case of 'b'Curtis Tucker'b' is instructive. Following his conviction in 2010 for robbing and assaulting a 74-year-old Manhattan man suffering from Parkinson\xe2\x80\x99s disease, Mr. Tucker was required to submit a DNA sample, which typically is obtained by swabbing the inside of a person\xe2\x80\x99s cheek. Three days later, that $30 test produced a match linking Mr. Tucker to a brutal 2004 assault and attempted rape of a 15-year-old girl in the stairwell of her Manhattan apartment building.'b'Mr. Tucker had been convicted multiple times in Manhattan courts for misdemeanor offenses that did not require providing a DNA sample. Had he been required to provided such a sample after his first misdemeanor conviction, the 2004 case would have been solved earlier and the 2010 attack prevented.'b'Crucially, DNA evidence does more than put criminals away; it also exonerates the innocent. One of my top goals as district attorney has been to avoid wrongful convictions. Having a tool like an all-crimes DNA databank at our disposal would go a long way toward helping us achieve that all-important goal of avoiding wrongful convictions.'b'Despite the truly remarkable benefits of DNA testing, some skeptics have questioned whether it is sufficiently regulated and reliable. This concern is understandable but unfounded. The collection of DNA is highly regulated in the eight state-of-the-art, accredited state labs that conduct criminal forensic analysis. Strict safeguards control the handling of DNA testing and results, including the storage of information by barcode and not name, with criminal penalties for those who violate these rules. When testing leads to a match in the databank, samples are retested at least once and often twice. To date in New York, we have never had a \xe2\x80\x9cfalse positive,\xe2\x80\x9d or the misidentification of DNA from one person as the DNA of another.'b'Collecting DNA from all those convicted of all crimes has received overwhelming bipartisan support from across the state, including from crime victims, their advocates, exonerated defendants, the state and city bar associations, and the state\xe2\x80\x99s district attorneys, police chiefs and sheriffs. But its passage has been stymied because other criminal justice legislation that does not enjoy such broad support has been tacked on to it. Let\xe2\x80\x99s not repeat that mistake this year.'b'No law enforcement tool is perfect, and, as with a fingerprint, a DNA match at a crime scene is an investigative tool, not proof positive of guilt. But DNA is by far the most reliable evidence we have today \xe2\x80\x94 more than eyewitness accounts, testimony and even confessions. And importantly, as we try to make our justice system more fair, DNA is truly color blind.'b'Chestnut Hill, Mass.'b'TWO weeks ago, dozens of cars were set alight in the French city of Clermont-Ferrand after a 30-year-old truck driver, Wissam El-Yamni, was roughed up and then died while in police custody. The uproar underscored the hostility of young minority men toward authority across communities in Europe, an antipathy that has at times led to deadly violence.'b'The failure of Islamic integration in Europe is often attributed \xe2\x80\x94 especially by right-wing parties \xe2\x80\x94 to an excess of tolerance toward the large-scale Muslim immigration that began in the mid-1970s. By recognizing Muslim religious requirements, the argument goes, countries like France, Britain and the Netherlands have unwittingly hindered assimilation and even, in some cases, fostered radicalism. But the unrest in gritty European suburbs stems not from religious difference, but from anomie.'b'Europeans should not be afraid to allow Muslim students to take classes on Islam in state-financed schools and universities. The recognition and accommodation of Islamic religious practices, from clothing to language to education, does not mean capitulation to fundamentalism. On the contrary, only by strengthening the democratic rights of Muslim citizens to form associations, join political parties and engage in other aspects of civic life can Europe integrate immigrants and give full meaning to the abstract promise of religious liberty.'b'The rise of right-wing, anti-immigrant parties has led several European countries to impose restrictions on Islamic dress, mosque-building and reunification of families through immigration law. These policies are counterproductive. Paradoxically, people for whom religion is otherwise not all that important become more attached to their faith\xe2\x80\x99s clothing, symbols and traditions when they feel they are being singled out and denied basic rights.'b'Take, for example, the French debate over whether to recognize the Jewish Day of Atonement, Yom Kippur, and the Muslim festival of Eid al-Adha as official holidays. Yes, the French state clings to the principle of \xe2\x80\x9cla\xc3\xafcit\xc3\xa9,\xe2\x80\x9d or secularism \xe2\x80\x94 but the state\xe2\x80\x99s recognition of Easter and Christmas as official holidays feels, to some Jews and Muslims, like hypocrisy. It is Islam\xe2\x80\x99s absence in the institutions young European Muslims encounter, starting with the school\xe2\x80\x99s calendar, classroom and canteen, that contributes to anger and alienation.'b'In the last few months, there have been some signs that the right-wing momentum has slowed. A French bill to ban headscarves from day care centers was killed in committee. The Dutch Parliament voted down a bill to outlaw Islamic animal slaughter. And Germany\xe2\x80\x99s most populous state helped offset a judicial ban on school prayer by announcing equal access to religion courses for Muslim students.'b'European countries could use a period of benign neglect of the Islam issue \xe2\x80\x94 but only after they finish incorporating religion into the national fabric. For too long, they have instead masked an absence of coherent integration policy under the cloak of \xe2\x80\x9cmulticulturalism.\xe2\x80\x9d The state outsourced the hard work of integration to foreign diplomats and Islamist institutions \xe2\x80\x94 for example, some students in Germany read Saudi-supplied textbooks in Saudi-run institutions.'b'This neglect of integration helped an unregulated \xe2\x80\x9cunderground Islam\xe2\x80\x9d to take hold in storefronts, basements and courtyards. It reflected wishful thinking about how long guest workers would stay and perpetuated a myth of eventual departure and repatriation.'b'In Britain, for example, race-based equality laws protected Sikhs and Jews as minorities, but not Hindus and Muslims, since they were still considered \xe2\x80\x9cforeign.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Institutional exclusion fueled a demand for religious recognition, and did much to unite and segregate Muslims. Islamist organizations became the most visible defenders of the faith. It is crucial now to provide the right mix of institutional incentives for religious and political moderation, and the most promising strategy for doing that is for governments to consult with the full range of law-abiding religious institutions that Muslims have themselves established.'b'The French Council for the Muslim Faith, the German Islam Conference, the Committee for Italian Islam and the Mosques and Imams National Advisory Board in Britain \xe2\x80\x94 all state-sanctioned Islamic organizations set up in the past decade \xe2\x80\x94 represent a broad cross-section of mosque administrators in every country. They have quietly begun reconciling many practical issues, from issuing mosque permits to establishing Islamic theology departments at public universities to appointing chaplains in the military and in prisons.'b'Ultimately, however, elected democratic institutions are the place where the desires of individual Muslims should be expressed. Ever since 1789, when a French legislator argued that \xe2\x80\x9cthe Jews should be denied everything as a nation, but granted everything as individuals,\xe2\x80\x9d Europeans have struggled to resolve the tension between rights derived from universal citizenship versus group membership.'b'Over the next 20 years, Europe\xe2\x80\x99s Muslim population is projected to grow to nearly 30 million \xe2\x80\x94 7 to 8 percent of all Europeans \xe2\x80\x94 from around 17 million. Granting Muslims full religious freedom wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t remove obstacles to political participation or create jobs. But it would at least allow tensions over Muslims\xe2\x80\x99 religious practices to fade. This would avoid needless sectarian strife and clear the way for politicians to address the more vexing and urgent challenges of socioeconomic integration.'b'Not long ago, a veteran Republican strategist told me that a politician could succeed with his zipper down, but not with his words unbridled.'b'He was talking about Newt Gingrich, and was saying that Gingrich\xe2\x80\x99s philandering and three marriages weren\xe2\x80\x99t going to be his real problem, given how many men in government had been forgiven for messy sexual pasts.'b'His greater liabilities were his wildly mixed messages, gross overstatements and insistence on inserting himself \xe2\x80\x94 like some mouthy Gump doppelg\xc3\xa4nger with a doctorate \xe2\x80\x94 into every key moment of the late 20th century. Gingrich was supposed to bloviate his way into oblivion.'b'Instead he bloviated his way to a 12-point victory in South Carolina and a credible shot at the Republican nomination. Grandiosity, it turns out, is good.'b'In fact he has doubled down on it. Quadrupled down, really. Although under fire since his previous surge two months ago for all his self-aggrandizing exaggerations, he hasn\xe2\x80\x99t grown careful or bashful or anything of the sort. Neither has the team around him.'b'In late December, when it was announced that he had failed to qualify for the Virginia primary, a campaign official 'b'compared'b' the blow to Pearl Harbor.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNewt and I agreed that the analogy is December 1941,\xe2\x80\x9d wrote the official, Michael Krull, on the candidate\xe2\x80\x99s Facebook page. I wonder which grim historical milestones they considered and rejected before finding consensus on that one.'b'In Monday night\xe2\x80\x99s debate, Gingrich characterized the end of his Congressional career after the 1998 midterms as wholly volitional, making his exit sound like a self-sacrificing blaze of glory rather than the acrimonious firestorm it was.'b'With Gingrich, the distance between reality and rhetoric isn\xe2\x80\x99t shrinking but growing, and the incongruities mount. He has lately fallen in love with his rants against \xe2\x80\x9cthe elites,\xe2\x80\x9d and casts himself as their most determined foe, but I can\xe2\x80\x99t for the life of me figure out a definition of elite that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t include him.'b'Are the elites those hyper-educated intellectuals who use big words? Gingrich has a Ph.D. in history from a prestigious private university, Tulane, and when it suits him, he plays Cerebellum in Chief with nonpareil diction and derision.'b'Are the elites rich people with fancy ZIP codes? He and his third wife, Callista, made more than $3.1 million in 2010 and have an estimated net worth in excess of $6.5 million. Since 2000 they have lived in the posh enclave of McLean, Va., not Appalachia, and have personally stimulated the economy with expenditures at Tiffany, not Zales.'b'He lashes out against secularists and trumpets his and Callista\xe2\x80\x99s Roman Catholicism, though the two of them lived for six years in 'b'explicit defiance'b' of its tenets.'b'Mitt Romney\xe2\x80\x99s reinventions pale beside Gingrich\xe2\x80\x99s. At one moment, in one passage of oratory, Gingrich is the only stick-to-his-guns conservative running. At another moment, in another passage, he\xe2\x80\x99s a seasoned practitioner of compromise, as proved by the Clinton years.'b'He\xe2\x80\x99s also a longtime Washington insider who\xe2\x80\x99s the only reform-minded outsider equipped to change the capital\xe2\x80\x99s ways. How does that work?'b'In contesting his second wife\xe2\x80\x99s 'b'claim'b' on ABC\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cNightline\xe2\x80\x9d that he had requested an open marriage, he accused the news media of a special anti-Republican zeal, conveniently forgetting how that same media \xe2\x80\x94 with his gleeful encouragement \xe2\x80\x94 pounced on the moral failings of President Clinton, a Democrat.'b'He rails that the media can\xe2\x80\x99t be trusted, then readily cites any dispatch that cuts in his favor as unassailable truth. He 'b'did this'b' on Monday on ABC\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cGood Morning America,\xe2\x80\x9d invoking a New York Times article from 2008 as part of his defense against Romney\xe2\x80\x99s charge that he has lobbied lawmakers.'b'He had initially been slated to appear on ABC on Sunday, on \xe2\x80\x9cThis Week,\xe2\x80\x9d but canceled after the network\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cNightline\xe2\x80\x9d report. He did competing networks\xe2\x80\x99 Sunday shows instead.'b'By Monday, though, he was ready to heed the siren call of George Stephanopoulos, his pique with ABC as transitory as his ire at CNN\xe2\x80\x99s John King last week was inflated. It\xe2\x80\x99s all one hyperbolic \xe2\x80\x94 and, in its way, brilliant \xe2\x80\x94 performance.'b'For a Republican electorate looking for heat, he delivers gust upon gust of hot air. Romney manages only a tepid breeze.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI have emotion and passion,\xe2\x80\x9d Romney told the anchor Chris Wallace on \xe2\x80\x9cFox News Sunday,\xe2\x80\x9d in a voice that communicated neither. Twice more he mentioned passion, as if willing it into his bones.'b'Wallace played a clip of Gingrich\xe2\x80\x99s South Carolina victory speech, noting how fiercely angry at the state of the country Gingrich seemed.'b'Romney said that he himself was \xe2\x80\x9cvery upset.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Most Democrats are elated. Gingrich seems to them a weaker opponent for President Obama than Romney would be. They\xe2\x80\x99re rooting for him.'b'But unbridled words have an unexpected currency right now. And one ill-timed, major economic relapse could give the general-election advantage to any Republican nominee, including Gingrich, whose bombast would then get the loudest microphone in the world.'b'I hope President Obama read about Maddie Parlier as he was working on his State of the Union address. Parlier is the subject of 'b'Adam Davidson\xe2\x80\x99s illuminating article'b' in the current issue of The Atlantic.'b'Parlier\xe2\x80\x99s father abandoned her when she was young and crashed his car while driving drunk, killing himself and a family of four. Maddie is smart and hard-working. She did reasonably well in high school but got pregnant her senior year.'b'She and the father of her child split up, which put the kibosh on her college dreams because she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t afford day care. She temped for a while. Her work ethic got her noticed, and she got a job as an unskilled laborer at Standard Motor Products, which makes fuel injectors.'b'Parlier earns about $13 an hour. She\xe2\x80\x99d like to become one of the better-paid workers in the plant, but, in today\xe2\x80\x99s factories, that requires an enormous leap in skills. It feels cruel, Davidson writes, to mention all the things Parlier would have to learn to move up. She doesn\xe2\x80\x99t know the computer language that runs the machines. \xe2\x80\x9cShe doesn\xe2\x80\x99t know trigonometry or calculus, and she\xe2\x80\x99s never studied the properties of cutting tools or metals. She doesn\xe2\x80\x99t know how to maintain a tolerance of 0.25 microns, or what tolerance means in this context, or what a micron is.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'A good attitude and hustle have taken Parlier as far as they can. It\xe2\x80\x99s hard, given her situation, to acquire the skills she needs to realize the American dream.'b'Davidson\xe2\x80\x99s article is important because it shows the interplay between economic forces (globalization and technology) and social forces (single parenthood and the breakdown of community support). Globalization and technological change increase the demands on workers; social decay makes it harder for them to meet those demands.'b'Across America, millions of mothers can\xe2\x80\x99t rise because they don\xe2\x80\x99t have adequate support systems as they try to improve their skills. Tens of millions of children have poor life chances because they grow up in disorganized environments that make it hard to acquire the social, organizational and educational skills they will need to become productive workers.'b'Tens of millions of men have marred life chances because schools are bad at educating boys, because they are not enmeshed in the long-term relationships that instill good habits and because insecure men do stupid and self-destructive things.'b'Over the past 40 years, women\xe2\x80\x99s wages have risen sharply but, as Michael Greenstone and Adam Looney of the 'b'Hamilton Project'b' point out, median incomes of men have dropped 28 percent and male labor force participation rates are down 16 percent. Next time somebody talks to you about wage stagnation, have them break it down by sex. It\xe2\x80\x99s not only globalization and technological change causing this stagnation. It\xe2\x80\x99s the deterioration of the moral and social landscape, especially for men.'b'The idiocy of our current political debate is that neither side seems capable of talking about the interplay of economic and social forces. Most of the Republican candidates talk as if all that is needed is more capitalism. But lighter regulation and lower taxes won\xe2\x80\x99t, on their own, help the Maddie Parliers of the world get the skills they need to compete.'b'Democrats, meanwhile, have shifted their emphasis from lifting up the poor to pounding down the rich. Democratic candidates no longer emphasize early childhood education and community-building. Instead they embrace the pseudo-populist Occupy Wall Street hokum \xe2\x80\x94 the opiate of the educated classes.'b'This materialistic ethos emphasizes reducing inequality instead of expanding opportunity. Its policy prescriptions begin (and sometimes end) with raising taxes on the rich. This makes you feel better if you detest all the greed-heads who went into finance. It does nothing to address those social factors, like family breakdown, that help explain why American skills have not kept up with technological change.'b'If President Obama is really serious about restoring American economic dynamism, he needs an aggressive two-pronged approach: More economic freedom combined with more social structure; more competition combined with more support.'b'As a survey of nearly 10,000 Harvard Business School grads by Michael Porter and Jan Rivkin makes clear, to get companies to locate their plants in the U.S., Obama is going to have to simplify the tax code, cut corporate rates, streamline regulations, make immigration policy more flexible and balance the budget over the long term.'b'To ensure there\xe2\x80\x99s skilled labor for those plants, Obama would have to champion different policies: successful training programs like 'b'Job Corps'b', better coordination between colleges and employers, better treatment for superstar teachers, more child care options and better early childhood education.'b'This agenda is libertarian in the capitalist sector and activist in the human capital sector. Don\xe2\x80\x99t triangulate meekly toward the center; select bold policies from both ends. That\xe2\x80\x99s what would help Maddie Parlier and millions like her.'b'It was early in the evening of Jan. 13 when 'b'Ryan Boatright'b', the freshman basketball player at the University of Connecticut, learned that he was being suspended from the team 'b'for the second time'b' this season. Earlier that day, he had flown into South Bend, Ind., with his teammates for a game against Notre Dame. The 19-year-old point guard was excited because some 400 people from his hometown, Aurora, Ill., were coming to see him play.'b'When his coach, Jim Calhoun, broke the news that the N.C.A.A. was still investigating him, Boatright collapsed in Calhoun\xe2\x80\x99s arms. In tears, he called his mother, Tanesha, who began weeping uncontrollably. 'b'As I chronicled on Saturday'b', it was her acceptance of plane tickets a year or so ago that had caused his first suspension. The N.C.A.A. had ruled the tickets an \xe2\x80\x9cimproper benefit,\xe2\x80\x9d and had ordered him to sit out six games and pay a $100-per-month fine to repay the tickets. What more, she wondered, could the N.C.A.A. want?'b'A lot, it turned out. Tanesha is a single mother raising four children on a small salary. The N.C.A.A. investigators viewed her circumstances as a cause for suspicion, not sympathy. For instance, she owns a car. Where did she get the money to pay for it, they asked? How did she pay for her home? And so on.'b'Concluding that she had no choice but to cooperate \xe2\x80\x94 otherwise, her son would surely pay a severe price \xe2\x80\x94 Tanesha turned over her bank statements, as the N.C.A.A. demanded. Four N.C.A.A. investigators pored through her financial records and conducted interrogations in Aurora, seeking \xe2\x80\x9cevidence\xe2\x80\x9d that she was getting money from \xe2\x80\x9cimproper\xe2\x80\x9d sources. (Tanesha declined to comment.)'b'When the investigators saw a series of cash deposits in her bank account, they demanded to know the source of the money. She told them: Friends had given her money so that she and her children could have a joyful Christmas. The investigators said they didn\xe2\x80\x99t believe her; they felt sure that she must have gotten the money from an unscrupulous sports agent or some other party outlawed by the N.C.A.A.'b'Meanwhile, her son remains in limbo, unable to play the game he loves, his reputation unfairly besmirched, while he awaits the N.C.A.A.\xe2\x80\x99s latest ruling. I keep hearing it might happen soon, but, so far, nothing. People associated with Connecticut basketball, including Calhoun, are said to be furious at the N.C.A.A.\xe2\x80\x99s treatment of Ryan Boatright. But the university is as fearful of the N.C.A.A. as Tanesha. It has yet to say a single word publicly on his behalf.'b'When I asked the N.C.A.A. about the Boatright case, the response I received was deeply disingenuous. Refusing to discuss the actions of its investigators, it essentially said that Connecticut, not the N.C.A.A., declared Boatright ineligible. That is technically true. Schools declare athletes ineligible because if they don\xe2\x80\x99t, the N.C.A.A. will deprive them of scholarships, force them to forfeit games and prevent them from playing in postseason games. Most astonishing, an N.C.A.A. spokeswoman told me that the organization does not have the legal authority to compel cooperation from parents. Again, technically true: Its real weapon \xe2\x80\x94 the threat of destroying their sons\xe2\x80\x99 careers \xe2\x80\x94 is far more potent than any mere subpoena.'b'Over the past three weeks, as 'b'I\xe2\x80\x99ve written a series of columns'b' about the abuses of the N.C.A.A., one question keeps reverberating in my head: How can this be happening in America?'b'How can children be punished for the deeds of their parents \xe2\x80\x94 deeds that aren\xe2\x80\x99t even wrong in any basic legal sense? How can the N.C.A.A. blithely wreck careers without regard to due process or common fairness? How can it act so ruthlessly to enforce rules that are so petty? Why won\xe2\x80\x99t anybody stand up to these outrageous violations of American values and American justice?'b'The columns have also prompted e-mails, mostly from parents of college athletes, with their own examples of N.C.A.A. injustices. The women\xe2\x80\x99s basketball player at Harvard who came to the United States from Britain and isn\xe2\x80\x99t allowed to play because she struggled when she first got to the U.S. and had to repeat a year of high school. The team manager \xe2\x80\x94 yes, team manager! \xe2\x80\x94 who was forced out of his role because he knew a high school player that his school was recruiting. The A students forced off the court because the N.C.A.A. does not include their high school A.P. courses among its \xe2\x80\x9capproved\xe2\x80\x9d coursework. The coach whose career was ended when the N.C.A.A. accused him of \xe2\x80\x9cunethical conduct\xe2\x80\x9d without giving him a chance to defend himself.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe N.C.A.A. is like the Gestapo,\xe2\x80\x9d wrote one parent in an e-mail. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s out there, we all fear it, and it is all-powerful and follows its own rules and makes them up as they go along. Who are they protecting? The same thing the Gestapo protected: themselves.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'After weeks of temporizing, Mitt Romney said he 'b'plans to release'b' a small slice of his tax records on Tuesday \xe2\x80\x94 his 2010 returns and an estimate for his 2011 taxes. It is not enough. American voters need to know a lot more about the business interests that Mr. Romney says make him the best candidate to be president. (President Obama, after all, released eight years\xe2\x80\x99 worth of tax records during the 2008 campaign; Mr. Romney\xe2\x80\x99s father, George, released 12 years\xe2\x80\x99 worth when he ran for president in 1968.)'b'Mr. Romney\xe2\x80\x99s main rival for the Republican presidential nomination, Newt Gingrich \xe2\x80\x94 after a lot of pious declarations about how Mr. Romney needed to come clean \xe2\x80\x94 has released only one year\xe2\x80\x99s worth of his tax records. He did so not because of any real dedication to transparency, but because he wanted to increase the pressure on Mr. Romney and to show that he had paid an effective tax rate of 31.7 percent, roughly twice the rate that Mr. Romney has said he paid.'b'There is lot more than that to be learned from Mr. Gingrich\xe2\x80\x99s documents, starting with the mockery they make of his claim to be an insurgent Washington outsider, the supposed anti-establishment candidate.'b'After he was drummed out of the House speaker\xe2\x80\x99s office in 1998, Mr. Gingrich set about creating a lucrative living, by trading on his political connections. 'b'In 2010, he reported a total income of $3.16 million'b' (including a tidy $76,200 Congressional pension).'b'Most of Mr. Gingrich\xe2\x80\x99s income has come from helping corporate clients gain access and solicitous treatment from Washington\xe2\x80\x99s power elite. One of his consulting groups, the 'b'Center for Health Transformation'b', 'b'gave clients advice in reaching what it called'b' \xe2\x80\x9ctop transformational leadership across industry and government.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'His services, according to news accounts, included helping his clients formulate arguments to get lawmakers to incorporate their interests in legislation. Over the years, that included up to $1.8 million in \xe2\x80\x9cconsulting fees\xe2\x80\x9d to him and his firm from Freddie Mac, the lending company that Mr. Gingrich has accused of helping to cause the housing crisis.'b'Mr. Gingrich insists that none of this highly paid work is lobbying. \xe2\x80\x9c'b'I was never a lobbyist'b',\xe2\x80\x9d he said on \xe2\x80\x9cMeet the Press\xe2\x80\x9d on Sunday. \xe2\x80\x9cI never did any lobbying.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'That is true, in the sense that Mr. Gingrich never registered as a lobbyist \xe2\x80\x94 someone who is paid to go to Congressional or government offices and make specific pitches on behalf of special pleaders to influence legislation. But people of his stature never register. They develop strategy and use their contacts to open doors and then leave the appointment-making to more junior people who are registered as lobbyists.'b'According to The Washington Post, 'b'the Gingrich brand generated $100 million'b' in revenue over the past decade for a collection of for-profit enterprises, including that health care group, which charged six-figure dues to large corporations.'b'So Mr. Gingrich can claim he was never a lobbyist, but there is no way he can claim that he is anything but a Washington insider who has made millions by trading on his political connections for more than a decade. He\xe2\x80\x99s a shrewd broker of Washington influence, and about as \xe2\x80\x9cestablishment\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 and cynical \xe2\x80\x94 as you can get.'b'President Rafael Correa of Ecuador is leading a relentless campaign against free speech, harassing his critics, forcing independent broadcasters off the air and hijacking the nation\xe2\x80\x99s courts in his bid to bankrupt the country\xe2\x80\x99s largest newspaper.'b'After Emilio Palacio, the editorial page editor of 'b'El Universo'b', wrote a column accusing Mr. Correa of ordering the army to open fire on a hospital during a police protest, Mr. Correa filed a criminal suit against the editor and three of the paper\xe2\x80\x99s directors, claiming \xe2\x80\x9caggravated defamation of a public official.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Despite outrageous irregularities \xe2\x80\x94 the case was finally decided by a \xe2\x80\x9ctemporary magistrate\xe2\x80\x9d who, according to an independent forensic analysis, may have outsourced the job of writing the decision to the president\xe2\x80\x99s lawyer \xe2\x80\x94 an appeals court confirmed a $40 million award for the president, plus three-year sentences for the directors and Mr. Palacio. A final appeal by the directors is expected to be heard on Wednesday. Mr. Palacio has run out of appeals.'b'Looking forward to next year\xe2\x80\x99s presidential elections, in which he is likely to run, Mr. Correa has also pushed through a law that would forbid the news media from \xe2\x80\x9ceither directly or indirectly promoting any given candidate, proposal, options, electoral preferences or political thesis, through articles, specials or any other form of message.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Mr. Correa\xe2\x80\x99s assault on the press has rightly drawn criticism from the 'b'Special Rapporteur for Freedom of Expression'b' at the 'b'Organization of American States'b'. Now he is trying to silence the rapporteur. Last month, his government presented the O.A.S. with recommendations to \xe2\x80\x9cimprove\xe2\x80\x9d the special rapporteur, by reducing its financing, limiting the scope of its annual reports and imposing a code of conduct to restrict its independence.'b'The United States and others only belatedly recognized what Mr. Correa was up to. In December, the O.A.S. adopted a broader final report on 'b'the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights'b' monitoring system that included some of the recommendations. When the O.A.S. ambassadors meet in Washington this week, they should do all they can \xe2\x80\x94 there is room to maneuver \xe2\x80\x94 to protect the financing and the voice of the rapporteur. Mr. Correa, predictably, couches his moves in populist rhetoric. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen we are liberating our states from the de facto powers that always dominated them \xe2\x80\x94 like the power of information \xe2\x80\x94 these de facto powers accuse us,\xe2\x80\x9d he said in'b' a speech'b' before Latin-American leaders in December. There is no doubt that his assault on a free press is an assault on democracy.'b'Latin America has a bitter history of authoritarian rule. It has struggled hard to get beyond those days. All of the hemisphere\xe2\x80\x99s democratic leaders, including President Obama, need to push back against Mr. Correa.'b'Two years ago, when the Supreme Court struck down bans on independent corporate and union expenditures in elections in the 'b'Citizens United'b' case, Justice Anthony Kennedy\xe2\x80\x99s majority opinion claimed that money does not \xe2\x80\x9cgive rise to corruption or the appearance of corruption.\xe2\x80\x9d While it might result in \xe2\x80\x9cinfluence over or access to elected officials,\xe2\x80\x9d he wrote, it is not the same as bribery.'b'Last month, in a 5-to-2 vote, the Montana Supreme Court rejected that misguided reasoning and 'b'upheld'b' a part of a state anticorruption law banning corporations from making political expenditures from general treasuries. The court\xe2\x80\x99s dissenters argued that Montana cannot ignore the Citizens United decision \xe2\x80\x94 and they may well be proved right when the case is appealed to the United States Supreme Court. Still, the majority and a dissenting opinion agree that Citizens United has given corporations enormous power barely distinguishable from bribery.'b'Montana has a long history of fighting political corruption. A century ago, state voters passed an initiative that banned corporate spending to help or hurt candidates for public office. They were responding to 'b'epic political corruption'b' caused by the copper kings who controlled a big part of the state\xe2\x80\x99s wealth.'b'The court\xe2\x80\x99s majority in Western Tradition Partnership v. Montana ruled that Citizens United does not apply to Montana\xe2\x80\x99s law because it is tailored to meet a compelling state interest and its burden on corporations\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9cpolitical activity or speech\xe2\x80\x9d is minimal \xe2\x80\x94 they can easily set up political action committees for contributions from officers and shareholders. The court also stressed the acute need to limit corporate influence in politics because elected officials shape policies that determine winners and losers in fights over the state\xe2\x80\x99s natural resources.'b'In Citizens United, the conservative majority turned itself into a copper kings\xe2\x80\x99 court. The Montana Supreme Court, faced with tangible effects of corporate electioneering, shows how that decision undermines the fight against political corruption \xe2\x80\x94 and can make it far worse.'b'Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey acted in the public interest when he signed a long-overdue bill that permits pharmacies to sell a limited number of syringes to individuals without prescriptions. This new law will save lives across the state by slowing the spread of blood-borne viruses like H.I.V.'b'Intravenous drug users in New Jersey who likely contracted H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, from contaminated needles have accounted for more than 40 percent of the nearly 76,000 H.I.V./AIDS cases recorded in the state since the beginning of the epidemic, compared with about 25 percent nationally. Many of those who died from the disease might never have been infected at all had the Legislature acted promptly on needle access bills that were introduced in various forms in the 1990s.'b'But the Legislature waited until 2006, when it authorized a handful of programs that were permitted to distribute clean needles to addicts. A 2010 state analysis found that they had been instrumental in recruiting addicts to treatment and that they had the potential to significantly slow the transmission of blood-borne diseases.'b'Not all addicts, however, are willing to be seen collecting syringes, so the new law allows pharmacies to sell as many as 10 syringes at a time to adults without a prescription. The pharmacies must provide them with information on treatment and instructions for safe disposal.'b'The state still needs to expand programs that provide addicts with treatment and access to clean needles.'b''b'To the Editor: 'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Bird Flu Scientists Agree to Delay Virus Research'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (news article, Jan. 21):'b'There is great debate in the scientific and public health community about what should be done regarding recent experiments in which scientists mutated H5N1 bird flu strains so that they could spread readily between ferrets.'b'Ferrets are the best model for predicting human flu transmission, so the assumption should be that this new strain would spread among humans, perhaps as easily as seasonal flu.'b'Both sides in the debate deeply value public health and are seeking to diminish the dangers of bird flu. The question is whether these new experiments increase or decrease the dangers of a bird flu pandemic.'b'Naturally occurring H5N1 bird flu has killed nearly 60 percent of the 'b'583'b' cases confirmed by the World Health Organization since 2003. Fortunately, it has not spread effectively among people. If this engineered transmissible H5N1 strain were to escape the lab by accident or intentional act, and if it maintained high lethality while spreading as effectively as seasonal flu, it could kill tens or hundreds of millions of people worldwide.'b'Those in favor of the work have argued that it will improve bird flu surveillance and vaccine development efforts. But it seems unlikely that bird flu surveillance and control programs will be substantially changed based on this research. And developing vaccines against H5N1 strains that are actually emerging in nature does not require this kind of research.'b'The potential benefits of the research do not justify the potential dangers, so the research should be discontinued. While in almost all circumstances basic research should be fully disseminated in the science community, in this case the results should not be published in a way that allows them to be replicated by others. If allowed to continue, the research should be performed only in pursuit of concrete, urgent goals under international approval and the greatest possible safety conditions.'b'TOM INGLESBY'b'\nBaltimore, Jan. 24, 2012'b''b''b'The writer, an infectious-disease doctor, is director of the Center for Biosecurity, University of Pittsburgh Medical Center.'b''b''b'\n'b'Editors\xe2\x80\x99 Note: 'b''b''b'We invite readers to respond to this letter for our Sunday Dialogue. E-mail: 'b'letters@nytimes.com'b''b''b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'If You\xe2\x80\x99re Mad for \xe2\x80\x98Downton,\xe2\x80\x99 Publishers Have Reading Lists'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (front page, Jan. 12):'b'In your very flattering article about books that might please fans of \xe2\x80\x9cDownton Abbey,\xe2\x80\x9d I was sorry that one title was missing: \xe2\x80\x9cTo Marry an English Lord,\xe2\x80\x9d by Gail MacColl and Carol McD. 'b''b'Cairo'b'THE fate of one man can sometimes clarify the deepest flaws of a government and of the society it rules. Today in Egypt, on the anniversary of its uprising against Hosni Mubarak, that man is Maikel Nabil Sanad.'b'Mr. Nabil spent much of the last year in a tiny, fetid cell in El Marg Prison in Cairo, where he went on a hunger strike. He was removed, under guard, to a hospital on New Year\xe2\x80\x99s Day to recuperate. Last week he was pardoned and yesterday he was released. But his fight \xe2\x80\x94 and his troubles \xe2\x80\x94 are probably not over.'b'What he has endured already illustrates not just the repressive practices of Egypt\xe2\x80\x99s interim military rulers. It also illuminates a broader challenge facing Egyptian society itself, if it hopes that democracy and pluralism will replace the Mubarak government.'b'That is because Mr. Nabil, unlike other jailed protesters, is a Coptic Christian by background, an atheist by belief and a pacifist whose rejection of violence has led him even to declare zealously that Israel has a right to live in peace in the region, a sentiment that contrasts with most Egyptians\xe2\x80\x99 grudging acceptance and suspicion of their neighbor.'b'So while other imprisoned dissidents have become causes c\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8bres here, Mr. Nabil has not. Still, he has continued to campaign against the interim government, and to preach that until all voices \xe2\x80\x94 even unpopular ones like his \xe2\x80\x94 can be heard, none will be safe.'b'The fact that reaction to his persecution has been muted, even among some activists, suggests how hard the struggle for free expression will be in Egypt.'b'Mr. Nabil\xe2\x80\x99s criticisms of the military predate the uprising. He agitated against conscription in 2009 and refused his call-up notice in 2010. He was detained for that \xe2\x80\x94 and detained again on his way to Tahrir Square in February. Military intelligence agents beat him for carrying a placard that said of the state: \xe2\x80\x9cWe want it civil, not religious or military.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Then his real troubles started. Shortly after Mr. Mubarak stepped down, Mr. Nabil wrote Facebook and blog posts, including one saying that the army and the people were 'b'never one hand'b' \xe2\x80\x94 an effort, Mr. Nabil said, to puncture a myth that the military had supported the protesters. (The post ridiculed a chant, \xe2\x80\x9cThe people and the army are one hand.\xe2\x80\x9d)'b'The post also said, long before other protesters would reach the same conclusion, that the revolution had \xe2\x80\x9cso far managed to get rid of the dictator but not of the dictatorship.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'On March 28, Mr. Nabil was arrested, and 13 days later he was sentenced by a military tribunal to three years in prison \xe2\x80\x94 later reduced to two \xe2\x80\x94 for insulting the army. His summary trial was one of thousands that bypassed guarantees for fair trials.'b'Relatives said he refused to write a formal apology to the armed forces. Instead, he continued his polemical writings from prison. In an essay, \xe2\x80\x9c'b'One Citizen'b',\xe2\x80\x9d that was smuggled out and posted online in December, he implored Egyptians to understand \xe2\x80\x9cthat all freedom is lost once they allow the wolf to choose the first victim from amongst the herd, that they cannot regain the freedom of society unless every \xe2\x80\x98one citizen\xe2\x80\x99 is free.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Meanwhile, Egypt\xe2\x80\x99s interim military rule has been marked by escalating repression and, ultimately, the use of live ammunition against protesters. Even so, the repression was calibrated. Most of the victims were from vulnerable minorities like revolutionary activists, human rights workers and Christians.'b'The military clearly believes it has the support of Egypt\xe2\x80\x99s majority, and wants to minimize the risk of losing it. These tactics were in evidence most dramatically in October, when the military forcefully dispersed a largely Coptic demonstration, resulting in 27 deaths. Even Mr. Nabil\xe2\x80\x99s release seems calibrated: it carried no admission of error by the army, and is being read here as an effort to deflate dissidence during the anniversary.'b'The army\xe2\x80\x99s violent actions last year are more significant. If they were meant to stigmatize a few unpopular opponents in order to justify repression, much of Egyptian society has to some degree been complicit. Majority public opinion has not turned against the generals, who say repression is a defense against \xe2\x80\x9chidden hands\xe2\x80\x9d that threaten \xe2\x80\x9cstability.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Some activists have publicly stood up for Mr. Nabil. But his case has received a mere fraction of the attention given the unjustly accused and recently released activist Alaa Abdel Fattah. That divergence exposes how distant Egypt remains from an abiding respect for unorthodox views like Mr. Nabil\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x94 an essential feature of pluralistic politics. To reach that goal, there will have to be fundamental changes not just in Egyptian law and voting, but in its society.'b'For now, Egypt\xe2\x80\x99s authorities must release all of their political detainees and retry, in civilian courts, all of the civilians sentenced by military courts. The United States and the international community must make it clear that violations of fundamental rights will hurt Egypt\xe2\x80\x99s relations with the world.'b'And Egyptian society must come to grips with the broader circumstances that allowed Mr. Nabil\xe2\x80\x99s detention and persecution to go largely unnoticed.'b'A visitor who saw Mr. Nabil late last year said he was \xe2\x80\x9cstruck by the weakness of his body compared to the strength of his mind.\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Nabil will need more of that strength. Social change is a gradual process, and widespread social indifference to his fate will not end soon.'b'But Egypt won\xe2\x80\x99t be a full democracy until its people value the lonely defiance of a man like Maikel Nabil, even when they differ with most of his beliefs.'b'In an essay, entitled \xe2\x80\x9cMaking It in America,\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'in the latest issue of The Atlantic'b', the author Adam Davidson relates a joke from cotton country about just how much a modern textile mill has been automated: The average mill has only two employees today, \xe2\x80\x9ca man and a dog. The man is there to feed the dog, and the dog is there to keep the man away from the machines.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Davidson\xe2\x80\x99s article is one of a number of pieces that have recently appeared making the point that the reason we have such stubbornly high unemployment and sagging middle-class incomes today is largely because of the big drop in demand because of the Great Recession, but it is also because of the quantum advances in both globalization and the information technology revolution, which are more rapidly than ever replacing labor with machines or foreign workers.'b'In the past, workers with average skills, doing an average job, could earn an average lifestyle. But, today, average is officially over. Being average just won\xe2\x80\x99t earn you what it used to. It can\xe2\x80\x99t when so many more employers have so much more access to so much more above average cheap foreign labor, cheap robotics, cheap software, cheap automation and cheap genius. Therefore, everyone needs to find their extra \xe2\x80\x94 their unique value contribution that makes them stand out in whatever is their field of employment. 'b'Average is over.'b''b'Yes, new technology has been eating jobs forever, and always will. As they say, if horses could have voted, there never would have been cars. But there\xe2\x80\x99s been an acceleration. As Davidson notes, \xe2\x80\x9cIn the 10 years ending in 2009, [U.S.] factories shed workers so fast that they erased almost all the gains of the previous 70 years; roughly one out of every three manufacturing jobs \xe2\x80\x94 about 6 million in total \xe2\x80\x94 disappeared.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'And you ain\xe2\x80\x99t seen nothin\xe2\x80\x99 yet. Last April, Annie Lowrey of Slate wrote about a start-up called \xe2\x80\x9cE la Carte\xe2\x80\x9d that is out to shrink the need for waiters and waitresses: The company \xe2\x80\x9chas produced a kind of souped-up iPad that lets you order and pay right at your table. The brainchild of a bunch of M.I.T. engineers, the nifty invention, known as the Presto, might be found at a restaurant near you soon. ... You select what you want to eat and add items to a cart. Depending on the restaurant\xe2\x80\x99s preferences, the console could show you nutritional information, ingredients lists and photographs. You can make special requests, like \xe2\x80\x98dressing on the side\xe2\x80\x99 or \xe2\x80\x98quintuple bacon.\xe2\x80\x99 When you\xe2\x80\x99re done, the order zings over to the kitchen, and the Presto tells you how long it will take for your items to come out. ... Bored with your companions? Play games on the machine. When you\xe2\x80\x99re through with your meal, you pay on the console, splitting the bill item by item if you wish and paying however you want. And you can have your receipt e-mailed to you. ... Each console goes for $100 per month. If a restaurant serves meals eight hours a day, seven days a week, it works out to 42 cents per hour per table \xe2\x80\x94 making the Presto cheaper than even the very cheapest waiter.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'What the iPad won\xe2\x80\x99t do in an above average way a Chinese worker will. Consider this paragraph from Sunday\xe2\x80\x99s terrific 'b'article in The Times'b' by Charles Duhigg and Keith Bradsher about why Apple does so much of its manufacturing in China: \xe2\x80\x9cApple had redesigned the iPhone\xe2\x80\x99s screen at the last minute, forcing an assembly-line overhaul. New screens began arriving at the [Chinese] plant near midnight. A foreman immediately roused 8,000 workers inside the company\xe2\x80\x99s dormitories, according to the executive. Each employee was given a biscuit and a cup of tea, guided to a workstation and within half an hour started a 12-hour shift fitting glass screens into beveled frames. Within 96 hours, the plant was producing over 10,000 iPhones a day. \xe2\x80\x98The speed and flexibility is breathtaking,\xe2\x80\x99 the executive said. \xe2\x80\x98There\xe2\x80\x99s no American plant that can match that.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d'b'And automation is not just coming to manufacturing, explains Curtis Carlson, the chief executive of SRI International, a Silicon Valley idea lab that invented the Apple iPhone program known as Siri, the digital personal assistant. \xe2\x80\x9cSiri is the beginning of a huge transformation in how we interact with banks, insurance companies, retail stores, health care providers, information retrieval services and product services.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'There will always be change \xe2\x80\x94 new jobs, new products, new services. But the one thing we know for sure is that with each advance in globalization and the I.T. revolution, the best jobs will require workers to have more and better education to make themselves above average. Here are the latest unemployment rates from the Bureau of Labor Statistics for Americans over 25 years old: those with less than a high school degree, 13.8 percent; those with a high school degree and no college,\xc2\xa08.7 percent; those with some college or associate degree,\xc2\xa07.7 percent; and those with bachelor\xe2\x80\x99s degree or higher, 4.1 percent.'b'In a world where average is officially over, there are many things we need to do to buttress employment, but nothing would be more important than passing some kind of G.I. Bill for the 21st century that ensures that every American has access to post-high school education.'b'Berkeley, Calif.'b'MANY potential homebuyers who can afford to buy are instead waiting, worried that home prices will continue to decline.'b'In its most recent quarterly survey, Fannie Mae reported a continuing decline in the fraction of renters and homeowners who think buying a home is a safe investment.'b'But there is a way to buy a home with less risk to one\xe2\x80\x99s hard-earned cash: a down-payment protection plan.'b'Down-payment protection would provide a sensible and affordable way to restore confidence. It would complement the proposals President Obama made in his 'b'State of the Union address'b' Tuesday for increasing mortgage refinancings at today\xe2\x80\x99s low interest rates.'b'When combined with other economic woes, is it any wonder that so many potential buyers, especially younger adults, are renting, or living with relatives? By one recent estimate, the nation has about two million fewer households than under more normal conditions. Some of these potential buyers hesitate to take the risk of buying, even though their jobs and credit history may qualify them for mortgages. While near-record numbers of houses all over the country are empty, the sidelines are crowded with this huge \xe2\x80\x9cshadow demand.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Activating that demand for houses, condos and apartments would help the sales of related goods and services, which would in turn help reduce unemployment.'b'Here\xe2\x80\x99s how down-payment protection could work. Homebuyers could purchase protection from the government for a one-time fee, say 1 percent of the house purchase price, or $2,000 on a house selling for $200,000. The fee could vary with the risk of house price declines in each area. The plan would be open to all buyers.'b'At the end of three years, the government would automatically mail checks to protected homeowners if average house prices in their area were lower than when they purchased their homes. (No decline, no check \xe2\x80\x94 just like 'b'auto insurance'b'.)'b'Or, the payment might be applied to the mortgage to reduce the balance due. Declines would be based on the government\xe2\x80\x99s house-price indexes for nearly 400 areas in the country. Either way, without selling their homes, at the end of the third year homebuyers would be quickly and fully compensated for any loss of equity, up to the amount of their down payment.'b'Down-payment protection would encourage lenders to ease currently tight credit conditions. The Federal Reserve has documented that banks\xe2\x80\x99 lending standards have become tighter. Maybe they\xe2\x80\x99ve tightened them too much. Because lenders\xe2\x80\x99 risks tend to rise as house prices fall, the protection could also be used to encourage lenders to ease their mortgage terms a bit. In that scenario, the buyer of the house could pay for the down-payment protection and then assign it to the lender in return for easier mortgage terms, like agreeing to lower rates, fees or down payments.'b'That, too, would advance the goal of allowing more borrowers to qualify and buy houses.'b'Only the federal government can readily offer a down-payment protection program that is large enough to raise actual and expected future house prices, which would in turn lower how much the buyer would have to pay. In addition, unlike private providers of protection, the government reaps substantial extra revenue when its policies raise national income. Even if the taxpayers provide some subsidy, to the extent that the economy does better, they would get some benefit.'b'Depending on the fees and revenue gains, based on a scenario of two million participating home buyers, the expected net cost to taxpayers would be a few billion dollars annually, far less than some of the housing programs that have already been tried.'b'And, if it demonstrated the viability of the protection, the government could pass the baton to the private sector.'b'Having the government offer not just mortgage insurance to protect lenders, but also down-payment protection for homebuyers, could increase demand. A stronger housing sector in turn improves business for those who provide related services and products, which would create more jobs.'b'Israel\xe2\x80\x99s Supreme Court is the body that provides checks and balances to the country\xe2\x80\x99s executive and legislative powers, upholding constitutional standards.
