And she is being heavily courted by the Communist Party to run at the top of its list for the Chilean Congress in the 2013 elections.'b'For all its recent stumbles, the movement\xe2\x80\x99s prospects of getting a woman under 26 elected to Congress would help fulfill one of its underlying aims, to kindle young people\xe2\x80\x99s interest in traditional politics. This may be Ms. Vallejo\xe2\x80\x99s greatest contribution: to restore faith in a discredited system by showing a new generation that politics can be responsive to the people\xe2\x80\x99s demands.'b'LOS ANGELES'b'CHEERLEADERS with Tourette\xe2\x80\x99s syndrome. Like a fly buzzing against the window, this weird arrangement of words flitted across the edge of my consciousness last week. I kept thinking I should take a minute to track down the Onion piece from which this kooky phrase surely emanated, but finally committed some desultory Googling, and discovered that the buzzing idea correlated (more or less) to an actual event. A break in the case \xe2\x80\x94 and the appearance of two of the girls in a television interview \xe2\x80\x94 brought the story to national attention.'b'One afternoon last October in a small town about 50 miles from Buffalo, a high school cheerleader lay down for a nap, and woke up changed. She had been struck not with Tourette\xe2\x80\x99s but with a host of symptoms that resembled it: facial tics, uncontrollable movement, stuttering, verbal outbursts. Several other schoolmates have been afflicted, for a total of 14 girls. One boy reported symptoms. \xc2\xa0'b'Parents, school officials and doctors investigated possible organic causes of this troubling event, and serially ruled out potential suspects, from vaccine reactions to environmental hazards. (Erin Brockovich is looking into possible toxic causes.) The girls continued to suffer, dropped out of school and gave television interviews in which their arms looped around wildly and their voices broke and warbled.'b'Well, that\xe2\x80\x99s the kind of nutty story that only happens once, or so I briefly thought, until more focused Googling quickly led me to an almost identical episode, this one in 2002, in a high school in rural North Carolina. Once again, a cheerleader was first to manifest the strange symptoms, and once again other girls, some of them cheerleaders, were struck with the same condition.'b'There are famous cases that closely mimic these strange events. In 1962, in a girls\xe2\x80\x99 school in Tanzania, a laughing epidemic spread to 95 students and lasted for months. In 1965 there was a fainting episode at a girls\xe2\x80\x99 school in Blackburn, England, that landed 85 girls in the hospital. In 1983, when there was a widespread fear of chemical warfare in the West Bank, more than 900 Arab schoolgirls and a few female Israeli soldiers exhibited the symptoms of having been gassed, but doctors found no specific cause for the outbreak.'b'In all of these cases, the ultimate diagnosis \xe2\x80\x94 unpalatable in our post-Freudian age \xe2\x80\x94 was good old-fashioned hysteria.\xc2\xa0In the cheerleader cases, the first girl seems to have suffered from some kind of mental or emotional distress, which she expressed through otherwise unrelated physical symptoms. The other girls \xe2\x80\x94 victims of yesteryear\xe2\x80\x99s mass hysteria and today\xe2\x80\x99s mass psychogenic illness, in which the symptoms of hysteria pass from person to person, like contagion \xe2\x80\x94 believed the condition to be communicable and \xe2\x80\x9ccaught\xe2\x80\x9d it.'b'Hysteria is the most retrograde and non-womyn-empowering condition. It\xe2\x80\x99s not supposed to happen anymore (we have Title IX!), but it won\xe2\x80\x99t seem to go away. Both history and myth are filled with stories of girls exhibiting bizarre symptoms around the time of puberty \xe2\x80\x94 from Cassandra and her raving, to the girls of the Salem witch trials, to the girls whose households were believed to be the site of poltergeist hauntings, to cheerleaders in New York and North Carolina. Pubescent girls, it seems, are manifestly more likely to exhibit extreme and bizarre psychological symptoms than are teenage boys.'b'What no one has been able to determine is why this is so, why it is the cheerleaders and not the linebackers who come down with tics and stuttering. Female adolescence is \xe2\x80\x94 universally \xe2\x80\x94 an emotionally and psychologically intense period. It is during this time that girls become aware of the emergence of womanhood, with both the great joy and promise that come with it, and also the threat of danger. Much on their minds is their new potential for childbearing, an event that for most of human history has been fraught with physical peril. Furthermore, their emergence as sexual creatures brings with it heady excitement and increased physical vulnerability. They are also sharply aware that soon they will have to leave home forever, and at the very moment when they are most keenly desirous of its comforts and protections.'b'Most parents of adolescent girls will never have to contend with episodes of hysteria of the kind experienced by the cheerleaders. But anyone with a teenage daughter can attest that this is a time of emotional extremes and high drama, of girls who are one moment affectionate youngsters and the next screaming banshees. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat\xe2\x80\x99s gotten into you?\xe2\x80\x9d the perplexed mother in \xe2\x80\x9cThe Exorcist\xe2\x80\x9d wonders about her demonized daughter; it\xe2\x80\x99s a question that the mothers of non-possessed girls often ask during the teenage years.'b'What girls need during this time is a stable and supportive space in which to work out all of this drama. In many respects a teenage girl\xe2\x80\x99s home is more important to her than at any time since she was a small child. She also needs emotional support and protection from the most corrosive cultural forces that seek to exploit her when she is least able to resist. Most of all she needs some privacy to work to make a way for herself as a strong and confident young woman. The emotional swings of normal female adolescence attest to its intensity, and they are also the reason girls need and deserve more protection during this time of their lives. As a neurologist treating the New York girls said: \xe2\x80\x9cThese girls will get better. We have to give them time and space.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'IN recent years, a trend has emerged in the behavioral sciences toward shorter and more rapidly published journal articles. These articles are often only a third the length of a standard paper, often describe only a single study and tend to include smaller data sets. Shorter formats are promoted by many journals, and limits on article length are stringent \xe2\x80\x94 in many cases as low as 2,000 words.'b'This shift is partly a result of the pressure that academics now feel to generate measurable output. According to the cold calculus of \xe2\x80\x9cpublish or perish,\xe2\x80\x9d in which success is often gauged by counting citations, three short articles can be preferable to a single longer one.'b'But some researchers contend that the trend toward short articles is also better for science. Such \xe2\x80\x9cbite size\xe2\x80\x9d science, they argue, encourages results to be communicated faster, written more concisely and read by editors and researchers more easily, leading to a more lively exchange of ideas.'b'In a'b' 2010 article'b', the psychologist Nick Haslam demonstrated empirically that, when adjusted for length, short articles are cited more frequently than other articles \xe2\x80\x94 that is, page for page, they get more bang for the buck. Professor Haslam concluded that short articles seem \xe2\x80\x9cmore efficient in generating scientific influence\xe2\x80\x9d and suggested that journals might consider adopting short-article formats.'b'We believe, however, there are a number of serious problems with the short-article format.'b'First, we dispute the importance of Professor Haslam\xe2\x80\x99s finding that short articles get more bang for the buck. Suppose that you conduct two studies, each offering evidence for the same conclusion, and you can opt to publish them either as one long article or as two short ones. Suppose that the scientists who will cite your studies will cite them in either format, either the long article or the pair of shorter articles. Based on citations, each of the three articles would have the same impact, but on a per-page measure, the shorter articles would be more \xe2\x80\x9cinfluential.\xe2\x80\x9d But this would reflect only how we measure impact, not a difference in actual substance or influence.'b'Second, we challenge the idea that shorter articles are easier and quicker to read. This is true enough if you consider a single article, but assuming that there is a fixed number of studies carried out, shorter articles simply mean 'b'more 'b'articles. And an increase in articles can create more work for editors, reviewers and, perhaps most important, anyone looking to fully research or understand a topic.'b'Third, we worry that shorter, single-study articles can be poor models of science. Replication is a cornerstone of the scientific method, and in longer papers that present multiple experiments confirming the same result, replication is manifestly on display; this is not always so with short articles. (Indeed the shorter format may discourage replication, since once a study is published its finding loses novelty.) Short articles are also more likely to suffer from \xe2\x80\x9ccitation amnesia\xe2\x80\x9d: because an author has less space to discuss previous relevant work, he often doesn\xe2\x80\x99t do so, which can give the impression that his own finding is more novel than it actually is.'b'Finally, as 'b'we discuss in detail'b' in this month\xe2\x80\x99s issue of the journal Perspectives on Psychological Science, we are troubled by the link between small study size and publication bias. Theoretically, if several small studies on a topic, each with its own small data set, are sent to publishers, the overall published results should be equivalent to the results of a single large study on that topic using a complete data set. But according to several \xe2\x80\x9cmeta-studies\xe2\x80\x9d that have been conducted, this is often not the case: rather than the small studies\xe2\x80\x99 converging on the same result as a large study when published, the small studies give a very different result.'b'The reason is that small studies generate a wide variety of results, and those studies that generate boring results or results contrary to what their authors predicted are either never submitted for publication or rejected. This doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean that the authors or the journal editors are being dishonest; it just means that they look for significant effects and give priority to novelty. Small studies are inherently unreliable \xe2\x80\x94 larger studies or, better still, multiple studies on the same topic, are more likely to give definitive, accurate results.'b'The rise of bite-size science is worrisome. We urge that editors demand more replication of unexpected findings and that the importance that the academic community gives to quantity of citations be balanced with a greater awareness of potential publication bias.'b'Until then, bite-size science will be hard to swallow.'b'THREE million children in this country take drugs for problems in focusing. Toward the end of last year, many of their parents were deeply alarmed because there was a 'b'shortage of drugs like Ritalin and Adderall'b' that they considered absolutely essential to their children\xe2\x80\x99s functioning.'b'But are these drugs really helping children? Should we really keep expanding the number of prescriptions filled?'b'In 30 years there has been a twentyfold increase in the consumption of drugs for attention-deficit disorder.'b'As a psychologist who has been studying the development of troubled children for more than 40 years, I believe we should be asking why we rely so heavily on these drugs.'b'Attention-deficit drugs increase concentration in the short term, which is why they work so well for college students cramming for exams. But when given to children over long periods of time, they neither improve school achievement nor reduce behavior problems. The drugs can also have serious side effects, including stunting growth.'b'Sadly, few physicians and parents seem to be aware of what we have been learning about the lack of effectiveness of these drugs.'b'What gets publicized are short-term results and studies on brain differences among children. Indeed, there are a number of incontrovertible facts that seem at first glance to support medication. It is because of this partial foundation in reality that the problem with the current approach to treating children has been so difficult to see.'b'Back in the 1960s I, like most psychologists, believed that children with difficulty concentrating were suffering from a brain problem of genetic or otherwise inborn origin. Just as Type I diabetics need insulin to correct problems with their inborn biochemistry, these children were believed to require attention-deficit drugs to correct theirs. It turns out, however, that there is little to no evidence to support this theory.'b'In 1973, I reviewed the literature on drug treatment of children for The New England Journal of Medicine. Dozens of well-controlled studies showed that these drugs immediately improved children\xe2\x80\x99s performance on repetitive tasks requiring concentration and diligence. I had conducted one of these studies myself. Teachers and parents also reported improved behavior in almost every short-term study. This spurred an increase in drug treatment and led many to conclude that the \xe2\x80\x9cbrain deficit\xe2\x80\x9d hypothesis had been confirmed.'b'But questions continued to be raised, especially concerning the drugs\xe2\x80\x99 mechanism of action and the durability of effects. Ritalin and Adderall, a combination of dextroamphetamine and amphetamine, are stimulants. So why do they appear to calm children down? Some experts argued that because the brains of children with attention problems were different, the drugs had a mysterious paradoxical effect on them.'b'However, there really was no paradox. Versions of these drugs had been given to World War II radar operators to help them stay awake and focus on boring, repetitive tasks. And when we reviewed the literature on attention-deficit drugs again in 1990 we found that all children, whether they had attention problems or not, responded to stimulant drugs the same way. Moreover, while the drugs helped children settle down in class, they actually increased activity in the playground. Stimulants generally have the same effects for all children and adults. They enhance the ability to concentrate, especially on tasks that are not inherently interesting or when one is fatigued or bored, but they don\xe2\x80\x99t improve broader learning abilities.'b'And just as in the many dieters who have used and abandoned similar drugs to lose weight, the effects of stimulants on children with attention problems fade after prolonged use. Some experts have argued that children with A.D.D. wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t develop such tolerance because their brains were somehow different. But in fact, the loss of appetite and sleeplessness in children first prescribed attention-deficit drugs do fade, and, as we now know, so do the effects on behavior. They apparently develop a tolerance to the drug, and thus its efficacy disappears. Many parents who take their children off the drugs find that behavior worsens, which most likely confirms their belief that the drugs work. But the behavior worsens because the children\xe2\x80\x99s bodies have become adapted to the drug. Adults may have similar reactions if they suddenly cut back on coffee, or stop smoking.'b'TO date, no study has found any long-term benefit of attention-deficit medication on academic performance, peer relationships or behavior problems, the very things we would most want to improve. Until recently, most studies of these drugs had not been properly randomized, and some of them had other methodological flaws.'b'But in 2009, findings were published from a well-controlled study that had been going on for more than a decade, and the results were very clear. The study randomly assigned almost 600 children with attention problems to four treatment conditions. Some received medication alone, some cognitive-behavior therapy alone, some medication plus therapy, and some were in a community-care control group that received no systematic treatment. At first this study suggested that medication, or medication plus therapy, produced the best results. However, after three years, these effects had faded, and by eight years there was no evidence that medication produced any academic or behavioral benefits.'b'Indeed, all of the treatment successes faded over time, although the study is continuing. Clearly, these children need a broader base of support than was offered in this medication study, support that begins earlier and lasts longer.'b'Nevertheless, findings in neuroscience are being used to prop up the argument for drugs to treat the hypothesized \xe2\x80\x9cinborn defect.\xe2\x80\x9d These studies show that children who receive an A.D.D. diagnosis have different patterns of neurotransmitters in their brains and other anomalies. While the technological sophistication of these studies may impress parents and nonprofessionals, they can be misleading. Of course the brains of children with behavior problems will show anomalies on brain scans. It could not be otherwise. Behavior and the brain are intertwined. Depression also waxes and wanes in many people, and as it does so, parallel changes in brain functioning occur, regardless of medication.'b'Many of the brain studies of children with A.D.D. involve examining participants while they are engaged in an attention task. If these children are not paying attention because of lack of motivation or an underdeveloped capacity to regulate their behavior, their brain scans are certain to be anomalous.'b'However brain functioning is measured, these studies tell us nothing about whether the observed anomalies were present at birth or whether they resulted from trauma, chronic stress or other early-childhood experiences. One of the most profound findings in behavioral neuroscience in recent years has been the clear evidence that the developing brain is shaped by experience.'b'It is certainly true that large numbers of children have problems with attention, self-regulation and behavior. But are these problems because of some aspect present at birth? Or are they caused by experiences in early childhood? These questions can be answered only by studying children and their surroundings from before birth through childhood and adolescence, as my colleagues at the University of Minnesota and I have been doing for decades.'b'Since 1975, we have followed 200 children who were born into poverty and were therefore more vulnerable to behavior problems. We enrolled their mothers during pregnancy, and over the course of their lives, we studied their relationships with their caregivers, teachers and peers. We followed their progress through school and their experiences in early adulthood. At regular intervals we measured their health, behavior, performance on intelligence tests and other characteristics.'b'By late adolescence, 50 percent of our sample qualified for some psychiatric diagnosis. Almost half displayed behavior problems at school on at least one occasion, and 24 percent dropped out by 12th grade; 14 percent met criteria for A.D.D. in either first or sixth grade.'b'Other large-scale epidemiological studies confirm such trends in the general population of disadvantaged children. Among all children, including all socioeconomic groups, the incidence of A.D.D. is estimated at 8 percent. What we found was that the environment of the child predicted development of A.D.D. problems. In stark contrast, measures of neurological anomalies at birth, I.Q. and infant temperament \xe2\x80\x94 including infant activity level \xe2\x80\x94 did not predict A.D.D.'b'Plenty of affluent children are also diagnosed with A.D.D. Behavior problems in children have many possible sources. Among them are family stresses like domestic violence, lack of social support from friends or relatives, chaotic living situations, including frequent moves, and, especially, patterns of parental intrusiveness that involve stimulation for which the baby is not prepared. For example, a 6-month-old baby is playing, and the parent picks it up quickly from behind and plunges it in the bath. Or a 3-year-old is becoming frustrated in solving a problem, and a parent taunts or ridicules. Such practices excessively stimulate and also compromise the child\xe2\x80\x99s developing capacity for self-regulation.'b'Putting children on drugs does nothing to change the conditions that derail their development in the first place. Yet those conditions are receiving scant attention. Policy makers are so convinced that children with attention deficits have an organic disease that they have all but called off the search for a comprehensive understanding of the condition. The National Institute of Mental Health finances research aimed largely at physiological and brain components of A.D.D. While there is some research on other treatment approaches, very little is studied regarding the role of experience. Scientists, aware of this orientation, tend to submit only grants aimed at elucidating the biochemistry.'b'Thus, only one question is asked: are there aspects of brain functioning associated with childhood attention problems? The answer is always yes. Overlooked is the very real possibility that both the brain anomalies and the A.D.D. result from experience.'b'Our present course poses numerous risks. First, there will never be a single solution for all children with learning and behavior problems. While some smaller number may benefit from short-term drug treatment, large-scale, long-term treatment for millions of children is not the answer.'b'Second, the large-scale medication of children feeds into a societal view that all of life\xe2\x80\x99s problems can be solved with a pill and gives millions of children the impression that there is something inherently defective in them.'b'Finally, the illusion that children\xe2\x80\x99s behavior problems can be cured with drugs prevents us as a society from seeking the more complex solutions that will be necessary. Drugs get everyone \xe2\x80\x94 politicians, scientists, teachers and parents \xe2\x80\x94 off the hook. Everyone except the children, that is.'b'If drugs, which studies show work for four to eight weeks, are not the answer, what is? Many of these children have anxiety or depression; others are showing family stresses. We need to treat them as individuals.'b'As for shortages, they will continue to wax and wane. Because these drugs are habit forming, Congress decides how much can be produced. The number approved doesn\xe2\x80\x99t keep pace with the tidal wave of prescriptions. By the end of this year, there will in all likelihood be another shortage, as we continue to rely on drugs that are not doing what so many well-meaning parents, therapists and teachers believe they are doing.'b'Research into the bird flu virus has set off an impassioned scientific debate over its risks and benefits. Here is a sampling.'b''b'To the Editor: 'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Bird Flu Scientists Agree to Delay Virus Research'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (news article, Jan. 21):'b'There is great debate in the scientific and public health community about what should be done regarding recent experiments in which scientists mutated H5N1 bird flu strains so that they could spread readily between ferrets.'b'Ferrets are the best model for predicting human flu transmission, so the assumption should be that this new strain would spread among humans, perhaps as easily as seasonal flu.'b'Both sides in the debate deeply value public health and are seeking to diminish the dangers of bird flu. The question is whether these new experiments increase or decrease the dangers of a bird flu pandemic.'b'Naturally occurring H5N1 bird flu has killed nearly 60 percent of the 'b'583'b' cases confirmed by the World Health Organization since 2003. Fortunately, it has not spread effectively among people. If this engineered transmissible H5N1 strain were to escape the lab by accident or intentional act, and if it maintained high lethality while spreading as effectively as seasonal flu, it could kill tens or hundreds of millions of people worldwide.'b'Those in favor of the work have argued that it will improve bird flu surveillance and vaccine development efforts. But it seems unlikely that bird flu surveillance and control programs will be substantially changed based on this research. And developing vaccines against H5N1 strains that are actually emerging in nature does not require this kind of research.'b'The potential benefits of the research do not justify the potential dangers, so the research should be discontinued. While in almost all circumstances basic research should be fully disseminated in the science community, in this case the results should not be published in a way that allows them to be replicated by others. If allowed to continue, the research should be performed only in pursuit of concrete, urgent goals under international approval and the greatest possible safety conditions.'b'TOM INGLESBY'b' Baltimore, Jan. 24, 2012'b''b''b'The writer, an infectious-disease doctor, is director of the Center for Biosecurity, University of Pittsburgh Medical Center.'b''b''b'Readers React'b''b'Knowledge is always empowering, and identifying specific genetic mutations enabling a flu virus strain that rarely infects people, albeit with very high fatality rates, to become more readily transmissible among humans could prove an important contribution, possibly opening the door to targeted therapeutics and preventatives.'b'In arguing whether this research should have been done, we must keep in mind that flu strains have very high mutation rates, and the disputed mutations could well have arisen naturally at any time. The research in question was approved by peer review and financed by the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, the federal entity with the deepest experience in evaluating and supporting studies of the most dangerous infectious organisms known, and was conducted in high security Biosafety Level 3 facilities.'b'So, I disagree with Professor Inglesby and those of like mind who seem to see only the risk side of a risk-benefit calculation. I respect the concerns of the National Science Advisory Board for Biosecurity and agree that \xe2\x80\x9crecipes\xe2\x80\x9d for producing these mutants should not be published. Further, all stocks of these mutants, as well as their \xe2\x80\x9crecipes\xe2\x80\x9d should be deposited immediately in highest-security Biosafety Level 4 facilities, and all further research conducted only in such facilities, thereby maximizing environmental safety and permitting authentication of scientists who propose further studies.'b'The recently agreed \xe2\x80\x9c60-day moratorium\xe2\x80\x9d on the research evokes memory of the fabled Asilomar Conference almost 40 years ago, where scientists developed an oversight regime permitting transformative recombinant DNA research to proceed and launching the biotechnology industry, while calming the public fears, outlandish predictions and hysterical reactions that greeted this research breakthrough.'b'The history of Western civilization amply shows the futility of efforts to suppress human curiosity and new scientific discoveries and insights that may challenge dogma and settled expectations or otherwise generate unease.'b'DAVID KORN'b' Boston, Jan. 25, 2012'b''b''b'The writer, the former vice provost for research at Harvard, is a consultant in pathology at Massachusetts General Hospital and a professor of pathology at Harvard Medical School.'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b'In principle the specific knowledge gained from biomedical research with influenza viruses might aid surveillance and suppression efforts. However, that decidedly optimistic view overlooks some inconvenient on-the-ground realities. Mother Nature may compose a completely novel killer virus at any time. A better use of limited resources may be ensuring that global surveillance efforts are adequate to detect emerging flu viruses as early as possible and providing the means to eradicate them swiftly.'b'The record of well-documented accidents involving a range of human and animal pathogens at biodefense and other facilities is not reassuring. For instance, the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) virus has escaped containment several times.'b'Controlling the dissemination of information and restricting future work seems advisable. But, in a real sense for anyone hoping to deter bioterrorists, that cat is already out of the bag.'b'A quick review of recent publications will reveal the simple method used to select this new virus. Whether they possess the precise nucleotide sequences or not, knowing the general technique and, more important, now knowing with certainty that such a beast can be made, would-be terrorists can collect their own bird flu viruses in Asia and attempt to brew up a nightmare.'b'Despite the good intentions of the scientists working with engineered H5N1 and presumably other such viruses in the future, I object to potentially betting so many lives on the promise that these experiments can be undertaken in complete safety.'b'TYLER A. KOKJOHN'b' Glendale, Ariz., Jan. 25, 2012'b''b''b'The writer is a professor of microbiology at Midwestern University.'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s disarming to read Dr. Inglesby\xe2\x80\x99s assertion that flu research should be discontinued if the potential for pathogen surveillance and disease control fail to justify the alleged dangers. To ban virus research unless its \xe2\x80\x9cconcrete, urgent goals\xe2\x80\x9d meet the approval of the powers that be is to turn science into an engine of the status quo, instead of a sometimes serendipitous force for social improvement.'b'And it\xe2\x80\x99s appalling that Dr. Inglesby advocates limiting the publication of research results on the basis of frankly fantastical scenarios like killing \xe2\x80\x9ctens or hundreds of millions of people.\xe2\x80\x9d We need only think back to the H1N1 flu outbreak of 2009 and recall the hysterical predictions of an imminent reprise of the terrible 1918 flu.'b'Closing off access to research findings creates the same problem as does keeping government secrets from the public: nobody can keep an eye on the \xe2\x80\x9cexperts.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'PHILIP ALCABES'b' New York, Jan. 25, 2012'b''b''b'The writer is a professor of public health at CUNY School of Public Health at Hunter College.'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b'Dr. Inglesby\xe2\x80\x99s argument that potential benefits of the controversial H5N1 research do not justify its dangers underscores a fundamental question: Who should weigh the costs and benefits of risky biological research?'b'To this point, responsibility for controlling such work has been placed primarily in the institutions supporting this work: local review boards and national funding agencies.'b'But past experience shows that when bioscience foxes guard their own chicken coops, there\xe2\x80\x99s a tendency to overlook issues that fall outside possible benefits \xe2\x80\x94 like environmental, health or security dangers.'b'Thus, in the words of director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, Dr. Anthony Fauci, the health and security risks of the H5N1 research \xe2\x80\x9cdidn\xe2\x80\x99t hit the radar screen\xe2\x80\x9d either in the home research institutions or during the multilayered review system of the National Institutes of Health.'b'Broad oversight is needed at the national levels as well as worldwide, primarily by people with knowledge in relevant fields who have no career, financial or institutional stakes in the projects they review.'b'SUSAN WRIGHT'b' Santa Cruz, Calif., Jan. 25, 2012'b''b''b'The writer is the author of \xe2\x80\x9cMolecular Politics: Developing American and British Regulatory Policy for Genetic Engineering, 1972-1982.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b'Dr. Inglesby\xe2\x80\x99s argument that research on avian influenza H5N1 transmission should be discontinued is flawed because it is not based on scientific facts.'b'To conclude that an influenza virus transmitted among ferrets will do so in humans is to ignore the fundamental principles of viral pathogenesis. The ferret is a good model for human influenza, but the diseases are not the same, and influenza virus strains behave differently in the two hosts. For example, the 2009 pandemic H1N1 virus, which caused severe infections in some ferret studies, had relatively mild effects in humans.'b'The controversy over the H5N1 influenza experiments is being driven by what many individuals, including Dr. Inglesby, consider to be a high fatality rate associated with infection. While avian H5N1 influenza has killed more than half of the 583 cases confirmed by the World Health Organization, it is unlikely that even a small fraction of infections has been detected under the W.H.O. surveillance system. The case fatality rate cited by W.H.O. is very likely orders of magnitude too high.'b'To conclude that H5N1 surveillance programs will not be changed by this research misses one of the main goals. As a result of this work, we know to look for specific mutations in the same virus as possible indicators of increased mammalian transmission. This is priceless scientific information.'b'The benefits to our understanding of influenza virus transmission far outweigh the theoretical and minimal risks.'b'VINCENT RACANIELLO'b' New York, Jan. 25, 2012'b''b''b'The writer is a professor of microbiology and immunology at Columbia University.'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b'After the recent announcement of a moratorium on research on laboratory-generated transmissible H5N1 viruses, the key questions to be asked are: Under what conditions should research with lab-generated transmissible H5N1 viruses be allowed to resume? When? Where? With what biosafety provisions? With what biosecurity provisions? With what oversight?'b'It would be irresponsible to resume research with lab-generated transmissible H5N1 viruses before implementation of a review process that identifies and weighs the risks and benefits, then mitigates and manages the risks.'b'The World Health Organization currently regulates research with the smallpox virus. It restricts work with the smallpox virus to just two labs worldwide, requires the highest standards of biosafety and biosecurity, and requires that all proposed experiments be reviewed and approved in advance.'b'The W.H.O. should take the system that it currently uses to regulate smallpox virus and apply it to lab-generated transmissible H5N1 viruses.'b'RICHARD H. EBRIGHT'b' Piscataway N.J., Jan. 25, 2012'b''b''b'The writer is a professor of chemistry and chemical biology at Rutgers University and an investigator of the Howard Hughes Medical Institute.'b''b'\xc2\xa0'b'In discussing whether the H5N1 bird flu virus findings remain unpublicized, we should remember that the sole coin of the realm for scientists are fully disseminated research findings. These are necessary for university appointments and advancement, to say nothing about acceptance by colleagues.'b'The present discussion brings to mind a similar problem faced by atomic scientists just before World War II. As word of Lise Meitner\xe2\x80\x99s discovery of nuclear fission spread through Europe, the Hungarian physicist Leo Szilard took it upon himself to persuade colleagues around the world to limit public discussion related to this discovery, to prevent Nazi scientists from developing an atomic bomb.'b'It seems clear to me, as a scientist, that when our discoveries have an impact in ways that threaten humanity existentially, we must sometimes delay the gratification that comes with publicizing our findings.'b'One hopes that pertinent details concerning this extraordinarily virulent virus will be suppressed.'b'ABRAHAM R. LIBOFF'b' Delray Beach, Fla., Jan. 25, 2012'b''b''b'The writer is professor emeritus of physics at Oakland University.'b''b''b'The Writer Responds'b''b'I fully agree with Dr. Kokjohn that improving our global surveillance system and our capacity to respond effectively to H5N1 with vaccines and medicines should be top global priorities. Those concrete goals should strongly influence the scientific agenda for H5N1 going forward.'b'I am not proposing that we create a new oversight system for biological research more broadly. But I do agree with Dr. Korn to the extent that, if this specific research is allowed to continue, it should be performed only with appropriate, international oversight and the highest biocontainment conditions.'b'Dr. Racaniello doubts the assumption that the experimental H5N1 strain would be transmissible in humans. But a recent report from leading Centers for Disease Control and Prevention scientists argued that \xe2\x80\x9conly the ferret model is equally well suited for studying both the pathogenicity and transmissibility of human and avian influenza viruses.\xe2\x80\x9d While no animal can perfectly predict human infection, we have to rely on the closest surrogates to make judgments. The principal scientist of the controversial H5N1 experiment said he believes that this engineered virus would spread as well as seasonal flu.'b'Dr. Alcabes believes that the numbers are exaggerated. Every year seasonal flu infects as many as a billion people. The only confirmed data we have regarding the H5N1 fatality rate is the list of W.H.O.-confirmed cases, nearly 60 percent of whom have died.'b'There is speculation that there may be many mild cases of H5N1 not in the W.H.O. database, but there are very few documented clinical cases of mild H5N1 infection. Even if the case fatality rate of this experimental strain were much lower, the consequences of a pandemic would be terrible. The 1918 flu killed about 2 percent of its victims \xe2\x80\x94 an estimated 50 million died. The global population was less than a quarter of what it is now.'b'I am not proposing, as Dr. Alcabes implies, that we should \xe2\x80\x9cban virus research.\xe2\x80\x9d On the contrary, I fully support research that diminishes the dangers of H5N1, precisely because of the lethality of the virus. But H5N1 research intended to create highly transmissible strains deserves extraordinary scrutiny.'b'To paraphrase a point made by Dr. Liboff, if discoveries have the potential to threaten humanity, we should take a different course.'b'TOM INGLESBY'b' Baltimore, Jan. 27, 2012'b''b'MIAMI'b'WHAT is it with Barack Obama\xe2\x80\x99s penchant for getting in tangles with blond politicians on airport tarmacs?'b'Usually, tarmacs are for joyous welcomes or teary goodbyes. We\xe2\x80\x99re 'b'that'b' close.'b'DAVOS, Switzerland'b'IN a filthy Ethiopian prison that is overridden with lice, fleas and huge rats, two Swedes are serving an 11-year prison sentence for committing journalism.'b'Martin Schibbye, 31, and Johan Persson, 29, share a narrow bed, one man\xe2\x80\x99s head beside the other\xe2\x80\x99s feet. Schibbye once woke up to find a rat mussing his hair.'b'The prison is a violent, disease-ridden place, with inmates fighting and coughing blood, according to Schibbye\xe2\x80\x99s wife, Linnea Schibbye Steiner, who last met with her husband in December. It is hot in the daytime and freezing cold at night, and the two Swedes are allowed no mail or phone calls, she said. Fortunately, she added, the 250 or so Ethiopian prisoners jammed in the cell protect the two journalists, pray for them and jokingly call their bed \xe2\x80\x9cthe Swedish embassy.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'What was the two men\xe2\x80\x99s crime? Their offense was courage. 'b'They sneaked'b' into the Ogaden region to investigate reports of human rights abuses.'b'Prime Minister Meles Zenawi, Ethiopia\xe2\x80\x99s increasingly tyrannical ruler, seemed to be sending a signal to the world\xe2\x80\x99s journalists: Don\xe2\x80\x99t you dare mess with me!'b'So the only proper response is a careful look at Meles\xe2\x80\x99s worsening repression. Sadly, this repression is abetted by acquiescence from Washington and by grants from aid organizations.'b'Those Swedish journalists will probably be released early because of international pressure. But there will be no respite for the countless Ethiopians who face imprisonment, torture and rape.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99m in Davos, Switzerland, for the annual meeting of the 'b'World Economic Forum'b', and so is Meles. I\xe2\x80\x99ve been pursuing him for the last few days, trying to confront him and ask him about his worsening pattern of brutality.'b'He has refused to see me, so I enlisted 'b'my Twitter followers'b' to report Meles sightings. He has some excellent officials under him, 'b'including a superb health minister'b', and Ethiopia\xe2\x80\x99s economy is making progress in health and agriculture. Ethiopia is full of aid organizations, and it has a close intelligence and military relationship with the United States government.'b'Yet since 2005, when an initial crackdown left 200 protesters dead and 30,000 detained, Meles has steadily tightened his grip. 'b'A Human Rights Watch report this month'b' noted that the government is forcibly removing tens of thousands of people from their rural homes to artificial villages where they risk starvation. Those who resist endure arrests, beatings or worse.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe repression is getting worse,\xe2\x80\x9d notes 'b'Tamerat Negera'b', who fled to the United States after the newspaper he edited was closed down in 2009. \xe2\x80\x9cHis vision seems an attempt to root out any dissent.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Meles has criminalized dissent, with 'b'a blogger named Eskinder Nega'b' now facing terrorism charges, which could mean a death sentence. His true crime was calling on the government to allow free speech and end torture.'b'Appallingly, the Meles regime uses foreign food aid to punish his critics. Ethiopia is one of the world\xe2\x80\x99s largest recipients of development aid, 'b'receiving about $3 billion annually'b', with the United States one of its largest donors. This money does save lives. But it also \xe2\x80\x9cunderwrites repression in Ethiopia,\xe2\x80\x9d in the words of Human Rights Watch.'b'Families and entire areas of the country are deliberately starved unless they back the government, human rights groups have shown. In Ethiopia, the verb \xe2\x80\x9cto starve\xe2\x80\x9d is transitive.'b'Look, I\xe2\x80\x99m a huge advocate of smart aid to fight global poverty. But donors and aid groups need to ensure that their aid doesn\xe2\x80\x99t buttress repression.'b'The Meles regime, run largely by a coterie from his own minority Tigrayan ethnicity, has been particularly savage in the Ogaden region, where it faces an armed uprising. When Jeffrey Gettleman, a colleague at The New York Times, went to the Ogaden in 2007, he found a pattern of torture and rape. The government then 'b'arrested Gettleman and two colleagues'b', detaining them for five days in harsh conditions.'b'The two Swedish reporters illegally entered the Ogaden and met a rebel group to examine that human rights wasteland. In December, 'b'they were sentenced to 11-year terms'b'.'b'Steiner, Schibbye\xe2\x80\x99s wife, said of the harsh conditions: \xe2\x80\x9cEleven years in an Ethiopian prison is equal to life, because you do not survive that long.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'Amnesty International says'b' that in the last 11 months, the government has arrested at least 114 Ethiopian journalists and opposition politicians. It described this as \xe2\x80\x9cthe most far-reaching crackdown on freedom of expression seen in many years in Ethiopia.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Prime Minister Meles, you may have dodged me in Davos, but your brutality toward Swedish, American and Ethiopian journalists will not silence the world\xe2\x80\x99s media. You\xe2\x80\x99re just inviting more scrutiny.'b'The system for reviewing presidential appointments is broken. The Senate has a constitutional duty to provide advice and consent on the naming of judges and high-ranking executive branch officials. But the process has been hijacked by cynical partisanship and cheap tricks.'b'This is not a new problem, but it has gotten intolerably worse and is now threatening to paralyze government, as Republicans use the filibuster to try to kill off agencies they do not like. The number of unfilled judicial seats is nearing a historic high.'b'It is time to end the ability of a single senator, or group of senators, to block the confirmation process by threatening a filibuster, which can be overcome only by the vote of 60 senators. We agree with President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s call in the State of the Union address for the Senate to change its rules and require votes on judicial and executive nominees within 90 days.'b'This is a major change of position for us, and we came to it reluctantly. The filibuster has sometimes been the only way to deny life terms on the federal bench to extremist or unqualified judges. But the paralysis has become so dire that we see no other solution.'b'The president could be doing a better job of nominating judges expeditiously. Still, 85 federal judgeships are vacant, a number that has grown by 65 percent under Mr. Obama. Of those, the federal court\xe2\x80\x99s administrators consider 31 to be \xe2\x80\x9cjudicial emergencies,\xe2\x80\x9d which means other judges on courts with those openings have unmanageable caseloads.'b'Today, 18 judicial nominees wait for Senate votes even though they were approved by the Judiciary Committee, 16 unanimously. It can take a year for a nominee to receive a vote, an extraordinary hardship \xe2\x80\x94 since many cannot work while they wait \xe2\x80\x94 that threatens to reduce the pool of highly qualified candidates.'b'There are many examples. Goodwin Liu, a liberal law professor nominated last year to an appellate bench, was filibustered even though he was entirely in the legal mainstream, supported by conservatives including Kenneth Starr and Clint Bolick. His offense: He once dared to criticize Justice Samuel Alito Jr. as being too conservative.'b'Democrats used the filibuster to impose a two-year delay on President George W. Bush\xe2\x80\x99s appointment of Jeffrey Sutton, a highly credentialed candidate, for a federal judgeship because of his doubts about Congress\xe2\x80\x99s power to enact legislation protecting workers and consumers.'b'It is not just judicial appointments that are frozen. When Congress created a vitally needed Consumer Financial Protection Bureau as part of the financial reform law, Republicans in the Senate decided to block confirmation of a chief so the agency could not exercise its full regulatory powers.'b'This was not a matter of rejecting one choice for substantive reasons and asking for another. Republicans first told Mr. Obama that they would not confirm any head of the bureau unless he first agreed to gut its powers. Mr. Obama dropped his original choice, the highly qualified Elizabeth Warren, before she was named. Senate Republicans then blocked the confirmation vote for Richard Cordray, a strong pro-consumer leader and the bureau\xe2\x80\x99s chief of enforcement. Mr. Obama gave Mr. Cordray a recess appointment, which means he will be able to serve only until the end of 2013.'b'Senators also use filibusters to block nonpolitical positions, like the administrator of the General Services Administration \xe2\x80\x94 to demand passage of a pet project, out of pique or, most troubling, as part of the Republicans\xe2\x80\x99 electoral strategy to block anything Mr. Obama wants.'b'There was an attempt to deal with this seven years ago. A bipartisan group of 14 senators agreed to prevent judicial filibusters except under \xe2\x80\x9cextraordinary\xe2\x80\x9d circumstances after Republicans threatened to do away with the filibuster rule they now abuse so routinely. The center did not hold, and the agreement fell apart.'b'Under Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s proposal, during the 90-day period, hearings can be held, research conducted, objections raised, thunderous speeches given. But in the end, the senators will have to vote directly on the nominee, not hide behind the filibuster. This will require making confirmation hearings substantive events, not the Kabuki theater they are now.'b'We know it is risky. But the nation votes for a president, who needs to be able to appoint top officials and judges. The Senate needs to decide whether to give its consent or not. We can only hope that the president and the Senate will do that job responsibly, especially when both are controlled by the same party. Voters could then watch and reach their own judgments. And with fewer vacancies, government and the judiciary could do the nation\xe2\x80\x99s work.'b'BORN this way.'b'That has long been one of the rallying cries of a movement, and sometimes the gist of its argument. Across decades of widespread ostracism, followed by years of patchwork acceptance and, most recently, moments of heady triumph, gay people invoked that phrase to explain why homophobia was unwarranted and discrimination senseless.'b'Lady Gaga even spun an 'b'anthem'b' from it.'b'But is it the right mantra to cling to? The best tack to take?'b'Not for the actress Cynthia Nixon, 45, whose comments in The New York Times Magazine last Sunday raised those very questions.'b'For 15 years, until 2003, she was in a relationship with a man. And she 'b'told'b' The Times\xe2\x80\x99s Alex Witchel that homosexuality for her \xe2\x80\x9cis a choice.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cFor many people it\xe2\x80\x99s not,\xe2\x80\x9d she conceded, but added that they \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t get to define my gayness for me.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'They do get to fume, though. Last week some did. They complained that she represented a minority of those in same-sex relationships and that she had furthermore handed a cudgel to our opponents, who might now cite her professed malleability as they make their case that incentives to change, not equal rights, are what we need.'b'But while her critics have good reason to worry about how her words will be construed and used, they have no right to demand the kind of silence and conformity from Nixon that gay people have justly rebelled against. She\xe2\x80\x99s entitled to her own truth and manner of expressing it.'b'\xc2\xa0Besides which, there are problems with some gay advocates\xe2\x80\x99 insistence that homosexuality be discussed and regarded as something ingrained at the first breath.'b'By hinging a whole movement on a conclusion that hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been \xe2\x80\x94 and perhaps won\xe2\x80\x99t be \xe2\x80\x94 scientifically pinpointed and proved beyond all doubt, they hitch it to a moving target. The exact dynamics through which someone winds up gay are \xe2\x80\x9cstill an open question,\xe2\x80\x9d said Clinton Anderson, the director of the Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual and Transgender Concerns Office of the 'b'American Psychological Association'b'. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is substantial evidence of various connections between genes, brain, hormones and sexual identity,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cBut those do not amount to a simple picture that A leads to B.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'One landmark study looked at gay men\xe2\x80\x99s brothers and found that 52 percent of identical twin brothers were also gay, in contrast with only 22 percent of nonidentical twin brothers and 11 percent of adoptive, genetically unrelated brothers. Heredity more than environment seemed to be calling the shots.'b'Other research has posited or identified common anatomical and chromosomal traits among gay men or lesbians, and there\xe2\x80\x99s discussion of a gay gene or, rather, set of genes in the mix. The push to isolate it is entwined with the belief that establishing that sexual orientation is like skin color \xe2\x80\x94 an immutable matter of biology \xe2\x80\x94 will make homophobia as inexcusable as racism and winnow the ranks of haters.'b'But bigotry isn\xe2\x80\x99t rational. Finding a determinative biological quirk, deviation or marker could prompt religious extremists who now want gays in reparative psychotherapy to focus on medical interventions instead. And a person\xe2\x80\x99s absence of agency over his or her concentration of melanin has hardly ended all discrimination against blacks.'b'What\xe2\x80\x99s more, the born-this-way approach carries an unintended implication that the behavior of gays and lesbians needs biological grounding to evade condemnation. Why should it?'b'Our laws safeguard religious freedom, and that\xe2\x80\x99s not because there\xe2\x80\x99s a Presbyterian, 'b' 'b'Buddhist or Mormon gene. There\xe2\x80\x99s only a tradition and theology that you elect or decline to follow. But this country has deemed worshiping in a way that feels consonant with who you are to be essential to a person\xe2\x80\x99s humanity. So it\xe2\x80\x99s protected.'b'Our laws also safeguard the right to bear arms: not exactly a biological imperative.'b'Among adults, the right to love whom you\xe2\x80\x99re moved to love \xe2\x80\x94 and to express it through sex and maybe, yes, marriage \xe2\x80\x94 is surely as vital to life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness as a Glock. Surely that\xe2\x80\x99s not just to my advantage but to society\xe2\x80\x99s, too.'b'WHEN liberals are in a philosophical mood, they like to cast debates over the role of government not as a clash between the individual and the state, but as a conflict between the individual and the community. Liberals are for cooperation and joint effort; conservatives are for self-interest and selfishness. Liberals build the Hoover Dam and the interstate highways; conservatives sit home and dog-ear copies of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Fountainhead.\xe2\x80\x9d Liberals know that it takes a village; conservatives pretend that all it takes is John Wayne.'b'In this worldview, the government is just the natural expression of our national community, and the place where we all join hands to pursue the common good. Or to borrow a line attributed to Representative Barney Frank, \xe2\x80\x9cGovernment is simply the name we give to the things we choose to do together.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Many conservatives would go this far with Frank: Government is one way we choose to work together, and there are certain things we need to do collectively that only government can do.'b'But there are trade-offs as well, which liberal communitarians don\xe2\x80\x99t always like to acknowledge. When government expands, it\xe2\x80\x99s often at the expense of alternative expressions of community, alternative groups that seek to serve the common good. Unlike most communal organizations, the government has coercive power \xe2\x80\x94 the power to regulate, to mandate and to tax. These advantages make it all too easy for the state to gradually crowd out its rivals. The more things we \xe2\x80\x9cdo together\xe2\x80\x9d as a government, in many cases, the fewer things we\xe2\x80\x99re allowed to do together in other spheres.'b'Sometimes this crowding out happens gradually, subtly, indirectly. Every tax dollar the government takes is a dollar that can\xe2\x80\x99t go to charities and churches. Every program the government runs, from education to health care to the welfare office, can easily become a kind of taxpayer-backed monopoly.'b'But sometimes the state goes further. Not content with crowding out alternative forms of common effort, it presents its rivals an impossible choice: Play by our rules, even if it means violating the moral ideals that inspired your efforts in the first place, or get out of the community-building business entirely.'b'This is exactly the choice that the 'b'White House has decided'b' to offer a host of religious institutions \xe2\x80\x94 hospitals, schools and charities \xe2\x80\x94 in the era of Obamacare. The new health care law requires that all employer-provided insurance plans cover contraception, sterilization and the morning-after (or week-after) pill known as 'b'ella'b', which can work as an abortifacient. A number of religious groups, led by the American Catholic bishops, had requested an exemption for plans purchased by their institutions. Instead, the White House has settled on an exemption that only covers religious institutions that primarily serve members of their own faith. A parish would be exempt from the mandate, in other words, but a Catholic hospital would not.'b'Ponder that for a moment. In effect, the Department of Health and Human Services is telling religious groups that if they don\xe2\x80\x99t want to pay for practices they consider immoral, they should stick to serving their own co-religionists rather than the wider public. Sectarian self-segregation is O.K., but good Samaritanism is not. But it\xe2\x80\x99s also an intimation of a darker American future, in which our voluntary communities wither away and government becomes the only word we have for the things we do together.'b'We welcomed the collapse this month of two flawed bills to prevent online piracy, bills that could have stifled speech and undermined Internet safety. But piracy by Web sites in countries like Russia and China, which offer high-quality bootleg copies of movies and music, is a real problem for the nation\xe2\x80\x99s creative industries. And there is legislation that could curb the operation of rogue Web sites without threatening legitimate expression.'b'The Online Protection and Enforcement of Digital Trade (OPEN) Act, sponsored by Senator Ron Wyden and Representative Darrell Issa, offers a straightforward and transparent approach to the problem. Content owners could ask the International Trade Commission to investigate whether a foreign Web site was dedicated to piracy. The Web site would be able to rebut the claim. If the commission ruled for the copyright holder, it could direct payment firms like Visa and PayPal and advertising networks like Google\xe2\x80\x99s to stop doing business with the Web site.'b'The bill addresses concerns of copyright holders that the process would be too slow to match the pirates\xe2\x80\x99 speed. It would allow them to request temporary restraining orders when there is urgency to, say, stop a Russian Web site from illegally streaming the Super Bowl. That Web site would still have a chance to respond, but it would have to move more quickly to make its case.'b'The OPEN Act also avoids some of the pitfalls of the previous bills. In his view, attaching the GPS was the sort of physical invasion of property the framers had in mind when they wrote the Bill of Rights.'b'Though Justice 'b'Samuel A. Alito Jr.'b' agreed that GPS tracking was a search, he ridiculed Justice Scalia for focusing on \xe2\x80\x9cconduct that might have provided grounds in 1791 for a suit for trespass to chattels.\xe2\x80\x9d For Justice Alito, the risk the GPS posed was loss of privacy, not property. Instead the question was whether long-term GPS tracking violated 'b'today\xe2\x80\x99s'b' \xe2\x80\x9creasonable expectations of privacy,\xe2\x80\x9d not those of another era. As a matter of existing doctrine, he asked the right question, but when applied to the government, the standard he used could turn our lives into the proverbial open book, and soon.'b'Focusing on public expectations of privacy means that our rights change when technology does. As Justice Alito blithely said: \xe2\x80\x9cNew technology may provide increased convenience or security at the expense of privacy, and many people may find the tradeoff worthwhile.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But aren\xe2\x80\x99t constitutional rights intended to protect our liberty even when the public accepts \xe2\x80\x9cincreased convenience or security at the expense of privacy\xe2\x80\x9d? Fundamental rights remain fundamental in the face of time and new inventions.'b'Paradoxically, Justice Scalia\xe2\x80\x99s approach will better protect privacy rights over the long term. (He didn\xe2\x80\x99t deny the importance of today\xe2\x80\x99s expectations; he simply stressed that at the very least, the Fourth Amendment protects rights we had when the framers drafted the Constitution.) Still, his approach is problematic. There isn\xe2\x80\x99t always an available 18th-century analog for current government conduct, like GPS tracking. Justice Alito facetiously suggested that the only 18th-century analog would have been a constable hiding in the back of someone\xe2\x80\x99s carriage. (When Justice Scalia agreed, Justice Alito wryly remarked that \xe2\x80\x9cthis would have required either a gigantic coach, a very tiny constable, or both.\xe2\x80\x9d) And when 18th-century analogs run out, the court is left with its reasonable expectation test.'b'In a related case, Kyllo v. United States, even Justice Scalia held that police use of a thermal imager to detect 'b'marijuana'b' \xe2\x80\x9cgrow lamps\xe2\x80\x9d within a home was a search \xe2\x80\x94 but only so long as such technology was \xe2\x80\x9cnot in general public use.\xe2\x80\x9d There\xe2\x80\x99s that time bomb: expanding use of technology narrows rights.'b'Among the justices in the Jones case, only Sonia Sotomayor insisted that fundamental rights not be hostage to technological change. She called into question the court\xe2\x80\x99s longstanding reliance on expectations of privacy, which she deemed \xe2\x80\x9cill-suited to the digital age.\xe2\x80\x9d She suggested reconsidering the rule that the police can, without a warrant, get the vast amounts of information about ourselves that we give to third parties. To her, sharing our secrets \xe2\x80\x94 including e-mail and banking histories \xe2\x80\x94 with someone else does not necessarily mean the government gets access, too. It is too bad her separate opinion mustered no other votes.'b''b'To the Editor:'b''b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Rejected in Tucson'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (editorial, Jan. 22):'b'As a Mexican-American educator who teaches Mexican-American history, I find Arizona\xe2\x80\x99s efforts disheartening.
